Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, adopted Aug. 23, 2010, deleted the former Art. II, §§ 2-12-2-32, 2-35, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from an ordinance adopted Mar. 10, 1958, §§ 1-12, 15; an ordinance adopted Mar. 14, 1960, § 1; Ord. No. C.O. 69-8, § 2, adopted Nov. 10, 1969; and Ord. No. C.O. 87-1, §§ 1, 2, adopted Feb. 23, 1987. 
Cross reference- Zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 
State Law reference- City planning, M.S.A., § 5.2991 et seq. 

Sec. 2-12. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Act 33 of PA 2008, as amended, MCL 125.3801 et seq. 
    Chief administrative official means the city administrator or the highest non-elected administrative office of the city. 
    Chief elected official means the mayor. 
    Commission: For the purposes of this article, the term "planning commission or commission" shall mean the City of Milan planning commission. 
    Ex-officio member means a member of the commission with full voting rights by virtue of holding another office for the term on the commission. 
    Planning jurisdiction means the legal boundaries of the city and any area outside of the city boundary that the planning commission deems related to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-13. - Created; general powers and duties. 
    There is created a planning commission for the city to be known as the city planning commission. The commission is created in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 285 of the Public Acts of the State of Michigan for 1931 as amended by Act No. 33, PA 2008 as amended, MCL 125.3801, et. seq. The commission shall have all the duties and powers and shall perform all of the functions provided by such Act as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-14. - Composition; qualifications and appointment of members. 
    The planning commission shall consist of nine (9) members. Eight (8) members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval and confirmation by a majority vote of the city council. The ninth member may be a member of the city council serving as the ex-officio member. If no member of the city council is appointed to the commission, the ninth member shall be chosen as the other eight (8) members. 
    As long as the city has less than five thousand (5,000) population to be qualified to be a member of the planning commission, the individual shall meet the following qualifications: (a) Seven (7) members shall be qualified electors of the city. Two (2) may be non-qualified electors. If population grows to an excess of five thousand (5,000), only one (1) member may be a non-qualified elector. 
    Membership shall be representative of important segments of the community, such as economic, governmental, educational and social development such as agriculture, material resources, recreation, education, public health, government, transportation, industry and commerce. The membership shall also be representative of the entire geography of the local unit of government to the extent practicable. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-15. - Terms of members. 
    The terms of the members of the planning commission shall be for three (3) years, except that in the case of a member of the council, the term shall correspond to his respective tenure. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-16. - Limitation as to other offices. 
    Members of the planning commission shall not serve as members of other city boards and commissions; except that only one (1) member may be a member of the zoning board of appeals or adjustment, and only one (1) member may be a member of the tax increment finance authority. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-17. - Removal of members. 
    The city council may remove a member of the planning commission for misfeasance, malfeasance or nonfeasance in office upon written charges and after a public hearing. Failure to disclose a potential conflict of interest shall be considered malfeasance of office. Failure to attend, without excused absence, three (3) or more meetings shall be considered nonfeasance in office. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-18. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies in the planning commission occurring otherwise than through the expiration of a term shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor in the case of members selected or appointed by him, and by the council in the case of the council appointed member. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-19. - Chairman and other officers; term of chairman. 
    The planning commission shall elect its own chairman and a secretary from the members of the commission and create and fill such other of its offices as it may consider advisable. The ex-officio member is not eligible to serve as chairperson. The planning commission may appoint advisory committees whose members are not members of the planning commission. The term of the office shall be one (1) year, with eligibility for reelection. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-20. - Open meetings; Freedom of Information Acts. 
    The planning commission shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting in each month at the municipal building in the city. Said meeting shall be held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act, 1976 PA 267, MCL 15.275. Public notice of the time, date and place of the regular or special meeting shall be given in the manner required by the Open Meetings Act. 
    Any writing, proposal owned, used or in the possession of or retained by the planning commission in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, as amended, MCL 15.231-15.246, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-21. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the planning commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-22. - Record of transactions, annual report, by-laws, conflict rules. 
    The planning commission shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be open to public examination. 
    The planning commission must make an annual report to city council detailing the operation of the commission and the status of planned activities. The report must include recommendations to city council related to planning and development. In conjunction with the annual report, a planning commission may prepare a detailed budget for city council approval or disapproval. 
    The planning commission shall adopt by-laws for the operation of the commission and rules for the transaction of business at its public hearings. Said rules shall include the following: 
Before casting a vote on a matter on which a member may reasonably be considered to have a conflict of interest, the member shall disclose the potential conflict of interest to the planning commission. The member is disqualified from voting on the matter if so provided by its rules or by a majority vote of the remaining members of the planning commission. Failure to disclose a potential conflict of interest as required by law constitutes malfeasance of office. If the member is not disqualified by a vote of the remaining members, he or she is required to vote. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-23. - Hiring of employees. 
    The planning commission may appoint a planning director and/or other employees as it may deem necessary for its work, whose appointment, promotion, demotion and removal shall be under the direction of the commission. Such appointees or employees shall be subject to the same provisions of employment law as govern other civil service employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-24. - Power to contract for special services. 
    The planning commission may contract with planners, engineers, architects and other consultants for such services as it may require, provided such expenditures are within the budget of the planning commission approved by city council. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-25. - Expenditures. 
    The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for that purpose by the city council, which shall provide the funds, equipment and accommodations necessary for the commission's work. No expenditure of any kind shall be made without an appropriation therefore having been first made by the city council. 
    The planning commission may accept gifts for the exercise of its function. A gift of money shall be deposited with the city treasurer in a special non-reverting account for expenditure solely by the planning commission for legally permitted purposes designated by the donor. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-26. - Master plan for physical development of city-Purpose. 
    The planning commission shall make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city including any areas outside of its boundaries which, in the commission's judgment, bear relation to the planning of the city. The plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and descriptive matter, shall show the planning commission's recommendations for the development of the territory, including, among other things, the general location, character and extent of streets, viaducts, subways, bridges, waterways, flood plains, water fronts, boulevards, parkways, playgrounds and open spaces, the general location of public buildings and other public property, and the general location and extent of public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, for water, light, sanitation, transportation, communication, power and other purposes; also the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of any of the foregoing ways, grounds, open spaces, buildings, property, utilities or terminals; the general location, character, layout and extent of community centers and neighborhood units; and the general character, extent and layout of the replanning and redevelopment of blighted districts and slum areas; as well as a zoning plan for the control of the height, area, bulk, location and use of buildings and premises. As the work of making the whole master plan progresses, the planning commission from time to time may adopt and publish parts thereof, any such part to cover one or more major sections or divisions of the city or one or more of the aforesaid or other functional matters to be included in the plan. The planning commission from time to time may amend, extend or add to the plan. 
    The master plan shall be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the city and its environs which will, in accordance with present and future needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development; including, among other things, adequate provision for traffic, the promotion of safety from fire and other dangers, adequate provision for light and air, the promotion of the healthful and convenient distribution of population, the promotion of good civic design and arrangement, wise and efficient expenditure of public funds, and the adequate provision of public utilities and other public requirements, including the architectural, structural and esthetic appearance of business structures and public buildings. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-27. - Master plan-Notice to prepare. 
    Before preparing a master plan, the planning commission shall send to all of the following, by first-class or personal delivery, a notice explaining that the planning commission intends to prepare a master plan and requesting the recipient's cooperation and comment: 
(1)  The planning commission, or if none, the legislative body of each municipality located within, adjacent and contiguous to the city. 
(2)  The regional planning commission, if any, for the region in which the city is located. 
(3)  The county planning commission, or if none, the county board of commissioners. 
(4)  Each public utility, railroad company owning or operating a public utility or railroad within the city and any governmental entity that registers its name and mailing address with the planning commission. 
(5)  The county road commission. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-28. - Master plan-Preparation of plan. 
    In the preparation of a master plan; a planning commission shall do all of the following: 
(1)  Make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of present conditions and future growth within the planning jurisdiction with due regard to its relation to neighboring jurisdiction. 
(2)  Consult with representatives of adjacent local units of government in respect to their planning so that conflicts in master plans and zoning may be avoided. 
(3)  Cooperate with all departments of state and federal governments and other public agencies concerned with programs for economic, social and physical development within the planning jurisdiction and seek the maximum coordination of the local unit of government's programs with these agencies. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-29. - Master plan-Elements of plan. 
    A master plan shall address land use and infrastructure issues projecting twenty (20) years into the future, using maps, plats, charts, and descriptive explanatory, and other related matter, showing the planning commission's recommendations for the physical development of the planning jurisdiction, which shall include: 
(1)  A land use plan that consists in part of a classification and allocation of land for agriculture, residences, commerce, industry, recreation, ways and grounds, public buildings, schools, soil conservation, forest, woodlots, open space, wildlife refuges, and other uses and purposes. If a county has not adopted a zoning ordinance under former 1943 PA 183 or the Michigan Zoning Enabling Act, 2006 PA 110, MCL 125.3101 to 125.3702, a land use plan and program for the county may be a general plan with a generalized future land use map. 
(2)  The general location, character, and extent of streets, railroads, airports, bicycle paths, pedestrian ways, bridges, waterways, and waterfront developments; sanitary sewers and water supply systems; facilities for flood prevention, drainage, pollution prevention, and maintenance of water levels; and public utilities and structures. 
(3)  Recommendations as to the general character, extent, and layout of redevelopment or rehabilitation of blighted areas; and the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of streets, grounds, open spaces, buildings, utilities, or other facilities. 
(4)  For a local unit of government that has adopted a zoning ordinance, a zoning plan for various zoning districts controlling the height, area, bulk, location, and use of buildings and premises. The zoning plan shall include an explanation of how the land use categories on the future land use map relate to the districts on the zoning map. 
(5)  Recommendations for implementing any of the master plan's proposals. 
(6)  If a master plan is or includes a master street plan, the means for implementing the master street plan in cooperation with the county road commission and the state transportation department shall be specified in the master street plan in a manner consistent with the respective powers and duties of and any written agreements between these entities and the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-30. - Master plan-Submittal to city council. 
    After preparing a proposed master plan, the planning commission shall submit the proposed master plan to the city council for their review and comments. The process of adopting a master plan shall not proceed any further unless the city council approves the final form of the master plan for distribution. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-31. - Master plan-Distribution of proposed master plan, comments. 
    If the city council approves the distribution of the master plan, the planning commission shall distribute the proposed master plan to the same entities set forth in section 2-27. Copies of the proposed plan may not be sent electronically unless the recipient is notified and does not object. 
    The secretary of the planning commission shall submit to the county planning commission or county board of commissioners a statement that the requirements of subsections 2-27(a) and (b) have been met. The statement shall be signed by the secretary and shall include the name and address of each planning commission or city council or legislative body to which a copy of the proposed master plan was submitted and the date of submittal. 
    An entity which received a copy of the proposed master plan may comment within sixty-three (63) days of receipt of the proposed plan. Such statements are advisory only. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-32. - Master plan-Public hearing, notice. 
    The planning commission shall hold not less that one public hearing on the proposed master plan, any such part, amendment, extension or addition thereto after the expiration of the sixty-three-day comment period required in section 2-31. Notice of time and place of the public hearing(s) shall be given not less than fifteen (15) days before the hearing by publication in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. Each entity entitled to receive notice in section 2-27 shall receive notice in the same manner required in section 2-27. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-33. - Master plan-Adoption of whole or parts by resolution of commission; hearing; notice; certificates to council and register of deeds. 
    The planning commission may, adopt the master plan, referred to in section 2-29, as a whole by a single resolution or may by successive resolutions to adopt successive parts of the plan, such parts corresponding with major geographical sections or divisions of the city or with functional subdivisions of the subject matter of the plan, and may adopt any amendment or extension thereof or addition thereto. The adoption of the plan or of any such part of amendment or extension or addition shall be by resolution of the planning commission carried by the affirmative votes of not less than six (6) members of the planning commission. The resolution shall refer expressly to the maps and descriptive and other matter intended by the commission to form the whole or part of the plan, and the action taken shall be recorded on the map and plan and descriptive matter by the identifying signature of the chairman and/or secretary of the planning commission. An attested copy of the plan or part thereof, when so adopted, shall be certified to the city council and to the county register of deeds. The secretary of the planning commission shall submit, in same manner as set forth in section 2-27, copies of the adopted master plan. 
    Approval of the proposed master plan by the planning commission is the final step for adoption of the master plan. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-34. - Master plan-Extensions, additions, revision or other amendments, notice five-year review. 
(a)  An extension, addition, revision or other amendment to a master plan shall be adopted by the following the same procedure required for adopting the original master plan. The following procedures, however, may be made without following those procedures: 
(1)  A grammatical, typographical or similar editorial change. 
(2)  A title change. 
(3)  A change to conform to an adopted plat. 
(b)  The sixty-three-day review period provided in section 2-31 shall be forty-two (42) days for extensions, additions, revisions or other amendments. 
(c)  If the changes proposed under this section consist of sub-plans, no additional notice following the notice of the preparation of the plan is required unless the planning commission is notified by the entity they choose to receive notice of sub-plans. 
(d)  At least every five (5) years after adoption of a master plan, the planning commission shall review the master plan and determine whether to commence the procedure to amend the master plan or adopt a new master plan. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-35. - Public works-Approval by commission and council or body having jurisdiction; plans for future. 
    Whenever the planning commission shall have adopted the master plan of the city or of one or more major sections or districts thereof, no street, square, park or other public way, ground or open space, or public building or structure, or utility shall be constructed or authorized in the city or in such planned section and district until the location, character and extent thereof shall have been submitted to and approved by the planning commission; provided, however, that in case of disapproval, the planning commission shall communicate its reasons to the city council which shall have the power to overrule such disapproval by a recorded vote of not less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of its entire membership; provided, however, that if the public way, ground, space, building, structure or utility be one the authorization or financing of which does not under the law or charter provisions governing the same, fall within the province of the city council, then the submission to the planning commission shall be by the board, commission or body having such jurisdiction, and the planning commission's disapproval may be overruled by such board, commission or body by a vote of not less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of its membership. The failure of the planning commission to act within sixty (60) days from and after the date of official submission to the planning commission shall be deemed approval. For the purpose of furthering the desirable future development of the city under the master plan, the planning commission, after the planning commission shall have adopted the master plan, shall prepare coordinated and comprehensive programs of public structures and improvements. The planning commission shall annually prepare such a program for the ensuing six (6) years, which program shall show those public structures and improvements, in the general order of their priority, which in the planning commission's judgment will be needed or desirable and can be undertaken within the six-year period. The above comprehensive coordinated programs shall be based upon the requirements of the community for all types of public improvements, and, to that end, each agency or department of the city concerned with such improvements shall, upon request, furnish the planning commission with lists, plans and estimates of time and cost of public structures and improvements within the purview of such department. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-36. - Same-Rescission of action by council; procedure. 
    Whenever the city council shall have ordered the opening, widening or extension of any street, avenue or boulevard, or whenever the city council shall have ordered that proceedings be instituted for the acquisition or enlargement of any park, playground, playfield or other public open space, such resolution shall not be rescinded until after the matter has been referred back to the planning commission for a report and until after a public hearing shall have been held. The city council shall have power to overrule the recommendation of the planning commission by a vote of not less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of its entire membership. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-37. - Publicity and education; recommendations; gifts; cooperation from public officials. 
    The planning commission shall have the power to promote public interest in and understanding of the master plan and to that end may publish and distribute copies of the plan or of any report and may employ such other means of publicity and education as it may determine. Members of the planning commission, when duly authorized by the planning commission, may attend city planning conferences or meetings of city planning institutes, or hearings upon pending city planning legislation, and the planning commission may, by resolution spread upon its minutes, pay the reasonable traveling expenses incident to such attendance. The planning commission shall, from time to time, recommend to the appropriate public officials programs for public structures and improvements and for the financing thereof. It shall be part of its duties to consult and advise with public officials and agencies, public utility companies, civic, educational, professional and other organizations, and with citizens with relation to the protecting or carrying out the plan. All public officials shall, upon request, furnish to the planning commission, within a reasonable time, such available information as it may require for its work. The planning commission, its members, officers and employees, in the performance of their functions, may enter upon any land and make examinations and surveys and place and maintain necessary monuments and marks thereon. In general, the planning commission shall have such powers as may be necessary to enable it to fulfill its functions, promote municipal planning or carry out the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-38. - Necessity for approval of plats; street system. 
    Whenever the planning commission shall have adopted that sort of a master plan relating to the major street system of the territory within its subdivision, jurisdiction or part thereof, and shall have filed a certified copy of such plan in the office of the county register of deeds of the county in which such territory or part is located, then no plat of a subdivision of land within such territory or part shall be filed or recorded until it shall have been approved by such planning commission and such approval entered in writing on the plat by the chairman or secretary of the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-39. - Subdivision plat and ordinance. 
    See Appendix B of the Milan City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
Sec. 2-40. - Modifications or interpretations of zoning ordinance. 
    All matters affecting modifications or interpretations of the city zoning ordinance shall first be submitted to the planning commission for investigation and recommendation. The planning commission shall make such investigation and submit its recommendations in writing within seven (7) days from the date of reference. The zoning board of appeals shall take no action within such period, awaiting the recommendations of the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 8-23-10) 
ARTICLE III. - BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 71-6, §§ 1-6, adopted May 24, 1971, did not expressly amend this Code, hence codification as Art. III, §§ 2-41-2-46, was at the discretion of the editors. 

Sec. 2-41. - Commission established. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established for the City of Milan a commission to be known hereafter as the beautification commission, which shall consist of no less than six (6) members, to be appointed by the mayor, in accordance with the city charter; provided, however, that the membership shall include as ex officio members the city administrator and the chairman of the city's planning commission and recreation commission. 
(b)  Initially, one-half (1/2) of the members shall be appointed for one (1) year terms, and the remainder for two (2) year terms; thereafter each appointment shall be for a two (2) year term; provided, however, that the creation of new positions on the commission shall be designed to maintain a balance of expiration dates in alternate years. 
(c)  Members of said commission shall be appointed forthwith upon the adoption and taking effect of this ordinance [article] and shall qualify by taking the oath of office, to be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 71-6, § 1, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-42. - Members to serve without remuneration. 
    Membership on said commission shall be honorary and the members shall serve without remuneration. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 71-6, § 2, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-43. - Organization. 
(a)  Said commission shall organize annually by electing a chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary from its membership at an organizational meeting to be held on the third Wednesday of February each, and shall adopt such rules of procedure as it may deem necessary to carry on its work. 
(b)  All opinions and recommendations offered or promulgated in the name of the commission shall have the support of a simple majority of the members present. 
(c)  Regular meeting of said commission shall be held quarter-annually and special meetings shall be called as needed, at times agreeable to the membership, and attendance at meetings shall be in accordance with Section 5.3 of the city charter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 71-6, § 3, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-44. - Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the commission to study, conceive, formulate, promulgate, and develop plans for the beautification of streets, highways, alleys, utility installations, parks, streams, playgrounds, yards, lots, and buildings; to encourage and recommend the placing, planting and preservation of trees, flowers, plants, shrubbery and other objects of ornamentation in the City of Milan; to collect, study and evaluate information on community improvements, and to make recommendations thereon. 
(b)  The beautification commission shall be responsible for rendering opinions on all matters relating to the use and development of city owned lands, the acquisition of new public lands, changes, in or additions to, the zoning ordinances of the city, and requests for specific uses of particular lands within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 71-6, § 4, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-45. - Philosophy. 
    The guiding philosophy of this commission shall be the concept of man as an integral part of the total life-system of the planet, and therefore completely dependent upon the perpetuation of all facets of that system. Realizing that man's economic and social objectives are often at variance with the welfare of the total life-system, it shall be the duty of said commission to work primarily for the preservation, rather than the destruction, of the local natural environment. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 71-6, § 5, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-46. - Effectiveness as an advisory body. 
    In order that the beautification commission shall be able to function in its conceived capacity, the city council and the city planning commission shall inform the beautification commission of any problem which is covered under Section 4 [2-44] of this ordinance [article], which the council or planning commission feels should be considered by the beautification commission, and in such cases, the beautification commission is to report its recommendations to the council; provided however, that nothing herein shall be construed to abridge, invade, supplant or change the powers or duties of the other commissions, departments, boards and agencies of the City of Milan. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 71-6, § 6, 5-24-71) 
Secs. 2-47-2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-51. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to create a public body corporate to act in the best interests of the City of Milan to halt property value deterioration, increase property tax valuation where possible in the downtown business district of the city, eliminate the causes of that deterioration, and to promote economic growth pursuant to Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 83-8, § 1, 10-24-83) 
Sec. 2-52. - Definitions. 
    The terms herein shall have the same meaning as given in Act 197 or as hereafter in this section provided, unless the content clearly indicates to the contrary, and shall be in addition to the terms provided in Act 197. 
(a)  Act 197 means Act 197 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1975 as now in effect or hereafter amended. 
(b)  Authority means the Milan Downtown Development Authority. 
(c)  City means the City of Milan. 
(d)  Council means the Milan City Council. 
(e)  Downtown district means the downtown district designated herein. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 83-8, § 1, 10-24-83) 
Sec. 2-53. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created pursuant to Act 197 the Milan Downtown Development Authority for the City of Milan, Michigan. The authority shall be a public body corporate and shall be known and exercise its powers under the title of "Milan Downtown Development Authority." The authority may adopt a seal, may sue and be sued in any court of this state, and shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purpose of its incorporation as provided herein and in Act 197. The enumeration of a power herein or in Act 197 shall not be construed as a limitation upon the general powers of the authority. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 83-8, § 1, 10-24-83) 
Sec. 2-54. - Designation of downtown district. 
    The boundaries of the downtown district in which the authority shall exercise its powers as provided by Act 197 are hereby established as shown on the downtown district map attached hereto as Attachment A [4], with all notations, references and other information shown thereon, and more particularly by the legal description attached hereto as Attachment B*, all of which shall be as much a part of this article as if fully described herein. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 83-8, § 1, 10-24-83) 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Attachments A and B have not been set out herein, but copies of same may be found on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 

Sec. 2-55. - Board. 
    The authority shall be under the supervision and control of a board consisting of the mayor of the city and 12 members. The members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to approval of the city council. Eligibility for membership on the board and terms of office shall be as provided in Act 197. All members shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 83-8, § 1, 10-24-83; Ord. No. C.O. 88-2, § 1, 5-9-88; Ord. No. 98-12, § 1, 12-28-98; Ord. No. 2016-02, § 1, 4-11-16) 
Sec. 2-56. - Powers. 
    As provided in Act 197, the authority shall prepare a development plan and financing plan for the downtown district or a development area within the district. The authority must obtain city council approval of all development and financing plans. The authority shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purposes of its incorporation and shall have all powers provided by Act 197 except that in developing a plan within the downtown area, the authority shall consider the following: 
(a)  Tax increment financing shall be only one of the financing methods considered and should be coordinated with private and other public investment funds. 
(b)  If tax increment financing is proposed, all governmental units levying a property tax shall be fully informed of this plan and any future amendments thereto. Such consultations are to be prior to any action by the city council on the proposal. 
(c)  The plan for the downtown area should show that the property taxes realized for each governmental taxing unit, over the long term, should be greater than if the downtown development district did not exist. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 83-8, § 1, 10-24-83) 
Sec. 2-57. - Termination. 
    Upon completion of its purposes, the authority may be dissolved by the city council. The property and assets of the authority, after dissolution and satisfaction of its obligations, shall revert to the city. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 83-8, § 1, 10-24-83) 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTED OFFICERS COMPENSATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-58. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish, pursuant to Act 8 of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, a mechanism and procedure for determining salaries of elected officials of the city, in place of the compensation provisions stated in section 4.3 of the Milan City Charter and the restriction contained in section 5.9 of the Milan City Charter with respect to changing salaries during the terms of elected officers. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
Sec. 2-59. - Definition. 
    For purposes of this article, the term "commission" shall mean the elected officers compensation commission. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91.5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
Sec. 2-60. - Commission created; general powers and duties. 
    There is created a local officers compensation commission to be known as the elected officers compensation commission. The commission is created in accordance with the provisions of Act 8 of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended. The commission shall determine the salaries of each elected official of the city and shall have all of the duties and powers provided by Act 8 of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
Sec. 2-61. - Membership; members to serve without compensation. 
    The commission shall consist of five (5) members who shall be registered electors of the city, appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the city council members elected and serving. Neither a member or employee of the legislative, executive, or judicial branch of the government, nor a member of the immediate family of a member or employee of the legislative, executive or judicial branch of government shall be a member of the commission. The members of the commission shall not receive compensation, but shall be entitled to actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of official duties. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
Sec. 2-62. - Terms of members; vacancies. 
    The terms of the members of the commission shall be five (5) years, except that of the members first appointed, one (1) each shall be appointed for terms of one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), and five (5) years. The first members shall be appointed within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this article [September 5, 1991]. Members other than the first members shall be appointed before October 1 of the year of appointment. Each commission member's term shall expire on December 31 of his/her fifth year of service. Vacancies shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired terms by the process specified in section 2-61 of this article for appointments. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91; Ord. No. 99-3, 6-28-99) 
Sec. 2-63. - Determination of salaries; expense allowances or reimbursements. 
    The commission shall determine the salary of each elected official of the city. The determination shall be the salary unless the city council, by resolution adopted by two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members elected to and serving on the city council, rejects it. The determination of the commission shall be effective thirty (30) days following its filing with the city clerk unless rejected by the city council. If the determination is rejected, the existing salary shall prevail. The expense allowance or reimbursement paid to elected officials in addition to salary shall be for expenses incurred in the course of city business and accounted for to the city. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
Sec. 2-64. - Meetings of commission; session days, quorum; concurrence of majority; chairperson. 
    The commission shall meet for not more than fifteen (15) session days in each odd numbered year and shall make its determination within forty-five (45) calendar days after its first meeting. As used in this section, "session day" means a calendar day on which the commission meets and a quorum is present. A majority of the members of the commission constitutes a quorum for conducting the business of the commission. The commission shall not take action or make a determination without a concurrence of a majority of the members appointed and serving on the commission. The commission shall elect a chairperson from among its members. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
Sec. 2-65. - Open meetings. 
    The business which the commission may perform shall be conducted at a public meeting of the commission held in compliance with Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of 1976, being Sections 15.261 to 15.275 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. Public notice of the time, date and place of the meeting of the commission shall be given in the manner required by Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of 1976. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
Sec. 2-66. - Freedom of information. 
    A writing prepared, owned, used, in the possession of, or retained by the commission in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with Act No. 442 of the Public Acts of 1976, being Sections 15.231 to 15.246 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
Sec. 2-67. - Implementation; changes in procedure for establishing compensation. 
    The city council shall implement this article by resolution. After one (1) year following the effective date of this article [September 5, 1991], the procedure for establishing the compensation of elected officials may be changed by charter amendment or revision. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
Sec. 2-68. - Referendum on ordinance. 
    Not more than sixty (60) days after the effective date of this article [September 5, 1991], a petition for referendum on this article may be filed pursuant to the procedure provided in the Milan City Charter or otherwise by filing a petition with the city clerk containing the signatures of at least five (5) percent of the registered electors of the city on the effective date of this article [September 5, 1991]. The election shall be conducted in the same manner as an election on a charter amendment. If a petition for referendum is filed, a determination of the commission shall not be effective until this article has been approved by the electors. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-5, § 1, 8-26-91) 
ARTICLE VI. - RESERVED[5] 

Footnotes:

No. 2000-03, adopted Feb. 28, 2000, disbanded the Solid Waste and Recycling Commission of the city and thereby eliminated provisions relating to said commission from the Code of Ordinances, formerly set out as Ch. 2, Art. VI and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 93-8, adopted Nov. 8, 1993. 

Secs. 2-69-2-73. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFICIAL FEE SCHEDULE 

Sec. 2-74. - Official fee schedule; resolutions and maintenance. 
    All fees and charges assessed by the city, excepting only ad valorem property taxes and related collection and administration fees, special assessments, and variable fees charged by the parks and recreation department for activities, events and instructions, shall be set by the city council through inclusion in an official fee schedule resolution. Thereafter, all new fees and charges to be assessed by the city and all revisions to the fees and charges included in the official fee schedule shall be established and effectuated by resolution of the city council setting forth the entire new official fee schedule, as changed by the addition of the new fees and charges and by the revision(s) to the prior fees and charges. The originals of the resolution specifying the initial official fee schedule and all subsequent resolutions amending the official fee schedule shall be filed and maintained by the clerk/treasurer with the official ordinance book mandated by Section 7.4 of the City Charter and shall be made available to the public as soon thereafter as is practicable. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 1, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 2-75. - Contrary statutes controlling. 
    In every case in which a state statue requires that the establishment or setting of particular fees or charges be accomplished by ordinance or another procedure other than city council resolution, such statute(s) shall supersede the provisions of this ordinance and govern the establishment and setting of those particular fees and charges; provided, however, that after such alternative action has been taken, the city council shall adopt a new resolution updating the official fee schedule to reflect the fees or charges established or set by the alternative action, and the original of such resolution shall be filed and maintained in accordance with section 2-69 of this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 1, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 2-76. - Untimely permits; additional fees; failure to pay; lien for delinquency; collection; remedies not exclusive. 
(a)  In every case in which a permit is required, by any section of the Milan City Code, to be obtained, the fee specified for such permit in the official fee schedule adopted by the city council shall be doubled if the required permit is not obtained at the time that is required by the applicable section of the Milan City Code. 
(b)  If the city administrator or the department head responsible for issuance of a particular permit determines that the fee specified for such permit in the official fee schedule adopted by the city council is insufficient to fully cover the costs incurred by the city in connection with work attributable to such permit, the city administrator or the applicable department head shall issue a bill to the permittee for the difference between (i) the fee amount specified for the applicable permit in the official fee schedule and (ii) the actual costs incurred by the city in connection with work attributable to the permit plus ten (10) percent of those costs. The amount so billed shall be immediately due and payable by the permittee to the city and shall be a lien on the premises for which the permit was issued. 
(c)  If the permittee fails and/or refuses to pay any portion of an amount billed pursuant to subsection (b) hereof within thirty (30) days after the billing date, the unpaid balance shall be deemed delinquent, and a penalty of ten (10) percent of the unpaid balance shall be added thereto. In addition, the city administrator or the applicable department head may immediately revoke the subject permit. If such delinquency shall continue for an additional thirty (30) days, the unpaid original balance and subsequent penalties shall become a lien upon the premises for which the permit was issued. On April 1 of each year, each department head shall certify all such unpaid balances and penalties which are delinquent to the city assessor, who shall enter the same upon the next tax roll against the premises to which the permit applied, and such charges and penalties shall be collected and such lien enforced in the same manner as provided for taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(d)  In the event that any fee or charge specified in the official fee schedule adopted by the city council for a permit is not timely paid by the permit applicant, the requested permit shall not be issued. In the event that any fee or charge specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council, whether for a permit or for something other than a permit, is not fully paid within thirty (30) days after the date on which the fee or charge is incurred, the unpaid balance shall be deemed delinquent, and a penalty of ten (10) percent of the unpaid balance shall be added thereto. If such delinquency shall continue for an additional thirty (30) days, the unpaid original balance and subsequent penalties shall become a lien upon the premises of the individual(s) on whose behalf the fee or charge was incurred, and such individuals shall also be liable for all costs incurred by the city in collecting and attempting to collect all such sums including, without limitation, reasonable attorney fees. On April 1 of each year, each department head shall certify all such unpaid balances and penalties which are delinquent to the city assessor, who shall enter the same upon the next tax roll against the premises to which the permit applied, and such charges and penalties shall be collected and such lien enforced in the same manner as provided for taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(e)  In the event that any check submitted to the city is returned as nonpayable or is otherwise not honored, the person submitting such check shall be liable to the city for a "returned check fee" in the amount specified for such fees in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(f)  Nothing contained in this section, including without limitation provisions for penalties and liens, shall in any way limit the city's remedies with respect to unpaid fees, charges and/or penalties of any type; and the city shall have in addition thereto all other rights available to it at law and in equity. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 1, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 2-77. - Effective date. 
    The effective date of this article shall be ten (10) days after its adoption and the publication of a summary hereof as provided by Section 7.4(b) of the Milan City Charter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 1, 5-9-94) 
ARTICLE VIII. - INDUSTRIAL FACILITIES EXEMPTION CERTIFICATES 

Sec. 2-78. - Application for industrial facilities exemption certificate; fee. 
    An applicant for an industrial facilities exemption certificate, pursuant to Public Act No. 198 of 1974, as amended, shall pay an application fee equal to the actual cost incurred by the city in processing the application, regardless of whether such application is granted or denied; provided however, that in no case shall such fee exceed two (2) percent of the total property taxes abated under Public Act No. 198 of 1974 for the term that the industrial exemption certificate is in effect. At the time of the filing of the application, the applicant shall pay an initial deposit against such fee in the amount specified in the Official Fee Schedule of the City of Milan. After city council action on the application, the applicant shall be invoiced for the remaining balance of the application fee, which shall be due and payable within seven (7) days of the applicant's receipt of such invoice. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 98-2, § 1, 6-22-98) 
Sec. 2-79. - Reserved.
