ARTICLE X. - CODE OF ETHICS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, adopted July 14, 2008, enacted provisions intended for use as sections 2-12-2-24. Inasmuch as there are already provision so designated, and at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been redesignated as sections 2-96-2-108. 

Sec. 2-96. - Purpose. 
    Public servants recognize that stewardship of the public interest is a primary concern and that they will work for the common good of the people of the city and not for any private or personal interest. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-97. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business entity means a corporation, a partnership, sole proprietorship, joint venture, unincorporated association, trust or other business form. 
    Interest means any right, title or share in something, either personal, financial, legal or equitable, which is owned, held or controlled, in whole or in part, directly or indirectly, by a public servant. 
    Public body means the city council and any board, authority, commission, committee, department, office or other agency of the city, and includes the city. 
    Public servant means the mayor, member of the city council, officer, full-time or part-time city employee and any person elected or appointed to any public body of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-98. - Intent. 
(a)  It is the intent of this Code that a public servant, regardless of whether specifically prohibited by this Code, shall avoid any action which might result in or create the appearance of: 
(1)  Using public office or employment for private gain. 
(2)  Giving improper preferential treatment to any person or organization. 
(3)  Impeding government efficiency or economy. 
(4)  A lack of independence or impartiality of action. 
(5)  Making a government decision outside of official channels. 
(6)  Affecting adversely the confidence of the public in the integrity of the city. 
(b)  It is not the intent of this Code to in any way limit the right or ability of any public servant to exercise his or her discretion in making legitimate policy decisions which are within his discretion so long as such action does not provide a special benefit to that person, relieve the public servant of a particular duty, or treat that person differently than other similarly situated city residents. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-99. - Fair and equitable treatment. 
    No public servant shall request, use or permit the use of any consideration, treatment, advantage or favor beyond that which is the general practice to grant or make available to the public at large. All public servants shall treat all citizens of the city with courtesy, impartiality, fairness and equality under the law. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-100. - Compliance. 
    All public servants shall always carry out their public duties in compliance with local ordinances, state and federal laws, the policies and/or rules and regulations governing public and private activities. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-101. - Use of public property. 
    No public servant shall request, use or permit the use of any publicly owned or publicly supported property, vehicle, equipment, material, labor or service, or money, for the personal convenience or the private advantage of self or of any other person. This requirement shall not be deemed to prevent any public servant from requesting, using or permitting the use of such publicly owned or publicly supplied property, vehicle, equipment, material, labor or service which is made available by general practice, to the public at large, or which is provided, as a matter of public policy for the use of public servants in the conduct of official business, as approved consideration for their services to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-102. - Matters requiring disclosure of actual or potential conflicts of interest. 
    The following disclosure requirements are established to avoid both actual and potential conflict between the private self-interest and the public interest of public servants: 
(1)  Self interest. No public servant, either on his or her behalf or on behalf of any other person, shall have an interest in any business transaction with any public body of the city, unless the person shall first make full public disclosure of the nature of such interest. 
(2)  Disclosure and disqualification. Whenever the performance of official duties shall require a public servant to deliberate and vote on any matter involving his financial or personal interest, that person shall publicly disclose the nature and extent of such interest and is disqualified from participating in the deliberations and voting on the matter. 
(3)  Dual employment. No public servant shall engage in employment with, or render services for, any person or entity, which has business transactions with any public body of the city, without first making full public disclosure of the nature and extent of the employment or services. 
(4)  Dual representation. A public servant shall make full public disclosure of business involving the city when attempting to use his official position to secure special privileges or exemptions for self or others. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-103. - Prohibited conduct. 
    All public servants are prohibited from engaging in the following conduct: 
(1)  Divulging confidential information to any person not authorized to obtain such information in advance of the time prescribed for its authorized release to the public. 
(2)  Benefiting personally or financially from confidential information. 
(3)  Representing his or her individual opinion as that of the city. 
(4)  Misusing city personnel resources, property, funds or assets not available to the public in general for personal or private use or gain. 
(5)  Soliciting or accepting a gift, favors, gratuities, loan of money, goods, services or other things of value which tend to influence the manner in which the public servant performs his or her official duties. 
(6)  Engaging in a business transaction which may cause the public servant to derive a personal profit or gain directly or indirectly as a result of his or her official position. 
(7)  Engaging in employment or rendering services that are incompatible or in conflict with the discharge of his or her official duties or that tend to impair his or her independence of judgment. 
(8)  Appearing on behalf of the private interests of a third party before any public body of the city. 
(9)  Appearing as a member of city council before proceedings of subordinate public bodies unless invited to provide factual information relevant to the discussion at hand. 
(10)  Participating in contracts, loans, grants, rate-fixing or issuing permits involving a business entity in which he or she has a substantial interest; however this provision shall not apply in the following circumstances: 
a.  Contracting with the city where: 
1.  The contract is awarded pursuant to sealed bids; 
2.  The public servant is not involved directly or indirectly or otherwise refrains from participation in the decision on the award of the contract; and 
3.  The city council, after reviewing the circumstances, determines the award of the contract would be in the best interest of the city. 
b.  Where the interest of the public servant in the business entity involves the holding of less than one (1) percent of the securities in a publicly traded business or less than five percent of any privately or closely held business and where the public servant will not have any involvement in the transaction on behalf of the contracting business entity. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-104. - Public disclosure, contents. 
    Whenever a public disclosure is required by this article, it may be made orally on the record at a meeting of the public body involved, or in a writing filed with the clerk/treasurer, in both of which cases it shall be made a part of the record of a regular city council meeting, and in either event shall include: 
(1)  The identity of all persons involved in the interest. 
(2)  The source and amount of income derived from the interest that may be considered as resulting from employment, investment or gift. The person required to file a disclosure statement in accordance with the provisions of this article must verify, in writing, under penalty of perjury, the information in the statement is true and complete as far as he knows. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-105. - Duties of the clerk/treasurer. 
    The clerk/treasurer shall examine all disclosure statements filed pursuant to this article and report irregularities immediately to the person filing the statement, to the city administrator, and the city attorney. Acceptance of a statement by the clerk/treasurer shall not constitute approval of the statement. The clerk/treasurer shall maintain a current list of all disclosure statements required to be available for public disclosure. The clerk/treasurer shall preserve all disclosure statements for at least three (3) years after the date on which they are filed. The clerk/treasurer shall make available to the public all statements that are required to be available for inspection during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-106. - Request for opinion from the city attorney. 
    Any public servant may request that the city attorney provide an advisory opinion interpreting the effect or application of this article generally, or on questions directly relating to the propriety of their conduct in a particular situation. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-107. - Delivery of copies of ethics code to public servants. 
    The clerk/treasurer shall deliver a copy of this article to each public servant as soon as practicable after the enactment of the ordinance from which this article derives, and to each new public servant at the time of employment or taking office. The clerk/treasurer shall also request that each such person sign and return an acknowledgement of receipt of a copy of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Sec. 2-108. - Violation. 
    Every person convicted of a violation of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. The penalty or penalties imposed are not exclusive remedies under this article and any and all statutory and Charter penalties or forfeitures may also be enforced. Any person convicted under the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of misconduct. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 7-14-08) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 73-3, adopted May 30, 1973, effective June 13, 1973, amended Ch. 3 to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 3 was derived from Ord. of April 19, 1934, §§ 1-3, 6-11, 13; Ord. of July 12, 1935, § 1; Ord. of Nov. 8, 1965, § 1; Ord. No. C.O. 70-2, § 1, adopted June 8, 1970; and Ord. No. C.O. 71-2, adopted Dec. 14, 1970. 
Cross reference- Public disturbance, endangering safety of person or property by intoxicated person in public place, § 13-4; offenses involving underage persons and alcoholic beverages, § 13-24. 
State Law reference- Michigan Liquor Control Act, M.S.A., § 18.971 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  Person shall mean any legal entity, including an individual, partnership, association, corporation, business trust, club or lodge. 
(b)  Alcohol shall be defined and construed to mean the product of distillation of fermented liquid, whether rectified or diluted with water or not, fit for beverage purposes, whatever may be the origin thereof. 
(c)  Spirits also referred to as "liquor" shall mean any beverage which contains alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed with potable water and other substances in solution and includes, among other things, wine containing an alcoholic content of over sixteen (16) percent by volume. 
(d)  Alcoholic beverage shall mean any spirituous, vinous, malt or fermented liquor, liquid or compound, whether or not medicated, proprietary, patented, and by whatever name called, containing one-half (1/2) of one (1) percent or more of alcohol by volume which is fit for use for beverage purposes. 
(e)  Class B Hotel shall mean a hotel licensed to sell beer, wine and spirits for consumption on the premises. 
(f)  Class C License shall mean a license to sell beer, wine and spirits for consumption on the premises. 
(g)  Sale shall include exchange, barter, traffic or furnishing any alcoholic beverage. 
(h)  Hotel shall mean a building or buildings, including a motel, which is kept open to the public for the lodging of guests, where all who conduct themselves properly and who are able and ready to pay for such services are received, if there be any accommodations for them. 
(i)  Restaurant shall mean an establishment that derives not less than fifty (50) percent of its gross receipts from the sale of food and beverages other than alcoholic beverages as determined by its most recent previous fiscal year. 
(j)  Bar shall be defined and construed to mean a barrier or counter over which any alcoholic liquor may be passed or served directly to customers. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 73-3, § 1, 5-30-73) 
Sec. 3-2. - Approval of city council prerequisite to application for state license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell beer, wine, or liquor for consumption on the premises within the City of Milan without having first obtained approval by the city council of its application for a license so to sell as required by state statutes. 
(A)  Standards for city council approval. 
(1)  General requirements. 
(a)  The applicant must be a citizen of the United States and of the State of Michigan. 
(b)  The applicant shall not have been convicted of three (3) or more violations of law relating to the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages or any felony within a period of five (5) years preceding the receipt of the application. 
(c)  The applicant must satisfy the city council that he/she is of good character. If the city council shall find that the conduct of the applicant has been such as to reasonably justify the conclusion that the applicant would either intentionally violate or neglect to comply with the provisions of this chapter, the application shall be disapproved. 
(d)  The applicant must produce satisfactory evidence that he/she has financial resources sufficient to allow him/her to meet the requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  Additional requirements for Class B Hotel License applicants. 
(a)  Shall have a minimum of twenty-five (25) guest rooms. 
(b)  Shall be a bona fide restaurant. 
(c)  Shall conform with all zoning and building rules and requirements established by the Milan City Code and by all codes incorporated and adopted by the Milan City Code. 
(d)  Shall agree to maintain accurate records of receipts and disbursements in such a manner that receipts from food and beverages other than alcoholic beverages will be readily distinguishable from receipts for alcoholic beverages. Such records shall be available for inspection by the city or its agent from time to time during normal business hours. 
(e)  The dining area shall be separated from the bar area by a partition extending from floor to ceiling and so designed as to conceal the bar and obscure the bar area in general from the dining area. 
(3)  Additional requirements for Class C License applicants. 
(a)  Shall be a bona fide restaurant. 
(b)  Shall conform with all zoning and building rules and requirements established by the Milan City Code and by all codes incorporated and adopted by the Milan City Code. 
(c)  Shall agree to maintain accurate records of receipts and disbursements in such a manner that receipts from food and beverages other than alcoholic beverages will be readily distinguishable from receipts for alcoholic beverages. Such records shall be available for inspection by the city or its agent from time to time during normal business hours. 
(B)  Application procedure. Prior to application to the Michigan Liquor Control Commission for a license to sell alcoholic beverages, an applicant shall make a request for requisite approval by the Milan City Council. Such request for approval shall be made upon forms provided for such purpose by the city; shall include all authorizations and releases deemed necessary by the city; and shall be submitted to the city clerk/treasurer. A fee as set forth in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council shall accompany all applications made pursuant to this chapter. Upon receipt of the completed application package and fee, the clerk/treasurer shall transmit the same to the chief of police who shall endorse upon such application his recommendation concerning the applicant. The clerk/treasurer shall endorse upon the application a statement as to whether the applicant is in default to the city in connection with the payment of any taxes or other obligations. Following endorsements by the chief of police and the clerk/treasurer, the clerk/treasurer shall transmit the application package to the city council for its consideration, but may first request the applicant to furnish such additional information as may be necessary to determine whether the requirements of this chapter have been met. Any grant of approval, denial of approval, or revocation or suspension of approval shall be evidenced by an appropriate resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 73-3, § 2, 5-30-73; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 2, 5-9-94; Ord. No. C.O. 96-3, § 1, 5-13-96) 
Sec. 3-3. - Subsequent cessation of compliance with requirements and/or standards. 
    Should any establishment at any time cease to meet the requirements of this chapter and should such failure continue for a period of six (6) months, the council may suspend or revoke its approval and the continued sale of liquor for consumption on the premises shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 73-3, § 3, 5-30-73) 
Sec. 3-4. - Conduct of business. 
    The owner, or owners, as well as the agents and servants of the owner or owners, actually engaged in the operation of an establishment licensed to sell any alcoholic beverages in the premises, shall, at all times, be responsible for the conduct of occupants and patrons. No disorderly, loud or boisterous conduct shall be permitted, nor shall any entertainment be provided or permitted which is offensive or indecent in its nature. No booths shall be permitted which are completely enclosed or capable of being either permanently or temporarily enclosed or locked. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 73-3, § 4, 5-30-73) 
Sec. 3-5. - Hours. 
    No person, either directly or indirectly, by himself, clerk, agent, servant or employee shall sell, give away or furnish any alcoholic beverages between 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. No licensee shall permit his premises to be occupied by persons other than himself or his bona fide employees between 2:30 a.m. to 7:00 a.m. on any day. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 73-2, § 5, 5-30-73) 
Sec. 3-6. - Consumption on public streets, etc., prohibited; license required for public establishments and stores. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on a public street, alley, park or on any other public place, including any stores or establishments doing business with the public in the city not licensed to sell such alcoholic beverage for consumption on such premises; it shall also be unlawful for anyone who owns, operates or controls any such public establishment or store, to permit the consumption of alcoholic liquors therein without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 73-3, § 6, 5-30-73) 
Sec. 3-6.1. - Transportation in open container. 
    No alcoholic liquor shall be transported or possessed in a container which is open, uncapped or upon which the seal is broken, within the passenger compartment of a vehicle on a street, highway, alley or any other public or private property which is open to the general public. If the vehicle does not have a trunk or compartment separate from the passenger compartment, a container which is open, uncapped or upon which the seal is broken, shall be encased or enclosed. This section shall not apply to any chartered passenger vehicles licensed by the Michigan Public Service Commission. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 77-15, 11-28-77) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 77-5, adopted Nov. 28, 1977, did not specifically amend this Code; its inclusion as § 3-6.1 was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 3-7. - Restrictions imposed by other city ordinances and/or statutes of the State of Michigan. 
    If any provision of any other ordinance of the City of Milan or any statutes of the State of Michigan imposes greater restriction in any respect than herein set forth, then the provision of such ordinance or state statute shall control in this respect. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 73-3, § 7, 5-30-73) 
Sec. 3-8. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), or by imprisonment in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 73-3, § 9, 5-30-73) 
ARTICLE II. - NUDITY IN ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 3-9. - Nudity defined. 
    For the purposes of sections 3-10 through 3-13, nudity shall be defined as the exposure to view by any person of any of the following body parts, either directly or indirectly, including, but not limited to, exposure through less than fully opaque clothing articles or body stockings: 
(a)  The whole or part of the pubic region; 
(b)  The whole or part of the anus; 
(c)  The whole or part of the buttocks; 
(d)  The whole or part of the genitals; and 
(e)  The breast area including nipple, or more than one-half of the area of the breast. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 97-3, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 3-10. - Prohibition. 
    Nudity shall be strictly prohibited in any establishment licensed or subject to licensing by the Michigan Liquor Control Commission. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 97-3, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 3-11. - Severability. 
    Every word, sentence and clause of this article shall be deemed to be severable, and should any word, sentence, clause, provision or part thereof be declared by a court to be invalid, the remaining provisions shall not be affected. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 97-3, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 3-12. - Effective date. 
    The effective date of this article shall be ten (10) days after its adoption and publication. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 97-3, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 3-13. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates sections 3-9 through 3-10 shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days in the county jail or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. Each day that a violation of sections 3-9 through 3-10 is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation for purposes of this section 3-13. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 97-3, 11-10-97) 
Chapter 5 - BLIGHT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, adopted November 14, 2005 created new Chapter 5, Blight. 

Sec. 5-1. - Purpose of chapter. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to prevent, reduce or eliminate blight or potential blight in the city by the prevention or elimination of certain environmental causes of blight or blighting factors which exist or which may in the future exist in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 11-14-05; Ord. No. 2015-05, 9-14-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-05, adopted Sept. 14, 2015, changed the title of § 5-1 from "Purpose of article" to read as set out herein. 
Sec. 5-2. - Enforcement of chapter. 
    This chapter shall be enforced by the building/zoning official of the city, or such other persons as shall be so designated. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 11-14-05; Ord. No. 2015-05, 9-14-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-05, adopted Sept. 14, 2015, changed the title of § 5-2 from "Enforcement of article" to read as set out herein. 
Sec. 5-3. - Causes of blight or blighting factors enumerated. 
    It is hereby determined that the following uses, structures and activities are causes of blight or blighting factors which, if allowed to exist, will tend to result in blight and undesirable neighborhoods: 
(1)  Unsightly conditions including accumulation of debris; fences characterized by holes, breaks, rot, crumbling, cracking, peeling or rusting; landscaping that is dead, characterized by uncontrolled growth or lack of maintenance, or is damaged; any other similar conditions of disrepair and deterioration; and the exterior visible use or display of tarps, plastic sheeting, or other similar materials as flexible or inflexible screening, fencing, or wall covering upon a residential lot; regardless of the condition of other properties in the neighborhood. The enforcement of this section will not apply to temporary emergency repairs to residential or commercial buildings. However, no such temporary emergency repairs shall be exempt from this section longer than four (4) weeks, without the express written consent of the building/zoning official of the city. 
(2)  The storage on any property of building materials, unless there is in force a valid building permit issued by the city for construction upon such property and such materials are intended for use in connection with such construction, or unless the storage of building materials is otherwise permitted as a principal or accessory use under the zoning ordinance, City Code, appendix A. Building materials shall include, but shall not be limited to, lumber, bricks, concrete or cinder blocks, plumbing materials, electrical wiring or equipment, heating ducts or equipment, shingles, mortar, concrete or cement nails, screws, or any other materials used in constructing any structure. The enforcement of this section will not apply to neatly stacked firewood. 
(3)  The storage or accumulation of litter, junk, trash, rubbish, refuse, waste materials, garbage, offal, paper, glass, cans, bottles, debris or other foreign substances of every kind and description, except as such may be stored as provided under the rules and regulations of this Code. The term "junk" shall include parts of machinery or motor vehicles; unused appliances stored in the open; metal or any other cast-off materials of any kind, whether or not the same could be put to any reasonable use. 
(4)  The existence of any structure or part of such structure, which because of fire, wind or other natural disaster or physical deterioration, is no longer habitable as a dwelling, nor useful for any other purpose for which it may have been intended or lawfully used. 
(5)  The existence of any vacant dwelling; garage or other accessory building, unless the same is securely locked, with windows intact or neatly boarded up, and otherwise protected to prevent entrance thereto by unauthorized persons. 
(6)  The existence of any partially completed structure, unless such structure is in the course of construction in accordance with a valid and subsisting building permit issued by the city and unless such construction is completed within the time specified by existing ordinances. 
(7)  The parking, storage or placing upon any public right-of-way, public property or private property within the city of any commercial truck, road tractor, semi trailer, pole trailer, bus, or coach bus for a period in excess of forty-eight (48) hours, unless the same is wholly contained in a fully enclosed building. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 11-14-05) 
Sec. 5-4. - Maintenance of causes of blight or blighting factors prohibited; exception. 
    No person shall maintain or permit to be maintained any of those causes of blight or blighting factors enumerated in section 5-3 upon any property in the city owned, leased, rented or occupied by such person, except as such uses of property may be permitted or incidental to the carrying out of any business or occupation authorized by the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 11-14-05) 
Sec. 5-5. - Violations, municipal civil infractions. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating section 5-4 shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction and shall be subject to a fine as follows: 
(1)  The fine for any first violation shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(2)  The fine for a second violation of this chapter that occurs within two (2) years of any prior violation of this chapter shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(3)  The fine for three (3) or more violations of this chapter that occur within two (2) years of any prior violations of this chapter shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 11-14-05; Ord. No. 2015-05, 9-14-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-05, adopted Sept. 14, 2015, changed the title of § 5-5 from "Violations, civil infraction" to read as set out herein. 
Sec. 5-6. - Each day a separate municipal civil infraction. 
    A separate municipal civil infraction shall be deemed committed upon each day during or when a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 11-14-05; Ord. No. 2015-05, 9-14-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-05, adopted Sept. 14, 2015, changed the title of § 5-6 from "Each day a separate civil infraction" to read as set out herein. 
Sec. 5-7. - Rights and remedies are cumulative. 
    The rights and remedies provided herein are cumulative and in addition to any other remedies provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 11-14-05) 
Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Fire limits established. 
    The fire limits of the city are hereby established as follows: 
    Commencing at the southwest corner of Lot 47 of the assessor's plat of the Village of Milan, Monroe County; thence northwesterly parallel with West Main Street to a point which would intersect with a southwesterly continuation of the westerly line of Lot 21 of the Supervisor's Plat Number 3 of the Village of Milan, Washtenaw County; thence northeasterly along said western line continuation to the northerly line of West Main Street; thence northwesterly along said northerly line to the southwest corner of Lot 3 of Braman's Addition; thence northeasterly along said line to the northwest corner of Lot 16 of Braman's Addition; thence southeasterly along south side of First Street to the easterly side of Tolan Street; thence northeasterly along easterly side of Tolan Street to the northwest corner of Lot 42 of Supervisor's Plat Number 4; thence southeasterly along the south side of Hurd Street to the northeast corner of Lot 44; thence southwesterly along west side of Ferman Street to a point which would intersect with a northwesterly continuation of the southerly line of Gay Street; thence southeasterly along said southern line continuation to the northeasterly corner of Lot 56; thence southwesterly along westerly line of Gay Street to the northerly line of East Main Street and continuing directly across Main Street to the southern side thereof; thence southeasterly along said southerly line of the northeast corner of Lot 42 of the assessor's plat of the Village of Milan, Monroe County; thence southwesterly to the southeast corner of Lot 42; thence northwesterly to the place of beginning, said description covering the fire limits of the city. 
(Ord. of 6-14-1899, § 1; Ord. No. C.O. 76-9, 11-8-76) 
Sec. 6-2. - Designation of agency to enforce provisions of state construction code. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Section 9 of Act 230 of the Public Acts of 1972 (Compiled Laws of 1948, section 125.1509), the building inspector of the City of Milan is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibilities of the city under Act 230 of the Public Acts of 1972, State of Michigan. The City of Milan hereby assumes responsibilities for the administration and enforcement of said act throughout its corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 74-5, § 1, 10-28-74) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 74-5 did not specifically amend the Code, hence codification as § 6-2 was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 6-3. - Pre-sale/purchase code compliance inspections; fees. 
    A fee shall be paid to cover the costs of each inspection requested by an owner, agent, proposed purchaser and/or contractor in connection with a planned sale or purchase of the subject property or with obtaining financing for the property (e.g., FHA or VA mortgage). The amounts of such fees shall be those specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council and shall apply separately to each inspection and reinspection of each of the trades (plumbing, mechanical, electrical, and building/structural). 
(Ord. No. C.O. 77-8, 7-12-77; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 4, 5-9-94) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 77-8, being nonamendatory of this Code, is included herein as § 6-3 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 6-4. - Installation, maintenance and inspection of fire detection systems in dwelling units let for occupancy; fees; penalties. 
(a)  No person shall let to another for occupancy any dwelling unit which is not equipped with smoke or fire detectors or with an automatic fire alarm system. The type, number and location of the detectors or alarm system shall be approved by the city building official in accordance with the standards for such detectors and systems contained in the Michigan Building Code adopted and made a part of this article. Batteries in battery operated detectors shall be replaced at least once a year. Detectors and automatic alarm systems shall be maintained in good operating condition, and shall be annually inspected by the building official of the City of Milan, or his designee, who shall affix a sticker to each such approved device in a conspicuous place showing the date of inspection and the signature of the inspector. The fees for such inspections and all necessary reinspections shall be those specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council and shall be paid by the owner of the inspected dwelling unit prior to the initial inspection and each re-inspection. Any such fee which is not paid within ninety (90) days from the date of the inspection or reinspection to which it applies shall be added to the next city real property tax bill as a part thereof, and shall be collected in the same manner as all other real estate taxes levied by the City of Milan. 
(b)  All electrical wiring of fire and smoke detection and alarm systems shall be in accordance with the City of Milan Electrical Code. 
(c)  The owner of each dwelling unit subject to this section 6-4 shall instruct the unit's occupant on the operation and testing of the detection and/or alarm system and recommend monthly testing thereof by the occupant of the dwelling unit. 
(d)  Any violation of, or failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination or responsibility for such a municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of this section is continued or permitted to exist shall constitute a separate municipal civil infraction. Neither the correction of any violation of the terms of this section, nor the imposition or satisfaction of any penalty imposed herein for such violation shall relieve the subject dwelling unit's owner of liability for the re-inspection fees assessed pursuant to subsection (a) thereof. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 79-1, §§ 1-4, 3-12-79; Ord. No. C.O. 85-9, § 1, 1-13-86; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 4, 5-9-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 3, 1-23-95) 
Cross reference- Building code adopted, § 6-12; electrical code adopted, § 6-39; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8. 
Secs. 6-5-6-11. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention code, § 8-01. 
Charter reference- Council to maintain a building and safety ordinance, § 4.23. 
State Law reference- Power of city to adopt building code, M.S.A., § 5.2073(k). 

Sec. 6-12. - Building code enforcement; modifications. 
(a)  Agency designated. Pursuant to the provisions of the Michigan Building Code, in accordance with section 9 of Act 230, P.A. 1972, as amended, the building official of the city is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the city under Act 230, P.A. 1972, as amended, State of Michigan. The city assumes responsibility for the administration and enforcement of such Act throughout its corporate limits. 
(b)  Current code; city-specific modifications. A copy of the Michigan Building Code to be enforced pursuant to this section shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk/treasurer and available for public inspection. The following sections of the building code adopted by the Construction Code Commission, Michigan Department of Labor, effective May 5, 1995, and corresponding sections of all Michigan Building Codes hereafter adopted by the Construction Code Commission, Michigan Department of Labor, are hereby made a part of this article to the same extent as if copied at length herein, with the modifications specified below: 
(1)  Section 102.2 shall read: 
" 102.2 Rehabilitation: The legal use and occupancy of any structure existing on the effective date of this code or for which it had been previously approved may be continued without change, except as may be specifically covered in this code or as may be deemed necessary by the building official for the general safety and welfare of the occupants and the public." 
(2)  Section 104.2 shall read: 
" 104.2 Appointment: The code official shall be appointed by the Mayor in accordance with the City Charter." 
(3)  Section 112.1 shall read: 
" 112.1 General: A fee shall be paid to the City of Milan before any plan examination or inspection is commenced and before any building permit (including any permit to begin work for any new construction, alteration, removal, demolition, or other building operation) is issued. Such fees shall be those specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. In addition, an amendment to a permit necessitating an additional fee shall not be approved until the additional fee has been paid." 
(4)  Section 116.4 shall read: 
"116.4 Violation penalties: 
"(1)  Any person, corporation or other entity, including an officer, director or employee of such corporation or entity, or any governmental official or agent charged with the responsibility of issuing permits or inspecting buildings or structures, who commits any of the following acts shall be liable for a municipal civil infraction: 
"(a)  Knowingly violates this code or the rules for enforcement of this code. 
"(b)  Knowingly constructs or builds a structure or building in violation of a condition of a building permit. 
"(c)  Knowingly fails to comply with an order issued by an enforcing official, agency, a construction board of appeals, or a board pursuant to this code. 
"(d)  Knowingly makes a false or misleading written statement or knowingly omits required information or a statement in an inspection report, application, petition, request for approval, or appeal to an enforcing official or agency, a construction board of appeals, or a board. 
"(e)  Knowingly refuses entry or access to an inspector lawfully authorized to inspect any premises, building, or structure pursuant to this code. 
"(f)  Unreasonably interferes with an authorized inspection. 
"(g)  Knowingly issues, fails to issue, causes to be issued, or assists in the issuance of a certificate, permit, or license in violation of this code. 
"(h)  Having a duty to report violations of this code or knowingly conceals a violation. 
"Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for any municipal civil infraction referenced in this section, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the official municipal civil infraction fines and costs schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Such fines and costs shall be in addition to any other remedy or cause of action for personal injury or property damage available to the city under state law. 
"(2)  With respect to subsection (1)(c), a person is liable for a separate municipal civil infraction for each day that the person fails to comply with a stop-work order validly issued by an enforcing official or agency or by an authorized local official, as defined in chapter 131/4 of the Milan City Code, and for each week that the person fails to comply with any other order validly issued by an enforcing official or agency or by an authorized local official, as defined in chapter 131/4 of the Milan City Code. With respect to subsection (1)(a) or (1)(d), a person is liable for a separate municipal civil infraction for each knowing violation of this code and for each false or misleading written statement or omission of required information or statement knowingly made in an application, petition, request for approval, or appeal to an enforcing official or agency, a construction board of appeals, or a board. With respect to subsection (1)(b), a person is liable for a separate municipal civil infraction for each knowing violation of a condition of a building permit. Each day that any violation of this code continues shall be deemed a separate municipal civil infraction." 
(5)  Section 117.2 shall read: 
" 117.2 Unlawful Continuance: It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop-work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition. Upon determination of responsibility for any such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the official municipal civil infraction fines and cost schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Such fine and costs shall be in addition to any other remedy or cause for personal injury or property damage available to the city under state law. Each day in which any violation or infraction referenced in this section shall continue shall be deemed a separate violation or infraction." 
(6)  Section 121.0 (page 7) shall be deleted. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 1; Ord. No. C.O. 76-6, 8-9-76; Ord. No. C.O. 79-9, 9-24-79; Ord. No. C.O. 82-8, § 1, 8-23-82; Ord. No. C.O. 85-8, § 1, 10-14-85; Ord. No. C.O. 88-4, § 1, 6-13-88; Ord. No. C.O. 93-1, § 1, 4-12-93; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 4, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 96-8, § 1, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 6-12.1. - Registration of building contractors. 
    Before performing any construction work within the City of Milan, all building contractors required to be licensed by the State of Michigan shall register with the building official. Registration with the building official requires presentation of the contractor's license and payment to the city of an annual registration fee. The amount of such fee shall be that specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 88-1, § 1, 4-25-88; Ord. No. C.O. 93-1, § 1, 4-12-93; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 5, 5-9-94) 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12.

The city assumes responsibility for the administration and enforcement of such Act throughout its corporate limits.

Sec. 6-13. - Interpretation and purpose of article. 
    In interpreting and applying the provisions of this article, such provisions shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the protection of the public health, morals safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Whenever the requirements of this article impose requirements of a lower standard than those that may be required under the provisions of the state housing code or any other state law, then that higher provision shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 4-24-67, § 2) 
Sec. 6-14. - Permit. 
(a)  It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction to construct, enlarge, alter or demolish a structure; or change the occupancy of a building or structure requiring greater strength, ingress, egress or sanitary provisions; or to change to another use; or to install or alter any equipment for which provision is made, or the installation of which is regulated by this Code or by any building code incorporated into this article by reference, without first filing an application with the building department in writing and obtaining a permit therefor; provided, however, that minor and ordinary repairs, except as hereafter provided, costing five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less, and which do not involve any violation of such codes, shall be exempt from this provision. 
(b)  Minor and ordinary repairs, as hereinbefore exempted, shall not include the cutting away of any wall, partition or portion thereof, the removal or cutting of any structural beam or bearing support, or the removal or change of any required means of egress, or rearrangement of parts of a structure affecting the ingress or egress requirements; nor shall minor or ordinary repairs include the addition to, alteration of, replacement or relocation of any standpipe, water supply, sewer, drainage, drain leader, gas, soil, waste, vent or similar piping, electric wiring or mechanical or other work affecting public health or general safety. 
(c)  Before any permit shall be issued under this article, a building permit and inspection fee shall be paid by the applicant. The amount of such fee shall be based upon the projected cost of the project and shall be the fee specified for such permit in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council. 
(d)  In addition to any building permit and inspection fee required by this section 6-14 and prior to the commencement of construction, a separate fee shall be paid to the City of Milan for each new commercial construction project and for each new single-family residential and two-family residential construction project within the city, for the purpose of the building official's review of the project plans to determine their conformance with applicable building and safety codes. The fees for such code compliance plans reviews shall be those specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, §§ 3, 7; Ord. No. C.O. 80-10, § 1, 9-22-80; Ord. No. C.O. 88-1, § 2, 4-25-88; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 6, 5-9-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 4, 1-23-95) 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 6-15. - Duty of builders, etc., to comply with article; penalties. 
    It shall be the duty of all architects, contractors, subcontractors, builders and other persons having charge of the erecting, altering, changing or remodeling of any building or structure, before beginning or undertaking any such work, to see that a proper permit has been granted therefor and that such work does not conflict with and is not in violation of the terms of this article. Any such architect, builder, contractor or other person doing or performing any such work of erecting, repair, altering, changing or remodeling without such a permit having been issued or in violation of or in conflict with the terms of this article, shall be deemed liable for a municipal civil infraction in the same manner and to the same extent as the owner of the premises or the person for whom such building is erected, repaired, altered, changed, or remodeled. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for any municipal civil infraction referenced in this section, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Such fine and costs shall be in addition to any other remedy or cause of action for personal injury or property damage available to the city under state law. Each day in which any violation or infraction referenced in this section shall continue shall be deemed a separate violation or infraction. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 4; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 4, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 6-16, 6-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 82-8, § 5, enacted Aug. 23, 1982, repealed §§ 6-16 and 6-17, relative to the effect of Art. II on construction as of April 24, 1967, and temporary basement and garage dwellings. Said sections were derived from Ord. of April 24, 1967, §§ 5, 6. 
Sec. 6-18. - Inspections. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the holder of every permit under this article to notify the building department twenty-four (24) hours in advance of the time when such building shall be ready for inspection. Four (4) such inspections shall be required on all buildings. The first inspection shall be required when forms or trenching for footings are in place and before the pouring of any concrete. The second inspection shall be required when the footings, basement walls, drain tile and waterproofing are in place and prior to backfilling. The third inspection shall be required when all walls, ceilings, partitions and structural elements of the building, heat ducts, plumbing and electrical wiring are in place and prior to concealing or application of any interior finish. The fourth inspection shall be required when the building is completed and prior to occupancy. 
(b)  In the case of sheds and garages having an area of less than eight hundred (800) square feet, only two (2) inspections shall be required. The first inspection shall be required when the forms for the footings and foundation walls are in place and before the pouring of concrete. The second inspection shall be required when the building is completed and before it is occupied. 
(c)  Failure to notify the building inspector at the time of any required inspection shall automatically cancel the building permit previously issued, and the payment of a new building permit fee shall be required before the reissue of said permit. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 8; Ord. No. C.O. 82-8, § 6, 8-23-82) 

Sec. 6-20. - Minimum width of single-family dwellings. 
    A single-family dwelling shall have a minimum exterior width of twenty (20) feet. Width shall be defined as the lesser of two (2) principal, overall, horizontal dimensions of the dwelling, and shall not include any extensions, add-on or additions. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-1, § 1, 3-12-84) 
Sec. 6-21. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 83-6, § 1, adopted June 27, 1983, repealed former § 6-21 which pertained to size and height of rooms and was derived from sections 10 and 11 of an ordinance enacted April 24, 1967, and Ord. No. C.O. 82-8, §§ 7 and 8, adopted Aug. 23, 1982. 
Sec. 6-22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 6-22, specifying requirements for windows, derived from Ord. of April 24, 1967, § 12, was repealed by Ord. No. C.O. 82-8, § 9, adopted Aug. 23, 1982. 
Sec. 6-23. - Access to living rooms, bedrooms and water closets. 
    In dwellings erected after April 24, 1967, access to every living room and to every bedroom shall be had without passing through a bedroom or through a room containing a water closet. Access to water closets must be possible from all bedrooms without passing through another bedroom or room used as a bedroom. This provision does not apply to a sleeping porch, sun parlor or any other enclosed outside porch adjacent to any water closet entered by way of a bedroom. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 13) 
Sec. 6-24. - Air space requirements for occupancy. 
    In no case shall a room, suite or group of rooms comprising a family dwelling unit, in any single or two-family dwelling, be so occupied as to provide less than eight hundred (800) cubic feet of air space per occupant, exclusive of cubic air space of bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, stairways, attics, utility rooms and basements. No bedroom or room used as a bedroom in any single or two-family dwelling shall be so occupied as to provide less than three hundred (300) cubic feet of air space per occupant, exclusive of the cubic feet of air space of bathrooms, toilet rooms and closets. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 14) 
Sec. 6-25. - Commercial buildings used in part for dwelling purposes to comply with article. 
    Each building used in part for dwelling purposes in connection with any business structure shall conform to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 15) 
Sec. 6-26. - Grade. 
    A minimum sloping grade of one (1) per cent from the front of the foundation of the house to the front lot line at the sidewalk level and from the rear wall of the foundation of the house to the rear lot line, shall be established and maintained in order to provide adequate drainage away from the foundation of the dwelling. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 16) 
Sec. 6-27. - Yards. 
    No part of any required yard, except a rear yard, shall be used for any detached garage or any accessory building. Any portion of a lot in front of the front building line shall be used for ornamental purposes only and nothing shall be placed thereon except trees, shrubs, fences or items of a similar nature, except that portion of improved driveways in front of the front building lines may be used for the temporary parking of passenger vehicles. All shrubs on corner lots planted along the street boundary line which may interfere with safe intersection vision clearance, shall be kept trimmed to not more than three (3) feet in height. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 17; Ord. No. C.O. 85-7, § 1, 7-22-85) 
Cross reference- Trees and shrubs, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 6-28. - Storage, parking and use of moving vans, automobile trailers, etc. 
    The storage, parking and/or use of moving vans, automobile trailers, semi-trucks and similar commercial vehicles or trailers, and mobile homes, shall not be allowed or considered a legal use in any district zoned residential, except as specifically authorized in the zoning ordinance. 
    The storage, parking and/or use of bus or streetcar bodies, other similar apparatus which might be used for dwelling purposes, tourist cabins, or tents shall not be allowed or considered a legal use in any district zoned residential. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 18; Ord. No. C.O. 72-11, § 1, 11-27-72; Ord. No. C.O. 85-7, § 1, 7-22-85) 
Cross reference- Zoning ordinance, App. A. 
Sec. 6-29. - Storage, parking, and use of house trailers, motor homes, special mobile equipment, recreational vehicles, dismounted campers prohibited within city limits in other than licensed storage facilities; exceptions; permits and fees. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein or in the City of Milan Zoning Ordinance, the storage, parking or use of house trailers, motor homes, special mobile equipment, dismounted campers, or other recreational vehicles as defined by the Michigan Vehicle Code, Chapter 1, being Act 300 of the Public Acts of 1949, as amended, or by common usage, is prohibited within the corporate limits of the City of Milan in other than a licensed storage facility. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of the City of Milan Zoning Ordinance, the storage of one unoccupied house trailer, motor home, camper attachment or similar recreational vehicle, in a garage or in a rear year is permitted, and provided further that when neither garage nor rear yard space is available, such house trailer, motor home, camper attachment or similar recreational vehicle may be stored in a side yard. 
(b)  A temporary permit may be issued for the front yard parking of one (1) house trailer, motor home or similar recreational vehicle, for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days only after application for the permit is made to the city building official, and the applicant pays to the city the fee for such permit. The amount of such permit fee shall be that specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. The building official shall issue such permit only if he inspects the applicant's property and determines that no rear or side yard either exists or is accessible for the parking of such vehicle and that the parking will take place on an improved driveway no closer than five (5) feet from the property line of the lot or the street right-of-way, whichever is further from the street. Such permit may be extended by written approval of the building official for an additional thirty (30) days, for a total of not more than sixty (60) days in any one (1) calendar year, with no additional permit fee. 
(c)  A house trailer, motor home or similar recreational vehicle may be parked in a front yard for a period not to exceed forty-eight (48) hours for loading and unloading purposes, only, without a temporary permit as provided in section 6-29(b). 
(d)  A temporary permit may be issued for the use of a house trailer, mobile home, motor home or mobile office trailer, in a nonresidential zoned district for purposes accessory to construction while such construction is in progress for a period not to exceed six (6) months, only after application for the permit is made to the city building official, the applicant pays to the city the permit fee, and the application is approved by the city council after certification by the building official that the subject vehicle is served with adequate sanitary facilities. Such permit may be renewed for additional six-month periods upon completion of the same procedures (including payment of fees) as hereinbefore set forth for each such period. The amounts of the fee for the initial and renewal permits shall be those specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 72-11, § 2, 11-27-72; Ord. No. C.O. 77-7, § 1, 7-12-77; Ord. No. C.O. 85-7, § 1, 7-22-85; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 7, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 6-30. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(b)  The penalties specified in these section shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other remedy that the city may have at law and/or in equity. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 5, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 6-31-6-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL CODE[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to adopt electrical code, M.S.A., § 5.2073(k); electricians generally, § 18.204(1) et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-39. - Electrical Code adopted. 
(a)  Agency designated. Pursuant to the provisions of the Michigan Electrical Code, in accordance with section 9 of Act 230, P.A. 1972, as amended, the building official of the city is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the city under Act 230, P.A. 1972, as amended, State of Michigan. The city assumes responsibility for the administration and enforcement of such Act throughout its corporate limits. 
(b)  Current code. A copy of the Michigan Electrical Code to be enforced pursuant to this section shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk/treasurer and available for public inspection. 
(Ord. of 4-24-67, § 1; Ord. No. C.O. 76-15, 11-22-76; Ord. No. C.O. 82-8, § 10, 8-23-82; Ord. No. C.O. 85-2, § 1, 7-8-85; Ord. No. 93-1, § 2, 4-12-93; Ord. No. 96-8, § 3, 12-9-96) 
Sec. 6-40. - Registration of electricians and electrical contractors. 
    Before any person shall engage in the business of electrical wiring or making alterations to the electrical wiring within the City of Milan, such person shall be licensed by the State of Michigan to do so and shall register with the building official. Registration with the building official requires presentation of the electrician's license and payment to the city of an annual registration fee. The amount of such fee shall be that specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. of 2-10-22, § 5; Ord. of 11-10-58; Ord. No. C.O. 76-15, 11-22-76; Ord. No. 93-1, § 2, 4-12-93; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 8, 5-9-94) 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12. 
State Law reference- State license, M.S.A., § 18.204(3). 
Sec. 6-41. - Permits; fees. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction to install or alter any equipment for which provision is made, or the installation of which is regulated by this Code or by any electrical code incorporated into this article by reference, without first filing an application with the building department in writing and obtaining a permit for such installation or alteration. Before any permit shall be issued under this article, a permit fee shall be paid for each permit required by any provision of this article. The amounts of such fees shall be those specified in the official fee schedule, including all exhibits thereto, adopted by resolution of the city council. The amounts of the permit fees specified in the official fee schedule shall be doubled if the permit is not obtained at the time required by this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 9, 5-9-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 6, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 6-42. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(b)  The penalties specified in this section shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other remedy that the city may have at law and/or in equity. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 7, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 6-43-6-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INSPECTOR 

Sec. 6-46. - Created. 
    There shall be an inspector of all electrical installations and safety engineering in the city who shall have charge of all electrical installation in the construction of all public buildings and residences and in the repairing of any electric wiring in any of the public buildings or residences of the city. 
(Ord. of 2-10-22, § 1) 
Sec. 6-47. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    A person who is an electrical journeyman, licensed by the State of Michigan, shall be appointed inspector by the city council. No person shall be appointed inspector who is not a citizen of the state. 
(Ord. of 2-10-22, § 2; Ord. No. C.O. 78-6, § 1, 10-9-78) 
Sec. 6-48. - Compensation. 
    The inspector shall receive such compensation for services as the city council shall decide. 
(Ord. of 2-10-22, § 6) 
Sec. 6-49. - General powers and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the inspector to have general supervision and control of the installation and wiring in the construction and alteration of all buildings and residences in the city, and supervision and examination of all applicants for licenses pertaining to the work of installation and wiring of buildings and residences in the city. 
(Ord. of 2-10-22, § 3) 
Sec. 6-50. - Inspections; fees. 
    The inspector shall cause to be inspected, from time to time, all public buildings and such other buildings within the city, as may be directed by the city council, in its judgment, and/or referred to him by the building and zoning officer, and residences when requested to do so by the owner of such residence. The owner of the premises to be inspected or the contractor or other agent required to obtain the inspection or reinspection shall pay a fee to the city prior to each inspection and reinspection. The amounts of such fees shall be those specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. of 2-10-22, § 4; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 10, 5-9-94) 
Secs. 6-51-6-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PLUMBING CODE[4] 
Footnotes:

(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 13, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 6-68. - Inspections; fees. 
    The inspector shall cause to be inspected, from time to time, all public buildings and such other buildings within the city, as may be directed by the city council, in its judgment, and/or referred to him by the building and zoning officer, and residences when requested to do so by the owner of such residence. (b)  The penalties specified in this section shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other remedy that the city may have at law and/or in equity. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 8, 1-23-95)

ARTICLE V. - HOUSING CODE 

Sec. 6-71. - International Property Maintenance Code adopted. 
(a)  The Stille-DeRossett-Hale Single State Construction Code Act [Public Act 1972 No. 230; MCL 125.1501 et seq.]; and the Home Rule City Act [Public Act 1909 No. 279; MCL 117.3(k)], as amended, provide that each city shall have power, whether so provided in its charter or not, to adopt, by reference in an ordinance, any codes, including property maintenance codes, that have been promulgated by a national organization or association which is organized and conducted for the purpose of developing any such code, provided that such code is clearly identified in the adopting ordinance, that its purpose is published with said ordinance and that printed copies thereof are kept in the office of the city clerk and/or building official, available for inspection by, and distribution to, the public at all times, and provided further that a complete copy of such code is available for public use and inspection at the office of the city clerk and/or building official, and that said publication shall also contain a notice to this effect. 
(b)  A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 edition, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the Property Maintenance Code of the city for regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the condemnation of buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use, and the demolition of such existing structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said property maintenance code on file in the office of the city clerk of the city are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set forth in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 6-71(c) of this chapter. 
(c)  The Property Maintenance Code, as adopted above, is hereby revised as follows: 
A.  Section 101.1. Title. Insert: "City of Milan". 
B.  Section 103.5. Fees. Insert: $55 per inspection. 
C.  Section 112.4. Failure to comply. Insert: $105.00 for 1st violation; $160.00 for subsequent violations. 
D.  Section 302.4. Weeds. Insert: To a height of not more than 4" on all premises and exterior property. 
E.  Section 304.14. Insect screens. Insert: "May 1 to October 1". 
F.  Section 602.3. Heat supply. Insert: "October 1 to May 1". 
G.  Section 602.4. Occupiable work spaces. Insert: "October 1 to May 1". 
(Ord. No. 2008-05, §§ 1, 2, 8-11-08; Ord. No. 2011-03, § 1, 6-13-11; Ord. No. 2016-03, § 1, 5-9-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-05, §§ 1, 2, adopted August 11, 2008, repealed section 6-71 in its entirety, which pertained to Basic Property Maintenance Code adoption, and derived from Ord. No. 2004-03, § 1, adopted July 12, 2004. See the code comparative table for a complete list of ordinances. 
Sec. 6-72. - Inspection of rental property for alleged violations; notice to owner to correct violations; reinspection; fees. 
(a)  When the city has been requested to inspect rental property for alleged violations of the Basic Property Maintenance Code, the building official or his duly appointed representative shall make an inspection and note any such violations observed by him, and notify the owner of the premises, or his agent, orally and in writing of the nature thereof with a demand for their correction. 
(b)  Within a reasonable time, which time shall be determined by the nature and seriousness of the violation(s), the building official or his designee shall reinspect the premises to determine whether or not the violation(s) first noted have been corrected. If all of the violation(s) have not been corrected, the owner shall be charged a reinspection fee, which shall be payable forthwith by the owner to the city clerk/treasurer. An additional fee shall be paid to the city clerk/treasurer by the owner for each reinspection thereafter made by the city, including the final inspection, until all the violations have been corrected. The amounts of the fees for the initial reinspection and all subsequent reinspections shall be those specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Charges for all reinspection fees shall be billed by the city clerk/treasurer immediately upon the close of the month during which issued, and shall be due and payable on or before the thirtieth day of the month during which billed. If not paid on or before such date, such charges shall be deemed delinquent and penalty of ten (10) per cent of the amount due shall be added thereto. 
(d)  All charges for reinspection fees not paid shall be a lien on the premises to which they apply, and on April 1st of each year shall be certified by the city clerk/treasurer to the city assessor, who shall enter the same (with penalties) upon the next tax roll against the premises to which such charges applied, and such charges and penalties shall be collected and the lien shall be enforced in the same manner as provided in respect to taxes assessed on the roll. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 79-11, §§ 2-5, 9-24-79; Ord. No. C.O. 82-8, § 14, 8-23-82; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 14, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 6-73. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(b)  The penalties specified in this section shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other remedy that the city may have at law and/or in equity. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 9, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 6-74-6-80. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VII. - FENCE/WALL ORDINANCE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1, adopted April 28, 2003, repealed and reenacted Article VII to read as herein set out. Formerly, Article VII pertained to fences and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 79-4, §§ 1-18, adopted August 13, 1979; Ord. No. C.O. 84-7, § 1, adopted June 11, 1984; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 11, adopted January 23, 1995; Ord. No. 94-5, § 15, adopted May 9, 1994. 
Cross reference- Zoning ordinance, App. A. 

Sec. 6-91. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the "Milan Fence/Wall Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1, 4-28-03) 
Sec. 6-92. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions are related to fences and walls: 
    Fences and walls: Linear structures, partitions or continuous hedgerows maintained for the purpose of enclosing an area. 
(1)  Chain-link fence: A fence constructed of galvanized steel or similar materials as approved by the building official for the purpose of enclosing or securing an area. Chain-link fences shall not include wire fences or fences of similar construction. 
(2)  Industrial fence: A chain-link or ornamental fence of no more than eight (8) feet in height and constructed of materials approved by the building official for the purpose of enclosing or securing an industrial use. 
(3)  Living fence: A continuous hedgerow of living plant material planted and maintained for the purpose of enclosing an area. 
(4)  Ornamental fence: A fence consisting of wrought iron, galvanized steel, aluminum, vinyl, wood or similar materials fabricated into a design with specific pattern elements or ornamentation. All spaces in the fence shall be open and unobstructed and the fence shall not block vision to an extent greater than 50-percent opacity. Opacity is the degree to which a fence is impervious to rays of light. This condition shall be measured by the observation of any two (2) square yard area of fence between one (1) foot above the ground level and the top of the fence. The observation shall be from a direction perpendicular to the place of the fence. Ornamental fences shall not include chain-link or wire fences or fences of similar construction. 
(5)  Privacy fence: A fence constructed of wood, vinyl or similar materials that blocks vision to an extent greater than fifty (50) percent opacity for the purpose of obscuring or screening an area from public view. 
(6)  Rail fence: A fence constructed of wood, vinyl or similar materials and consisting of one (1) to four (4) horizontal rails connecting to vertical posts spaced a minimum of six (6) feet apart. All spaces in such fences shall be open and unobstructed and such fences shall not block vision to an extent greater than forty (40) percent. 
(7)  Temporary fence: A fence constructed of canvas, plastic, chain-link, wood or similar material as approved by the building official for the purpose of enclosing or securing an area. Such fences shall not remain in place for a period greater than six (6) months unless approved by the building official. 
a.  Construction: A fence erected for the purpose of securing a construction site against unauthorized access. The building official may require such fences as part of an approved permit. 
b.  Special events: A fence erected for the purpose of public safety at a special event. Such fences shall not be erected across public rights-of-way except as authorized by the city police department and department of public works for special community events only. 
(8)  Decorative wall: A masonry wall of no more than four (4) feet in height, consisting of brick, stone or similar materials as approved by the building official and constructed with a design that includes specific pattern elements or ornamentation. All spaces in the wall shall be open and unobstructed. 
(9)  Obscuring wall: A masonry wall no more than six (6) feet in height consisting of brick, stone or similar materials as approved by the building official and constructed for the purpose of enclosing, obscuring or screening an area from view. 
(10)  Damaged fence or wall: A fence or wall that is not properly secured, in danger of collapse or has otherwise been found by the building official to be in a damaged condition. 
(11)  Illegal fence or wall: A fence that was illegally erected or installed, or a fence that is not in compliance with the provisions of this article and does not meet the definition of a legal nonconforming fence. 
(12)  Legal nonconforming fence or wall: A fence or wall which was legally erected or installed but is no longer in compliance with the provisions of this article. Such fences or walls must be located outside of any existing right-of-way and wholly upon the parcel to which they are associated. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1, 4-28-03) 
Sec. 6-93. - General requirements for fences and walls. 
(a)  Construction and maintenance. Fences and walls shall be securely constructed in conformance with this article and all applicable building codes and shall consist of durable, weather-resistant materials as approved by the building official. Masonry piers may be used as part of a fence installation with the approval of the building official. Fences and walls shall be maintained in good order, painted, rust proofed or otherwise protected against damage and decay so as to present an orderly appearance. 
(b)  Hazards. Fences and walls shall not be erected in a manner that obstructs free and clear vision or would be a hazard to traffic or pedestrians. Fences and walls shall not be erected within public rights-of-way. 
(c)  Orientation of finished side. Fences that have one finished or decorative side shall be oriented with the finished or decorative side facing outward towards adjacent parcels and away from the interior of the lot to which the fence is associated. Masonry walls shall be finished in a similar manner on all sides. 
(d)  Site drainage and utilities. Fences and walls shall not be erected in a manner that obstructs the free flow of surface water within or across the lot to which it is associated or the adjacent lots. Fences and walls shall not be erected in a manner that causes damage to underground utilities. 
(e)  Position on boundary line. Fences and walls, including, but not limited to posts, foundations and overhanging elements, shall be located completely within the limits of the lot to which they are associated. 
(f)  Height and location requirements.

(1)  All required setbacks for fences and walls shall be measured from the property line or existing street right-of-way line. Height of such fences or walls shall be measured from the grade level to the highest point of the fence or wall. 
(2)  Fences and walls located within required side and rear yards may be erected on the property line with the submission of written consent from all adjacent property owners or a letter from a licensed surveyor to the building official verifying the location of lot boundaries. 
(3)  Fences and walls are not permitted within the required front yard of any zoning lot. 
(4)  In the case of a corner lot, a fence may be permitted in all rear and side yards. Within the side yard that fronts the street, a fence may be permitted if it is beyond 25 feet of the public street right-of-way line and does not project past the front principal building corners. For the purpose of this section the side yard that fronts the street is the yard along the street not designated as the front street in the plat, the address or by the board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1, 4-28-03; Ord. No. 2006-04, § 1, 7-10-06) 
Sec. 6-94. - Prohibited fences and walls. 
    The following fences and walls are prohibited within the city:
