(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 7-14. - Duties of the administrative official. 
    The city directs its construction code act designated enforcing agent, the City of Milan Building Official, to administer, apply, and enforce the floodplain management regulations as contained in the state construction code (including Appendix G) and to be consistent with those regulations by: 
(1)  Obtaining, reviewing, and reasonably utilizing flood elevation data available from federal, state, or other sources pending receipt of data from the FEMA to identify the flood hazard area and areas with potential flooding. 
(2)  Ensuring that all permits necessary for development in floodplain areas have been issued, including a floodplain permit, approval, or letter of no authority from the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality under the floodplain regulatory provisions of Part 31, "Water Resources Protection," of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 PA 451, as amended. 
(3)  Reviewing all permit applications to determine whether the proposed building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding. Where it is determined that a proposed building will be located in a flood hazard area or special flood hazard area, the construction code act enforcing agent shall implement the following applicable codes according to their terms: 
a.  Floodplain management regulation portions and referenced codes and standards of the current Michigan Residential Code. 
b.  Floodplain management regulation portions and referenced codes and standards of the current Michigan Building Code. 
c.  Appendix G of the current Michigan Building Code. 
(4)  Reviewing all proposed subdivisions to determine whether such proposals are reasonably safe from flooding and to ensure compliance with all applicable floodplain management regulations. 
(5)  Assisting in the delineation of flood hazard areas; providing information concerning uses and occupancy of the floodplain or flood-related erosion areas, maintaining floodproofing and lowest floor construction records, cooperating with other officials, agencies, and persons for floodplain management. 
(6)  Advising FEMA of any changes in community boundaries, including appropriate maps. 
(7)  Maintaining records of new structures and substantially improved structures concerning any certificates of floodproofing, lowest floor elevation, basements, and elevations to which structures have been floodproofed. 
(8)  Review, on an ongoing basis, all amended and revised FHBMs and flood insurance rate maps (FIRMs) and related supporting data and revisions thereof and revisions of 44 CFR, Part 60, Criteria for Land Management and Use, and to make such revisions in its floodplain management regulations as may be necessary to continue to participate in the program; and 
(9)  Any other management criteria as may be found in § 60.3 floodplain management criteria for flood-prone areas 44CFR Cha 1 (10-1-07 edition) as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 7-15. - Development in a flood hazard area. 
    Any person, owner or authorized agent who intends to conduct any development in a flood hazard area shall first make application to the building official and shall obtain the required permit. Such application shall: 
(1)  Identify and describe the development to be covered by the permit. 
(2)  Describe the land on which the proposed development is to be conducted by legal description, street address or similar description that will readily identify and definitely locate the site. 
(3)  Include a site plan showing the delineation of the flood hazard areas, floodway boundaries, flood zones, design flood elevations, ground elevation, proposed fill and excavation and drainage pattern and facilities. 
(4)  Indicate the use and occupancy for which the proposed development is intended. 
(5)  Be accompanied by construction documents, grading and filling plans and other information deemed appropriate by the building official. 
(6)  State the valuation of the proposed work. 
(7)  Be signed by the applicant or applicant's authorized agent. 
    The permit shall become invalid if the proposed development is not commenced within one hundred eighty (180) days after it is issued or if work authorized is suspended or abandoned for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 7-16. - Variances. 
    The zoning board of appeals shall hear and decide requests for variances from the requirements of this article consistent with the standards and consideration set forth in Appendix G, Michigan Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Sec. 7-17. - Penalty. 
    A violation of any provision of article II of chapter 7 shall be a municipal civil infraction under Michigan Law unless superseded by FEMA regulations, punishable as provided in section 1-8 of the Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Chapter 8 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations generally, Ch. 6; installation of fire detection systems in dwellings let for occupancy, § 6-4; civil defense and disaster control, Ch. 7; ashes containing hot embers not to be placed in containers for collection, § 9-6; burning garbage prohibited, § 9-13; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 
State Law reference- Fire Prevention Act, M.S.A., § 4.559(1) et seq.; see also § 28.437 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-01. - International Fire Code adopted. 
(a)  Adoption of Fire Prevention Code. That certain document, three copies of which are kept on file in the office of the city clerk of the city, being marked and designated as the International Fire Code, 2012 edition as published by the International Code Council, including Appendix Chapters A, B, C, D, E and G, be and is hereby adopted by reference as the fire prevention code of the city for regulating, governing and safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits for hazardous uses or operations; and each and all other regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of said fire prevention code, on file in the office of the city clerk of the city are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof as if fully set forth in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in sections 8-01(b) and 8-01(c) of this section. 
(b)  Additions, Insertions, Changes and Amendments. The International Fire Code, 2012 edition, as adopted above, is hereby revised as follows: 
Section 101.1. Insert: City of Milan. 
Section 109.4. Insert: misdemeanor, $500, 90 days in the appropriate blanks. 
Section 111.4 Insert: $100, $500 in the appropriate blanks. 
(c)  Geographic Limits. That the geographic limits referred to in sections 5704.2.9.6.1 (geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited), 5706.2.4.4 (geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks is prohibited), 5806.2 (geographic limits in which the storage of flammable cryogenic fluids in stationary containers is prohibited), and 6104.2 (geographic limits in which the storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas) of the 2012 International Fire Code are hereby established as follows: 
    No quantity of such liquids, fluids, or gases, in excess of the exempt amounts listed in the 2012 International Fire Code shall be stored, handled or used except in M-1, M-2 and NR-1 zoned districts in the city with "special land use" designation and approval. 
(d)  Conflict of Laws. 
(1)  In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of the International Fire Code, 2012 edition, as adopted in section 8-01, et seq. and a provision of any local ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation, the local ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation shall control. 
(2)  In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of such code and a provision of any state law, rule or regulation, the state law, rule or regulation shall control. 
(3)  In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of such code and a provision of any other technical code adopted by reference by the city, the stricter or higher standard shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2008-06, §§ 1, 2, 8-21-08; Ord. No. 2011-04, §§ 1, 2, 6-13-11; Ord. No. 2016-04, § 1, 5-9-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-06, §§ 1, 2, adopted August 21, 2008, repealed section 8-01 in its entirety, which pertained to basic fire prevention code adoption, and derived from Ord. No. 2004-03, § 2, adopted July 12, 2004. See the code comparative table for a complete list of ordinances. 
Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this act: 
(a)  Agricultural and wildlife fireworks means fireworks devices distributed to farmers, ranchers, and growers through a wildfire management program administered by the United States Department of the Interior or the department of natural resources of this state. 
(b)  APA standard 87-1 means 2001 APA standard 87-1, standard for construction and approval for transportation of fireworks, novelties, and theatrical pyrotechnics, published by the American Pyrotechnics Association of Bethesda, Maryland. 
(c)  Articles pyrotechnic means pyrotechnic devices for professional use that are similar to consumer fireworks in chemical composition and construction but not intended for consumer use, that meet the weight limits for consumer fireworks but are not labeled as such, and that are classified as UN0432 or UN0432 under 49 CFR 172.101. 
(d)  Consumer fireworks means fireworks devices that are designed to produce visible effects by combustion, that are required to comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations promulgated by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission under 16 CFR parts 1500 and 1507, and that are listed in APA standard 87-1, 3.1.2, 3.1.3, or 3.5. Consumer fireworks do not include low-impact fireworks. 
(e)  Consumer fireworks certificate means a certificate issued under subsection (d). 
(f)  Department means the department of licensing and regulatory affairs. 
(g)  Display fireworks means large fireworks devices that are explosive materials intended for use in fireworks displays and designed to produce visible or audible effects by combustion, deflagration, or detonation. Fireworks consist of consumer fireworks, low-impact fireworks, articles pyrotechnic, display fireworks, and special effects. 
(h)  Firework or fireworks means any composition or device, except for a starting pistol, a flare gun, or a flare, designed for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, deflagration, or detonation. Fireworks consist of consumer fireworks, low-impact fireworks, articles pyrotechnic, display fireworks, and special effects. 
(i)  Low-impact fireworks means ground and handheld sparkling devices as that phrase is defined under APA standard 87-1, 3.1, 3.1.1.1 to 3.1.1.8, and 3.5. 
(j)  Minor means an individual who is less than eighteen (18) years of age. 
(k)  NFPA 1123 means the "Code of Fireworks Display", 2010 edition, developed by NFPA. 
(l)  NFPA 1124 means the "Code for the Manufacture, Transportation, Storage, and Retail Sales of Fireworks and Pyrotechnic Articles", 2006 edition, developed by NFPA. 
(m)  Novelties means that term as defined under APA standard 87-1, 3.2, 3.2.1, 3.2.2, 3.2.3, 3.2.4, and 3.2.5 and all of the following: 
(i)  Toy plastic or paper caps for toy pistols in sheets, strips, rolls, or individual caps containing not more than .25 of a grain of explosive content per cap, in packages labeled to indicate the maximum explosive content per cap. 
(ii)  Toy pistols, toy cannons, toy canes, toy trick noisemakers, and toy guns in which toy caps as described in subparagraph (i) are used, that are constructed so that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion, and that are not designed to break apart or be separated so as to form a missile by the explosion. 
(iii)  Flitter sparklers in paper tubes not exceeding one-eighth-inch in diameter. 
(iv)  Toy snakes not containing mercury, if packed in cardboard boxes with not more than twelve (12) pieces per box for retail sale and if the manufacture's name and quantity contained in each box are printed on the box; and toy smoke devices. 
(n)  Permitted building or structure is a building or structure that is affixed to a foundation on a site that has fixed utility connections and that is intended to remain on the site for more than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive calendar days. 
(o)  Person means an individual, agent, association, charitable organization, company, limited liability company, corporation, labor organization, legal representative, partnership, unincorporated organization, or any other legal or commercial entity. 
(p)  Retailer means a person who sells consumer fireworks or low-impact fireworks for resale to an individual for ultimate use. 
(q)  Retail location means a facility listed under NFPA 1124, 7.1.2. 
(r)  Special effects means a combination of chemical elements or chemical compounds capable of burning independently of the oxygen of the atmosphere and designed and intended to produce an audible, visual, mechanical, or thermal effect as an integral part of a motion picture, radio, television, theatrical, or opera production or live entertainment. 
(s)  State fire marshal means the state fire marshal appointed under section 1b of the Fire Prevention Code, 1941 PA 207, MCL 29.1b. 
(t)  Warehouse means a permanent building or structure used primarily for the storage of consumer fireworks or low-impact fireworks. 
(u)  Wholesaler means any person who sells consumer fireworks or low-impact fireworks to a retailer or any other person for resale. Wholesaler does not include a person who sells only display fireworks or special effects. 
(Ord. No. 2012-04, § 1, 7-9-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-04, § 1, adopted July 9, 2012, repealed the former § 8-1, and enacted a new § 8-1 as set out herein. The former § 8-1 pertained to fireworks-sale or gift prohibited; exception; permit and derived from an ordinance adopted May 11, 1923; and Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 18, adopted May 9 1994. 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12. 
State Law reference- Sale of fireworks prohibited, M.S.A., § 28.440(1); authority of council to grant permits for use of fireworks for public display, § 28.440(2). 
Sec. 8-2. - Sale and use of fireworks. 
(1)  [Sale of consumer fireworks.] A person shall not sell consumer fireworks in the city unless the person annually obtains a consumer fireworks certificate from the Department of Licensing and Regulation of the State of Michigan under Section 4 of Act 256 of PA 2012 (MCL 28.454). 
(a)  No person shall sell any consumer fireworks to a minor. 
(b)  Sale of consumer fireworks from retail location. 
    Consumer fireworks shall only be sold from a retail location meeting the requirements Section 5 of Act 256 of PA 2012 (MCL 28.455) and the building, fire and zoning codes of the City of Milan (AG Opinion 7266 of 2012). 
(2)  Sale of low impact fireworks. A person shall not sell low impact fireworks unless he or she has registered with the low impact fireworks retail registry not less than ten (10) days before selling the fireworks in each calendar year pursuant to section 6 of Act 256 of PA 2012 (MCL 28.456). 
(3)  Sale and use of permitted fireworks. Novelties, consisting of snappers, drop pops, snakes, party poppers, smoke balls and sparkling devices and any other device defined under APA standard 87-1, 3.2, 3.2.1,3.2.2, 3.2.3, 3.2.4 and 3.2.5 as amended may be sold, stored, displayed for sale, transported, used or distributed without regulation. 
(4)  Ignition, discharge and use of consumer fireworks. It shall be unlawful for any person to ignite, discharge and use consumer fireworks at any time from any location in the City of Milan except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 1:00 a.m. on the day preceding, the day of, or the day after a national holiday. 
(5)  Articles pyrotechnic or display fireworks ignition; permit; competency and qualifications of operators; retention fee. 
(a)  The city council, upon application in writing, on forms provided by the State of Michigan and payment of a fee set from time to time by the legislative body, if any, may grant a permit for the use of agricultural or wildfire fireworks, articles pyrotechnic, display fireworks, or special effects manufactured for outdoor pest control or agricultural purposes, or for public or private display within the city by municipalities, fair associations, amusement parks, or other organizations or individuals approved by the city council, if the applicable provisions of this act are complied with. 
(b)  Before a permit for articles pyrotechnic or a display fireworks ignition is issued, the person, firm, or corporation applying for the permit shall furnish proof of financial responsibility by a bond or insurance in an amount, character, and form deemed necessary by the local governing authority to satisfy claims for damages to property or personal injuries arising out of an act or omission on the part of the person, firm, or corporation or an agent or employee of the person, firm, or corporation, and to protect the public. 
(c)  A permit shall not be issued under this act to a nonresident person, firm, or corporation for ignition of articles pyrotechnic or display fireworks in this state until the person, firm, or corporation has appointed in writing a resident member of the bar of this state or a resident agent to be the legal representative upon whom all process in an action or proceeding against the person, firm, or corporation may be served. 
(d)  The city council shall rule on the competency and qualifications of articles pyrotechnic and display fireworks operators as required under NFPA 1123, as the operator has furnished in his or her application form, and on the time, place and safety aspects of the display of articles pyrotechnic or display fireworks before granting permits. 
(Ord. No. 2012-04, § 1, 7-9-12; Ord. No. 2013-02, § 1, 6-24-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-04, § 1, adopted July 9, 2012, repealed the former § 8-2, and enacted a new § 8-2 as set out herein. The former § 8-2 pertained to fireworks-discharge prohibited; exception; permit and derived from an ordinance adopted May 11, 1923; and Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 18, adopted May 9, 1994. 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12. 
State Law reference- Discharge of fireworks prohibited, M.S.A., § 28.440(1); authority of council to grant permits for use of fireworks for public display, § 28.440(2). 
Sec. 8-3. - Bystanders to assist in extinguishing fires, etc. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of all persons who are bystanders at any fire occurring in the city whenever required, ordered or directed by the chief of the fire department or by any member of the council, to assist in the extinguishing of any such fire and in the removal, preservation and protection of any property endangered hereby. 
(b)  Every person who, at any such fire, shall without sufficient excuse wilfully neglect or refuse to comply with any such requirement, order or direction shall for each such neglect or refusal be deemed to have violated this section. 
(Ord. of 4-20-1899, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 8-4. - Injuring, etc., city fire ladders. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to molest, injure or interfere with the fire ladders belonging to the city, or to remove them or any of them from the place where the same may be kept by the city or by the proper authorities thereof, except in case of fire. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1897, § 1) 
Sec. 8-5. - Use of buildings for public assemblages; certificate; permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is the owner of or has control of any hall, theater, opera house or building of any kind, to use or permit the same to be used for public assemblages of people unless such person shall have first obtained, from the authorities designated by the applicable state statute(s), a certificate in writing certifying that they have examined the hall, theater, opera house or other building as the case may be, and the same is well and sufficiently constructed in accordance with the regulations of the state fire marshal, and further that such building shall in all respects conform to sections 18.441 through 18.461 of Michigan Statutes Annotated and amendments thereto. All of the provisions of such state statutes are hereby adopted by the city by reference and made a part of this article. 
(b)  Any owner, occupant, lessee, manager, person or officer in charge of or having the management or control of any hall, theater, opera house or building within the city limits, shall make application in writing to the clerk/treasurer for a permit to operate such hall, theater, opera house or building that is used or to be used for public assemblages of persons. Accompanying such application shall be a certificate from the authorities designated in subsection (a) and the state fire marshal as to whether or not the hall, theater, opera house or building for which the application is made conforms with the provisions of the state statutes above referred to. At the time of submission of such application and certificate, the applicant shall also pay to the city a permit fee in the amount specified for such permits in the official fee schedule adopted by the resolution of the Milan City Council. Every such permit shall expire on the first June 30 following its issuance, and any renewal thereof shall require reapplication and the payment of a new permit fee as herein provided. Application for the renewal of any such permit, together with the permit fee provided for herein, shall be filed not less than ninety (90) days prior to the expiration of the existing permit. 
(c)  The clerk/treasurer shall present all applications made under this section to the city council for its consideration. The city council shall grant the permit applied for in each such application if the applicant has conformed in all respects with the provisions of the state statues referenced in subsection (a) hereof and with all of the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. of 5-12-39, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 19, 5-9-94) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; licenses, Ch. 12. 
Secs. 8-6-8-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 8-16. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "department" shall mean the Milan Volunteer Fire Department. 
Sec. 8-17. - Composition; qualifications of members. 
    The fire department of the city shall consist of one (1) chief, one (1) assistant chief and sufficient volunteer firemen who are citizens and residents of the city. No one under twenty-one (21) years of age shall be qualified to serve. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-18. - Appointment of members. 
    All appointments to membership in the fire department of the city shall be submitted by the fire department to the council, subject to the bylaws of the fire department. All appointments to membership shall be first approved by the council. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-19. - Election of chief and assistant chief; term; qualifications. 
    The chief and assistant chief of the fire department of the city shall be elected by the department and approve by the council for a term of one (1) year. The chief and assistant chief are to be chosen from the department and must have been a member of the department for at least five (5) years. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-20. - Compensation of chief, assistant chief and members. 
    Remuneration for the services of the chief, the assistant chief and the members of the fire department of the city shall be established by the council each year at the time of the appointment of the chief and the assistant chief. In no case shall any fireman be paid any sum for services who does not respond to a fire call. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-21. - Chief to have general supervision of department. 
    The chief of the fire department of the city shall have general supervision of the department, which supervision shall be subject to and not conflict with such rules and bylaws for the government and management of the department as may from time to time be adopted by the department. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Charter reference- General powers and duties of fire chief, § 4.17. 
Sec. 8-22. - Authority of chief to suspend or discharge members. 
    Any member of the fire department of the city may be suspended or discharged from the department by the chief at any time he may deem such action necessary for the good of the department. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-23. - Members subject to removal by council. 
    Every member of the fire department of the city shall be subject to removal at the pleasure of the council. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-24. - Members subject to rules and regulations of council. 
    Every member of the fire department of the city shall be subject to all rules and regulations prescribed by the council. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-25. - Members required to adopt code of bylaws and rules. 
    Members of the fire department of the city are hereby authorized, empowered and required from time to time to adopt a code of bylaws and rules for the control, management and government of the department. Such code of bylaws and rules, after adoption by the department, shall not become effective until presented to and approved by the council. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-26. - Chief and assistant chief required to inspect buildings and premises; right of entry. 
    The chief and assistant chief of the fire department of the city are hereby authorized, empowered and required to inspect from time to time, but at least twice annually, all buildings and premises in the city where accumulations of combustible materials and other hazardous conditions are liable to exist and make a report of conditions of all buildings in the business section of the city to the city council. For the purpose of inspection they are hereby empowered to enter any and all buildings and premises in the city at any reasonable hour. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
State Law reference- Inspection of buildings and premises to discover fire hazards, M.S.A., § 4.559(8). 
Sec. 8-27. - Chief and assistant chief required to keep records. 
    The chief and assistant chief of the fire department of the city are required to devise forms or methods of keeping records and shall see that records are kept of all fires, fire losses, method of extinguishment, drills, hose apparatus, minor equipment and condition of hydrants, the same to be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-28. - Authority of chief and assistant chief to call other fire departments for assistance. 
    The chief and/or assistant chief of the fire department of the city, either or both, are given the authority to call other fire departments in the event that he or they think it necessary to preserve property and/or life. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-29. - Chief to be in charge at scene of fire. 
(a)  In all cases of fire, the chief of the fire department of the city, or in his absence, the assistant chief, shall have full power and absolute control and command, and shall cause the several pieces of apparatus to be worked in the most advantageous manner. 
(b)  Should the chief and assistant chief be absent from a fire, a member having charge of the apparatus first arriving at the fire shall assume the duties of the chief until the arrival of his superior officer. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-30. - Person in charge at scene of fire given police authority; removal of obstructions to fire hydrants. 
    The chief and the assistant chief of the fire department of the city or officers in command at any fire are hereby vested with full and complete police authority and are hereby authorized and directed to require and secure the removal of any and all obstructions from in front of and around fire hydrants. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-31. - Right-of-way of fire vehicles. 
    The speed limitation and stop street ordinances of the city shall not apply to vehicles when operated with due regard to safety under the direction of a volunteer fireman while on a fire run, nor to fire patrol vehicles when traveling in response to a fire alarm. This exemption shall not, however, protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequences of reckless disregard of the safety of others. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 21. 
Sec. 8-32. - Duty of chief to insure fire apparatus in good working order, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department of the city to see that the fire apparatus of the department is at all times in place and in good working order and to order the same kept in as good condition as it should be; and when the expense of making necessary repairs shall be less than fifty dollars ($50.00) the chief shall authorize such repair completed and when such bills are presented, if correct and just, to recommend the same to the city council for payment. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-33. - Authority of council to contract with surrounding townships to provide fire protection service. 
    The city council is hereby authorized to enter into contract agreements with surrounding townships to provide such townships with fire protection service. Such contracts are to set forth the method by which the cost of operating the fire department is to be shared and the payment to personnel necessary to operate the fire equipment. Such contracts or agreements shall be worded so as to relieve the city of any and all liability. The city shall under no circumstance be held responsible for failure of fire department men or equipment to arrive at the scene of a fire in time to avoid or reduce loss. The city shall under no circumstance be held responsible for failure of equipment to operate when called to a rural fire. The city shall under no circumstance be held responsible for any portion of loss suffered at any fire to which the fire department is called outside the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-34. - Response to fires within surrounding townships, villages and cities. 
    Fire occurring within the surrounding townships, villages and cities shall be responded to in the same manner as fires within the city; provided, duly signed and approved contracts with these communities are in effect and, provided, such response will incur no loss or hazard to property or life within the city due to the absence of fire department equipment or fire department personnel therefrom. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Sec. 8-35. - Duty of chief to submit reports of fires. 
    Within one (1) month after each fire, either within the city or the townships, the chief of the fire department shall report to the city clerk the occurrence of such fire. The report shall include the time and location of the fire, the name and address of the owner of the property involved, the number and names of the firemen attending the fire and the time spent by each man, the amount of loss and the name of the insurance company and any other facts pertinent to the event. In the case of a township fire, the city clerk shall then render a bill for services based on the terms of the contract then in force. 
(Ord. of 8-24-59) 
Chapter 9 - GARBAGE, RUBBISH, REFUSE AND RECYCLING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. C.O. 94-1, adopted February 14, 1994, repealed Ch. 9, Arts. I, II, §§ 9-1-9-22, 9-31-9-40 in its entirety and added a new Ch. 9 to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 9 pertained to garbage, trash and refuse and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 86-6, § 1, adopted November 24, 1986; Ord. No. 89-4, § 1, adopted August 28, 1989 and Ord. No. 90-8, § 1, adopted October 22, 1990. 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 5; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; depositing refuse in bodies of water or streams, § 10-2(a); litter, § 13-51 et seq.; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; rubbish obstructing sidewalks, § 18-2; trees and shrubs, Ch. 22; water and sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference- Power of city to establish and maintain garbage system for collection and disposal of garbage and to levy annual garbage tax, M.S.A., § 5.2681; Garbage Disposal Act, § 5.2726(1) et seq.; littering, § 28.603(1). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Definitions 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
(a)  Administrator means the city administrator of the city. 
(b)  Apartment or condominium complex means one (1) or more buildings, each of which is comprised of five (5) or more dwellings units, each of which dwelling units is occupied by, or designed for occupancy by, a separate family or household. 
(c)  Bags means plastic sacks designed to store refuse with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by top. Total weight of a bag and its contents shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. 
(d)  Bulky waste means refrigerators, freezers and air-conditioners (from which freon has been removed prior to the owner's placement of same for collection by contractor), water tanks, washing machines, dryers, stoves, furniture, tires, automobile parts not exceeding four (4) feet in length or fifty (50) pounds in weight, and other waste materials other than construction debris. 
(e)  Bundle means tree, shrub and brush trimmings securely tied together forming an easily handled package not exceeding four (4) feet in length or fifty (50) pounds in weight. 
(f)  City means the City of Milan, Michigan. The phrase "within the city" shall be interpreted as meaning "anywhere within the corporate limits of the city." 
(g)  Commercial unit means a dwelling, including an apartment or condominium complex, that is not included in the definition of residential unit due to the number of dwelling units contained therein and any other building, including, without limitation, stores, offices and factories, that are occupied by producers of commercial refuse that is stored for collection in nonportable containers. 
(h)  Commingled material means a mixture of types of recyclables separated from other solid waste but requiring further processing after collection by the city or a contractor. 
(i)  Construction debris means waste building materials resulting from residential construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations and which are included within any applicable household hazardous-waste exceptions set forth in P.A. 1979, No. 64, or in the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. 6901, et seq. No concrete, asbestos, asphalt shingles, or hazardous waste (as defined in this chapter) shall be eligible for collection as construction debris. Construction debris eligible for collection shall be limited to not more than three (3) portable containers, each not exceeding fifty (50) pounds in weight, and on an occasional basis only. 
(j)  Container means either a portable container, a nonportable container, or a recyclables container (as defined in this chapter), as the case may be, but excluding ferrous metal containers, glass containers, and plastic containers, as defined in this chapter. All containers other than bags shall be of a type easily washable. 
(1)  Portable container means a receptacle with a capacity of greater than twenty (20) gallons but not more than thirty-five (35) gallons constructed of plastic, metal or fiberglass, having handles of adequate strength for lifting and having tightfitting lids capable of preventing entrance into the container by vermin. The mouth of the container shall have a diameter greater than or equal to that of the base. The weight of a container and its contents shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds except for purposes of section 9-33 of this chapter, concerning separation and storage of soft yard waste, portable containers shall be deemed to include bags, as defined in this section. 
(2)  Nonportable containers means any container with capacity greater than thirty (35) gallons fixed with devices permitting mechanical lifting and dumping. 
(3)  Recyclables containers means plastic bins or other containers furnished, with or without cost, by the city or a contractor and specifically designated by the city as being approved for the storage of recyclables other than soft yard waste. 
(k)  Contractor or contracted agent means the person, corporation or partnership authorized by the city to collect, process, market, and/or dispose of solid waste and recyclables within the corporate limits of the city. 
(l)  Curbside recyclables collection means the collection of recyclables at the point of generation by the city or a contractor on a regularly scheduled weekly basis. 
(m)  Dead animals means animals weighing ten (10) pounds or less that have expired from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human use or consumption. 
(n)  Disposal site means a refuse depository including but not limited to sanitary landfills, transfer stations, incinerators, and waste processing/separation centers licensed, permitted or approved by all governmental bodies and agencies having jurisdiction thereover and requiring such licenses, permits or approvals to receive disposal. 
(o)  Ferrous metal container means those nonaluminum food containers which are attracted to a magnet, commonly referred to as tin cans. 
(p)  Garbage means dead animals and every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable and/or other matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing, handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains or other animal or vegetable matter including, but not by way of limitation, all putrescible or easily decomposable animal or vegetable waste matter which is likely to attract flies or rodents, except (in all cases) any matter included in the definitions of bulky waste, construction debris, hazardous waste or rubbish specified in this section. 
(q)  Glass container means all containers made from silica or sand, soda ash and limestone, the product being transparent or translucent and being used for packaging or bottling of various matter, and all other material commonly known as glass, excluding, however, blue glass, flat glass, plate glass and glass commonly known as window glass. 
(r)  Hard yard waste means wood-compostable material such as branches and other nonleafy parts of trees. 
(s)  Hazardous waste means waste, in any amount, which is defined, characterized or designated as hazardous by the United States Environmental Protection Agency, Michigan Department of Natural Resources or other appropriate state agency by or pursuant to federal or state statute or regulation, and any waste, in any amount, which is regulated under federal or state law. For purposes of this chapter, the term hazardous waste shall also include motor oil, gasoline, paint and paint cans, but shall not include latex paint cans containing only latex paint that has fully dried. 
(t)  Plastic containers means high-density polyethylene (HDPE) containers often known as Recycling Type 2 containers and polyethylene terephthalate (PETE) containers often known as Recycling Type 1 containers, except any plastic motor oil container, regardless of whether it is marked with a number 2 in a triangle or a number 1 in a triangle. For example: water, cider and milk jugs with a number 2 in a triangle imprinted thereon and laundry detergent bottles with a number 1 in a triangle imprinted thereon. 
(u)  Premises means land, water, buildings or other structures, vehicles, watercraft or part thereof upon or in which refuse is stored. 
(v)  Producer means an occupant of a residential unit or commercial unit who generates refuse or recyclables. 
(w)  Recyclables means materials suitable for recycling as determined by the director of public works, provided that in all cases, such materials shall include at least the following: newsprint, ferrous metal containers, glass, numbers 1 and 2 plastic containers, aluminum, corrugated cardboard, glossy paper (including magazines) and soft yard waste. 
(x)  Refuse means all garbage, rubbish, bulky waste and dead animals (as defined in this chapter) but not including body wastes of a type acceptable for discharge into the city's sanitary sewer system. 
(1)  Residential refuse means all rubbish generated by a producer at a residential unit. 
(2)  Commercial refuse means all rubbish generated by a producer at a commercial unit. 
(y)  Residential unit means a dwelling within the corporate limits of the city occupied by a person or group of persons comprising not more than four (4) families. A residential unit shall be deemed occupied when either water or domestic light and power services are being supplied thereto. A condominium dwelling, whether of single- or multi-level construction, consisting of four (4) or less contiguous or separate single-family dwelling units shall be treated as a residential unit except that each single-family dwelling within any such condominium dwelling shall be deemed to be and billed as a separate residential unit. 
(z)  Rubbish means all waste wood, wood products, tree trimmings, dead trees or branches thereof, soft yard waste, hard yard waste, chips, shavings, sawdust, printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and discarded mattresses, used and discarded clothing, used and discarded shoes and boots, combustible waste pulp and other products such as are used for packaging or wrapping, crockery and glass, ashes, cinders, floor sweeping, mineral or metallic substances, and any and all other waste materials not included in the definitions of bulky waste, construction debris, dead animals, garbage or hazardous waste. 
(aa)  Soft yard waste means grass, leaves, yard and garden trimmings and waste, and other nonwoody vegetation. 
(bb)  Solid waste means all residential refuse acceptable for curbside disposal and collection under Sections 9-14 and 9-15 of this chapter and all recyclables. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-2. - Collection and disposal generally. 
(a)  The city council shall control the storage, collection and disposal of refuse within the city and shall provide, directly or by contract, a public refuse collection and refuse disposal service for premises within the city. The city council shall make such administrative rules and regulations consistent with the terms of this chapter which shall be necessary to carry out the authority herein granted. 
(b)  Collection of refuse shall be made from residential units and commercial units in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted by the city council. 
(c)  All disposal of refuse shall be by a method in accordance with the requirements of the state and shall include the maximum practicable rodent, insect and nuisance control at the place of disposal. 
(d)  Any producer or person who generates or is otherwise responsible for (1) refuse on any premises not serviced by the refuse-collection system of the city or for (2) refuse not acceptable for collection by the city, shall make arrangements for the collection and disposal of such refuse but shall otherwise comply in all respects with the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-3. - City authorized to purchase equipment and maintain or contract for disposal system; collection of charges; payment; delinquency penalty; lien on property. 
(a)  The city council is authorized to make funds available by appropriation or by other means in accordance with the applicable laws of the State of Michigan and the procedures of the city for the purchase of equipment and the maintenance and operation of a refuse and recyclables-collection and disposal system and/or contract. 
(b)  Refuse collection and disposal services shall be charged to each recipient of those services, and shall also be charged to all residential and commercial units that are eligible to receive those services, through the persons and entities owning them, regardless of whether the collection and disposal services are used or are not used by such units. The minimum rates to be charged each quarter shall be those specified in the City of Milan Official Fee Schedule. The fee schedule shall specify rates for single-family residential units; for each unit of multifamily residential units and commercial-unit dwellings; and for residential commercial units utilizing nonportable containers. 
(c)  Residential units and commercial units which choose not to dispose of refuse through the city's collection system shall still be charged the minimum residential or commercial quarterly rate, whichever is applicable, this being the standby rate for having collection and disposal service available to the units. 
(d)  The charges for the collection and disposal of refuse and recyclables shall be included with the city's water billings. Billings shall be made quarterly at the rate specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council. All bills shall become due and payable on or before the twentieth day of the month following the billing date. A penalty of ten (10) percent of the amount of each unpaid bill shall be added after the twentieth day of the month following the billing date. 
(e)  Any penalties imposed for late charges in relation to city water bills shall also be imposed upon the fees specified in this chapter. 
(f)  Subject to the provisions of subsection 24-63(a) of this Code, charges for services furnished by the system shall be a lien thereon, and on May thirtieth and October thirty-first of each year the person or agency charged with the management of such system shall certify any such charges which have been delinquent for three (3) months or more to the city assessor, who shall enter the same (with penalties) upon the next tax roll against the premises to which such services shall have been rendered, and said charges and penalties shall be connected and said lien shall be enforced in the same manner as provided in respect to taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(g)  The city council reserves the right to enter into or discontinue special contracts for the collection, disposal and regulation of any and all refuse and recyclables in the city and to levy special rates to cover the costs of such collection, disposal, and regulation. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-8, § 1, 1-22-96; Ord. No. 99-4, § 1, 8-23-99) 
Sec. 9-4. - Containers-Required; exception. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to permit refuse, except bulky waste, to accumulate or be stored on any premises except in portable or nonportable containers meeting the specifications included in the definitions contained in section 9-1 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 13, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-5. - Same-To be set out within required times. 
    In all areas receiving curbside collection service, all solid waste, recyclables, and their containers shall be set out for collection on the curb line, or between the sidewalk and the curb, not earlier than 6:00 p.m. on the day before the scheduled pickup and not later than 7:00 a.m. on the day of the scheduled pickup. Solid waste or recyclables set out for collection later than 7:00 a.m. on the day of the scheduled pickup may not be collected. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-6. - Same-Ashes containing hot embers prohibited. 
    Ashes containing hot embers shall not be placed in containers for collection. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-7. - Same-To be removed after having been emptied. 
    In all areas where solid-waste or recyclables containers are set out on the curb line or between the sidewalk and the curb, such containers shall be removed by the occupant of the premises by no later than 9:00 a.m. of the day after the day of the scheduled pickup. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-8. - Owner and occupant responsible for sanitary condition of premises and for costs of enforcement and corrective action. 
    Both the title-holder of record and the occupant(s) of any premises within the city shall be responsible for the sanitary condition of the premises owned and/or occupied by him or her, and for the costs of all enforcement measures and corrective actions engaged in by or on behalf of the city as the result of any violation of this chapter; and it shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to place, deposit or allow to be placed or deposited on premises owned or occupied by him/her any refuse except as designated by the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 13, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-9. - Keeping refuse, etc., which may be injurious to public health on premises. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to keep in, on or about the premises owned or occupied by him/her any refuse or any other substance which may be injurious to the public health unless it is kept in a closed, covered container as required by the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 13, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-10. - Unlawful deposits. 
(a)  It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to throw or deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited any refuse upon any private property, street, alley, gutter, sidewalk or public grounds within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to import any refuse into the city for the purpose of including, placing or causing it to be included or placed for collection by the city or the city's contractor, or to include, place or cause any such imported refuse to be included or placed for collection by the city or the city's contractor, without first obtaining the written permission of the city to do so. The city council shall approve or disapprove all requests for such importation and inclusion of refuse for collection by the city or its contractor, and such decision shall be communicated to the requesting party by the administrator or the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 13, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-11. - Deposit on premises of another prohibited. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to deposit, throw or leave any refuse on the premises of any other person in the city. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 13, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-12. - Burying refuse prohibited. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to bury refuse anywhere within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 13, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-13. - Burning refuse prohibited. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to burn refuse in or on public or private property within the corporate limits of the city; provided, however, that nothing in this chapter shall preclude the otherwise lawful burning of wood in fireplaces, wood stoves or cooking grills. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 13, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-14. - Refuse acceptable for collection. 
    The following refuse shall be considered to be acceptable for collection: 
(1)  Garbage. As defined in section 9-1(p) of this chapter. 
(2)  Ashes. The cold residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible materials. 
(3)  Rubbish. As defined in section 9-1(z) of this chapter, excluding soft yard waste and hard yard waste. 
(4)  Dead animals. As defined in section 9-1(m) of this chapter. 
(5)  Bulky waste. As defined in section 9-1(d) of this chapter. 
(6)  Construction debris. As defined in section 9-1(i) of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-15. - Refuse not acceptable for collection; prohibition. 
(a)  The following refuse shall be considered not acceptable for collection: 
(1)  Hazardous waste and all dangerous material or substances such as poisons, acids, caustics, infected materials, toxic chemicals and known carcinogens. 
(2)  Unusual quantities of materials resulting from the razing, repair, excavation or construction of buildings or structures such as earth, plaster, mortar, roofing materials and lumber including all construction-type materials which exceed the volume and weight limits specified in section 9-1(i) of this chapter. 
(3)  Materials which have not been prepared for collection in accordance with this chapter or regulations promulgated pursuant thereto. 
(4)  All other materials that are not included within the categories specified in section 9-14 of this chapter. 
(b)  No person shall include, place or cause to be included or placed for collection alone or with other refuse, any refuse declared by this section to be not acceptable for collection. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-16. - Preparation and placement of garbage, refuse and recyclables for collection. 
(a)  Garbage shall be drained and wrapped prior to being stored in containers for collection. 
(b)  Refuse and recyclables shall be placed at and collected from such place on the premises as may be prescribed in the rules governing collections established by the city council. 
(c)  Animal waste from domestic pets, including cat litter material, shall be placed in a sealed plastic bag prior to placement into approved containers. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-17. - Preparation of bulky rubbish and recyclables for collection. 
    Bulky rubbish and bulky recyclables, such as trees, limbs, newspapers and large cardboard boxes, shall be placed into bundles so as not to exceed four (4) feet in length nor fifty (50) pounds in weight; and all such bundles shall be securely tied. Placement shall be in accordance with the provisions of section 9-33 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-18. - Schedule for collection. 
    The city council, or the director of public works, shall arrange a schedule for the collection of refuse and recyclables and shall give public notice of the schedule together with all changes and corrections which may from time to time be made to such schedule. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-19. - Vehicles used for collection and disposal. 
(a)  All vehicles used for the collection or disposal of refuse shall have enclosed bodies or suitable provision for covering the body. Provision and use of a tarpaulin or canvas cover to enclose open bodies of collection vehicles may be permitted when specifically approved by the city council. 
(b)  Vehicles used for the collection or disposal of garbage, or of refuse containing garbage, shall have water-tight bodies of easily cleanable construction, shall be cleaned at sufficient frequency to prevent nuisance or insect breeding, and shall be maintained in good repair. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-20. - Conveying garbage, etc., through streets. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any resident or nonresident to convey through the public streets of the city any garbage, refuse or decaying vegetable matter unless such person is authorized by the city council and unless the same if [is] carried in closed covered containers; provide, however, that this section shall not preclude the otherwise lawful transportation of yard waste to composting sites approved by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 13, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-21. - License to conduct a garbage and refuse collection business. 
    A license shall be issued on a yearly basis upon payment of a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) or such other amount as may be specified in the fee schedule ordinance adopted by the city council for the privilege of conducting a garbage and refuse collection business within the city limits. Such licensee shall be subject to frequent inspections by officials or appointed representatives of the city council as to cleanliness, regularity of pickups, compensation for such services, whether by the city or otherwise, and general conduct in the matter of conducting such business. Compensation for such services shall be established annually by resolution of the city council. Civil fines shall be established, thereby regulating and controlling the conduct of the licensee in the pursuance of its services. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 13, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-22. - Inspection and investigation to enforce chapter. 
    The city council shall have power to provide for the inspection and investigation of conditions relating to the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Secs. 9-23-9-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MANDATORY RECYCLING 

Sec. 9-31. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to achieve economic and ecological efficiency by requiring the residents of the city receiving curbside solid waste collection to recycle certain household solid- waste products. It is intended that this mandatory recycling will promote the general health and welfare of the residents of the city by reducing the level of solid waste requiring disposal, preserving natural resources and by extending the life of and reducing the need for additional disposal facilities. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-32. - Definitions. 
    The definitions specified in section 9-1 of this chapter shall also apply to this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-33. - Procedure. 
(a)  Separation of recyclables and placement for removal from residential households and commercial unit dwellings. 
(1)  All persons residing in residential units and in commercial unit dwellings shall separate recyclables from all other solids waste produced by such unit's occupants. Such recyclables, except soft and hard yard wastes and bundled cardboard, shall be placed commingled in an approved recyclables container and placed at curbside for collection on the same day as the other solid waste is collected. Such placement shall be made within the time periods specified in section 9-5 of this chapter. 
(2)  All persons residing in residential units and in commercial unit dwellings shall separate soft and hard yard wastes from all other solid waste generated by the unit's occupants. Soft yard waste shall be further separated from hard yard waste. Soft yard waste shall be placed in either biodegradable, brown kraft paper bags designed for compostable materials and so marked, or portable containers labeled with stickers approved by the city. Such stickers shall be obtained from the city. 
(3)  Violations of this section 9-33 shall result in penalties being assessed as provided in section 9-40 of this chapter. 
(b)  Preparation of recyclables. Glass, plastic and metal recyclables shall be clean and all contents shall be removed therefrom prior to placement at curbside for collection. Nonmetal caps shall be removed from glass recyclables; all caps shall be removed from plastic recyclables; and labels shall be removed from metal recyclables prior to collection. Magazines shall be bundled and placed inside of a recyclables container. Cardboard shall be bundled and placed beside the recyclables container. Ferrous metal containers and plastic containers should be flattened prior to their placement in the recyclables container for collection. The city council may specify further preparation requirements as may be required to permit processing of recyclables provided that written notice of additional requirements shall be publicized prior to their implementation. 
(c)  Recyclables bins. 
(1)  Upon request by the property owner, one recyclables bin will be furnished by the city for each newly constructed house and each newly constructed apartment dwelling unit, at no charge to the property owner. 
(2)  Upon request by the property owner, one recyclables bin will be furnished by the city for each commercial unit wishing to participate in the city's recycling program, at no charge to the property owner. 
(3)  All recyclables bins furnished by the city shall remain the property of the city, and shall remain at the premises for which they were issued. Persons vacating the premises for which a bin was issued by the city shall cause the bin to remain at the vacated premises. The owner of the premises, both owner-occupied and rental premises, shall be responsible for ensuring that all recyclables bins issued for the premises remain at such premises. 
(4)  Each property owner to whom a recyclables bin is issued shall replace such bin in the event that it is lost or stolen, and shall be responsible for the cost of such replacement. 
(5)  Additional recyclables bins beyond those specified in subsections (c)(1) and (c)(2) of this section, including replacements for lost and stolen bins, shall be obtained from the city upon payment of a fee, which shall be based upon the city's cost of such bins at that time; provided, however, that persons who, upon moving into an existing house or rental unit, discover that the recyclables bin previously issued for those premises has been removed in violation of subsection (c)(3) of this section will, upon request, be issued one (1) replacement bin at the city's expense. Nothing in this subsection shall limit the city's rights under subsections (c)(3) or (c)(4) of this section. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 94-8, § 1, 1-9-95) 
Sec. 9-34. - Exceptions and variances. 
(a)  If a resident of a residential unit is physically incapable of placing recyclables at curbside and no other resident of the same household is capable of carrying out such obligation, special arrangements shall be made by the city or its contracted agent to have collection personnel collect recyclables from the rear or side of the residential structure. 
(b)  In cases of extreme hardship or practical difficulties, the director of public works may, upon receipt of a written request, authorize variances to this chapter's requirements regarding separation, points of collection and collection frequency. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-35. - Authorized collectors. 
(a)  No person except those individuals, partnerships and corporations authorized by the City shall collect or pick up or cause to be collected or picked up recyclables which have been placed for collection at curbside or in a designated nonportable container. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall result in penalties being assessed as provided in section 9-40 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-36. - Right of generator or producer to sell or donate recyclables. 
    Any person, partnership or corporation generating recyclables may sell or donate them to any person, partnership or corporation, whether for profit or not-for-profit. The buyer or recipient of such material, if not the authorized collection agent of the city, shall not under any circumstances pick up recyclables from the curbside or any other collection point in the city. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-37. - Responsibilities of contracted agent. 
(a)  The contracted agent shall be responsible for the weekly curbside collection of recyclables placed for collection in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. Such collection of recyclables shall occur on the same day that other solid waste is collected. The contracted agent shall not collect solid waste from a residential unit or a commercial unit dwelling if a portable container (other than a recyclables container) at the premises is found to contain recyclables or if recyclables at the premises are otherwise not in compliance with this chapter. The contracted agent shall promptly report all such instances of mixed recyclables and other solid waste and all instances of other noncompliance with this chapter to the director of public works. 
(b)  The contracted agent or its designee shall provide for the further separation of the commingled recyclables and for their sale. The proceeds from any sale of collected recyclables shall be divided between the city and its contracted agent as determined by the terms of the authorizing contract. 
(c)  At least every six (6) months, the contracted agent shall furnish the director of public works with reports separately listing the tonnages of (i) recyclables, (ii) soft yard waste, (iii) hard yard waste and (iv) all other solid waste combined, that were collected and processed by the contracted agent during the preceding six-month period. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-38. - City revenues. 
    Revenues received by the city from the sale of recyclables shall be used to establish and fund a separate fund category to be known as the environmental fund. Monies in this fund shall be used solely for: 
(1)  Preserving, protecting and improving the physical environment of the city including its soil, air and waters, both surface and subsurface; and 
(2)  Education of the citizens of the city concerning environmental issues, including recycling. 
    These revenues, if not spent during the fiscal year in which they are generated, shall be carried forward as a surplus in this fund into the next year and so accumulate until spent. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 9-39. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Failure of occupants of residential units or commercial unit dwellings to place a designated recyclables container at curbside containing recyclables along with the other residential solid waste will result in such other solid waste being subjected to review by the city or its contracted agent to determine if this article is being observed. If such review finds recyclables commingled with other waste, the director of public works shall notify the occupant of the violation and discuss the violation with the occupant, informing the occupant that if all such violations are not promptly corrected, the city or its contracted agent may refuse to collect solid waste from the premises. Upon the occupant's failure to correct such violations, the director of public works may, without further notice to the violator, order that solid waste not be collected from the premises. Occupants shall be required to remove all uncollected solid waste from curbside by not later than 9:00 a.m. on the day following the day of the city-wide collection. 
(b)  Solid waste which contains unseparated soft yard waste will not be collected from the premises by the city or its contracted agent. The contracted agent shall promptly notify the director of public works of all such violations of this chapter. The director of public works shall notify the occupant of the premises of the violation and discuss the violation with the occupant, informing the occupant that if all such violations are not promptly corrected, the city or its contracted agent may refuse to collect solid waste from the premises. Upon the occupant's failure to correct such violations, the director of public works may, without further notice to the violator, [direct] that solid waste not be collected from the premises. Occupants shall be required to remove all uncollected solid waste from curbside not later than 9:00 a.m. on the day following the day of the city-wide collection. 
(c)  In the event that the title-holder of record and the occupant(s) of any premises within the city shall violate any provision of this chapter, both the title-holder of record and the occupant(s) of the premises shall be financially responsible for the costs of all enforcement measures and corrective actions engaged in by or on behalf of the city as the result of the violation, including, without limitation, the costs of all cleanup, collection and disposal engaged in by or on behalf of the city. The charges for all such costs shall be deemed to be "charges for the collection and disposal of refuse and recyclables"; shall be levied, imposed and collected in the manner specified in section 9-3 of this chapter; and, when levied or assessed, shall become a lien upon the premises in the manner specified in section 9-3 of this chapter. The terms of this subsection 9-39(c) shall not operate to preclude a violating occupant from receiving the notice and correction opportunity specified in subsections 9-39(a) and 9-39(b) of this chapter for a first-time violation of a type specified in either of those subsections. 
(d)  The provisions of this chapter shall be enforceable by any authorized local official, as defined in section 131/4-1 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 14, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-40. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this chapter is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(b)  The penalties specified in this section shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other remedy that the city may have at law and/or in equity, including but not limited to, the measures specified in section 9-39 and/or the city's recoupment of the costs of enforcement measures and corrective actions. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 15, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 9-41. - Effective date. 
    The effective date of this chapter shall be ten (10) days after its adoption and the publication of a summary hereof as provided by Section 7.4(b) of the Milan City Charter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-1, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Chapter 10 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city relative to dangerous, offensive or unhealthful conditions, § 2.2(19); authority of council relative to public health and safety, § 6-9; authority of council to create a board of health, § 6-9. 
Cross reference- Public health and safety officer, § 2-3; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals and fowl, Ch. 5; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 9; litter, § 13-51 et seq.; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; swimming pools, Ch. 20; trees and shrubs, Ch. 22; water and sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 24; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 
State Law reference- Public health generally, M. S. A., § 14.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Nuisances; penalties. 
(a)  It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to create or to suffer to be on any premises within the corporate limits of the city any nuisance caused by exercising any trade or calling, or any nuisance caused by any building, slaughterhouse, stable, barn, sink, vault, cellar, privy, yard, hogpen, manure pile, drain, sewer or other place, house or thing, or any nuisance whatever. 
(b)  In the event that any person shall violate the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, any authorized local official, as defined in section 131/4-1 of this Code, shall be authorized to notify, order or require the person responsible for such violation, if known, to forthwith cure such violation or cause the same to be cured in some effectual manner. If any such person shall neglect or refuse to comply with any such notice, order or requirement, he or she shall be deemed liable for a separate and distinct municipal civil infraction for each day after receiving any such notice, order or requirement, during which he or she shall continue to so neglect or refuse to cure the violation. Further, the curing of the violation of subsection (a) after receipt of the notice, order or requirement specified in this subsection (b), shall not operate to relieve any party of liability for the municipal civil infraction referenced in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  The penalties specified in this section shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other remedy that the city may have at law and/or in equity. 
(Ord. No. 4-21-1899, §§ 1, 3, Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 16, 1-23-95) 
Charter reference- Power of city to prevent and abate nuisances, § 2.2(19); power to require owner of real property to abate public hazards and nuisances, § 2.2(25); authority of council relative to hazards and nuisances, § 11.7. 
Cross reference- Police, Ch. 15 
Sec. 10-2. - Pollution of streams, etc.; storage of explosives, etc.; damaged structures; unguarded excavations; unguarded machinery; spilling loads from vehicles; placement of signs, etc. on public property; penalties. 
(a)  No person shall pollute any stream, lake or other body of water, or any land within the City of Milan, or air above the City of Milan by depositing or permitting to be deposited therein, thereon or thereunder, as the case may be, any refuse or any foul, noxious or toxic solid, liquid or gaseous substance, vapor or fumes, except as may be expressly permitted by another section of this Code, and then, only in strict accordance with and subject to the limits specified in such other section of this Code. 
(b)  No explosive, inflammable liquid, or other dangerous substance shall be stored in any manner or in any amount contrary to the provisions of this Code or to the statutes of the State of Michigan, whichever shall be more restrictive. 
(c)  No person shall cause or permit to remain standing and unguarded any building, wall or other structure which has been damaged by fire, decay, or otherwise, and which is so situated as to endanger the safety of the public. 
(d)  No person shall cause or permit any excavation to remain unfilled and unguarded so as to jeopardize the safety of the public. 
(e)  No person shall cause or permit any dangerous, unguarded machinery to be placed or left in any public place or on private property, so situated as to jeopardize the safety of the public. 
(f)  No person shall drive or operate, or cause to be driven or operated, upon any public street or right-of-way any truck or other motor vehicle which is constructed or loaded so as to permit any part of its load or contents to blow, fall, or be deposited upon any street, right-of-way or other public or private place dirt, grease, sticky substances or foreign matter of any kind which may jeopardize the public safety or require removal by the city. Provided, however, that under circumstances determined by the director of public works to be in the public interest, such director may grant any person a temporary exemption from the provisions of this subsection, conditioned upon such person's cleaning and correcting the violating condition at least once daily and the execution of an agreement by such person to reimburse the city for any extraordinary maintenance expenses incurred by the city in connection with such violation. 
(g)  No person shall place or cause to be placed on any tree, pole, or other structure located on public property within the corporate limits of the city and paper, poster, sign, card or advertising matter. 
(h)  Violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this chapter is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(i)  The penalties specified in this section shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other remedy that the city may have at law and/or in equity. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 76-7, 8-23-76; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 6, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 10-3-10-11. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NOXIOUS WEEDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Control and eradication of noxious weeds, M. S.2 A., § 9.631(1) et seq.; unlawful use of noxious weeds, etc., §§ 28.181, 28.182. 

Sec. 10-12. - Mandatory cutting of grass and weeds; penalty for failure to comply. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner, possessor and occupier of land within the city, and of every person having charge of any such land, to cut or cause to be cut down all grass growing thereon, and to also to cut or cause to be cut down and destroyed all Canada thistles, milkweed, wild carrots, oxeye daisies and other noxious weeds growing thereon, to a height of not greater than four (4) inches, at least six (6) times each year, being once before the first day of May; thereafter, once before the first day of June; and thereafter, once before the first day of July; and thereafter, once before the first day of August; and thereafter, once before the first day of September; and thereafter once before the first day of October, and more often if necessary to prevent them from going to seed. Resulting grass clippings and weeds shall be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 9 of this Code. 
(b)  It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any owner, possessor or occupier of land within the city, or any person having charge of such land, to fail to conform to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this section, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of subsection (a) of this section is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(Ord. of 11-12-62, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. C.O. 74-1, § 2, 5-13-74; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 17, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 99-2, 6-28-99) 
State Law reference- Duty of owners of land to destroy noxious weeds, etc., M. S. A., § 9.631(4); maximum penalty, § 9.631(4). 
Sec. 10-13. - Notice to remedy or remove weeds, etc.; how given; failure to cure; penalties. 
(a)  In the event that any owner, possessor or occupier of land, or any person in charge thereof, shall refuse or neglect to comply with the provisions of section 10-12 of this article within the time limit specified therein, the director of public works or his or her designee shall be authorized to notify, in writing, the person responsible for such violation, if known, to cure such violation or cause the same to be cured by the end of the tenth day after the date of such notice. Such notice shall be served in any means permitted by chapter 131/4 of this Code for the service of a municipal ordinance violation notice.
