Such notice may, but shall not be required to, be given by the issuance of a municipal ordinance violation notice or a citation for a municipal civil infraction, as those terms are defined in chapter 131/4 of this Code. The giving of such notice by any other means shall not preclude the additional issuance of a municipal ordinance violation notice or a citation for a municipal civil infraction for such violation. 
(b)  If a person has once been served with the notice specified in subsection (a) of this section and fails and/or refuses to cure the violation of section 10-12 of this article by the end of the tenth day after the date of service of such notice or, thereafter, within ten (10) days after any of the dates specified in section 10-12 of this article, he or she shall be deemed liable for a separate and distinct municipal civil infraction and for an additional separate and distinct municipal civil infraction for each day thereafter that he or she continues to fail or refuse to cure the violation, in addition to the procedures and penalties specified in section 10-14 of this article. Further, the curing of the original violation of section 10-12 within the specified ten-day period shall not operate to relieve any party of liability for the municipal civil infraction referenced in section 10-12 of this article. 
(Ord. of 11-12-62, § 3; Ord. No. C.O. 74-1, § 3, 5-12-74; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 17, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 10-14. - Correction or removal of weeds by city generally. 
(a)  If a person has once been served with the notice specified in subsection (a) of this section and fails and/or refuses to cure the violation of section 10-12 of this article by the end of the tenth day after the date of service or such notice or, thereafter, within ten (10) days after any of the dates specified in section 10-12 of this article, the director of public works shall be authorized to cause all the grass and weeds on the subject property to be cut down to a height not greater than that specified in section 10-12. The director of public works shall keep an accurate account of the expenses incurred in carrying out the provisions of this section with respect to each parcel of land entered upon therefor, and shall make a sworn statement of such account and present the same to the clerk/treasurer. 
(b)  The owner, possessor or occupier of land in violation of section 10-12, and/or the person in charge thereof, shall be jointly and severally liable to the city for the full amount of all costs incurred by the city pursuant to this section plus an amount equal to ten (10) per cent of such amount for administrative overhead, in addition to any other penalty provided or permitted by this Code. 
(Ord. of 11-12-62, § 4; Ord. No. C.O. 74-1, § 4, 5-13-74; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 17, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 10-15. - Charges; collection. 
    The clerk/treasurer shall bill or cause the billing of all costs incurred by the city pursuant to section 10-15, including the administrative overhead surcharge, to the owner and/or occupant of land for which grass and/or weeds were cut by the city, and/or to person having charge of such land. 
(Ord. of 11-12-62, § 5; Ord. No. C.O. 74-1, § 5, 5-13-74; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 17, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 10-16. - Charges to be a lien on premises in violation. 
    All charges billed by the clerk/treasurer pursuant to section 10-15 shall, upon billing, become a lien upon the premises to which they apply. On May 30, October 31 and/or thirty (30) days prior to the issuance of any and all tax bills each year, the clerk/treasurer shall certify any and all unpaid charges for such services which have been delinquent three (3) months or more and shall add thereto ten (10) percent of total charges against each of the several premises so certified to cover the city's additional costs should this procedure be necessary to effect collection, and shall enter the resulting total upon the next tax roll against each of the premises so certified. This lien shall be collected and/or enforced in the same manner as provided in respect to that for any other taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(Ord. of 11-12-62, § 5; Ord. No. C.O. 74-1, § 6, 5-13-74; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 17, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 2007-06, § 1, 10-15-07) 
State Law reference- Lien against land for expenses and enforcement of lien, U. S. A., § 9.631(4). 
Secs. 10-17-10-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ENVIRONMENTAL MATTERS 

Sec. 10-25. - Purpose and policy. 
    This article sets forth the uniform requirements for any person or entity seeking permit approval from the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the Michigan Department of Natural Resources, or any other state or federal agency or department having jurisdiction over matters of environmental protection, and assists the city in monitoring compliance with applicable state and federal laws and regulations. The objectives of this article are: 
(1)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the grounds or waters within the city, or into the air above the city; 
(2)  To protect the health and welfare of all of the citizens and inhabitants of the city; 
(3)  To provide the city with timely notice of any potential or actual detriment to the quality of life in the city, or to the health, safety and welfare of its citizens and inhabitants; and 
(4)  To enable the city to monitor compliance with applicable state and federal laws and regulations, and to coordinate its environmental protection efforts with those of state and federal agencies and department having jurisdiction over matters of environmental protection. 
    It is not the purpose or intent of this article to impose an additional city-approval requirement for the permit applicant, except where, and only to the extent, such approval is provided for or required by any federal or state statute or regulation or by another section of the Milan City Code, including, but not limited to, building and occupancy permits. 
(Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 4-10-95) 
Sec. 10-26. - Procedure. 
(a)  Any person or entity engaging or intending to engage in any activity, or creating or intending to create any condition, within the city, which requires permit approval from the United States Environmental Protection Agency and/or the Michigan Department of Natural Resources and/or any other state or federal agency or department having jurisdiction over matters of environmental protection shall notify the city of such fact in writing, in accordance with this article. 
(b)  The written notice required by subsection a of this section 10-26 shall consist of not less than a complete copy of the entire permit application document, including all supporting materials, attachments and exhibits, that is filed with the state and/or federal agencies or departments that will having jurisdiction over the permit(s) in question, together with such other materials and/or information as the applicant may wish to submit to the city. These materials shall be filed with the city clerk/treasurer, by certified mail or personal delivery, contemporaneously with the filing of such materials with the state and/or federal agencies or departments having jurisdiction over the permit(s) in question. The city clerk/treasurer shall record the date and time of his or her receipt of the submitted materials and shall cause a notice or receipt of such materials to be delivered to the city administrator and the city council. 
(Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 4-10-95) 
Sec. 10-27. - Limitations; reservations; severability. 
(a)  Except where, and only to the extent, expressly required by any federal or state statute or regulation or by another section of the Milan City Code, nothing contained in this article shall create or be deemed to impose upon the city or any officer or employee of the city any obligation to engage in substantive review of materials submitted pursuant to this article, or to issue any form or approval or denial of the plans or proposals contained in such materials. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this article shall operate as or be deemed to constitute a waiver of, or limitation upon, any right and/or authority that the city or any officer or employee of the city may have pursuant to applicable state and federal statutes or regulations with respect to any environmental matter referenced in, pertaining to, and/or arising out of the materials submitted pursuant to this article. 
(c)  The provisions of this article are severable, and if any of the provisions, words, phrases clauses or terms, or the application thereof to any person, firm, corporation or entity, or to any circumstances, shall be held invalid, illegal, or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision or findings shall not in any way affect the validity, legality or constitutionality of any other provision, word, phrase, clause or term, and they shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 4-10-95) 
Sec. 10-28. - Penalties for violation. 
(a)  The violation of any provision of any section of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this article, the violator, in addition to any other penalty specified in this article, shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate municipal civil infraction. 
(b)  The City of Milan Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule is hereby amended to specify the following fines and costs for violations of any provision of any section of this article. 
Fine for violation Costs for violation 1st violation: $1,000.00 1st violation: $10.00 2nd violation: $2,500.00 2nd violation: $25.00 3rd & subsequent violations: $5,000.00 3rd & subsequent violations: $50.00  
    Promptly after the adoption of this article, copy of the entire new Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule, as changed by the addition of the new civil fines specified in this article shall be prominently posted at the Civil Infractions Bureau and made available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 95-3, § 1, 4-10-95)

ARTICLE II. - LIBRARY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, adopted Sept. 9, 1991, amended former §§ 11-12-11-20 relative to the library board to read as herein set out. Section 3 of said ordinance specifically repealed former §§ 11-21-11-26. The provisions of former Art. II derived from Ord. No. C.O. 67-68-5, §§ 1-4, adopted Jan. 8, 1968. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Library board generally, M.C.L., § 397.201 et seq., M.S.A., § 15.1661 et seq. 

Sec. 11-12. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "board" shall mean the Milan Public Library Board, and the term "directors" shall mean the members of that board. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, § 2, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 11-13. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the operation and governance of the free public library known as the Milan Public Library in conformance with all applicable state statutes. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, § 2, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 11-14. - Provisional board; composition and term. 
    The city council, by a majority vote of its elected members, shall appoint a provisional board consisting of six (6) members, chosen with reference to their fitness for office, who shall hold office until the election of a permanent board as provided for in this article. ;hn0; (Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, § 2, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 11-15. - Qualifications of board members. 
    All members of the board, both provisional and permanent, shall be qualified and registered electors of the city on the date of their election and/or appointment, and not more than one (1) member of the city council, and no employee of the city, shall at any time be a member of the board. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, § 2, 9-9-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.C.L., § 397.202, M.S.A., 15.1662. 
Sec. 11-16. - Permanent board, composition and terms. 
    At the first biennial general election after December 31, 1991, six (6) directors shall be elected in the manner provided for in this article. The terms of two (2) of the directors shall be two (2) years; the terms of two (2) of the directors shall be four (4) years; and the terms of two (2) of the directors shall be elected for six (6) years. Biennially thereafter, two (2) directors shall be elected for six-year terms. Each term of office shall commence in January of the year immediately after the biennial election. A director shall hold office until his or her successor is elected, qualified and takes office. In the event of a vacancy in a directorship, the board shall appoint a person to hold the office until the election. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, § 2, 9-9-91; Ord. No. C.O. 94-2, § 1, 2-14-94) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.C.L., § 397.203, M.S.A., § 15.1663. 
Sec. 11-17. - Nomination and election of permanent board of directors. 
    The directors of the permanent board shall be nominated and elected on nonpartisan ballots. A candidate for library board director shall file with the city clerk nominating petitions bearing the signatures of a number of registered and qualified electors of the city equal to not less than one (1) per cent of the total number of votes cast for the mayor in the last election in which the mayor was elected. The Michigan election law, Act No. 116 of the Public Acts of 1954, being Sections 168.1 to 168.992 of the Michigan Compiled Laws, as amended, shall govern the circulation and filing of nonpartisan nominating petitions and the conduct of nonpartisan elections under this section. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, § 2, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 11-18. - Officers. 
    Immediately after their appointment, in the case of the provisional board, and in January of each year following a biennial election, in the case of the permanent board, the directors shall meet and elect one (1) of their number president, together with such other officers as they may deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, § 2, 9-9-91; Ord. No. C.O. 94-2, § 1, 2-14-94) 
Sec. 11-19. - Powers and duties of the board. 
(a)  The board shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for its own guidance and for the government of the library and reading room, as may be expedient and not inconsistent with applicable state statutes. The board shall have exclusive control of the expenditure of all moneys collected to the credit of the library fund, and of the construction of any library building, and, of the supervision, care and custody of the grounds, rooms and buildings constructed, leased or set apart for the library, subject only to the provisions of section 11-20 of this article. The board shall have power to purchase and lease grounds, and to occupy, lease and erect an appropriate building or buildings for the use of the library, and shall have power to appoint a suitable librarian and necessary assistants, to fix their compensation, and to remove any and all such appointees. The board shall, in general, carry out the spirit and intent of all applicable state statutes in establishing and maintaining a public library and reading room. 
(b)  All powers and duties prescribed in this section shall be held, exercised and discharged by the provisional board and by the subsequently elected permanent board, whichever may then be in existence. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, § 2, 9-9-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.C.L., §§ 397.205, 397.207, M.S.A., §§ 15.1665, 15.1667. 
Sec. 11-20. - Finances. 
(a)  All moneys received for the library, whether received initially by the board or by the city and including, without limitation, all tax revenues and monetary donations, shall be deposited with the clerk-treasurer of the city, who shall keep them deposited in the city treasury to the credit of the library fund and separate and apart from other moneys of the city. The expenditure of all funds so deposited shall be under the exclusive control of the library board, provided that such funds shall be drawn upon and disbursed to the board by the city clerk-treasurer only upon the clerk-treasurer's receipt of a written voucher approved by the library board and properly authenticated. The city clerk-treasurer shall prescribe the form of such written vouchers, provided that the authority to so prescribe shall in no way diminish the board's exclusive control of the expenditure of moneys collected to the credit of the library fund. 
(b)  Inasmuch as a one-mill special tax was previously authorized pursuant to state law for the support of the free library board, by resolution adopted and delivered to the city council prior to the council's adoption of the city's budget for the ensuing fiscal year, shall estimate that a lesser sum of money is necessary for the support and maintenance of the library, the city council shall annually cause the one-mill tax to be levied upon the taxable property in the city, and the city clerk-treasurer shall collect such tax for deposit to the credit of the library fund, in the same manner as are other general taxes in the city. 
(c)  If the library board by resolution determines that the amount of money necessary for the support and maintenance of the library exceeds revenues that would be generated by the previously authorized one-mill tax, the question of increasing the library millage to not more than two (2) mills on the dollar of taxable property in the city shall be placed on the ballot at the next regular election for the city, or at a special election for the city, with the costs of that special election being paid from the library fund. 
(d)  A tax levied under this section shall be in addition to any tax limitation imposed by the city's charter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-6, § 2, 9-9-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.C.L., § 397.201, M.S.A., § 15.661.  
Chapter 12 - LICENSES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city to regulate trades, occupations and amusements, § 2.2(17); power of city relative to licenses, § 2.2(20). 
Cross reference- State license required to engage in business of selling alcoholic liquor, § 3-2; license required for public establishments and stores relative to consumption of alcoholic liquors therein, § 3-6; license for mechanical amusement devices, § 4-1 et seq.; license to engage in business of electric wiring or to make alterations to the wiring of any building, § 6-40; permit to erect or alter buildings or structures, § 6-40; license for plumbers, § 6-62; permit to sell fireworks, § 8-1; permit to discharge fireworks, § 8-2; license to use buildings for public assemblages, § 8-5; permit and license for transient and itinerant merchants and itinerant vendors, § 14-18 et seq.; license to obstruct streets, alleys, etc., § 18-1; license to obstruct sidewalks, § 18-2; permit to obstruct sidewalks, § 18-19; permit to construct curbs and gutters, § 18-40; permit for private swimming pools, § 20-17; permit to plant trees and shrubs, § 22-14; permit for public utilities to chemically control and trim trees and shrubs, § 22-19; license for taxicabs, § 23-17 et seq.; license for public drays, § 23-52 et seq.; permit relative to storm sewers, §§ 24-71, 24-72. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to provide, in its charter, for the regulation of trades, occupations and amusements, M.S.A., § 5.2082(4). 

Sec. 12-1. - Licenses required by chapter to be secured as provided herein. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act or thing, or pursue or carry on any trade, occupation or business within the city for which a license is required by this chapter until he shall have first secured such license in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 1) 
Sec. 12-2. - Auctioneers; selling property at public auction or outcry; permits. 
    Every person who shall exercise the business or trade of any auctioneer or sell property at public auction or outcry within the city shall, before doing so, obtain an annual permit therefor and shall pay the sum specified for such permit in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council. Upon written request by the organization in question, the city council may approve the issuance of a daily auction permit to a qualified nonprofit or charitable organization upon payment of the fee specified for such a daily permit in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 3; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 20, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 12-3. - Pawnbrokers; permits. 
    No person shall conduct business as a pawnbroker within the city without first obtaining an annual permit to do so. The fee for such permit shall be that specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 5; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 20, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 12-4. - Circuses; caravans of animals; permits. 
    The proprietor, manager or other person in charge of any circus or caravan of animals shall, before exhibiting the same within the city, first obtain a permit to do so and shall pay for such permit the sum specified for same in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 6; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 20, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 12-5. - Theatrical exhibitions, etc. 
    The proprietor or manager of any theatrical exhibition, sporting performance, exhibition of natural or artificial curiosities, side show, concert, or any other public show, performance, or exhibition which is not specified in section 12-4 of this article and for which an admission fee of money is charged shall, before giving any performance or exhibition of or with the same, obtain an annual permit to do so and shall pay for such permit the fee specified for same in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any exhibition, performance or concert by the teachers and/or pupils of any public or private school within the city or by any other organization, order or society composed of residents of the city. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 7; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 20, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 12-6. - Separate licenses to be taken out for different business places and for each vocation or business. 
    If any person shall carry on any trade, business or occupation, or do any act or thing requiring a license under this chapter at different places in the city at one and the same time, he shall take out a separate license for each such business place, and if any person shall carry on two (2) or more vocations or kinds of business, each of which, if carried on separately would by the provisions of this chapter, require a license, he shall take out a separate license for each vocation or business. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 2) 
Sec. 12-7. - Applications generally. 
    All applications for a license required by this chapter shall be made to the mayor and shall be in writing, signed by the person desiring the license and shall state the business occupation or matter to be licensed, the time for which such license is sought and the name and residence of the person to whom the license is to be issued, which application shall be filed with the city clerk and preserved in his office. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 9) 
Sec. 12-8. - Issuance; contents; register to be kept. 
(a)  All licenses required by this chapter shall be granted by the mayor and signed by him. Each license shall state therein its proper consecutive number, the amount paid therefor, the name of the person licensed, the business occupation or the matter licensed and the time for which the license was granted. 
(b)  No license shall be granted under this section until the amount required therefor shall have been paid to the mayor or into the city treasury. The mayor shall keep a correct register of all licenses issued, which register shall state the consecutive number of each license, the name of the person to whom issued, for what purpose, the date of issue, the time of expiration, and the amount paid therefor. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, §§ 10, 13) 
Sec. 12-9. - Not assignable; carrying on vocation, etc., under license of another prohibited. 
    No license granted under this chapter shall be assignable for any purpose, nor shall any person carry on any vocation or business or do any act or thing under any license granted to any other person. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 11) 
Sec. 12-10. - Revocation. 
    The city council may at any time revoke and annul any license granted under this chapter, whenever in its opinion it shall be expedient so to do. Whenever any license is so revoked and annulled, the city clerk shall give notice thereof in writing to the person to whom such license was granted or to his agent or employee in the business for which the license was granted. If any license shall be revoked and annulled because of the wrongful or unlawful acts of the person to whom it was granted, all the money paid for the license revoked shall be forfeited. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 12) 
Sec. 12-11. - Carrying on certain vocations, etc., without a license. 
    Every proprietor, agent, manager, person in charge, employee, assistant or performer in any circus, caravan of animals, public exhibition, play, sporting game, side show, theatrical performance or concert who shall engage in, assist at, perform in or in any manner aid to carry on the same or either thereof, for which a license is required by this chapter and for which a license shall not have been duly granted, shall be deemed to have violated this section. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, § 14)

Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary. 
(a)  The word "city" is the City of Milan. 
(b)  The word "person" is any person, firm, partnership, company, association, corporation, club or organization of any kind. 
(c)  The words "alcoholic beverage" shall include any spirituous, vinous, malt, fermented liquor, beer, wine, spirits, alcoholic liquids and compounds whether or not medicated, proprietary, patented, and by whatever name called, containing one-half of one per cent (1/2 of 1%) or more of alcohol by volume, which are fit for beverage purposes. 
(d)  The words "public place" as used in this article shall mean any street, alley, park, public building, any place of business or assembly open to or frequented by the public or any place which is open to the public view or to which the public has access. 
(e)  The words "police officer" as used in this article shall mean any regular, commissioned police officer or any reserve police officer, or any officer or agent of any law enforcement agency of this state or any other state or federal officer. 
(f)  Masculine pronouns in this article shall be construed to include both male and female persons. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-2. - Assault; assault and battery; domestic assault. 
(a)  No person shall commit an assault, or an assault and battery, on any other person. 
(b)  No person shall commit an assault, or an assault and battery, on his or her spouse, or former spouse, an individual with whom he or she has or has had a dating relationship with, an individual with whom he or she has had a child in common, or a resident or former resident of his or her household. 
(c)  As used in this chapter, "dating relationship" means frequent, intimate associations primarily characterized by the expectation of affectional involvement. This term does not include a casual relationship or an ordinary fraternization between two individuals in a business or social contacts. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or ninety-three (93) days imprisonment, or both. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. 96-7, § 1, 9-23-96; Ord. No. 2002-02, § 1, 4-8-02) 
Sec. 13-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-03, § 1, adopted Jan. 13, 2014, repealed § 3-3, which pertained to begging and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1982. 
Sec. 13-4. - Public disturbance or endangering safety of person or property by intoxicated person in public place. 
    No person shall be intoxicated in a public place if he is either endangering directly the safety of another person or of property or is acting in a manner that causes a public disturbance. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverage, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 13-5. - Present in public while impaired by use of controlled substance. 
    No person shall be present in any public place with his ability to walk, talk or see significantly impaired by the use of any controlled substance, as defined by Public Act 196 of 1971, as amended, provided, however, that his section shall not be construed to apply to a person whose faculties have been impaired by medication prescribed by a physician and taken as directed. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-6. - Fighting. 
    No person shall engage in any fight in a public place. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-7. - Trespass. 
    No person shall: 
(a)  Without the lawful authority of the owner or occupant of any lands, enter upon the lands or premises of another having been forbidden to do so by the owner or occupant either directly or by visibly posted signs; 
(b)  Upon being notified to depart from lands or premises of another by the owner or occupant or the agent of the owner or occupant, remain upon said lands or premises. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-8. - Prowling. 
    No person shall knowingly prowl about the premises owned or leased by another in the nighttime without the express consent of the owner or lessee. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-9. - Window peeping. 
    No person shall knowingly go upon the property of another occupied as a residence and look, peer or peep into or through a window of a building on that property, at any person without the express or implied consent of that person. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-10. - Remaining in public place after closing hours. 
    No person shall remain in a public place after its regular closing hours after being told to leave by one authorized to give such an order. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-11. - Unauthorized repose. 
    No person shall occupy, lodge or sleep in any vacant or unoccupied barn, garage, house, shed, shop or other structure, building, automobile, truck, railroad, car, public park or parking lot without the permission of the owner. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-12. - Obstruction of passage. 
    No person shall conduct himself in any public place, or join with one or more other persons in a public place, if he knows or should know that, singly or together with others with whom he has joined, he is unreasonably obstructing the free and uninterrupted passage of the public along any street or sidewalk or into and out of any building to which the public has lawful access, or in interfering unreasonably with the lawful use of the public of any place of business. This section shall not be interpreted to conflict with the regulations of the National Labor Relations Board regarding picketing in labor disputes. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-13. - Disturbing the public peace. 
    No person shall persist in disturbing the public peace and quiet by loud or aggressive conduct, having once been clearly informed by persons affected, or by a police officer, that he is, in fact, unreasonably causing such a disturbance. Notice need not be given, however, when such persons affected reasonably believe that to do so would constitute a risk to their personal safety. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-14. - Disturbing a public meeting. 
    No person shall persist in disturbing the peace and orderly conduct of any meeting of a public body or any meeting open to the general public, including services of religious worship, by any conduct or communication which, by its very existence, inflicts injury or intends to incite an immediate breach of the peace, or which prevents the peaceful and orderly conduct of such meeting, after having been clearly informed that he is, in fact, unreasonably causing such disturbance. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-15. - Permitting a disturbance of the peace. 
    No person shall knowingly permit a person in any place owned or controlled by him to disturb the public peace by loud or boisterous conduct. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-16. - Harassment. 
    No person shall knowingly harass any other person. "Harass" is defined as any repeated nonverbal conduct which is specifically intended to frighten, embarrass or anger the person or persons who are the object of such conduct or which the person accused has reason to know is likely to produce such reactions, or as any verbal communication which, by its very utterance, inflicts injury or tends to incite an immediate breach of the peace. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-17. - Interference with police or firemen. 
    No person shall knowingly obstruct or resist any member of the police force or fire department in the discharge of his lawful duties, or fail to obey the lawful order of said officer, knowing him to be a member of the police force or fire department. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-18. - Refusal to identify. 
    No person shall refuse to identify himself with his name and residence address when requested by a police officer after being informed by the police officer that he is investigating the possible violation of a statute or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-19. - False summons. 
    No person, without good reason therefor, shall summon, by telephone or otherwise, the police or fire department, any public or private ambulance, or any other services of any kind, to go to any address where the service called for is not needed. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-20. - Impersonating a police officer. 
    No person shall falsely impersonate any member of the police department of this city or any official police agency of this state or any other state or other federal agency by wearing of a uniform or presenting a badge or identification card or carrying any weapon such as night stick or chemical mace or by carrying handcuffs designated to be carried by such law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-21. - Immoral conduct. 
    No person shall utter vile, profane or obscene language in any public place; nor shall any person engage in any indecent, immoral or obscene conduct in any public place; nor shall any person make any immoral exhibition or indecent exposure of his or her person in any public place; nor shall any person urinate or defecate on any public street, sidewalk, floor or that part of any public building open to the public, or any other place in view of the public not specifically designated for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-22. - Houses of prostitution. 
(a)  No person shall keep a house of ill fame or a house of prostitution or any place used for purposes of lewdness, and no person shall lease or let any dwelling, house, room or other premises knowing that the lessee intends to use it as a place of resort for the purpose of prostitution. 
(b)  No person shall be in or remain in any house of ill fame or house of prostitution for the purpose of prostitution, lewdness or debauchery. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-23. - Soliciting for prostitution. 
    No person shall solicit or accost any person in a public place for the purpose of inducing participation in an act of prostitution or in any other illegal, indecent, immoral or depraved act. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-24. - Offenses involving underage persons and alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  No person shall sell or deliver any alcoholic beverage to a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years in the City of Milan, either directly or indirectly; provided, that the sale or delivery of an alcoholic beverage to a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years upon the authority of a prescription of a physician licensed by the State of Michigan, shall not be a violation of this section. 
(b)  Purchase, consumption, or possession of alcoholic liquor by a person less than twenty-one (21) years of age; attempt; violation; fines; sanctions. 
(1)  No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall purchase or attempt to purchase alcoholic liquor, consume or attempt to consume alcoholic liquor, possess or attempt to possess alcoholic liquor, or have any bodily alcohol content, in the City of Milan, except as provided in this section and MCL 257.624b. A person under the age of twenty-one (21) years who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by the following: 
a.  For the first violation by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), and may be ordered to participate in substance abuse prevention services or substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation services as defined in section 6107 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.6107, and designated by the administrator of the office of substance abuse services, and may be ordered to perform community service and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his or her own expense as described in subsection (b)(2). 
b.  For a second violation, by imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days but only if the court finds that the person violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatment, screening, or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction or juvenile adjudication, by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), or both, and maybe ordered to participate in substance abuse prevention services or substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation services as defined in section 6107 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.6107, and designated by the administrator of the office of substance abuse services, to perform community service, and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his or her own expense as described in subsection (b)(2). 
c.  For a third or subsequent violation, by imprisonment for not more than sixty (60) days but only if the court finds that the person violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatment, screening, or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction or juvenile adjudication, by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both, and may be ordered to participate in substance abuse prevention services or substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation services as defined in section 6107 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.6107, and designated by the administrator of the office of substance abuse services, to perform community service, and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his or her own expense as described in subsection (b)(2). 
(2)  A court may order an individual convicted of violating subsection (b)(1) to undergo screening and assessment by a person or agency as designated by the substance abuse coordinating agency as defined in section 6103 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.6103, in order to determine whether the individual is likely to benefit from rehabilitative services, including alcohol or drug education and alcohol or drug treatment programs. A court may order an individual subject to a conviction or juvenile adjudication of, or placed on probation regarding, a violation of subsection (b)(1) to submit to a random or regular preliminary chemical breath analysis. The parent, guardian, or custodian of a person under 18 years of age not emancipated under 1968 PA 293, MCL 722.1 to 722.6, may request a random or regular preliminary chemical breath analysis as part of the probation. 
(3)  A peace officer may arrest an individual based in whole or in part upon the results of a preliminary chemical breath analysis. The results of a preliminary chemical breath analysis or other acceptable blood alcohol test are admissible in a criminal prosecution to determine whether the person has consumed or possessed alcoholic liquor or had any bodily alcohol content. 
(4)  A law enforcement agency, upon determining that an individual less than 18 years of age who is not emancipated under 1968 PA 293, MCL 722.1 to 722.6, allegedly consumed, possessed, purchased alcoholic liquor, attempted to consume, possess, or purchase alcoholic liquor, or had any bodily alcohol content in violation of subsection (b)(1) shall notify the parent or parents, custodian, or guardian of the individual as to the nature of the violation if the name of a parent, guardian, or custodian is reasonably ascertainable by the law enforcement agency. The law enforcement agency shall notify the parent, guardian, or custodian not later than 48 hours after the law enforcement agency determines that the individual who allegedly violated subsection (b)(1) is less than eighteen (18) years of age and not emancipated under 1968 PA 293, MCL 722.1 to 722.6. The law enforcement agency may notify the parent, guardian, or custodian by any means reasonably calculated to give prompt actual notice including, but not limited to, notice in person, by telephone, or by first-class mail. If an individual less than seventeen (17) years of age is incarcerated for violating subsection (b)(1), his or her parents or legal guardian shall be notified immediately as provided in this subsection. 
(5)  This section does not prohibit a person from possessing alcoholic liquor during regular working hours and in the course of his or her employment if employed by a person licensed by 1998 PA 58, MCL 436.1101 et seq., by the commission, or by an agent of the commission, if the alcoholic liquor is not possessed for his or her personal consumption. 
(6)  The following individuals are not considered to be in violation of subsection (b)(1): 
a.  A person who has consumed alcoholic liquor and who voluntarily presents himself or herself to a health facility or agency for treatment or for observation including, but not limited to, medical examination and treatment for any condition arising from a violation of sections 520b to 520g of the Michigan penal code, 1931 PA 328, MCL 750.520b to 750.520g, committed against a minor. 
b.  A person who accompanies an individual who meets both of the following criteria: 
(i)  Has consumed alcoholic liquor. 
(ii)  Voluntarily presents himself or herself to a health facility or agency for treatment or for observation including, but not limited to, medical examination and treatment for any condition arising from a violation of sections 520b to 520g of the Michigan penal code, 1931 PA 328, MCL 750.520b to 750.520g, committed against a minor. 
c.  A person who initiates contact with a peace officer or emergency medical services personnel for the purpose of obtaining medical assistance for a legitimate health care concern. 
(7)  This section does not limit the civil or criminal liability of a vendor or the vendor's clerk, servant, agent, or employee for a violation of the Milan City Code or 1998 PA 58, MCL 436.1101 et seq. 
(8)  The consumption of alcoholic liquor by a person who is enrolled in a course offered by an accredited postsecondary educational institution in an academic building of the institution under the supervision of a faculty member is not prohibited by this subsection if the purpose of the consumption is solely educational and is a requirement of the course. 
(9)  The consumption by a person of sacramental wine in connection with religious services at a church, synagogue, or temple is not prohibited by this subsection. 
(10)  Subsection (1) does not apply to a person who participates in either or both of the following: 
a.  An undercover operation in which the person purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the person's employer and with the prior approval of the local prosecutor's office as part of an employer-sponsored internal enforcement action. 
b.  An undercover operation in which the person purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the state police, the commission, or a local police agency as part of an enforcement action unless the initial or contemporaneous purchase or receipt of alcoholic liquor by the person was not under the direction of the state police, the commission, or the local police agency and was not part of the undercover operation. 
(11)  The state police, the commission, or a local police agency shall not recruit or attempt to recruit a person for participation in an undercover operation at the scene of a violation of subsection (b)(1), MCL 436.1703(1), MCL 436.1701(1), or MCL 436.1801(1). 
(12)  In a criminal prosecution for the violation of subsection (b)(1) concerning a person having any bodily alcohol content, it is an affirmative defense that the person consumed the alcoholic liquor in a venue or location where that consumption is legal. 
(13)  As used in this section: 
a.  "Any bodily alcohol content" means either of the following: 
(i)  An alcohol content of two-one hundredths (0.02) grams or more per one hundred (100) milliliters of blood, per two hundred ten (210) liters of breath, or per sixty-seven (67) milliliters of urine. 
(ii)  Any presence of alcohol within a person's body resulting from the consumption of alcoholic liquor, other than consumption of alcoholic liquor as a part of a generally recognized religious service or ceremony. 
b.  "Emergency medical services personnel" means that term as defined in section 20904 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.20904. 
c.  "Health facility or agency" means that term as defined in section 20106 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.20106. 
(c)  No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall make any false statements or give false information or identification to any person regarding his or her age in order to secure the sale or the furnishing of alcoholic beverages. 
(d)  No person shall make false statements or give false information regarding the age of a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years in order to procure the sale or furnishing of alcoholic beverages to such person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(e)  No person shall procure, counsel, aid, assist or abet another in the commission of an offense under this section. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. 2015-03, § 1, 4-13-15) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 13-25. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor under the age of seventeen (17) years to loiter, idle, congregate or otherwise be in or on any public street, highway, alley, park or any public place, between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., or minors fifteen (15) years of age or under from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m., immediately following, except where the minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian, or some adult above twenty-one (21) years of age delegated by the parent or guardian to accompany such child, or where the presence of such minor in such place or places is connected with and required by some legitimate work, trade, profession or occupation in which such minor is engaged, or where such minor is upon an emergency errand or other legitimate business directed by his parent or guardian. The provisions of this subsection do not apply when going to or coming from a legitimate church, municipal or school function or returning from the theater with the permission of the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor. 
(b)  Any person assisting, aiding, abetting or encouraging any minor under the age of seventeen (17) years to violate the provisions of subsection (a), shall be guilty of violation of this section, and when any minor is found violating the provisions of subsection (a), a presumption shall arise that the parent or legal guardian having the care and custody of the minor assisted, aided, abetted and encouraged such minor in so violating subsection (a). 
(c)  The parent or guardian of the minor child shall be held responsible for the enforcement of subsections (a) and (b). 
(d)  Any parent or guardian found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-8. Any minor violating the provisions of this section shall be dealt with in accordance with juvenile court law and procedure. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-26. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1, adopted Feb. 23, 2015, repealed § 13-26, which pertained to larceny and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1982. 
Sec. 13-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-01, § 2, adopted Feb. 23, 2015, repealed § 13-27, which pertained to fraudulent schemes and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1982. 
Sec. 13-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-01, § 3, adopted Feb. 23, 2015, repealed § 13-28, which pertained to taking bicycle without permission and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1982. 
Sec. 13-29. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-01, § 4, adopted Feb. 23, 2015, repealed § 13-29, which pertained to checks without sufficient funds and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1982. 
Sec. 13-30. - Destruction of property. 
    No person shall knowingly and maliciously destroy, damage, deface or remove any property not his own. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-31. - Vandalism of public property. 
(a)  No person shall willfully and maliciously destroy, damage or deface any public building, street, sidewalk, sign, fire hydrant, fence or any publicly owned place or item of personal property within the city. 
(b)  No person shall willfully and maliciously destroy, damage or remove any tree, shrub, wildflower or other vegetation, or destroy, damage or remove any publicly owned property in any public park or recreation area in the city. 
(c)  Any person who violates either of the aforesaid subdivisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(d)  In addition to the penalties provided in this section for violation of its provisions, any person convicted of an act of vandalism shall reimburse the city for the amount of damages if guilty of subsection (a) or three (3) times the amount of damages if guilty of subsection (b), as determined by the court. 
(e)  In every case of conviction for the violation of subsection (b) hereof, the court before whom the conviction is obtained shall enter a judgment in favor of the city and against the defendant for liquidated damages in a sum as provided in subsection (d). The city shall, with the assistance of the city attorney, collect the award by execution or otherwise. If two (2) or more defendants are convicted of violating subsection (b) hereof, the judgment for damages shall be entered against them jointly. If the defendant is a minor, the judgment shall be entered against his or her parents. 
(f)  In every case of conviction for the violation of subsection (a) hereof, the city may recover damages against the person so convicted for the amount of damages, or if the person convicted is a minor, against the minor's parents for the amount of damages not exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(g)  The city may pay a reward of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) to any person, other than police officers or the employees of the city, who gives information which leads to the arrest and conviction of any person for violation of this section. 
(h)  All claims made pursuant to this section shall be in writing and filed with the city clerk not more than thirty (30) days after the sentencing of the person convicted under this section. The claim shall state the date and place of the incident, the name of the offender, and the name and address of the person or persons making the claim. The clerk shall refer the claim to the city attorney and chief of police who shall investigate the same and submit the claim, together with a recommendation, to the city council for its approval or denial. Upon the approval of the city council, the claim shall become a general obligation of the city and payable as such by the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 88-6, § 1, 8-8-88) 
Cross reference- Conduct in parks, § 131/2-7. 
Sec. 13-32. - Throwing objects from vehicles. 
    No person shall throw any object from any standing or moving vehicle or toward any person or vehicle if he knows or should know that damage to person or property, or alarm which may foreseeably produce damage to person or property, is likely to result. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-33. - Possession of certain knives and other weapons. 
(a)  No person shall carry a dagger, dirk, stiletto or knife having a blade over three (3) inches in length, concealed on or about his person, or whether concealed or otherwise in any motor vehicle operated or occupied by him, except in his dwelling house or place of business or on other land possessed by him. This prohibition shall not apply to hunting knives adapted and carried as such, household table service or kitchen utensils adapted and carried for such use, or for knives adapted and carried for use in the person's occupation or profession. 
(b)  No person shall have in his possession any knife having the appearance of a pocket knife, the blade or blades of which can be opened by the flick of a button, pressure on a handle or other mechanical contrivance. This prohibition shall not apply to any one-armed person carrying a knife on his person in connection with his living requirements. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police or any other officer designated by the chief of police to seize all weapons in violation of this section and to dispose of such weapons as prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-34. - Firearms, bows, shot guns, air guns, pellet guns and slingshots. 
(a)  No person shall fire any shot gun, rifle, pistol, or other firearm within the city limits of the City of Milan unless it can be deemed necessary to protect his life or the lives of his family; except however, that the chief of police may authorize shooting at registered and approved sites. 
(b)  No person shall shoot a B-B gun, gas-fired pellet gun, dart gun, bow and arrow or slingshot within the city limits unless it is on such person's property for the purpose of target practice. Such target practicing shall be supervised by an adult whose property is being used and such target must be located so as to prevent any pellets, B-B's, arrows or darts from leaving such person's property. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police or any officer designated by the chief of police to seize all guns or weapons of any type used in violating this section and he shall dispose of such weapons as provided by law. 
(d)  No person shall sell, loan or furnish to any minors, any firearm in which any explosives can be used, or any dynamite fuse or caps, gun powder or other explosives. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-35. - Barbed wire fences. 
    No person shall build or permit to be built a barbed wire fence upon or along any street, alley, or sidewalk, or upon that area adjacent to any street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-36. - Unused refrigerators. 
    No person shall store, maintain, discard or dispose of any unused refrigerator, ice box, freezer, or any other container or appliance capable of containing a child and having a self-locking door on the exterior, without first complying with one or more of the following safety precautions: 
(1)  Removal of all exterior locks. 
(2)  Removal of all doors or covers. 
(3)  Storing the appliance in such manner as to make entry inaccessible by causing the doors or covers to be firmly pressed against the wall, ground or floor. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-37. - Telephone harassment. 
    No person shall telephone, visit or otherwise communicate with any person repeatedly or cause the same to be done for the primary purpose of harassing such other person or his family. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-38. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-01, § 5, adopted Feb. 23, 2015, repealed § 13-38, which pertained to connecting to public utility without permission and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1982. 
Sec. 13-39. - Fires and other hazards. 
    No person, when in proximity to a fire or other hazard, shall refuse or knowingly fail to obey a reasonably official request or order to move for the purpose of maintaining public safety. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-40. - State law misdemeanors. 
    Every act prohibited by the State of Michigan as a misdemeanor, is hereby incorporated by reference as if fully rewritten herein and prohibited, and whoever violates the provisions of this section within the limits of the City of Milan shall upon conviction thereof, be subject to penalty provided by the said state law. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-41. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or ninety (90) days in the county jail or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation unless a different penalty is expressly provided for in this Code, or in any amendments thereof. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. 2015-03, § 2, 4-13-15) 
Sec. 13-42. - Smoking in the city buildings prohibited. 
    No person shall use, carry or possess a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or other lighted tobacco or smoking device in any building or other enclosed, indoor area owned or operated by the city. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 91-3, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. C.O. 91-3, adopted Aug. 12, 1991, added a new § 13-63. Such section has been redesignated as § 13-42 at the discretion of the editor for classification purposes. 
Secs. 13-43-13-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTER 

Sec. 13-51. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following definitions shall apply, and the word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory: 
    Authorized private container means any container, as defined in section 13-51 of this chapter, stored and/or placed on private property, for the storage and collection of litter. 
    Authorized public container means any container, as defined in section 13-51 of this chapter, authorized and/or placed by the city on public property for the storage and collection of litter. 
    Bulky waste means refrigerators, freezers and air-conditioners (from which freon has been removed prior to the owner's placement of same for collection by the contractor), water tanks, washing machines, dryers, stoves, furniture, tires, automobile parts not exceeding four (4) feet in length or fifty (50) pounds in weight, and other waste materials other than construction debris. 
    City means the City of Milan, Michigan. The phrase "within the city" shall be interpreted as meaning "anywhere within the corporate limits of the city." 
    Commingled material means a mixture of types of recyclables separated from other solid waste by requiring further processing after collection by the city or a contractor. 
    Construction debris means waste building materials resulting from residential construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations and which are included within any applicable household hazardous-waste exception s set forth in P. A. 1979, No. 64, or in the Resource Conservation and Recovery Ace, 42 U.S.C. 6901, et seq. 
    Container means either a portable container, a nonportable container, or a recyclables container (as defined in this article), as the case may be, but excluding ferrous metal containers, glass containers, and plastic containers, as defined in this article. 
(1)  Portable container. A litter receptacle with a capacity of greater than twenty (20) gallons but not more than thirty-five (35) gallons constructed of plastic, metal or fiberglass, having handles of adequate strength for lifting and having tight-fitting lids capable of preventing entrance into the container by vermin. 
(2)  Nonportable containers. Any litter container with capacity greater than thirty-five (35) gallons fixed with devices permitting mechanical lifting and dumping. 
(3)  Recyclables containers. Plastic bins or other containers furnished, with or without cost, by the city or a city contractor and specifically designated by the city as being approved for the storage of recyclables other than soft yard waste. 
    Dead animals means animals weighing ten (10) pounds or less that have expired from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human use or consumption. 
    Garbage means dead animals and every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable and/or other matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing, handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains or other animal or vegetable matter including, but not by way of limitation, all putrescible or easily decomposable animal or vegetable waste matter which is likely to attract flies or rodents, except (in all cases) any matter included in the definitions of bulky waste, construction debris, hazardous waste, or rubbish specified in this section. 
    Hard yard waste means wood-compostable material such as branches and other nonleafy parts of trees. 
    Hazardous waste means waste, in any amount, which is defined, characterized or designated as hazardous by the United States Environmental Protection Agency, Michigan Department of Natural Resources or other appropriate state agency by or pursuant to federal or state statute or regulation, and any waste, in any amount, which is regulated under federal or state law. For purposes of this article, the term hazardous waste shall also include motor oil, gasoline, paint and paint cans. 
    Litter means any refuse, and any notice, poster or other device posted in violation of the provisions of section 13-59 of this chapter. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
    Private property means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys and other public rights-of-way, and any and all buildings, structures and grounds owned and/or controlled by any governmental entity, including but not limited to, any public park, square or space, and all structures thereon and all appurtenances thereto. 
    Private property means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys and other public rights-of-way, and any and all buildings, structures and grounds owned and/or controlled by any governmental entity, including but not limited to, any public park, square or space, and all structures thereon and all appurtenances thereto. 
    Premises means land, water, buildings and other structures, vehicles, and watercraft, and any part thereof. 
    Recyclables means materials suitable for recycling as determined by the director of public works. 
    Refuse means all garbage, rubbish, bulky waste and dead animals (as defined in this article) but not including body wastes of a type acceptable for discharge into the city's sanitary sewer system. 
    Rubbish means all waste wood, wood products, tree trimmings, dead trees or branches thereof, soft yard waste, hard yard waste, chips, shavings, sawdust, printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and discarded mattresses, used and discarded clothing, used and discarded shoes and boots, combustible waste pulp and other products such as are used for packaging or wrapping, crockery and glass, ashes, cinders, floor sweeping, mineral or metallic substances, and any and all other waste materials not included in the definitions of bulky waste, construction debris, dead animals, garbage or hazardous waste. 
    Soft yard waste means grass, leaves, yard and garden trimmings and waste, and other nonwoody vegetation. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-13-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 18, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-52. - Litter in public places. 
(a)  No person shall throw, sweep or otherwise deposit litter in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public property within the city, except in authorized public containers, as defined in section 13-51 of this chapter. 
(b)  Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk abutting their premises free of litter. Violation of this subsection (b) shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 18, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-53. - Placement of litter in receptacles to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in authorized public containers or in authorized private containers shall do so in a manner to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public property or upon any private property. Violation of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination or responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 18, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-54. - Truckloads causing litter. 
    No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being spilled, scattered, blown or otherwise deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 92-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-55. - Litter thrown by persons in vehicles. 
    No person, while a driver or a passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-56. - Litter in lakes and streams. 
    No person shall throw or otherwise deposit litter in or upon any lake, pond, river, stream or any other body of water including the ice upon such water. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-57. - Litter in parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in authorized public containers and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any public property or upon any private property. When authorized public containers are not provided or cannot accommodate additional litter, all litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of provided elsewhere in this Code. Violation of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 18, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-58. - Yard waste in streets. 
    No person shall place or otherwise deposit any hard yard waste or soft yard waste in the street right-of-way except for collection and then only when stored and placed in accordance with Chapter 9 of the Milan City Code. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 18, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-59. - Posting notices prohibited. 
    No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device, calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamp post, public utility pole or tree, or upon any public property except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 18, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-60. - Litter on private property. 
    No person shall throw, scatter, sweep or otherwise deposit litter on any private property not owned by such person within the city except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 18, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-61. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of refuse until the next scheduled collection of the refuse by the city or the city's contractor, if such refuse is stored in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 9 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 18, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-62. - Penalties. 
    Unless expressly stated to constitute a municipal civil infraction, the violation of any provision of this article is hereby declared to be a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court, together with costs of prosecution. Each day upon which such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 18, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 13-63-13-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STORING AND PARKING OF JUNKED MOTOR VEHICLES 

Sec. 13-71. - Storing or parking on private property prohibited. 
    The storing or parking on private property of a motor vehicle not bearing a currently valid motor vehicle registration plate, or not being in an operating condition (by which is meant at the least, an engine that runs, having four (4) wheels and four (4) pneumatic tires capable of holding air, and a working battery), is declared to be a nuisance and a municipal civil infraction, and is hereby prohibited, unless such vehicle, body or chassis is enclosed in a building so as to the [be] not visible from adjacent properties. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 19, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-72. - Violation by owner or occupant of property. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to permit the storing or parking of any vehicle, body or chassis prohibited by this article, and the owner and/or the occupant of any property within the City of Milan upon which such prohibited storing or parking is permitted to exist shall be equally liable under this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 19, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-73. - Exceptions. 
    The following uses are excepted from the provisions hereof: 
(a)  Duly licensed new and used car and truck sales businesses may store motor vehicles in operating condition which do not bear currently valid motor vehicle registered license plates. 
(b)  Any person who purchases a motor vehicle and transfers to said motor vehicle registered license plates from an old vehicle which was not sold or traded in at the time of said purchase, shall be allowed a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days from the removal of said registered license plates to dispose of said old vehicle, provided that said old vehicle is in an operating condition. 
(c)  Under special hardship conditions or for the preservation of a historic or classic vehicle, a person may, by filing a timely request with the city council, be granted an extension of sixty (60) days to remove such vehicle from his or her property. The city council, or such administrative office as it may by resolution direct, may upon proper cause shown, grant an applicant a reasonable additional extension of time to remove said vehicle. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-74. - Removal of vehicle; serving or posting notice. 
    Regardless of whether a municipal civil infraction violation notice and/or a municipal civil infraction citation has or has not been issued for violation of section 13-71 or section 13-72, the Chief of Police may remove or cause to be removed any motor vehicle, body or chassis, or parts thereof, being in violation of this article, from any unenclosed private property after having given written notice to the owner or occupant of such property of his intention to so do at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to such removal. Such notice shall be personally served on the owner or occupant of the property, if occupied, or may be posted in a conspicuous place upon vacant or unoccupied property. Such motor vehicles, bodies, chassis or parts thereof shall either be removed to a place of storage or disposed of in accordance with law. The removal thereof, however, shall not excuse or relieve any responsible person from the obligation imposed by this article to keep his or her property free from nuisances as herein defined, nor from the penalties for the violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 19, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-75. - Municipal civil infraction; penalties. 
    The violation of, or failure to comply with any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 19, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 13-76-13-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ANIMALS 

Sec. 13-80. - Animals generally. 
    Animal means any living reptile or mammal, and shall include, but not be limited to; pigs, cows, cats, dogs, sheep, goats, chickens, ducks, rabbits, ponies, horses, snakes, livestock and fowl. 
    Keeping of certain animals is restricted. 
(1)  The keeping of any hogs or swine, cows, horses, goats, ducks, geese, doves, pigeons, chickens or other livestock or fowl within the limits of the city is declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. 
Exception: Chickens may be kept according to the following conditions: 
a.  A maximum of four (4) hens may be kept per parcel. Roosters are prohibited. 
b.  No person shall keep any chickens for slaughter. 
c.  Enclosure: 
(i)  Chickens must be kept in an enclosure or fenced area at all times. During daylight hours, chickens may be allowed outside their chicken pens in a securely fenced yard, subject to the provisions of article VII [of chapter 5] of the Code of Ordinances (Fence/Wall Ordinance), and only if supervised. Chickens shall be secured within the henhouse during non-daylight hours. 
(ii)  Enclosures must be clean, dry, and odor free, kept in a neat and sanitary condition at all times, in a manner that will not disturb the use and enjoyment of neighboring lots due to noise, odor or other adverse impact. 
(iii)  The hen house and chicken pen must provide adequate ventilation and adequate sun and shade. 
(iv)  Enclosures shall be located at least twenty-five (25) feet from any dwelling on a neighboring parcel. 
d.  Henhouse: 
(i)  A henhouse shall be provided and shall be designed to provide safe and healthy living conditions for the chickens while minimizing adverse impacts to other residents in the neighborhood. It shall be enclosed on all sides and shall have a roof and doors. Access doors shall be able to be shut and locked at night. Opening windows and vents must be covered with predator and bird proof wire of less than one (1) inch openings. 
e.  A person shall keep hens in the backyard only. For this subsection, "backyard" means the portion of a lot enclosed by the property's rear lot line and the side lot lines to the points where the side lot lines intersect with an imaginary line established by the rear of the single-family structure and extending to the side lot lines. 
f.  The owner or custodian of any chickens shall maintain the premises wherein such chickens are kept in a clean and sanitary condition, free from rodents, vermin and disagreeable odors. 
g.  All enclosures for the keeping of hens shall be constructed, repaired and maintained in a manner to prevent rat, mice or other rodents from being harbored underneath, within, or within the walls of the enclosure. 
h.  All feed and other items associated with the keeping of hens that are likely to attract or to become infested shall be so protected so as to prevent rats, mice or other rodents from gaining access to or coming into contact with them. 
i.  No chicken shall be kept on parcels with more than one (1) dwelling. 
j.  Private restrictions on the use of property shall remain enforceable and take precedence over the ordinance from which this section derives. Private restrictions include, but are not limited to, deed restrictions, condominium master deed restrictions, neighborhood association by-laws and covenant deeds. The interpretation and enforcement of this private restriction is the sole responsibility of the private parties involved. 
(2)  The keeping of all poisonous reptiles is prohibited. The keeping or sale of all wild or exotic reptiles or animals is prohibited, unless applicable state and/or federal licenses are obtained. 
(Ord. No. 2003-01, § 2, 2-24-03; Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 13-81. - Animals generally. 
(a)  No person shall cruelly treat or abuse any animal or bird. 
(b)  No person shall throw or deposit any poisonous substance in any exposed public or private place where it endangers or is likely to endanger, any animal or bird. 
(c)  No person, except a police officer acting in his official capacity, shall molest, injure, kill or capture any wild bird, or molest or disturb any wild bird's nest or the contents thereof.
