(d)  No person shall ride, drive or lead any horse, pony, donkey, or mule other than in the traveled roadway of streets and public ways except when upon privately owned property with the consent of the owner. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-82. - Dogs and cats-Leash law. 
(a)  It is deemed by the City of Milan the ownership of a dog and/or cat is a privilege which carries with it responsibilities to the city and its residents with regard to the care and custody of said dog and/or cat. 
(b)  For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply, and the word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory: 
(1)  The word "owner" shall include every person having a right to property in the dog and/or cat in question, every person who keeps or harbors such dog and/or cat or has it in his or her care, and every person who permits such dog and/or cat to remain in or about the premises occupied by him or her. For the purposes of this act, any person keeping or harboring any animal for seven (7) consecutive days shall be deemed the owner thereof within the meaning of this chapter. 
(2)  "Reasonable control" is a dog and/or cat which is (a) secured by a leash held by the owner, or some other person with the permission of the owner in all cases other than while upon private property of the owner, (b) or unless the dog and/or cat is confined in a closed automobile. 
(3)  A dog and/or cat shall be deemed to be "unconfined" anytime it shall be outside a building, fence or enclosure of its owner. 
(c)  It shall be considered a violation of this section for the owner of any dog and/or cat if their dog and/or cat is in breach of any of the following restrictions: 
(1)  No dog and/or cat shall be unconfined unless under reasonable control as herein defined. 
(2)  No dog shall be unconfined at any time unless licensed as required by law and unless wearing its license tag and evidencing rabies immunization. 
(3)  No female dog and/or cat shall be beyond the premises of such owner when the dog and/or cat is in heat. 
(4)  A dog/cat shall be deemed to be not under control when it shall defecate on any private or public property and its owner, agent or some member of his family shall fail to immediately clean up the area defecated upon by removing such waste material from the private or public property. 
(d)  Any dog or cat that is found at large within the city and which is in violation of any of the prohibitions enumerated in subsection (c) of this section may be seized and impounded by the dog warden or by any police officer of the city, and subject to the provisions of Public Act 114 of 1926, as amended. 
(e)  Violation of subsections (c) and (d) above shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs schedule adopted by resolution by city council. 
(f)  No vicious dog and/or cat shall be unconfined unless securely muzzled and led by a leash. Any dog and/or cat shall be deemed vicious which has bitten a person or domestic animal without molestation, or, which by its actions, gives indications that it is liable to bite any person or domestic animal without molestation. 
    Upon conviction for violation of any of the provisions of this subsection (f), the violator shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both, plus the costs of prosecution. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 20, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 2003-01, § 3, 2-24-03; Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 8-9-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, adopted Aug. 9, 2010, amended § 13-82 by changing the title from "Dogs and cats-Misdemeanor violations" to "Dogs and cats-Leash law." 
Sec. 13-83. - Same-Municipal civil infractions. 
(a)  No dog or cat shall at any time, by loud or frequent or habitual barking, yelping, howling, or otherwise crying out, cause annoyance to people in the surrounding neighborhood. 
(b)  No dog or cat shall be owned, harbored or kept which, by destruction of property or trespassing on the property of another, (may cause) a nuisance. 
(c)  All places of confinement or quarters for the housing and use of dogs and/or cats shall be kept in a sanitary condition and free from foul odors. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to possess, harbor, shelter or keep more than three (3) adult dogs, cats, or combination thereof, except kennels, veterinary hospitals, clinics, pet shops or nature preserves in properly zoned districts. 
(e)  Any person who shall have in his possession a dog and/or cat which has contracted rabies or which has been subjected to rabies, or which is suspected of having rabies, or which has bitten any person, shall upon demand of the police department or the health officer, produce and surrender up such dog and/or cat to the police department or their designee to be held for observation at a location to be chosen by the police department or health officer, at the sole cost of the owner of the animal, for such period of time as is determined to be necessary by a veterinarian licensed by the State of Michigan. 
(f)  Every person who owns or harbors a dog and/or cat which has been attacked or bitten by another dog and/or cat or other animal showing the symptoms of rabies shall immediately notify the police department of his or her possession of such dog and/or car. 
(g)  Violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 21, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 2011-02, § 2, 5-9-11) 
ARTICLE V. - NOISE CONTROL 

Sec. 13-84. - Noise control generally. 
    Each of the following acts is declared to constitute a municipal civil infraction and be prohibited, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  Animal and bird noises. The keeping of any animal or bird which, by causing frequent or long-continued noise, shall disturb the comfort or repose of any person. 
(2)  Construction noises. The erection (including excavating therefor), demolition, alteration or repair of any building, and the excavation of streets and highways, on Sundays, and other days except between the hours of 7:00 a. m. and 6:00 p. m., unless a permit is first obtained from the city. 
(3)  Sound amplifiers. Use of any loudspeaker, amplifier or other instrument or device, whether stationary or mounted on a vehicle for any purpose, except by speakers in the course of a public address which in noncommercial in character, shall be subject to the following restrictions: 
a.  A permit from the city must first be obtained. 
b.  Sound amplification permitted shall be limited to music or human speeches. 
c.  The permitted hours shall be limited to between the hours of 11:30 a. m. and 6:30 p. m., each day, excepting on Sundays and legal holidays during which no such use, other than the above excepted, shall be permitted. 
d.  Sound amplifying equipment mounted on vehicles shall not be operated unless the vehicle upon which such equipment is mounted is operated at a speed of at least ten (10) miles per hour except when the vehicle is stopped or impeded by traffic. 
e.  Sound amplification equipment shall not be used within one hundred (100) yards of schools or churches. 
f.  The volume of sound shall be controlled so that it will not be audible for a distance in excess of one hundred (100) feet from the sound amplifying equipment and so that it is not unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing, or otherwise a nuisance to persons within the area of audibility. 
g.  No sound amplifying equipment shall be operated with an excess of fifteen (15) watts of power in the last stage of amplification. 
(4)  Engine exhausts. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary, internal combustion engine, or motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which effectively prevents loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(5)  Handling merchandise. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening of destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers. 
(6)  Blowers. The discharge into the open air from any noise-creating blower or power fan unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled sufficiently. 
(7)  Hawking. The hawking of goods or merchandise, of any type, in a loud and boisterous manner. 
(8)  Radio and musical instruments. The playing of any radio, television set, phonograph, or any musical instrument in such volume, particularly during the hours between 11:00 p. m. and 7:00 a. m., or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, place of worship, school, dwelling unit, or other type or residence, or of any person in the vicinity. 
(9)  Shouting and whistling. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing or the making of any other loud noise on the public streets between the hours of 11:00 p. m. and 7:00 a. m., or the making of any such noise at any time as to disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, place of worship, school, dwelling unit, or other type or residence, or of any person in the vicinity. 
(10)  Whistle or siren The blowing of any whistle or siren, excepting the duly authorized sounding of a whistle or siren to give notice of the time to begin or stop work, for which a permit from the city setting forth reasonable controls has been issued, or as a warning of fire or danger. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 22, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 13-85. - Exceptions to section 13-84. 
    None of the terms or prohibitions of section 13-84 shall apply to or be enforced against: 
(a)  Emergency vehicles. Any police or fire vehicle or any ambulance, while engaged upon emergency business. 
(b)  Highway and construction. Excavations or repairs of bridges, streets, or highways by or on behalf of the City of Milan or State of Michigan. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-86. - Municipal civil infraction; penalty. 
    Violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 22, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 13-87-13-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MOTORBOATS 

Sec. 13-90. - Operation of motorboats. 
(a)  Any motorboat, launch or other watercraft, the motive power of which is an internal combustion engine using gas, gasoline, naphtha or other like energy, operated on the inland waters within the city shall be equipped with a stock factory muffler, underwater exhaust or other modern or improved device capable of adequately muffling the sound of the exhaust of such engine. Such muffler shall be kept and remain closed, and such exhaust or device shall be kept in proper working order by any person operating or in charge of such motorboat, launch or other watercraft, at all times when such engine is in operation, except in a publicly announced and properly supervised motorboat race, regatta or speed trial. The term "capable of adequately muffling the sound of the exhaust of such engine," as used in this section, shall be construed to mean that the motor's exhaust shall at all times be so muffled or suppressed as not to disturb the peace and quiet of persons in the locality. 
(b)  No such motorboat shall be operated on any of the inland waters within the city in a reckless manner or at an excessive rate of speed so as to endanger the life or property of any person in or on such waters, having due regard to the presence of other boats, bathers, persons engaged in fishing, or objects in or on such waters and of any other conditions then existing. No person shall operate such motorboat on such waters at a rate of speed greater than will permit him to bring it to a stop within the assured clear distance ahead. Provided, that nothing herein contained shall be in contravention of any existing valid state or federal regulation but shall be deemed in addition thereto where not inconsistent therewith. 
(c)  Any motorboat operated on the inland waters within the city during the period from one hour after sunset to one hour before sunrise shall be equipped with a light on the bow which can be plainly distinguished at a distance of five hundred (500) feet. 
(d)  Any officer duly authorized to make arrests, including any officer of the department of conservation, may and it shall be his duty to arrest without warrant any person violating any of the provisions of this section in his presence. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
Sec. 13-91. - Penalty. 
    Any violation of the provisions of this article shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), and/or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 82-9, § 1, 10-12-82) 
ARTICLE VII. - MASSAGE PARLORS, AND SIMILAR BUSINESSES AND MASSAGISTS 

Sec. 13-92. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall be construed to have the meanings as stated, unless it is apparent from the context that a different meaning is intended. 
    Person: Any individual, firm, corporation, partnership, association or other form of business organization or group. 
    Massage: A method of treating external parts of the body for remedial or hygienic purposes, consisting of rubbing, stroking, kneading, adjusting or tapping with the hand or any instrument, electric, magnetic or otherwise, with or without supplementary aids. 
    Massage parlor: Any Turkish bath parlor, steam bath, sauna bath, magnetic healing institute, or any room, place, establishment, institution where treatment of any nature for the human body is given by means of massage, as herein defined, and where a massage, alcohol rub, fomentation, bath, physiotherapy, manipulation of the body or similar treatment is given. 
    Massage school: A school which is recognized by the Michigan State Board of Massage, which requires for admission students with a tenth grade education or its equivalent, which employs one or more competent licensed massagists as instructors. For the purposes of this article, a correspondence school shall not be construed to be a recognized school. 
    Massagist: Any person, male or female, who administers to another person, for any form of consideration or gratuity, a massage, alcohol rub, fomentation, bath, electric or magnetic massage procedure, manipulation of the body or other similar procedure. 
    Student: Any person who, under the guidance of an instructor in a massage school, is being trained or instructed in the theory, method or practice of massage. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-93. - License required. 
    For the purpose of promoting and protecting the public health, safety and welfare of persons and property in the city, no person shall practice, engage in, carry on or operate the business of a massagist or conduct, operate and carry on a massage parlor, massage school, or similar business within the city without first having applied for and obtained the required city license; nor shall any person employ as a massagist any person who does not hold a current license as required by this article. No person shall practice massage for compensation without obtaining and maintaining in effect a license as a massagist as required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-94. - Requirements and duties. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of an owner, operator, manager or licensee in charge of or in control of a massage parlor, massage school or similar business to ensure that each person employed or engaged in such business as a massagist shall have first obtained a valid massagist license required by this article. 
(b)  Any owner, operator, manager or licensee in charge of or in control of a massage parlor, massage school or similar business who employs a person performing as a massagist as defined in this article who is not in possession of a valid massagist license or allows such an employee to perform, operate or practice within a massage parlor shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-95. - Application investigation fee. 
(a)  Any person desiring to obtain a license to operate a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, or to perform massage services shall submit a written application, in accordance with section 13-96, to the city clerk/treasurer, who shall refer all such applications to the chief of police for an investigation. 
(b)  Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable investigation fee in an amount to be set by the city council. This application fee shall be payable to the city clerk/treasurer at the time the application is filed with the city clerk/treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-96. - Application; requirements. 
    Any applicant for a license required herein shall submit the following information to the city clerk/treasurer: 
(1)  The full name and present address of the applicant. 
(2)  The two (2) previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of applicant and dates of residence, and all addresses of the applicant for the past five (5) years. 
(3)  A description of the service(s) to be provided. 
(4)  The location and mailing address of the proposed establishment. 
(5)  If the applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of each of the officers and directors of such corporation, the names and addresses of the registered agent of the corporation and of each stockholder, and the names and addresses of each owner of the property on which the use is proposed. 
(6)  If the applicant is a limited liability company, the names and addresses of each of the managers and members of the company, the name and address of the registered agent of the company, and the names and addresses of each owner of the property on which the use is proposed. 
(7)  If the applicant is a partnership, the names and addresses of each of the partners including limited partners. 
(8)  Written proof (birth certificate or sworn affidavits) that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(9)  The applicant's height, weight, sex, eye color, hair color, date of birth, location of birth, Social Security number, and any alias used in the past five (5) years. 
(10)  One portrait photograph of at least two inches by two inches (2? × 2?) and a complete set of the applicant's fingerprints which shall be taken by the chief of police or his agent. 
(11)  Business, occupation, or employment of the applicant for the three (3) years immediately preceding the date of the application, including the name and the address of the employers. 
(12)  A certificate from a medical or osteopathic doctor stating that the applicant has, within thirty (30) days immediately prior thereto, been examined and found to be free of any contagious or communicable disease. 
(13)  A statement of the history of the applicant in the operation of a massage parlor or similar business or occupation, including, but not limited to, whether or not such person, is [in] previously operating in this or another municipality or state under license, has had such license revoked or suspended and the reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation. 
(14)  All criminal convictions other than traffic violations, including the date of the conviction, nature of the conviction and the case number of the conviction. 
(15)  The application shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant. 
(16)  The following additional information shall be contained in any application for a license to conduct a massage parlor or similar business: The number of employees who intend to give massages; the names and qualifications of all such employees; and copies of all massagist licenses held by all such employees. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-97. - License procedures. 
(a)  In accordance with section 13-95, the city clerk/treasurer shall refer all license applications to the chief of police, who shall have a reasonable time in which to investigate the application and the background of the applicant. Based on such investigation, the chief of police, or his representative, shall render a recommendation as to the approval or denial of the license to the city clerk/treasurer. 
(b)  The chief of police, or his representative, shall recommend denial of an application if the character, reputation, moral integrity, or physical or mental condition of the applicant or his employees is found to be detrimental to the public health, safety, morals or general welfare of persons or property in the city. In making the recommendation, the chief of police, or representative, shall consider the following: 
(1)  Criminal history. All of the applicant's convictions, the reasons therefor, and the activities of the applicant subsequent to his/her conviction(s). 
(2)  License and permit history. The license and permit history of the applicant; whether such person has previously operated in the city or state or in another municipality or state under a license or permit; whether such person has had such license or permit revoked or suspended and the reasons therefor; and the activity of the applicant subsequent to such action. 
(c)  The city's building official, the Milan Area Fire Department and the county health officer shall inspect the premises proposed to be devoted to the massage parlor, massage school or similar business and shall make within a reasonable time separate recommendations to the city clerk/treasurer concerning compliance with the requirements of this article, all other city ordinances, and all other applicable laws and regulations. 
(d)  After receiving the appropriate recommendations, the city clerk/treasurer, or designee thereof, shall grant a license to the establishment only if all requirements for a massage parlor, massage school or similar business are met and shall issue a license to all persons who have applied to perform massage services in such establishment only if all the requirements for same are met. The city clerk/treasurer may properly deny either type of license for reasons including, but not limited to, a negative recommendation, supported by objective evidence, by any individual or entity listed in subsection (b) or (c) of this section. 
(e)  Any person denied a license pursuant to these provisions may submit a written appeal, within thirty (30) days of the denial, to the city council setting forth reasons why the license should be granted. The city council may grant or deny the license after a public hearing and such decision shall be final. Such public hearing shall be held within sixty (60) days from the date of the appeal. 
(f)  All licenses issued under this article are nontransferable; provided, however, a change of location of a massage parlor or similar business may be permitted pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-98. - Facility requirements. 
    No license to conduct a massage parlor, massage school or similar business shall be issued unless an inspection by the city reveals that the establishment complies with each of the following minimum requirements: 
(a)  A sign shall be posted at the main entrance identifying the establishment as a massage parlor or massage school, provided that all such signs shall comply with the sign requirements of the city. 
(b)  Minimum lighting shall be provided in accordance with the city building and electrical codes. 
(c)  Minimum ventilation shall be provided in accordance with the city building code. 
(d)  Adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing instruments used in performing the acts of massage shall be provided. 
(d)  Hot and cold running water shall be provided at all times. 
(f)  Closed cabinets shall be provided, which cabinets shall be used for the storage of clean linen. 
(g)  Adequate bathing, dressing, locker and toilet facilities shall be provided for patrons. A minimum of one tub or shower, one dressing room containing a separate locker with lock, one toilet and one wash basin shall be provided by every massage parlor; provided, however, that if male and female patrons are to be served simultaneously at the establishment, separate bathing, a separate massage room or rooms, separate dressing and separate toilet facilities shall be provided for male and female patrons. 
(h)  All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, bathtubs, steam rooms and all other physical facilities for this establishment must be kept in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. Wet and dry heat rooms, steam or vapor rooms, or steam or vapor cabinets, shower compartments, and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly cleaned each day of operation. Bathtubs and/or showers shall be thoroughly cleaned after each use. 
(i)  Clean and sanitary towels and linens shall be provided for each patron of the establishment. No common use of towels or linens shall be permitted. 
(j)  A minimum of one separate wash basin shall be provided in each massage parlor for the use of employees of any such establishment. The basin shall provide soap or detergent and hot and cold running water at all times and shall be located within or as close as practicable to the area devoted to the performing of massage services. In addition, there shall be provided at each wash basin, sanitary towels placed in permanently installed dispensers. 
(k)  No massage shall be performed in a massage parlor, massage school, or similar business in a private room which is completely closed to the view of other persons; however, reasonable measures may be used to offer privacy to patrons such as partitions, stalls, curtains and the like. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-99. - Inspections. 
(a)  Every establishment being operated as a massage parlor, massage school or similar business shall be subject to inspection by the city during operating hours for the purpose of enforcing any of the provisions of this article relating to the public health, safety and welfare of persons and property in the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse entry to premises in which a massage parlor, massage school, or similar business is being operated to any city official or authorized agent for the purpose of making an inspection contemplated by this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-100. - License fee. 
    Any person granted a license to operate a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, or to administer massages, shall pay to the city clerk/treasurer an annual fee in an amount specified in the city's official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. The license year shall be from the period from the date of license issuance to the next December 31, inclusive, unless otherwise provided. All licenses issued for the license year shall expire on the thirty-first day of December unless suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-101. - Medical certification. 
    Each person performing massage services shall be required to obtain a medical certification every six (6) months as required under section 13-96(11), to be produced upon request of a city official or agent performing an inspection under this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-102. - License renewal. 
    The holder of any license to operate a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, or a license to perform massage services, shall renew the same at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date of expiration. The license shall be renewed only if the applicant submits a sworn affidavit that the matters contained in the original application are correct and only after the city clerk/treasurer determines, after receiving the appropriate recommendations pursuant to section 13-97, that all of the requirements set forth in this article continue to be met. In addition to the affidavit, the applicant must submit a signed statement from a doctor stating that the applicant for a massagist's license has been examined within thirty (30) days prior to the reapplication and found to be free from any contagious or communicable disease. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-103. - Display of license. 
    All licenses required and granted under this article shall be displayed in a conspicuous place so that it may be readily seen by persons entering the premises where the massage, bath or treatment is given. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-104. - Unlawful activities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to massage any other person, or give or administer any bath or baths, or to give or administer similar treatments for illegal purposes, or for monetary gain or profit [or to] have any contact with a persons' breast, genital area or buttocks in a manner intended to arouse, appeal to or gratify a person's lust, passions or sexual desire. Any violation of this provision shall be deemed grounds for revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-105. - Employees. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the holder of the license for the massage parlor or similar business, or the employer of any person purporting to act as massagist, to ensure that each person operating as a massagist shall first have obtained a valid license pursuant to the provisions of this article. All other employees of the massage parlor or similar business shall provide annually to the city clerk/treasurer's office a medical certificate stating that the applicant has, within thirty (30) days immediately prior thereto, been examined and found to be free of any contagious or communicable disease. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-106. - Clothing apparel. 
    Uniforms or garments covering the torso shall be worn by massagists or employees while attending patrons. Such uniforms or garments shall opaquely cover the massagist's genital areas, breasts and buttocks. Such uniforms or garments shall be washable material and shall be kept in a clean condition. The sleeves of the uniform or garment shall not reach below the elbow. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-107. - Patronage of massage business by minors. 
    No person licensed as a massagist shall massage or treat any person under the age of seventeen (17) years upon the licensed premises, except upon written order by a licensed medical doctor, doctor of osteopathic medicine, or physical therapist, such order being dated and in the possession of the massagist giving the massage or treatment. If the person under the age of seventeen (17) years is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian during the massage or treatment, this provision shall not apply. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-108. - Name of business. 
    No person licensed under this article shall operate under any name or conduct the licensed business under any designation not specified in the license. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-109. - Hours of operation. 
    No massage parlor, massage school, or similar business shall be open to the public for business between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-110. - Revocation and suspension of license. 
(a)  No license issued pursuant to this article shall be revoked until after a hearing before the city council to determine just cause for such revocation. The city clerk/treasurer, the building official, or the chief of police may order any such license suspended pending such hearing, and it shall be unlawful for any person to carry on the business of a massagist or to operate as a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, depending upon the particular type of license which has been suspended, until the suspended license has been reinstated by the city council. Notice of such hearing shall be given in writing and served at least five (5) days prior to the date of the hearing. The notice shall state the grounds of the complaint against the holder of the license or against the business carried on by the licensee at the establishment and shall state the time and place where the hearing shall be held. In cases where a license issued pursuant to this article is suspended in accordance with this section 13-110, such hearing shall be held within sixty (60) days from the date of such suspension. 
(b)  The notice shall be served upon the licensee by delivering it to the person or by leaving the notice at the place of business or residence of the licensee in the custody of a person of suitable age and discretion. In the event the licensee cannot be found and the service of the notice cannot be made in this matter, a copy of the notice shall be mailed, postage fully prepaid, addressed to the licensee at his place of business or residence and posted conspicuously on the premises at least five (5) days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-111. - Sale or transfer. 
(a)  Upon the sale or transfer of any interest in a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, the existing license for such business shall be null and void. A new application shall be made by the person(s), firm or entity desiring to own or operate the massage parlor, massage school or similar business. 
(b)  Any sale or transfer of any interest in an existing massage establishment or any application for an extension of the building or other place of business of the massage establishment shall require inspection and shall require compliance with section 13-97. Any person granted a license to operate a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, or to administer massages, shall pay to the city clerk/treasurer an annual fee in an amount specified in the city's official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-112. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to the following: 
(a)  Medical doctors, doctors of osteopathic medicine, doctors of chiropractic medicine, physical therapists, psychiatrists, psychologists, clinical social workers, and family counselors, who are licensed to practice their respective professions in the State of Michigan. 
(b)  Nurses who are registered under the laws of this state and who administer a massage in the normal course of nursing duties. 
(c)  A trainer of any duly constituted athletic team who administers a massage in the normal course of training duties. 
(d)  Barbers and beauticians who are duly licensed under the laws of this state and who administer a massage in the normal course of their duties. 
(e)  Participants in growth seminars or sensitivity sessions provided such seminars or sessions are conducted by a member of one of the exempted professions defined in this section above. 
(g)  Any duly licensed establishment in which only the above described persons exclusively practice their respective professions. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Sec. 13-113. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment for not more than ninety days (90) in the county jail or both such fine and imprisonment for each violation. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation for purposes of this section. 
(Ord. No. 97-2, § 1, 11-10-97) 
Secs. 13-114-13-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - DRUG PARAPHERNALIA 

Sec. 13-131. - Definitions. 
    The term "drug paraphernalia" as used in this article means any equipment, product or material of any kind or nature whatsoever which is used, intended for use or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packing, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  An isomerization device specifically designed for use in increasing the potency of any species of plant which plant is a controlled substance. 
(2)  Testing equipment specifically designed for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness, or purity of a controlled substance. 
(3)  A weight scale or balance specifically designed for use in weighing or measuring a controlled substance. 
(4)  A diluent or adulterant, including, but not limited to, quinine hydrochloride, mannitol, mannite, dextrose, and lactose, specifically designed for use with a controlled substance. 
(5)  A separation gin or sifter specifically designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from, or in otherwise cleaning or refining, marihuana. 
(6)  An object specifically designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marihuana, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body. 
(7)  A kit specifically designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, or harvesting any species of plant which is a controlled substance or from which a controlled substance can be derived. 
(8)  A kit specifically designed for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, or preparing controlled substances. 
(9)  A device, commonly known as a cocaine kit, that is specifically designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing controlled substances into the human body, and which consists of at least a razor blade and a mirror or other item used in lieu of a mirror. 
(10)  A device commonly known as a bullet, that is specifically designed to deliver a measured amount of controlled substances to the user. 
(11)  A device, commonly known as a snorter, that is specifically designed to carry a small amount of controlled substances to the user's nose. 
(12)  A device, commonly known as an automotive safe, that is specifically designed to carry and conceal a controlled substance in an automobile, including, but not limited to, a can used for brake fluid, oil, or carburetor cleaner which contains a compartment for carrying and concealing controlled substances. 
(13)  A spoon, with or without a chain attached, that has a small diameter bowl and that is specifically designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing controlled substances into the human body. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 6-10-02) 
Sec. 13-132. - Purpose. 
    This article is enacted to preserve the health, safety and welfare of the people of the city by rendering unlawful the manufacture, sale, use, delivery, possession or distribution, or the attempt to manufacture, sell, use, deliver, possess or distribute drug paraphernalia. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 6-10-02) 
Sec. 13-133. - Possession of drug paraphernalia. 
    It is unlawful for any person, business entity or corporation to use, or to possess with intent to use, drug paraphernalia. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 3, 6-10-02) 
Sec. 13-134. - Manufacture, sale or delivery of drug paraphernalia. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell, deliver, possess with intent to deliver or sell, or manufacture with intent to deliver or sell, drug paraphernalia. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 4, 6-10-02) 
Sec. 13-135. - Advertisement of drug paraphernalia. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place in any newspaper, magazine, handbill, or other publication distributed in the city any advertisement, the purpose of which, in whole or in part, is to promote the sale of any object designed or intended for use as drug paraphernalia. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 5, 6-10-02) 
Sec. 13-136. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to manufacturers, wholesalers, jobbers, licensed medical technicians, technologists, nurses, hospitals, research teaching institutions, clinical laboratories, medical doctors, osteopathic physicians, dentists, chiropodists, veterinarians, law enforcement agencies, pharmacists and embalmers in the lawful course of business or professional activity, nor to persons suffering from any medical condition which repairs administering prescribed medication. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 6, 6-10-02) 
Sec. 13-137. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of any provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both. Each day a violation continues shall be considered a separate offense and may be punished accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 10, 6-10-02) 
Secs. 13-138-13-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - POSSESSION AND/OR SALE OF CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES 

Sec. 13-150. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Controlled substance means any drug, immediate precursor or substance, by whatever official, common, usual, chemical, or trade name known, that is delineated in Schedules 1 through 5 of Part 72 of the Michigan Public Health Code, being MCL 333.7201 through MCL 333.7231, as amended. 
    Drug means: 
(1)  A substance and/or synthetic equivalent that is recognized as a drug in the official United States Pharmacopoeia, official Homeopathic Pharmacopoeia of the United States, or official National Formulary, or any supplement to any of them; or 
(2)  A substance that is intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease in human beings or animals; or 
(3)  A substance, other than food, that is intended to affect the structure or function of the body of human beings or animals; or 
(4)  A substance that is intended for use as a component of any substance specified within this definition. 
    Identification card means a card that is issued by an authorized provider which: 
(1)  Permits the staff and volunteers of a needle-exchange program to pick up from, and distribute hypodermic syringes or needles to, participants in a needle-exchange program, and 
(2)  Permits the participants in a needle-exchange program to possess hypodermic syringes or needles. 
    Immediate precursor means a substance which the Michigan Board of Pharmacy, or its designated or established authority, has found to be and by rule designates as being the principal compound commonly used or produced primarily for use, and which is an immediate chemical intermediary used or likely to be used in the manufacture of a controlled substance, the control of which is necessary to prevent, curtail, or limit manufacture. 
    Prescription form means a printed form which is authorized and intended for use by a prescribing practitioner to prescribe a controlled substance or a prescription drug and which meets the requirements of rules promulgated by the Michigan Board of Pharmacy, or its designated or established authority. 
(Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 13-151. - Possession, sale, etc., prohibited generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, sell, offer for sale, distribute, administer, dispense, prescribe or give away any controlled substance for which the unlawful possession, sale, offer for sale, distribution, administration, dispensation, prescription, or giving away is punishable by imprisonment for not more than one (1) year under any of the provisions contained within Part 74 of the Michigan Public Health Code, being MCL 333.7401 through MCL 333.7461; MSA 14.15(7401) through 14.15(7461), provided, that this division shall not be construed to prohibit the possession, sale, offer for sale, distribution, administration, dispensation, or prescription of any controlled substance, or its derivative, in accordance with this division. 
(Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 13-152. - Dispensing by authorized persons; controlled substances obtained pursuant to this section to be kept in original package. 
(a)  A manufacturer, wholesaler, apothecary, medical doctor, osteopathic physician, dentist, veterinarian, chiropodist who, or a public or private hospital, sanitarium or institution which, treats in whole or in part a disability, disease, inebriety or controlled substance addiction, may purchase, receive, possess, sell, distribute, prescribe, administer or dispense a controlled substance, provided, that: 
(1)  The individual or entity shall comply with all provisions contained within Part 73 of the Michigan Public Health Code, being MCL 333.7301 through MCL 333.7341; MSA 14.15(7301) through 14.15(7341); and 
(2)  Neither a medical doctor, osteopathic physician, or other person specified in this section, who is authorized to prescribe any controlled substance, shall prescribe such substance for his or her own use, nor shall any pharmacist honor such a prescription form. 
(b)  Any controlled substance obtained pursuant to this section shall be kept in its original package or container, provided, that this requirement shall not be construed to apply to any duly licensed medical doctor, osteopathic physician, dentist, veterinarian, or chiropodist, or to any authorized person or persons acting directly under their supervision or control. 
(Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 13-153. - Exceptions for possession of controlled substances. 
    The provisions of this [article] that restrict the possession of any controlled substance, or any derivative, compound, preparation, or mixture thereof shall not apply: 
(1)  To common carriers or warehousemen, or their employees, while engaged in the lawful transportation or storage of a controlled substance; or 
(2)  To manufacturers, wholesalers, jobbers, licensed medical technicians, technologists, nurses, hospitals, research teaching institutions, clinical laboratories, medical doctors, osteopathic physicians, dentists, chiropodists, veterinarians, pharmacists, and embalmers, or their employees, while engaged in the normal legal course of their respective business or profession; or 
(3)  To public officers or employees while engaged in the performance of their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 13-154. - Fraud and deceit in obtaining controlled substances by, and unauthorized use of, a prescription form prohibited. 
(a)  Any fraud, deceit, misrepresentation, subterfuge, or concealment of a material fact, including providing a false name or a false address for the purpose of obtaining any controlled substance or providing a false statement on any prescription form, shall be deemed a violation of this division. 
(b)  A person who has obtained the possession of any controlled substance shall not use the same, or permit or authorize its use, for any purpose other than that specifically provided for by the prescription form. 
(Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 13-155. - Presence in places where controlled substances are illegally stored or kept prohibited. 
    A person shall not knowingly remain in any building, apartment, store, automobile, boat, boathouse, airplane, or any other place where any controlled substance is illegally sold, dispensed, furnished, given away, stored, or kept with the intent to unlawfully use or possess such controlled substance. 
(Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 13-156. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall be convicted of violating any provision of this division shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both in the discretion of the court. 
(b)  Each day a violation continues shall be considered a separate offense and may be punished accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 13-157. - Civil forfeiture. 
    Any controlled substance that is manufactured with intent to sell, possessed with intent to use or sell, used, or sold in violation of this division shall be seized and forfeited to the City of Milan. 
(Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 13-158. - Exceptions for medical marihuana. 
    The provisions of this [article] shall not apply to any individual possessing or using marihuana under the direction, prescription, supervision, or guidance of a physician or other licensed medical professional. As used in this subsection, "physician or other licensed medical professional" means a person licensed under Article 15 of the Public Health Code, MCL 333.16101 to 333.18838; MSA 14.15(16101) to 14.15 (18838). 
(Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 6-25-12) 
Secs. 13-159-13-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - THEFT 

Sec. 13-170. - Third degree retail fraud, penalty for violation. 
    A person who does any of the following in a store or in its immediate vicinity is guilty of retail fraud in the third degree, a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than ninety-three (93) days or a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or three (3) times the value of the difference in price, property stolen, or money or property obtained or attempted to be obtained, whichever is greater, or both imprisonment and a fine: 
(1)  While a store is open to the public, alters, transfers, removes and replaces, conceals, or otherwise misrepresents the price at which property is offered for sale, with the intent not to pay for the property or to pay less than the price at which the property is offered for sale, if the resulting difference in price is less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(2)  While a store is open to the public, steals property of the store that is offered for sale at a price of less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(3)  With intent to defraud, obtains or attempts to obtain money or property from the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for and belongs to the store, if the amount of money, or the value of the property, obtained or attempted to be obtained is less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 6, 2-23-15) 
Sec. 13-171. - Defrauding purveyor of food and lodging, presumption, penalty for violation. 
(a)  Hotels, motels, inns, restaurants, cafes. No person shall procure any food, entertainment or accommodation at any hotel, motel, inn, restaurant or cafe, without paying therefor, except when credit is given therefor by express agreement. Failure to pay with intent to defraud such keeper thereof, out of payment for food, entertainment or accommodation shall constitute a misdemeanor upon conviction. Complaint must be made within sixty (60) days of the violation hereof. 
(b)  Boardinghouses, lodginghouses, roominghouses. No person shall procure any food, entertainment or accommodation at any boardinghouse, lodginghouse or roominghouse without paying therefor, except when credit is given therefor by express agreement. Failure to pay with intent to defraud such keeper thereof, out of payment for food, entertainment or accommodation shall constitute a misdemeanor upon conviction. Complaint must be made within ten (10) days of the violation hereof. 
(c)  Presumption of intent. Obtaining food, entertainment or accommodation by false pretenses, whereby false or fictitious show of baggage or other property, or refusal or neglect to pay therefor on demand, or payment therefor with check, draft or order upon a bank or other depository upon which payment was refused, or absconding without paying or offering to pay therefor, or surreptitiously removing or attempting to remove baggage, shall be prima facie evidence of such intent to defraud. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or ninety (90) days in the county jail or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 6, 2-23-15) 
Sec. 13-172. - Larceny, penalty for violation. 
    No person shall commit the crime of larceny by taking any property not his own and to which he has no claim or right with the intent to permanently deprive the owner of lawful possession, or receive or possess any such property knowing the same to be stolen. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or ninety (90) days in the county jail or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 6, 2-23-15) 
Sec. 13-173. - Fraudulent schemes, penalty for violation. 
    No person shall engage in any fraudulent scheme, trick or device, to obtain money or other valuable things from another person, nor shall any person aid or assist such trick or scheme to obtain money or other valuable things. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or ninety (90) days in the county jail or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 6, 2-23-15) 
Sec. 13-174. - Taking bicycle without permission, penalty for violation. 
    No person shall knowingly take possession of and ride or take away any bicycle without the express or implied permission of the owner. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or ninety (90) days in the county jail or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 6, 2-23-15) 
Sec. 13-175. - Checks without sufficient funds, presumption, penalty for violation. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person with intent to defraud, shall make or draw or utter or deliver any check, draft or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository, knowing at the time of such making, drawing, uttering or delivering, that the maker, or drawer, has not sufficient funds in or credit with such bank or other depository, for the payment of such check, draft, or order, in full, upon its presentation. 
(b)  Presumption when payment refused. As against the maker or drawer thereof, the making, drawing, uttering or delivering of a check, draft or order, payment of which is refused by the drawee, when presented in the usual course of business, shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and of knowledge of insufficient funds in or credit with such bank or other depository, provided such maker or drawer shall not have paid the drawee thereof the amount due thereon, together with all costs and protest fees, within five (5) days after receiving notice that such check, draft or order has not been paid by the drawee. 
(c)  Presumption based on notice of protest. Where such check, draft or order is protested, on the ground of insufficiency of funds or credit, the notice of protest thereof shall be admissible as proof of presentation, nonpayment and protest, and shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud, and of knowledge of insufficient funds or credit with such bank or other depository. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or ninety (90) days in the county jail or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 6, 2-23-15) 
Sec. 13-176. - Connecting to utility or cable without permission, penalty for violation. 
    No person shall make or maintain an operating connection to a public utility, private utility, or cable facilities without the permission of the owner of such utility or facilities. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or ninety (90) days in the county jail or both such fine and imprisonment for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 6, 2-23-15) 
Chapter 131/4 - MUNICIPAL CIVIL INFRACTIONS 

Sec. 131/4-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings specified below: 
    Act means Act. No. 236 of the Public Acts of 1961, as amended. 
    Authorized city official means any of the following individuals: (i) any sworn officer of the Milan Police Department; (ii) the Milan Building and Zoning Official; (iii) the director of public works; (iv) the department of public works foreman; and/or (v) the superintendent of the wastewater treatment plant, each and all of whom are authorized to issue municipal civil infraction citations and municipal civil infraction violation notices. 
    Bureau means the City of Milan Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau established by this chapter. 
    Municipal civil infraction means an act or omission that is prohibited by the city ordinances and sections of ordinances specified in section 131/4-14 of this chapter and/or by an ordinance or section of an ordinance which states that a violation of its terms is a municipal civil infraction. 
    Municipal civil infraction action means a civil action in which the defendant is alleged to be responsible for a municipal civil infraction, including but not limited to a trailway municipal civil infraction. 
    Municipal civil infraction citation means a written complaint or notice prepared by an authorized city official, directing a person to appear in court regarding the occurrence or existence of a municipal civil infraction violation by the person cited. 
    Municipal civil infraction determination means a determination that a person is responsible for a municipal civil infraction by one of the following: 
(1)  An admission of responsibility for the civil infraction; 
(2)  An admission of responsibility for the civil infraction "with explanation"; 
(3)  A preponderance of the evidence at a formal or informal hearing on the question; or, 
(4)  A default judgment for failing to appear at a scheduled appearance for a hearing as directed by a citation or other notice. 
    Municipal civil infraction violation notice and Municipal ordinance violation notice both mean a written notice, other than a "municipal civil infraction citation," prepared by an authorized city official, directing a person to appear at the City of Milan Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau and to pay the fine and costs if any, prescribed pursuant to this chapter, for the violation of an ordinance or ordinance section, the violation of which is a municipal civil infraction. 
    Trailway municipal civil infraction means a municipal civil infraction involving the operation of a motor vehicle on a recreational trailway at a time, in a place, or in a manner prohibited by an ordinance or section of an ordinance, which specifies that a violation of its terms constitutes a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-2. - Bureau established; staffing; rules and regulations. 
    In accordance with the provisions of Section 8396 of the Act, the City of Milan Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau is hereby established for and in the City of Milan. The Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau shall be organized and operated in accordance with the provisions of the Act. The Bureau shall be located at the Milan City Hall, and shall be under the supervision and control of the city administrator. The hours of operation of the bureau shall be set by resolution of the city council. The staffing of the bureau shall be fixed by the city administrator using qualified city employees, subject to approval by the city council. The city administrator, subject to approval by the city council, may also adopt rules and regulations for the operation of the bureau. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-3. - Disposition of violations. 
    The bureau may dispose of only those municipal civil infraction violations for which a minimum fine has been scheduled and for which a municipal civil infraction violation notice (as opposed to a citation) has been issued. The mere fact that a minimum fine has been scheduled for a particular violation shall not entitle any person to dispose of a violation at the bureau. Nothing contained in this chapter shall prevent or restrict the city from issuing a municipal civil infraction citation for any violation or from prosecuting any violation in a court of competent jurisdiction. No person shall be required to dispose of a municipal civil infraction violation at the bureau and, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, may instead have the violation processed before a court of competent jurisdiction. The unwillingness of any person to dispose of any violation at the bureau shall not prejudice the person or in any way diminish the person's rights, privileges or protection accorded by law. The bureau shall be responsible for accepting admissions of responsibility for the municipal civil infractions referenced in the first sentence of this section, and for the collection and retention of all civil fines and costs imposed therefor, pursuant to the schedule provided for in section 131/4-13 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-4. - Commencement of a municipal civil infraction action; service of citation. 
(a)  A municipal civil infraction action is commended upon the issuance of a citation meeting the requirements specified in Act No. 12, Public Acts of 1994. An authorized city official may issue a citation to a "person", as defined in section 1-2 of the Milan City Code, under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  The authorized city official witnesses the person violate an ordinance, the violation of which is a municipal civil infraction; 
(2)  Based upon investigation, the authorized city official has reasonable cause to believe that the person is responsible for a municipal civil infraction; 
(3)  Based upon investigation of a complaint by someone who allegedly witnessed the person violate an ordinance, the violation of which is a municipal civil infraction, the authorized city official has reasonable cause to believe that the person is responsible for a municipal civil infraction and, the prosecuting attorney or other attorney for the city approves in writing issuance of the citation. 
(b)  Except in the case of a trailway municipal civil infraction which caused damage to a natural resource or facility or which resulted in the impoundment of the involved vehicle by an authorized city official, upon the occurrence of any of the circumstances specified in subsection (a) of this section, the authorized city official shall prepare and subscribe, as soon as possible and as completely as possible, an original and three copies of the citation. The place specified in a citation for appearance shall be the district court having territorial jurisdiction over the place where the municipal civil infraction occurred, and the time specified in the citation for appearance shall be within a reasonable time after the citation is issued. 
(c)  A citation for a municipal civil infraction signed by an authorized city official shall be treated as made under oath if the violation alleged in the citation occurred in the presence of the authorized city official signing the complaint and if the citation contains the following statement immediately above the date and signature of the official: "I declare under penalties of perjury that the statements above are true to the best of my information, knowledge, and belief." 
(d)  In a municipal civil infraction action which involves the use or occupancy of land or a building or other structure, a copy of the citation need not be personally served upon the alleged violator but may be served upon an owner or occupant of the land, building, or structure by posting the copy on the land or attaching the copy to the building or structure. In addition, a copy of the citation shall be sent by first-class mail to the owner of the land, building, or structure at the owner's last known address. In all other municipal civil infraction actions, the authorized city official shall personally serve the third copy of the citation on the alleged violator. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-5. - No fee for issuance of citation; false statements in citations; penalties for violation. 
(a)  An authorized city official issuing a citation under this chapter for a municipal civil infraction shall not accept a fee for issuing the citation. An authorized city official who violates this subsection (a) is guilty of misconduct in office and subject to removal from office. 
(b)  An authorized city official who, knowing the statement is false, makes a materially false statement in a citation issued under this chapter is guilty of perjury, a felony punishable by imprisonment for not more than fifteen (15) years, and in addition is in contempt of court. 
Sec. 131/4-6. - Issuance of municipal ordinance violation notice; payment of fine and costs; effect of failure to admit responsibility and pay civil fine and costs and subsequent actions; notices issued to minors. 
(a)  Except in the case of a trailway municipal civil infraction which caused damage to a natural resource or facility or which resulted in the impoundment of the involved vehicle by an authorized city official, an authorized city official may issue and serve a municipal ordinance violation notice, instead of a citation, under the same circumstances and upon the same persons as provided in section 131/4-4 of this chapter for the service of a citation. 
(b)  The person to whom a municipal ordinance violation notice is issued under this chapter shall appear at the Milan Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau and there pay the fine and costs prescribed under this chapter for the municipal civil infraction at issue on or before the date specified on the municipal ordinance violation notice. 
(c)  If a municipal ordinance violation notice is issued under this chapter and the person to whom it is issued does not make an admission of responsibility and pay, at the Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau, the prescribed civil fine and costs prescribed pursuant to this chapter for the violation, a citation may be filed with the district court having jurisdiction over the municipal civil infraction and a copy of the citation may be served by first-class mail upon alleged violator at his or her last known address. The citation shall consist of a sworn complaint containing the allegations stated in the municipal ordinance violations notice and shall fairly inform the defendant how to respond to the citation. A citation issued under this section shall be processed in the same manner as a citation served personally upon a defendant pursuant to section 131/4-4 of this chapter. 
(d)  If the person to whom a municipal ordinance violation notice is issued under this chapter is under the age of seventeen (17) at the time of the occurrence of the violation and such person does not make an admission of responsibility and pay, at the Municipal Ordinance Violations Bureau, the civil fine and costs prescribed pursuant to this chapter for the violation, and a citation is thereafter issued for the municipal civil infraction, the juvenile division of the probate court of the county where the violation is alleged to have occurred shall have jurisdiction over the proceedings and shall proceed to hear and dispose of the case, as provided by chapter XIIA of Act. No. 288 of the Public Acts of 1939, being sections 712A.1 to 712A.28 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-7. - Options of person to whom citation is issued; formal and informal hearings; failure to appear; citations issued to minors. 
(a)  The defendant to whom a citation for a municipal civil infraction is issued shall appear by or at the time specified in the citation and, except as provided in subsection (e) of this section 131/4-7, may respond to the allegations in the citation as provided in this section 131/4-7. 
(b)  If the defendant wishes to admit responsibility for the municipal civil infraction, the defendant may do so by appearing in person, by representation, or by mail. Upon acceptance of the admission, the court may order any of the sanctions permitted by MCL § 600.8727. 
(c)  If the defendant wishes to admit responsibility for the municipal civil infraction "with explanation," the defendant may do so in either of the following ways: 
(1)  By appearing by mail; or 
(2)  By contacting the court in person, by mail, by telephone, or by representation to obtain from the court a scheduled date and time for an appearance, at which time the defendant shall appear in court, in person or by representation. 
The court shall accept the admission as though the defendant had admitted responsibility under subsection (b) of this section and may consider the defendant's explanation by way of mitigating any sanction that the court may order under MCL § 600.8727. The court may also require the defendant to provide a further explanation or to appear in court. 
(d)  If the defendant wishes to deny responsibility for a municipal civil infraction, the defendant shall do so by appearing for an informal or formal hearing. If the hearing date is not specified on the citation, the defendant shall contact the court in person, by representation, by mail, or by telephone, and obtain a scheduled date and time to appear for an informal or formal hearing. If the hearing date is specified on the citation, the defendant shall appear on that date. The hearing shall be an informal hearing, unless a formal hearing is requested by the defendant or the plaintiff as provided by MCL § 600.8717. The party requesting a formal hearing must be received both by the court and the other parties at least ten (10) days before the hearing date. If a hearing is scheduled by telephone, the court shall mail the defendant a confirming notice of that hearing by regular mail to the address appearing on the citation or to an address that is furnished by the defendant. 
(e)  An authorized city official issuing a citation for a trailway municipal civil infraction which caused damage to a natural resource or facility or which resulted in the impoundment of the involved vehicle by the authorized city official shall require the defendant to appear at a formal hearing. 
(e)  If the defendant fails to appear as directed by the citation or other notice at a scheduled appearance under this section, at a scheduled informal hearing, or at a scheduled formal hearing, the court shall enter a default judgment against the defendant. Except in the case of a trailway municipal civil infraction which caused damage to a natural resource or facility or which resulted in the impoundment of the involved vehicle by an authorized city official, the return of the citation with an admission of responsibility and with full payment of applicable civil fines and costs, return of the citation with an admission of responsibility with explanation, or timely application to the court for a scheduled date and time for an appearance at which to admit responsibility with explanation or for an informal or formal hearing constitutes a timely appearance. 
(f)  If the person cited for the municipal civil infraction is under the age of seventeen (17) at the time of the occurrence of the violation, the juvenile division of the probate court of the county where the violation is alleged to have occurred has jurisdiction over the proceedings and shall proceed to hear and dispose of the case, as provided by chapter XIIA of Act. No. 288 of the Public Acts of 1939, being sections 712A.1 to 712A.28 of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-8. - Necessity of sworn complaint. 
    If an authorized city official issued a citation under section 131/4-4 or section 131/4-6 of this chapter, the district court may accept an admission with explanation or an admission or denial of responsibility upon the citation without a sworn complaint. If the defendant denies responsibility for the municipal civil infraction, further proceedings shall not be held until a sworn complaint is filed with the court. A warrant for arrest for failure to appear on the municipal civil infraction citation shall not be issued until a sworn complaint is filed with the court. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-9. - Conduct of formal and informal hearings; witness fees. 
(a)  An informal hearing shall be conducted pursuant to MCL § 600.8719, and a formal hearing shall be conducted pursuant to MCL § 600.8721. 
(b)  There shall not be a jury at an informal hearing. At an informal hearing, the defendant shall not be represented by an attorney and the city shall not be represented by the prosecuting attorney or city attorney. Notice of a scheduled informal hearing shall be given to the city. The city and defendant may subpoena witnesses. If a judge or district court magistrate determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the defendant is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, the judge or magistrate shall enter an order against the defendant as provided in MCL § 600.8727. Otherwise, a judgment shall be entered for the defendant, but the defendant is not entitled to costs for the action. The city and defendant are entitled to appeal the decision of an informal hearing. The appeal shall be de novo in the form of a scheduled formal hearing. An appeal from a district court judge shall be heard by a different judge of the district, and an appeal from a district court magistrate shall be heard by a judge of the district. 
(c)  A formal hearing shall be conducted only by a judge of the district court. In a formal hearing, the defendant may be represented by an attorney, but is not entitled to appointed counsel at public expense. Notice of a formal hearing shall be given to the prosecuting attorney or the city attorney. The attorney for the city shall appear in court for a formal hearing and is responsible for the issuance of a subpoena to each witness for the city. The defendant may also subpoena witnesses. There shall not be a jury trial in a formal hearing. If the judge determines by the preponderance of all evidence that the defendant is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, the judge shall enter an order against the defendant as provided in MCL § 600.8727. Otherwise, a judgment shall be entered for the defendant, but the defendant is not entitled to costs of the action. 
(d)  Witness fees need not be paid in advance to a witness. Witness fees to a witness on behalf of the city are payable by the district control unit of the district court where the hearing occurs, or by the city if the hearing involves an ordinance violation in a district where the district court is not functioning. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-10. - Costs to be imposed; recipient of costs; writs and orders. 
(a)  If a defendant is determined to be responsible or responsible "with explanation" and is ordered to pay a civil fine, the district judge or magistrate shall summarily tax and determine the costs of the action, which are not limited to the costs taxable in ordinary civil actions and may include all expenses, direct and indirect, to which the plaintiff has been put in connection with the municipal civil infraction, up to the entry of judgment. Costs of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be ordered. Except as otherwise provided by law, costs shall be payable to the general fund of the city. 
(b)  In addition to ordering the defendant to pay a civil fine, costs and, in the case of certain trailway municipal civil infraction actions, damages and expense, the judge or district court magistrate may issue and enforce any judgment, writ or order necessary to enforce the ordinance at issue, and shall have equitable jurisdiction and authority concurrent with that of the circuit court in matters and to the extent necessary to do so. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 2018-03, § 1, 7-9-18) 
Sec. 131/4-11. - Rights of city upon defendant's default in payment of civil fine, costs, damages and/or expenses. 
    Upon the default by a defendant in a municipal civil infraction action in the payment of any civil fine, costs, damages and/or expenses imposed in the municipal civil infraction action, the City of Milan shall have all of the rights provided by law, including without limitation the rights specified in Act No. 12 of the Public Acts of 1994, with respect to the penalties to be imposed for such default and the remedies available to the plaintiff upon such a default. Those rights shall include, but not be limited to, the right to move for an order to show cause why the defendant should not be held in civil contempt; the right to obtain, enforce and discharge a lien upon the land, building, or structure involved in the municipal civil infraction; and the right to institute an action in a court of competent jurisdiction for the collection of the fines and costs imposed for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-12. - Rights of city in cases involving trailway municipal civil infraction. 
    The City of Milan shall have all of the rights provided by law, including without limitation the rights specified in Act No. 12 of the Public Acts of 1994 and MCL § 600.8733, in the case of any trailway municipal civil infraction. Those rights shall include, but not be limited to the right to seize and impound the involved vehicle and to obtain and enforce a lien upon such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 131/4-13. - Schedule of civil fines and costs for municipal civil infractions. 
    A schedule of civil fines payable to the Bureau for admissions of responsibility by persons served with municipal ordinance violation notices is hereby established, and shall be known as the City of Milan Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule. The fines for the violations listed in section 131/4-14 shall be those specified in "Appendix 1" to this section, which appendix is attached hereto and incorporated into this section 131/4-13 by reference. A copy of the current Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule council may, by resolution, modify or expand the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule, and may cause to be included therein civil fines for municipal civil infractions hereafter created by the city council.
