Promptly after each such modification, a copy of the entire new Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule, as changed by the addition of the new civil fines and by the revision(s) to the prior fines, shall be prominently posted at the Bureau and made available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 2018-03, § 2, 7-9-18) 
Sec. 131/4-14. - Initial ordinance provisions the violation of which shall be deemed to be municipal civil infractions. 
(a)  Except as provided in sections [1-8, 1-9 or 1-10] of this code, it is hereby determined that violation of any of the provisions of any of the following sections of the Milan City Code shall constitute a municipal civil infraction, and upon an admission of responsibility therefor at the Bureau, there shall be imposed upon the responsible party a civil fine and costs in such amounts as may be established by the city council and specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule, and upon a determination of responsibility therefor following any informal or formal hearing as provided in this chapter, there shall be imposed upon the responsible party a civil fine and costs in such amounts as may be established by the district court: 
Chapter 6: Sections 6-4; 6-12; 6-12.1; 6-12.3; 6-12.4; 6-14; 6-15; 6-18-6-20; 6-23-6-29; 6-39-6-41; 6-50; 6-61-6-63; 6-68; 6-69; 6-71; 6-72; 6-82; 6-93. Chapter 9: Sections 9-2-9-21; 9-33-9-39. Chapter 10: Sections 10-1; 10-2; 10-12; 10-13. Chapter 13: Sections 14-52(b); 13-53; 13-57-13-61; 13-71; 13-72; 13-83; 13-84. Chapter 171/2: Sections 171/2-3-171/2-6; 171/2-8; 171/2-10-171/2-13; 171/2-15. Chapter 18: Sections 18-1-18-7; 18-19-18-25; 18-40; 18-41; 18-56; 18-57; 18-59; 18-60. Chapter 20: Sections 20-17-20-32. Chapter 22: Sections 22-6-22-17. Chapter 24: Sections 24-2-24-6; 24-8-24-17; 24-19; 24-20; 24-23; 24-44; 24-45; 24-48; 24-87; 24-95-24-101; 24-103-24-109; 24-111-24-117; 24-120; 24-123-24-136; 24-139; 24-140; 24-144-24-152; 24-156; 24-160-24-163.  
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall in any way prohibit or restrict the Milan City Council from creating, by ordinance, new or additional municipal civil infractions, or from converting, by ordinance, existing misdemeanors to municipal civil infraction. This subsection is supplemented and hereby deemed to include by conversion from ordinance existing misdemeanors to new civil infractions for any provisions of the Milan Zoning Ordinance which has been decriminalized pursuant to any amendment to the Zoning Ordinance. All former misdemeanors as set forth under the Zoning Ordinance which have been decriminalized are now subject to the provisions of subsection (a) above. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 1, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 99-5, § 1, 1-20-2000) 
Chapter 131/2 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, adopted Apr. 11, 2011, deleted the former Art. I, §§ 131/2-1-131/2-10, and enacted a new Art. I as set out herein. The former Art. I pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2007-07, § 1, adopted Oct. 29, 2007. 

Sec. 131/2-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. The word shall, is always mandatory, not merely directory. When inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the single number, and words in the singular number include the plural. 
    Authorized is written permission given by the city council, mayor, city administrator, or recreation director, and filed with the chief of police. 
    City is the City of Milan 
    Commission is the parks and recreation commission. 
    Dawn is defined as sunrise. 
    Director is the director of parks and recreation. 
    Dusk shall be defined as sunset. 
    Park is a park, playground, recreation center, or any other area in the city, owned and/or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Sec. 131/2-2. - Hours of operation of city parks. 
    City parks shall open at dawn each morning and shall remain open until dusk the evening of that day, and from that time until dawn the following morning, the city parks shall be closed, except for activities registered with or sponsored by the parks and recreation commission, or its director. 
    Any park or section thereof may be declared closed to the public by the director at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular stated intervals (daily or otherwise), either entirely or merely for specific uses, as the director shall find reasonably necessary. The local law enforcement agency shall have the authority to close any park or section thereof, in the interest of public safety. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use, occupy, frequent, loiter in or be in any park or any part thereof in the city unless the park is officially open to the general public or said person has or is a part of a group that has a permit or permission of the director to be in a closed portion of the park or, generally, in the park after hours. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Sec. 131/2-3. - Use of picnic and pavilion areas. 
    A picnic area or pavilion shall be used by the public on a first come, first serve basis unless the area is designated for permitted use. No person shall use any portion of the picnic areas, buildings or structures for the purpose of holding picnics or other group activities, unless otherwise reserved, to the exclusion of others for an unreasonable time if the facilities are crowded. The director shall have the authority to regulate the activities in such areas when necessary to prevent congestion and to secure the maximum use for the comfort and convenience of all. Visitors shall comply with any directions given to achieve this end. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Sec. 131/2-4. - Reserved picnic areas or pavilion structures. 
    No person or organization except the permitted person or organization shall use designated picnic areas or pavilions during times posted for rental use only. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Sec. 131/2-5. - Permits. 
(a)  Application. Applications for park permits shall be filed with the parks and recreation department and signed by the director. Reservations will be taken on a first come first serve basis. Such applications shall be sworn to and shall state: 
(1)  The name of the person or organization wishing to conduct such activity. 
(2)  If the activity is proposed to be conducted for, or on behalf of, an organization, the name, address and telephone of the headquarters of the organization, and the authorized and responsible head of such organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be chairperson or responsible for such activity and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
(4)  The name, address and telephone number of the person to whom the permit is to be issued. 
(5)  The date when such activity is to be conducted. 
(6)  The park or portion thereof for which such permit is desired. 
(7)  An estimate of the anticipated attendance. 
(8)  The hour when such activity will start and terminate. 
(b)  Criteria for issuance. The director shall issue a permit when: 
(1)  The proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public's enjoyment of the park. 
(2)  The proposed activity or use does not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of the public health, welfare, safety or recreation. 
(3)  The proposed activity or use is not unreasonably anticipated to incite violence, crime or disorderly conduct. 
(4)  The proposed activity will not entail unusual, extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the city. 
(5)  The proposed use will not create noise to the extent that it unreasonably disturbs persons within the city. 
(6)  The facilities desired have not been reserved for another use at the days and hours requested for in the application. 
(7)  The application has been accompanied by a nonrefundable park permit application fee, in an amount to be set by the city council from time to time to cover the city's administrative costs in reviewing and evaluating the application. 
(8)  The usage permit shall be filed with the police department upon issuance. 
(c)  Notice of denial; appeal of denial. Within seven (7) days after receipt of an application, the director shall apprise an applicant in writing of his or her reasons for denying a permit if the permit is denied, and any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal in writing within five (5) days to the city council, which shall consider the application under the standards set forth in subsection (b) of this section and sustain or overrule the director's decision within two (2) weeks. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(d)  Liability of permittee. The person or organization to whom a permit is issued shall be liable for any loss, damage or injury to any person or property whatever by reason of negligence, gross negligence, or recklessness of the person or organization to whom such permit shall have been issued or any of his or her guests. 
(e)  Revocation. The director shall have the authority to deny or revoke a permit for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud misrepresentation or false statements contained in the application for the permit. 
(2)  Fraud misrepresentation, or false statements made by the permit holder on the performance of the authorization operation. 
(3)  The current or repeated past failure to comply with the provisions of park rules, ordinances of the city, including this article, or the laws of the state. 
(4)  The permittee or his or her designee is not present for the entire specified use, and/or fails to present the permit upon the request of the director, a police officer, or an ordinance inspector during the permitted use. 
(5)  The person or organization that received the permit attempts to transfer the permit to any other person or organization not named on the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Sec. 131/2-6. - Conduct in the parks. 
(a)  Littering. 
(1)  Litter must be disposed of in the proper receptacles. No person shall throw or deposit litter, refuse or trash in any park within the city except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the refuse and trash will be prevented from being blown by the elements around the park. Where receptacles are full or not provided, all such litter, refuse and trash shall be carried away from the park. 
(2)  Organized groups using the park are responsible for cleaning up their area. 
(3)  No person shall bring or dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, leaves, rubbish, waste, garbage, refuse or trash into the park. 
(b)  Motor vehicles. 
(1)  Operation of motor powered vehicles in areas not designated for traffic is prohibited unless authorized by the director, with the exception of emergency, service and authorized vehicles. 
(2)  Speed limit shall be five (5) miles per hour on designated roadways. 
(3)  Boats with motors are restricted to five (5) horsepower or less. 
(4)  No person shall operate or have within his possession within the boundaries of any park any off road motor driven vehicle, including but not limited to, a mini bike, dirt bike, dune buggy, all-terrain vehicle, snowmobile or similar motorized vehicle unless authorized in writing by the director of parks and recreation for athletic field maintenance. 
(5)  All motorized vehicles shall be muffled as to not disturb the enjoyment of the park for other residents. 
(c)  Animals. 
(1)  Animals and pets are prohibited in city parks, except those pets contained on a leash or other suitable restraint. The person who owns or is in charge of the dog or pet shall immediately remove all droppings deposited by such dog or pet by any sanitary method. The droppings shall be disposed of by the person owning or in charge of the dog or pet on the property of the person owning or in charge of the dog or pet or only deposited in a trash receptacle if so deposited inside a bag or paper wrapping. 
(2)  No exotic pets (snakes, spiders, birds, ferret, weasels, etc...) shall be permitted in the park unless part of an event or activity authorized by the director of parks and recreation. 
(d)  Fires. Except as hereinafter otherwise provided, no person shall build or cause to be built a fire or fires in a city park. The building of a fire or fires is permitted provided it or they are attended at all times as follows: 
(1)  In fireplaces and stoves provided by the city. Trash barrels and similar receptacles are not to be construed. 
(2)  In portable grilles or suitable burning device designed for cooking of food. 
(3)  In special cases of use of organizations where it is deemed appropriate, "open pit" or "bonfire" above ground burning may be permitted by written consent of the city council or the parks and recreation commission and filed with the police department. 
(e)  Common courtesy. Using any of the buildings, structures, or other facilities for an unreasonable amount of time when facilities are crowded is prohibited. 
(f)  Hunting and fishing. No person shall hunt, pursue, trap or molest any wildlife within city parks. Fishing is permitted according to state law. 
(g)  Camping. No one shall erect or set up tents, shacks, house trailers, camping trailers or other temporary shelter to camp or spend the night in the park without written permission from the city council or the parks and recreation director and filed with the police department. 
(h)  Adult use of children equipment. No person aged fourteen (14) or older shall use any of the playground equipment placed in the park for the use of children, except those persons who are assisting children aged thirteen (13) and under using the playground equipment for its intended purpose or as permission is otherwise granted by the director of parks and recreation. 
(i)  Damaging or tampering with buildings or other park property and equipment. 
(1)  No person shall willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, displace, or remove any park buildings, bridge, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, painting material, public utilities or appurtenances, signs, notices or placards whether temporary or permanent, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(2)  No person shall skateboard, bike, skate, walk, stand or sit upon railings, fences, monuments or buildings in the park. 
(j)  Damaging property, trees, shrubbery, flowers or lawns. No person shall willfully damage, cut, carve, climb, dig, transplant or remove any growing thing, including but not limited to tree, plant, flower, shrub, rock, mineral, artifact or other material or injure the bark of any tree or plant. No person shall dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any area in the park. 
(k)  Injuring wild animals or birds. 
(1)  No person shall attempt to injure, kill, shoot, or throw missiles at any animal, reptile or bird in a park. No person shall remove or have in his possession, give away, sell or offer to sell, or buy or offer to buy, or accept as a gift, any specimen alive or dead, of any animal, reptile or bird from a park. Poisonous snakes are the only exception to this section of the ordinance. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to feed or attempt to feed any animal or bird any known noxious substance. 
(l)  Alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or consume alcoholic beverages, including spirits, liquor, beer or wine, in any city park, except when purchased on the premises from a duly licensed vendor approved by city council and the parks and recreation commission. 
(m)  Firearms, fireworks or dangerous projectiles. 
(1)  No person shall have in his or her possession or control any rifle, shotgun, pistol or other firearm, slingshot, bow, arrow, crossbow, pellet gun, air rifle, gas projectile or ejecting devise, fireworks, explosive or other dangerous devices or material or weapon within the boundaries of a park, unless the person can produce the appropriate county, state, or federal permit to carry said device; provided that a local, county, state or federal law enforcement officer may carry a firearm, but only to the extent that said law enforcement officer is required by his or her job to carry such firearm on his or her person at all times. 
(2)  Professionally licensed and insured firework displays may be allowed in the park upon approval of the director of parks and recreation, chief of police, and the Milan City Council. 
(3)  No person shall throw any stones or other missiles within a park or hit any golf balls or other missiles in any part of the park unless in areas specifically designated for such activity. 
(n)  Disorderly conduct. No person or group of persons shall engage in any drunken, loud, boisterous, disorderly, indecent or lewd conduct, nor shall any person or group of persons commit or engage in any assault or other loud and/or aggressive, harassing or intimidating individual or group activity which shall endanger or annoy other persons or disturb the peace or good order within the boundaries of any city park. No person shall remain within the boundaries of a park after being requested by an ordinance officer, park official, volunteer officer or police officer to leave the park for a violation of a rule or regulation of the park commission or for a violation of this article. 
(o)  Persons excluded from parks. Any person who, while in a park, violates these regulations or other rules of the park commission or ordinances of the city or state, or engages in activity which unreasonably interferes with the peaceful use of the park or neighboring property by others may be barred from a park or parks by the director or any full time police officer. A person so barred shall be informed, in writing, of the time period during which that person is excluded from the park. If said order excludes a person for more than twenty-four (24) hours, it must be approved by the parks and recreation director or police chief. No person under such an order shall enter or remain in a park during the time that person is barred from the park. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Sec. 131/2-7. - Penalties. 
    Violations of any provision of sections 131/2-1 through 131/2-7 are hereby declared to be a ninety-day misdemeanor. Any person convicted of such violation shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Sec. 131/2-8. - Fees for parks and recreation department facilities. 
    The fees payable for and relating to the reservation, rental and use of the buildings and facilities under the supervision and direction of the department of parks and recreation shall be those specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Sec. 131/2-9. - Feeding of Branta Canadensis Maxima prohibited. 
    The feeding of unconfined Branta Canadensis Maxima, (known as Canada Geese) in any public park or on any other property owned or operated by the city is prohibited. 
(1)  The following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings stated herein unless their use in the text of this chapter clearly demonstrates a different meaning. 
    Feed means to give, place, expose, deposit, distribute or scatter any edible material with the intention of feeding, attracting or enticing wildlife. Feeding does not include baiting in the legal taking of fish and/or game. 
    Person means any individual, corporation, company, partnership, firm, association, or political subdivision of this state subject to municipal jurisdiction. 
(2)  No person shall feed, in any public park or on any other property owned or operated by the city, any Branta Canadensis Maxima (Canada Geese). 
(3)  Any person found to be in violation of this section shall be ordered to cease the feeding immediately. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Sec. 131/2-10. - Violations. 
    Violation of section 131/2-9 shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the official municipal civil infraction fees and costs schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 4-11-11) 
Secs. 131/2-11-131/2-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 72-1, §§ 1-3, adopted February 14, 1972, did not expressly amend this Code; hence codification as Art. II, §§ 131/2-16-131/2-19, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 131/2-16. - Created. 
    A parks and recreation commission is hereby created pursuant to authority provided in Section 4.24 of the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 72-1, 2-14-72) 
Sec. 131/2-17. - Parks and recreation commission members. 
(a)  The mayor of the city, subject to the approval and confirmation by a majority vote of the city council shall appoint a parks and recreation commission consisting of seven (7) members provided that the present membership of nine (9) members be continued until January 1, 1973, and that thereupon two (2) members shall be appointed for a one (1) year term, two (2) members shall be appointed for a two (2) year term and three (3) members shall be appointed to a three (3) year term and that thereafter terms of all members shall be three (3) years. At no time may more than one (1) of the parks and recreation commission be a member of the city council. Each appointee shall be a resident of the city for at least six (6) months prior to the date of his appointment, and shall be qualified and registered elector of the city on such day and throughout his tenure of office. 
(b)  The mayor may, with the approval of the council and upon the recommendation of the parks and recreation commission, remove any member who fails to fulfill the duties of his office under provisions of Sections 5.3 or 5.4 of the Charter. Such removals shall be made on after a hearing, of which said member has been given notice ten (10) days in advance. Such notice shall include a copy of charges made by the parks and recreation commission. Any recommendation for removal of a member shall be made in writing to the council and shall state the reason for the recommendation. 
(c)  Vacancies created by resignation, removal from the city or by action of the city council shall be filed by appointment of the mayor with approval and confirmation by a majority vote of council in the same manner as the original appointment shall be for the balance of the unexpired term of the member being replaced. Members shall serve without compensation and shall hold office until their successors are appointed. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 72-1, § 1, 2-14-72) 
Sec. 131/2-18. - Organization. 
(a)  The parks and recreation commission shall elect annually at its regular meeting next following the city council meeting at which annual appointments have been made, a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. 
(b)  The chairman shall be the presiding officer of the parks and recreation commission. He may appoint such committees as are deemed necessary or advisable and perform such other duties as may be established by the commission or city council. 
(c)  The vice-chairman shall perform the duties of the chairman in the absence of the chairman. 
(d)  The secretary shall keep a true and complete record of all appointments, actions by the commission and minutes of the meetings of the commission which shall be kept on file with the city clerk. The secretary shall also perform the usual duties of that office and such other duties as may be established by the commission or city council. 
(e)  Five (5) members of the parks and recreation commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. All opinions and recommendations to be made in the name of the parks and recreation commission shall have the support of not less than a simple majority of the members present. 
(f)  Regular meetings shall be held monthly and special meetings may be called as deemed necessary by the chairman at times agreeable to the membership. Attendance at meetings shall be in accordance with Section 5.3 of the city charter. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 72-1, § 2, 2-14-72) 
Sec. 131/2-19. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The duties of the parks and recreation commission shall be to advise the city council on parks and recreational activities and facilities including but not limited to developing a comprehensive parks and recreation master plan. This commission shall also serve in a liaison capacity as the city council's designated representative in presenting proposed projects and programs relating to parks and recreation and evaluating and reporting public response thereto. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 72-1, § 3, 2-14-72) 
Chapter 14 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, TRANSIENT AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Licensing and regulation of transient merchants, M.S.A., § 19.691 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS, TRANSIENT AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, adopted Nov. 8, 2010, deleted the former Art. II, §§ 14-16-14-32, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to peddlers, hawkers and hucksters and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 70-4, §§ 1, 2, 4-16, adopted July 27, 1970; Ord. No. C.O. 81-2, § 1(a), (c), (d) , adopted July 13, 1981; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 22, adopted May 9, 1994; Ord. No. 2003-03, §§ 1-4, adopted Feb. 24, 2003; and Ord. No. 2008-04, § 1, adopted Aug. 11, 2008. 

Sec. 14-16. - Permit and license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler, itinerant vendor or transient or itinerant merchant as hereafter defined, within the corporate limits of the City of Milan without first obtaining a permit and license therefore as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-17. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Itinerant vendor, transient or itinerant merchant shall mean all persons, both principals and agents, who engage or conduct in the city, a temporary business of selling goods, wares, or merchandise, in any place in this city, and who, for the purpose of conducting business, temporarily occupies any lot, building, room or structure of any kind. Does not include any persons that are conducting business activities within a physical building of an existing established business, subject to the ad valorem tax roles of the City of Milan, at the invitation of the business owner. Transaction of business by any person in one place for a period of less than six (6) months consecutively shall be prima facie evidence that such person was a transient or itinerant merchant within the intent and meaning of this article. 
    Peddler, as used herein shall include any person, whether a resident of the City of Milan or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden, truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance, and further provided that one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article, shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this article. The word "peddler" shall include the words "hawker," "solicitor," "street" or "foot vender" and "huckster." 
    Person as used herein shall include the singular and the plural and shall also mean and include any person, firm or corporation, association, club, co-partnership or society, or any other organization. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-18. - Application for permit and license; application fee. 
    Each applicant for a permit and license under this article must file with the city clerk/treasurer a sworn application in writing (in duplicate), on a form to be furnished by the city clerk/treasurer, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(2)  Address (legal and local); 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold. 
(4)  A list of all participating employees or individuals, including an address, phone number, driver's license number and date of birth; 
(5)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(6)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(7)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with license number or other means of identification. 
(8)  A photograph, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall show the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(9)  If food is to be sold, a health card or its equivalent, if applicable, issued by either the county health department or other state regulatory agency; 
(10)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the office and the punishment or penalty assessed therefore; 
(11)  If itinerant vendor, or transient or itinerant merchant and proposing to conduct business on property not owned by the applicant, a letter from property owner granting permission to use property. 
    The city shall approve an application for a permit and/or license hereunder within a reasonable period of time no later than five (5) days from submittal of all information required by said application. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-19. - Investigation of applicant; issuance, denial of permit and license; content, record of permit, license. 
(a)  Upon receipt of such application, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and criminal history for the protection of public good. 
(b)  If as a result of such investigation, the applicant's business responsibility or driver's license history for the prior twenty-four (24) months is found to be unsatisfactory, and/or the criminal history determines a criminal conviction over the past five (5) years, the chief of police and/or the city administrator shall endorse on such application disapproval and reason(s) for the same, and return the said application to the city clerk/treasurer, who shall notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit and license will be issued. 
(c)  If as a result of such investigation, the business responsibility, driver's license or criminal background check are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police and the city administrator shall endorse on such application approval, and return the said application to the city clerk/treasurer who shall, upon payment of the prescribed license fee, issue to the applicant his license for the carrying on of the business applied for. 
(d)  Such license shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address, and photograph of said licensee, the class of the license issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of the issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such peddling. 
(e)  The city clerk/treasurer shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-20. - Fees for permits and licenses. 
(a)  The fees for annual licenses under this article shall be those specified for same in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Annual license fees shall be assessed on a calendar year basis, and on and after July first, the license fee for the remainder of the same calendar year shall be one-half (1/2) of the annual license fee specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-21. - Identification card. 
    The city clerk shall issue to each licensee at the time of the approval of the licensee's application, an identification card bearing the name of the licensee, the period for which the license is issued and the number of the license. This identification card shall be worn by the licensee on an outer garment in such a way as to be conspicuous during such times as said licensee is engaged in peddling. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-22. - Unauthorized use of approved identification. 
    No license or badge or other approved identification issued under the provisions of this article shall be used or worn at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-23. - Loud noises and speaking devices. 
    No peddler, nor any person in his behalf, shall make any noise in the use of his or her licensed activity which is in violation of section 13-84 of the Milan City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-24. - Use of streets and public property. 
    No peddler shall have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, nor shall he be permitted to operate in any congested area where his operations might impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this section, the judgment of a police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
    No itinerant vendor, or transient or itinerant merchant shall be allowed to conduct business from a stationary stand or temporary structure on public property or within public right-of-way without the express written consent of the city council. 
    Exemption: Itinerant vendors and transient or itinerant vendors who are participating in a city council approved special event located on public property or within a public right-of-way may conduct business from a stationary stand or temporary structure within the perimeter of the special event location. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-25. - Exhibition of license. 
    Peddlers, itinerant vendors, and transient or itinerant merchants are required to exhibit their licenses at the request of any citizen. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-26. - Enforcement of provisions by police. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the City of Milan to require any person seen peddling, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce his peddler license, and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-27. - Records of licenses issued, violations. 
    The chief of police shall report to the city clerk all convictions for violation of this article, and the city clerk shall maintain a record for each license issued and record the reports of violation therein. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-28. - Revocation of permits and licenses; grounds specified, notice and hearing required. 
(a)  Permits and licenses issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the city clerk and police chief of the City of Milan after notice and hearing, or any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business as peddler; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
(5)  Conducting the business of peddling in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and place of hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last known address at least five (5) days prior to the date set for hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-29. - Appeal from denial or revocation of permit and license. 
    Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police or the city clerk in the denial of an application for permit or license as provided in section 14-19 of this article, or in the decision with reference to the revocation of a license as provided in section 14-28 of this article, shall have the right of appeal to the council of the City of Milan. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the council, within fourteen (14) days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. The council shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in section 14-28 of this article for notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and order of the council on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-30. - Expiration of licenses. 
    All annual licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall expire on the 31st of December in the year when issued. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-30.5. - Prohibited conduct by peddlers, transient and itinerant merchants and itinerant vendors. 
A.  No peddler, solicitor, itinerant vendor or transient or itinerant merchant shall knock at the door, ring the doorbell, or enter or call upon the premises of any residence, apartment, or other dwelling unit or business in the City upon which is clearly displayed at the entrance a notice that reads "NO SOLICITORS," "NO PEDDLERS," "NO SALES," "NO TRESPASSERS," or that otherwise clearly purports to prohibit peddlers, solicitors, transient and itinerant merchants and itinerant vendors, unless such person is or has been expressly invited upon the premises by the owner or occupant thereof. 
B.  No peddler, solicitor, itinerant vendor or transient or itinerant merchant shall remain at a residence, apartment, or other dwelling unit or business or on the premises thereof after the owner or occupant thereof has requested any such person to leave. 
C.  No peddler, solicitor, itinerant vendor or transient or itinerant merchant shall enter upon any property or call upon any owner or occupant of the property by any means of entry or contact other than by approaching the front entry door of the premises. No peddler, solicitor, itinerant vendor or transient or itinerant merchant shall enter into an attached or detached garage or building, or a rear or side yard, unless expressly invited by the owner or occupant of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 1, 9-14-15) 
Sec. 14-31. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 14-32. - Exemptions. 
    The following persons are exempt from the requirements of section 14-20, but shall be required to comply with every other provision of this article regulating such activity. 
(1)  Any person engaged in the retail sale of goods, wares or merchandise at a permanent location in the city and subject to the city's ad valorem real or personal property taxes conducting business as a transient merchant at any other location within the city. 
(2)  Any person exempt from the licensing requirements of this article by virtue of state or federal law. 
(3)  Any person selling at a fair, festival or similar event at the invitation of the event's sponsor, if all of the following conditions are met: 
a.  The sponsor has applied for, and received, a peddlers permit as required by this article. 
b.  The sponsor is a government entity or nonprofit organization as defined by the IRS. 
c.  The sponsor provides a list of the event's vendors' business addresses and sales tax license numbers to the city clerk/treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Chapter 15 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals and fowl, Ch. 5; miscellaneous offenses and provisions, Ch. 13; false calls for police department, § 13-18; traffic, Ch. 21; vehicles for hire, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Cooperation with state police, M.S.A., § 4.436; power to pursue, arrest and detain persons outside city limits, § 5.2114; minimum annual police salaries, § 5.3322(1) et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - General duties of chief generally. 
    The duties of the chief of police, besides those already provided for by the law and acts of incorporation, shall be to perform the duties of peace officer in all cases of a breach of peace or disorderly conduct within the corporation limits of the city, and to perform all services required by the laws and ordinances of the city. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to serve and execute all processes to him directed by a court of competent jurisdiction; to enforce the laws and ordinances of the city; to arrest drunken and disorderly persons, disturbers of the peace, and persons in actual commission of acts indictable by the laws and ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. of 4-20-1899, § 1) 
Charter reference- General powers and duties of chief of police, § 4.16. 
Cross reference- Chief of police to investigate applicant for license to operate mechanical amusement device, § 4-23; duty of chief of police relative to nuisances, § 10-1(a); duty of chief of police relative to license for transient and itinerant merchants and itinerant vendors, § 14-26; duty of chief of police relative to obstructing street, alleys, etc., § 18-1(b), (c); duty of chief of police relative to obstructing sidewalks, § 18-2. 
Sec. 15-1.1. - Duties of chief of police regarding unclaimed property. 
(a)  The chief of police shall be charged with the custody of such lost, stolen or otherwise unclaimed personal property as may be delivered to, recovered by or otherwise come into the possession of the police department and shall dispose of such personal property, except impounded motor vehicles, perishable produce, animals or property which by its nature is required by law to be registered, such as, but not limited to, handguns, as follows: 
(1)  The chief of police shall designate a member of the police department to act as an appraiser to examine, appraise and inventory each article of lost money or lost personal property surrendered to the custody of the department. Property found to have little or no intrinsic or commercial value in the opinion of the appraiser shall be inventoried and recorded separately from property found by the appraiser to have intrinsic or commercial value and may be returned immediately to the finder and left in his custody. A record of property having intrinsic or commercial value, containing a description of the property, a record of the place where found, the date taken into custody, the appraiser's estimate of the value and the final disposition thereof, and, if sold, the amount received certified by the city treasurer, shall be maintained by the chief of police. This record shall be in the form of a bound book which shall be a public record to be kept on file in the police department. 
(2)  Any and all unclaimed money or personal property in the custody of the chief of police shall be kept for a period of six (6) months unless the identity of the owner shall sooner be discovered. If the identity of the owner shall be learned while such property is in the custody of the police department, the chief of police shall notify the owner in writing, which notice shall advise him that unless he shall reclaim the same within thirty (30) days from the date said notice is given that he shall have forfeited any claim to the return of such money or personal property. Any person making a claim for the return of lost money or personal property shall establish his ownership to the satisfaction of the chief of police and such money or personal property shall be returned to him upon payment of the cost of expenses of storage incurred by the department. 
(3)  After any lost money or lost personal property shall have been in the custody of the chief of police for six (6) months and the owner shall not have been found or has abandoned his claim to the property, and there being no claim of ownership pending against such property, the same may be returned by the chief of police to the finder thereof if said finder shall have complied with the provisions of this chapter regarding lost property, in all respects. As to any such property remaining in the custody of the police department as to which there are no claims pending and no finder having any rights therein, the chief of police shall cause said property, except money, to be sold at public auction, reserving the right to reject any or all bids. Notice of the time and place of such sale shall be given by publishing notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. Such notice shall set forth a full description of said property. The chief of police is hereby authorized to deliver and convey such property to the successful purchaser upon payment of the full purchase price without any warranty or representation as to title and with the understanding that in the event the rightful owner recovers such property in an action at law against such purchaser that the liability of the City of Milan shall be limited to the amount paid by said purchaser for such property. The proceeds of all such sales and any money which shall have been held for six (6) months against which there is no claim pending either by any purported owner or by the finder thereof, shall be paid over by the chief of police to the city treasurer to the credit of the general fund. The City of Milan may purchase property at any such sale in the same manner as any other bidder. 
(4)  Each public auction held pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be under the direction of the chief of police and the city clerk shall act as clerk in recording any and all sales made. 
(b)  Personal property excepted from the aforesaid disposition procedure by the opening paragraph of the foregoing subsection, shall be disposed of as follows: 
(1)  Impounded motor vehicles shall be disposed of in accordance with state law. 
(2)  Perishable produce may be sold within twelve (12) hours, if unclaimed, and the proceeds therefrom held and disposed of pursuant to subparagraphs (2) and (3) of subsection (a) aforesaid. 
(3)  Lost animals, other than dogs or cats, may be sold within seventy-two (72) hours if unclaimed and the proceeds therefrom held and disposed of pursuant to subparagraphs (2) and (3) of subsection (a) aforesaid. Lost dogs or cats shall be impounded and be subject to the provisions of Article III, Chapter 13 of this Code. 
(4)  Handguns, and other personal property of a nature that it is required by law to be registered, shall be disposed of in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 75-3, § 2, 9-22-75) 
Sec. 15-2. - City prison generally. 
(a)  A city prison shall be kept and maintained within the city and the chief of police shall be the keeper thereof. 
(b)  In all cases when persons violating the ordinances of the city may be sentenced to imprisonment therefor, such imprisonment may be in the city prison at the discretion of the magistrate imposing the sentence. 
(c)  All persons sentenced to confinement in the city prison and all persons imprisoned thereon on execution for nonpayment of fines for violations of the ordinances of the city shall be kept at hard labor in and about the buildings belonging to or used by the city, or upon the grounds, streets and alleys of the city. 
(Ord. of 12-12-1894, §§ 1-3) 
Secs. 15-3-15-12. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MINIMUM EMPLOYMENT STANDARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 15-13. - Adopted. 
    The minimum employment standards for law enforcement officers as established and adopted by the Michigan Law Enforcement Officers Training Council in accordance with Act No. 203, Public Acts of 1965 are hereby adopted as set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
State Law reference- Law Enforcement Officers Training Council Act of 1965, M.S.A., § 4.450(1) et seq. 
Sec. 15-14. - Standards declared minimum. 
    The standards of the Michigan Law Enforcement Officers Training Council are recognized as minimum standards and higher standards are recommended by the training council when qualified applicants are available. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 68-10, § 3, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-15. - Compliance with state law. 
    Law enforcement officer recruitment and employment practices and standards shall be in compliance with existing state statutes governing this activity. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-16. - Age. 
    All law enforcement officers shall be at least twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-17. - Citizenship. 
    All law enforcement officers shall be citizens of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-18. - Education. 
    All law enforcement officers shall have graduated from high school or equivalent. "Equivalent" is defined as having attained a passing score on the general education development test indicating high school graduation level. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-19. - Fingerprinting. 
    All law enforcement officers shall be fingerprinted and a search of local, state and national fingerprint files made to disclose any criminal record. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-20. - Felons prohibited. 
    The law enforcement officer shall not have been convicted of a felony offense. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-21. - Character. 
    The law enforcement officers shall be of good moral character as determined by a favorable report following a comprehensive background investigation covering school and employment records, home environment, personal traits and integrity. Consideration will be given to any and all law violations, including traffic and conservation law convictions as indicating a lack of good character. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-22. - Physical, emotional and mental fitness generally. 
    The applicant for a position as a law enforcement officer shall be of acceptable physical, emotional and mental fitness as established by a licensed physician following an examination to determine if the applicant is free from any physical, emotional or mental condition which might adversely affect his performance of duty as a police officer. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-23. - Specific physical and mental condition. 
    The trainee for a position as a law enforcement officer shall possess normal hearing and normal color vision. He shall be free from any impediment of the senses. He must possess normal visual functions and visual acuity in each eye correctable to 20/20. The trainee must be physically sound; well developed physically, with height and weight in relation to each other and to age as indicated by accepted medical standards, and in possession of his extremities. He shall be free from any physical defects, chronic diseases, organic diseases, organic or functional conditions, or mental instabilities which may tend to impair efficient performance of duty or which might endanger the lives of others or himself if he lacks these qualifications. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-24. - Medical history. 
    A declaration of the applicant's medical history shall become a part of the background investigation. The information shall be available to the examining physician. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Sec. 15-25. - Interview required. 
    An oral interview shall be held by the hiring authority or his representative, to determine the applicant's acceptability for a police officer position and to assess appearance, background and ability to communicate. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-10, § 1, 9-23-68) 
Chapter 16 - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; subdivisions, Ch. 19; water and sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 24; zoning, App. A. 
State Law reference- Municipal improvements generally, M.S.A., § 5.2251 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Capital improvement revolving fund. 
(a)  Creation. There is hereby established in the City of Milan a fund to be hereafter known as the capital improvement revolving fund. 
(b)  Purpose. The capital improvement revolving fund shall be used for acquiring, extending, altering or repairing any public improvement and/or equipment which the city, by general law, is authorized to acquire, extend, alter or enlarge and to be used for the operational expenditures of the city for improvements and/or equipment. 
(c)  Sources of revenue; allocation of monies. The clerk and treasurer of the city is hereby ordered and directed, immediately upon the adoption and taking effect of this section, to allocate and credit the capital improvement revolving fund with monies now on hand not already committed to other purposes by lawful action of the council or monies hereafter acquired which are derived from the following sources: 
(1)  All monies presently on hand or hereafter received by the city from the sale or exchange of city real estate. 
(2)  Miscellaneous revenues received by the city which shall include specifically: Unexpended monies on hand at the end of any fiscal year, received in the payment of taxes and by the city, which such monies are not covered by budget appropriation and, in the opinion of council, are not needed for specific fund purposes either current or contingent and are otherwise unencumbered. 
(d)  Appropriations. The council may annually, by and in accordance with the budgetary procedure, include in the annual budget or appropriation bill an item of money to be raised by taxation in the ensuing year, which such money, when collected, shall be credited to the capital improvement revolving fund. 
(e)  Investment. The monies accumulated in such fund shall, from time to time, upon authority of council, be invested by the clerk and treasurer in such securities as are authorized by the general law of the state as lawful for the investment of sinking and interest funds for the repayment of outstanding bond issues of the city. 
(f)  Expenditures to be for construction of public improvements and/or emergency and operational services of the city. Any and all monies or credits hereinafter assigned, transferred and appropriated to the capital improvement revolving fund shall be held in such fund for the use by the city for general public improvements and/or emergency and operational services of the city that are specifically authorized by council. Monies so accumulated in such fund shall not be transferred, encumbered or otherwise disposed of except for the construction of public improvements and/or emergency and operational services of the city. 
(g)  Procedure. Whenever the council of the city determines the need and advisability to acquire any public improvements and/or emergency and operational services, the cost of which is to be defrayed wholly or in part by monies from the capital improvement revolving fund, the provisions as required shall be fully complied with by the council causing to be prepared maps, plans specifications and estimates of costs of the proposed improvements and/or emergency and operational services and the adoption of a specific resolution determining to acquire such improvement and/or emergency and operational services. Separate proceedings shall be taken for each separate type or kind of improvement and/or emergency and operational services. The council shall provide for the transfer of all or part of the costs of such improvement and/or emergency and operational services from the capital improvement revolving fund. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 76-4, §§ 1-7, 7-13-76) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C. O. 76-4, §§ 1-7, being nonamendatory of this Code, has been included herein as § 16-1 at the discretion of the editors. 
Secs. 16-2-16-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENT PROCEDURE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Special assessments, Ch. 11. 

Sec. 16-16. - Definition. 
    The term "public improvement," as used in this article, shall include the reconstruction in whole or in part of any structure or work as well as the original construction thereof. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 2, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-17. - Article to govern. 
    The making and financing of public improvements in the city by the special assessment method shall be governed by this article and all proceedings therefor shall be taken in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 1, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-18. - Determination of cost. 
    The cost of surveys, maps, drawings, plans and specifications for a public improvement and all expenses incident to the proceedings for the making of such improvement, the making and collecting of the special assessments therefor, and the issuance of bonds in anticipation of such special assessments, shall be deemed a part of the cost of such improvement. Whenever any property is acquired by condemnation, or otherwise, for the purpose of any public improvement, all or any part of the cost thereof may be included as a part of the cost of such improvement. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 2, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-19. - Assessment may be based on estimated cost. 
    Any assessment may be made upon the basis of the estimated cost of the improvement if the actual cost has not been definitely determined. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 2, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-20. - Petition generally. 
    A petition addressed to the council may be filed with the city clerk requesting the council to make a public improvement therein described and to assess the cost thereof, or such part of the cost as the council shall decide, to benefited lands comprising a special assessment district to be determined by the council. Any petition so filed may be in one (1) or more parts and shall be signed by the owners of lands having at least fifty per cent (50%) of the privately owned frontage abutting upon the proposed improvement. The city clerk shall not present to the council any petition not so signed. A purchaser of a land contract shall be deemed the owner of such land. Such petition, in addition to the signatures of the owners, shall contain a brief description of the property owned by the respective signers thereof. The genuineness of the signatures on each petition or part thereof shall be verified by the affidavit of the circulator. Any such petition shall not be mandatory upon the council, but shall be advisory only, and in no event shall such petition be deemed jurisdictional. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 3, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-21. - Authority of council to make public improvements; initial procedure. 
(a)  Irrespective of whether or not a petition shall have been filed in accordance with section 16-20, the council may determine to make any public improvement and to defray the whole or any part of the cost thereof by special assessment upon property especially benefited thereby. The council shall by resolution declare its intention to do so, stating therein the nature and the route or location of the proposed improvement and the lands and premises proposed to be included in the special assessment district and assessed therefor, and shall cause to be prepared and submitted to the city council, the following: 
(1)  A map or drawing showing the route or location of such proposed improvement and such proposed special assessment district. 
(2)  Plans and specifications for such proposed improvement. 
(3)  An estimate of the cost thereof. 
(b)  Upon the submission of the map or drawing, plans, specifications and cost estimate required by subsection (a), the city council shall, if it desires to proceed with the making of the improvement and the special assessments therefor, so declare by resolution. The city council by such resolution shall order the aforesaid map or drawing, plans, specifications and cost estimate to be filed in the office of the city clerk for public examination, shall determine the necessity of such improvement, shall state the estimated cost thereof and what part or proportion, if less than all, shall be paid by special assessment and what part or proportion, if any, shall be a general obligation of the city, shall specify the number of installments in which assessments may be paid, and shall designate the district or lands and premises upon which the special assessments shall be levied. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, §§ 4, 5, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-22. - Hearing; notice. 
(a)  Before finally determining to make the improvement and the special assessments therefor, the city council shall hold a public hearing at a time and place to be fixed by the city council. At such hearing the council shall hear and consider any objections which may be submitted by any interested person with respect to the making of such improvement and the assessing to the designated special assessment district of all or that part of the cost of the improvement which the city council has proposed to so assess. 
(b)  The city council shall cause notice of such hearing to be given by the city clerk not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of such hearing, by publication thereof at least once in a newspaper having general circulation in the city, and by sending by first class U.S. mail, postage thereon fully prepaid, a copy of such notice addressed to each person in whose name any land in the special assessment district is assessed on the last preceding tax assessment roll of the city, at his last known address, and also (if such address is different from the address of the premises in the district) a copy of such notice addressed to the "Occupant" of each such premises which has an address served by U.S. mail. Such notice shall specify the improvement, describe the district, state the estimated cost and the division thereof as between the district and the city at large, and give notice that the map or drawing, plans, specifications and cost estimate of the improvement are on file with the city clerk for public examination. 
(c)  At the time of such hearing, or any adjournment thereof, which may be without further notice, the city council shall hear and consider such objections as are submitted and shall record in the minutes of such meeting the names of all persons objecting, the properties owned by them, and the nature of their objections. The city council without further notice, may revise, correct, amend or change the map or drawing, plans, specifications, estimate and/or district; provided, that no property shall be added to the district until notice be given as above provided or by personal service upon the owners thereof and a hearing afforded such owners. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 6, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-23. - Adoption of resolution to make improvement; contents. 
    After the hearing provided for in section 16-22, if the city council desires to proceed with the making of the improvement and the special assessments therefor, it shall adopt a resolution approving the map or drawing, plans, specifications and cost estimate as originally presented or as revised, corrected, amended, or changed, determining to make the improvement, designating the lands and premises constituting the special assessment district therefor, stating what part of the cost of the improvement, if any, shall be assumed and paid from the general funds of the city and directing that the remainder be assessed in accordance with benefits to the lands and premises constituting such special assessment district, specifying the number of installments in which the assessments shall be payable, and ordering the city assessor to prepare a special assessment roll for all or that part of the cost to be so assessed; provided, that if, prior to the adoption of such resolution, written objections to the improvement have been filed by more than fifty per cent (50%) of the number of owners of privately owned real property to be assessed for the improvement, or in the case of a paving or similar improvement, more than fifty per cent (50%) of the number of owners of frontage to be assessed, shall object in writing to the proposed improvement, then such resolution shall not be adopted and such improvement shall not be made, except in case of sidewalk construction, without a five-sevenths (5/7) vote of the members-elect of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 7, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-24. - Special assessment roll-Preparation; filing; certificate. 
(a)  The city assessor shall thereupon, after the adoption of the resolution so directing, as provided for in section 16-23, prepare the special assessment roll in which shall be entered and described all the lands and premises to be assessed, with the names of the respective owners thereof, if known, and the amount to be assessed against each such parcel of land or premises. Such amount shall be such relative portion of the whole sum to be levied against all the lands and premises in the special assessment district as the benefit to such parcel of land or premises bears to the total benefits to all the lands and premises in the special assessment district. There shall also be entered upon such roll the amount which has been assumed by the city at large, if any. 
(b)  When the city assessor shall have completed the assessment roll, he shall file the same in the office of the city clerk, after first having affixed thereto a certificate stating that it was made pursuant to a resolution of the city council adopted on a specified date and that in making such assessment roll he has, according to his best judgment, conformed in all respects to such resolution, this article, and the charter of the city. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 8, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-25. - Same-Hearing; notice. 
(a)  Before confirming any assessment roll, the city council shall appoint a time and place when it will meet and review the same and hear any objections thereto. The city council shall cause notice of such hearing and of the filing of such assessment roll to be given by the city clerk not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of such hearing, by publication thereof at least once in a newspaper having general circulation in the city, and by sending by first class U.S. mail, postage thereon fully prepaid, a copy of such notice addressed to each person in whose name any land is assessed on such roll, at his last known address, and also (if such address is different from the address of the premises in the district) a copy of such notice addressed to the "Occupant" of each such premises which has an address served by U.S. mail. 
(b)  The city council shall meet at the appointed time and place and at such meeting or any adjourned meeting (which may be without further notice), shall review the special assessment roll and hear and consider any objections thereto, and shall record in the minutes of such meeting the names of all persons who objected to such roll, the properties owned by them, and the nature of their objections. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 9, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-26. - Same-Confirmation. 
(a)  After the hearing on the special assessment roll, provided for in section 16-25, the city council by resolution may confirm the same, or may correct it as to any matter appearing therein and confirm it as so corrected, or may refer it back to the city assessor for revision, or may annual it and direct a new roll to be made. No special assessment roll shall be confirmed except with the affirmative vote of at least five (5) members of the city council. If, at or prior to final confirmation of any special assessment roll, more than fifty per cent (50%) of the number of owners of privately owned real property to be assessed thereon, or in the case of paving or similar improvement, more than fifty per cent (50%) of the number of owners of frontage to be assessed thereon, shall object in writing to the proposed improvement, the special assessment roll shall not be confirmed, except in case of sidewalk construction, without a five-sevenths (5/7) vote of the members-elect of the city council. When a special assessment roll shall be confirmed, the city clerk shall endorse thereon the date of confirmation. After such confirmation the special assessment roll and all assessments therein shall be final and conclusive. 
(b)  No work shall be commenced on any public improvement to be financed in whole or in part by special assessment until after confirmation of the special assessment roll therefor, nor shall any confirmation, except for legal, engineering, administrative and other services required for the preparation of the map, drawings, plans, specifications and cost estimate for the improvement and the taking of necessary proceedings, including the making of the special assessment roll, for the levying of the special assessments. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, §§ 10, 11, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-27. - Payment of special assessments. 
(a)  Special assessments may be made payable in one or more installments, as determined by the city council, but such installments may not exceed five (5) in the case of sidewalk improvements, fifteen (15) in the case of paving or similar street improvements, and twenty (20) in the case of water, storm sewer, sanitary sewer or other improvements. The first installment shall be due at such time after confirmation as the city council shall provide and the several subsequent installments shall be due at intervals of twelve (12) months from the due date of the first installment. The amount of each installment (if more than one) need not be extended upon the special assessment roll until after confirmation. All assessments, if payable in more than one installment, shall bear interest after confirmation at a rate as determined by the city council between one-half (1/2) of one per cent (1%) and one per cent (1%) for each month or fraction thereof that the same remain unpaid. Such accrued interest on all unpaid installments shall be due and payable annually on the due dates of the respective installments. Any one or more installments may be paid at any time before due together with accrued interest on such installments. 
(b)  If any installment is not paid when due, then the same shall be deemed to be delinquent, and there shall be collected thereon, in addition to interest as above provided, a collection fee of one per cent (1%) and a penalty of two per cent (2%) of such installment. In case any assessment or any installment thereof shall remain unpaid on the first Monday of May following the date when the same became delinquent, the same shall be reported unpaid by the city treasurer to the city council, and such delinquent assessments, together with all accrued interest, shall be transferred and reassessed on the next annual city tax roll in a column headed "Special Assessments" with a penalty of four per cent (4%) upon such total amount added thereto, and when so transferred and reassessed upon such tax roll, shall be collected in all respects as provided for the collection of city taxes. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, §§ 12, 13, 6-24-68; Ord. No. C.O. 82-10, § 1, 2-15-83) 
Sec. 16-28. - Lien of city upon property assessed. 
(a)  Special assessments and all interest, charges and penalties thereon, from the date of confirmation of the roll and until paid, shall be and remain a lien upon the property assessed of the same character and effect as the lien created by general law for the state and county taxes and by the city charter for city taxes. 
(b)  No judgment or decree, nor any act of the city council vacating a special assessment shall destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the property assessed, for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the same, or as by a regular mode of proceeding might be lawfully assessed thereon. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 14, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-29. - Collection of special assessments. 
(a)  When any special assessment shall be confirmed, the city council shall direct the assessment so made in the special assessment roll to be collected. The assessor shall thereupon deliver to the city treasurer such special assessment roll to which the mayor shall attach his warrant commanding the city treasurer to collect from each of the persons assessed in such roll the amount of money assessed to and set opposite his name therein. Upon receiving such special assessment roll and warrant, the city treasurer shall proceed to collect the several amounts assessed therein. 
(b)  In addition to any other remedies and without impairing the lien therefor, any delinquent special assessment together with interest and penalties may be collected in an action of assumpsit in the name of the city against the person assessed, in any court having jurisdiction. If in any such action it shall appear that by reason of any irregularities or informalities the assessment has not been properly made against the defendant or upon the premises sought to be charged, the court may, nevertheless, on satisfactory proof that expense has been incurred by the city, which is a proper charge against the defendant or the premises in question, render judgment for the amount properly chargeable against such defendant or upon such premises. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, §§ 15, 16, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-30. - Procedure when lot or parcel of land is divided after confirmation of special assessment. 
    Should any lot or parcel of land be divided after a special assessment thereon has been confirmed and before the collection thereof, the city council may require the city assessor to apportion the uncollected amounts upon the several parts of such lot or parcel of land. The report of such apportionment when confirmed shall be conclusive upon all parties, provided that before such confirmation, notice of hearing shall be given to all the interested parties by personal service or by publication and mailing as provided in case of an original assessment roll. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 17, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-31. - When additional pro rata assessments may be made. 
    Additional pro rata assessments may be made when any special assessment roll proves insufficient to pay for the improvement for which it was levied and the expenses incidental thereto, or insufficient to pay the principal and interest on bonds issued in anticipation of such assessment roll; provided, that the additional pro rata assessment shall not exceed ten per cent (10%) of the assessment as originally confirmed, unless a meeting of the city council be held to review such additional assessment, for which meeting notices shall be published and mailed as provided in the case of review of the original special assessment roll. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 18, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-32. - Power of council to make new assessment where original declared invalid or illegal. 
    Whenever any special assessment roll shall, in the opinion of the city council, be invalid by reason of irregularity or informality in the proceedings, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge such assessment to be illegal, the city council shall, whether the improvement shall have been made or not, or whether any part of the assessment shall have been paid or not, have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made. All proceedings on such reassessment and for the collection thereof shall be conducted in the same manner as provided for in original assessment except as to corrections in the proceedings required to make the assessment legal. Whenever any sum or part thereof, levied upon any property in the assessment so set aside, has been paid and not refunded, the payment so made shall be applied upon the reassessment. If the payments exceed the amount of the reassessment, refunds shall be made. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 19, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-33. - Special assessment account. 
    Moneys raised by special assessments for any public improvement shall be credited to a special assessment account and shall be used to pay for the costs of the improvement for which the assessment was levied and for expenses incidental thereto, to repay any principal and interest on money borrowed therefor, and to refund excessive assessments. The excess by which any special assessment proves larger than the actual cost of the improvement and expense incidental thereto may be placed in the general fund of the city if such excess is five per cent (5%) or less of the assessment, but should the assessment provide larger than necessary by more than five per cent (5%) the entire excess shall be refunded on a pro rata basis to the owners of the property assessed. Such refund shall be made by credit against future unpaid installments to the extent such installments then exist and the balance of such refund shall be in cash. No refunds may be made which contravene the provisions of any outstanding evidence of indebtedness secured in whole or in part by such special assessment. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 20, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-34. - Procedure when expense incurred by city relative to single premises.
