    When any expense shall have been incurred by the city upon or in respect to any single premises, which expense is chargeable against such premises and the owner thereof under the provisions of the charter or any ordinance of the city or law of the state, and is not of that class required to be prorated among the several lots and parcels of land in a special assessment district, an account of the labor, material and service for which such expense was incurred, with a description of the premises upon or in respect to which the expense was incurred, and the name of the owner, if known, shall be reported to the city treasurer, who shall immediately charge and bill the owner, if known. In the event that the city treasurer finds that such amount is not otherwise collectible, he shall report the same to the city council which may direct the city assessor to prepare a special assessment roll covering all such charges reported to it, together with a penalty of ten per cent (10%). Such roll shall be filed with the city clerk, who shall present the same to the city council. Thereafter the same proceedings shall be followed in respect to such special assessment roll as are provided in section 16-24 and subsequent sections of this article and all the provisions of such sections with reference to special assessments generally shall apply to special assessments under this section, insofar as the same may be applicable. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 21, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-35. - No lands exempted from assessment; exception. 
    No lands in a special assessment district which are benefited by the improvement therein, shall be exempt from assessment, but if the same are owned by a public or other corporation exempt by law from the payment of special assessments, then the special assessments against such lands, or the installments thereof, may be paid by the city as the same become due or may be paid in advance of their due dates or may be paid by the exempt unit by special agreement. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 22, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-36. - City to pay special assessment or installments when property owner unable because of poverty. 
    As authorized in section 11.11 of the city charter, in the event that a lien to secure payment of a special assessment or any one (1) or more installments thereof is created in favor of the city by deed of the addressed property to the city by reason of the finding of the assessor and council that the owner of such property is unable because of poverty to pay such assessment or installments and should be accorded relief therefrom, the obligation of the owner to make such payment shall thereby become the obligation of the city. The city shall pay from its general fund any such assessment or installments, together with interest and penalties, which falls due during the period while the beneficial ownership of such property remains in the grantor of such deed and while the agreement of the city to grant such relief remains in effect. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 23, 6-24-68) 
Charter reference- Certain postponements of payments, § 11.11. 
Sec. 16-37. - Making special assessment roll when funds on hand or revolving fund exists. 
    In the event that funds are on hand or a revolving fund exists to defray the expense of any public improvement prior to the completion thereof, the special assessment roll therefor may be made within sixty (60) days after the improvement is completed and shall be based upon the actual cost thereof. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 24, 6-24-68) 
Sec. 16-38. - Participation of city in intergovernmental improvements. 
    When the city may, by law, participate in intergovernmental improvements, the cost of which may be defrayed in whole or in part by special assessments, the procedure therefor shall be as provided by the law permitting the same. If such procedure is not so provided, the procedure established by this article and under authority of the city charter shall govern. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 68-9, § 25, 6-24-68) 
Chapter 17 - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 79-3, § 1, adopted May 29, 1979, repealed former Ch. 17, §§ 17-1-17-7, relative to railroads, derived from Ord. of April 20, 1899, and Ord. of Feb. 17, 1913. Sections 2-7 of said Ord. No. C.O. 79-3 enacted provisions included herein as a new Ch. 17, §§ 17-1-17-6. 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; traffic, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Railroads generally, M.S.A., § 22.3 et seq. 

Sec. 17-1. - Speed limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to run or operate, or cause to be run or operated, any railroad train, car or engine, whether forward or backward, within five hundred (500) feet of any grade crossing, street or alley within the City of Milan at other than a safe speed. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 79-3, § 2, 5-29-79) 
Sec. 17-2. - Warning signal. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be operated, any railroad train, car or engine, while moving within the City of Milan, without twice sharply sounding a whistle or siren within five hundred (500) feet of any grade crossing, street or alley. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 79-3, § 3, 5-29-79) 
Sec. 17-3. - Obstructing travel. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or cause a railroad train, car or engine to stand at any grade crossing or street within the City of Milan, so as to obstruct travel upon any said crossing or street, or sidewalks appurtenant thereto, for a period in excess of five (5) minutes, except when such standing or obstruction is the result of an accident or mechanical failure. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 79-3, § 4, 5-29-79) 
Sec. 17-4. - Riding, boarding train for amusement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or board any railroad car or engine for amusement without the express permission of a conductor, engineer or other person in charge of said railroad car or engine. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 79-3, § 5, 5-29-79) 
Sec. 17-5. - Throwing objects at trains, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw any stones, missiles or other objects at railroad trains, cars or engines within the City of Milan. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 79-3, § 6, 5-29-79) 
Sec. 17-6. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both, at the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 79-3, § 7, 5-29-79) 
Chapter 171/2 - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 23 of Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, adopted May 9, 1994, amended Ch. 171/2, §§ 171/2-1-171/2-17 to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 171/2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 77-4, §§ 1-17, adopted April 11, 1977. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 

Sec. 171/2-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to prevent soil erosion and sedimentation from nonagricultural development within the City of Milan by requiring proper provisions for water disposal and the protection of soil surfaces during and after construction, in order to promote the safety, public health, convenience and general welfare of the community. This chapter is enacted pursuant to the provisions of Act 347, P.A. 1972, as amended, and the provisions of said act, together with the rules promulgated thereunder, are incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Certification: A signed, written statement by the city building official, that specific constructions, inspections or test where required have been performed and that such comply with the applicable requirements of this chapter or regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
(2)  Erosion: The process by which the ground surface is worn away by action of wind, water, gravity or a combination thereof. 
(3)  Excavation or cut: Any act by which soil or rock is cut into, dug, quarried, uncovered, removed, displaced or relocated and shall include conditions resulting therefrom. 
(4)  Fifty-year flood plain: That area which would be inundated by storm runoff or flood water equivalent to that which would occur with a rainfall or flood of fifty-year reoccurrence frequency after total development of the watershed. 
(5)  Grade: Any stripping, excavating, filling, stockpiling, or any combination thereof and shall include the land in its excavated or filled condition. 
(6)  Grading permit: A permit issued to authorize work to be performed under this chapter. 
(7)  Stripping: Any activity which removes or significantly disturbs the vegetative surface cover including cleaning and grubbing operations. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-3. - Compliance with chapter required for site plan or plat approval. 
    No site plan or plat shall be approved under of the Milan Zoning Ordinance unless such site plan or plat shall include soil erosion and sediment control measures consistent with the requirements of this chapter and related land development regulations. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-4. - Compliance with chapter required for occupancy. 
(a)  No certificate of occupancy for any building, other than a single-family unit, shall be issued under the City Code unless the applicant for such certificate shall have complied substantially with the requirements of this chapter and related land development regulations and shall have substantially completed all soil erosion and sediment control measures contained in any plat or site plan approval for the applicant. 
(b)  If permanent soil erosion control measures are not in place at the time the certificate of occupancy for a single-family unit is issued, a security deposit will be posted with the building department. 
(c)  Upon the approval of the city council, the building department will publish a lot stabilization policy which will establish the amount of the single-family unit security deposit, the policy regarding forfeiture of the security deposit, inclement weather policy, and other rules and guidelines necessary to insure compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94; Ord. No. 2001-05, § 1, 11-12-01) 
Sec. 171/2-5. - Permits and fees. 
(a)  Except as expressly permitted by this chapter, no person shall do any grading, stripping, excavating or filling unless he has first received a valid grading permit issued by the building official in accordance with this chapter. 
(b)  A separate application shall be required for each grading permit required by this chapter. Plans, specifications and timing schedules shall be submitted with each application for a grading permit. The plans shall be prepared or approved and signed by a professional engineer or by an architect; provided that the building official may waive such preparation, approval and signature requirements if, in the judgment of the building official, the work entails little hazard to the adjacent property and does not include the construction of a fill upon which a structure may be erected. 
(c)  The plans and specifications accompanying the grading permit application shall contain the following data: 
(1)  A vicinity sketch at the scale of one (1) inch equals two hundred (200) feet indicating the side location as well as the adjacent properties within five hundred (500) feet of the site boundaries. 
(2)  A boundary line survey of the site on which the work is to be performed. 
(3)  A plan of the site at a scale of one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet showing: 
a.  Name, address and telephone number of the owner, developer, and petitioner. 
b.  A timing schedule indicating the anticipated starting and completion dates of the development sequence and the time of exposure of each area prior to the completion of effective erosion and sediment control measures. 
c.  A certified statement of the quantity of excavation and fill involved. 
d.  Existing topography at a maximum of five-foot contour intervals. 
e.  Proposed topography at a maximum of five-foot contour intervals. 
f.  Location of all structures and natural features on the site. 
g.  Location of all structures and natural features on the land adjacent to the site and within fifty (50) feet of the site boundary line. 
h.  Location of all proposed additional structures and development on the site. 
i.  Elevations, dimensions, location, extent and the slope of all proposed grading (including building and driveway grades). 
j.  The estimated total cost of the required soil erosion controls. 
k.  Plans of all drainage provisions, retaining walls, cribbing, planting, antierosion devices, and other protective devices to be constructed in connection with, or as a part of, the proposed work, together with a map showing the drainage runoff of the area served by any drains. 
l.  Other information or data as may be required by the building official, such as a soil investigation report which shall include, but not be limited to, data regarding the nature, distribution and supporting ability of existing soils and rock on the site. 
(d)  At the time of filing an application for a grading permit, the applicant shall pay a plan review fee, in the amount that is specified for such fee in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. At the same time, the applicant shall also pay a grading permit fee, which shall be based upon the acreage of the proposed project, and which shall be in an amount that is specified for such fees in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council; provided, however, that if, in the building official's judgment, a plan involves unusual conditions that will likely result in engineering and/or inspection costs exceeding such fee amount, the building official may, at the time that the application is filed or during the installation and course of completion of the work, require that the applicant deposit an additional sum to be applied against the city's cost of the engineering and inspection work required by this chapter. Upon final inspection and completion of the work in accordance with the grading permit, the city shall refund to the applicant any sums so deposited which exceed the city's cost of the engineering and inspection work required by this chapter. For purposes of this section, the city's cost shall be deemed to be the amounts paid to the engineer(s) for inspection services plus ten (10) per cent of such amount. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-6. - Bond requirement. 
(a)  A grading permit shall not be issued for grading involving the movement of more than one thousand (1,000) cubic yards of soil unless the permit applicant shall first post with the building official a bond, executed by the owner and a corporate surety authorized to do business in this state as a surety, which bond shall be in a form approved by the city attorney, payable to the city, and in the amount of the estimated total cost of the work authorized by the permit. Such total cost shall be estimated by the building official. In lieu of a surety bond, the applicant may file with the city a cash bond or an instrument of credit approved by the city attorney in the amount equal to that which would be required for the surety bond. 
(b)  Every bond and instrument of credit submitted under this chapter shall include, and every cash deposit shall be made on, the penalty conditions that the permittee shall comply with all of the provisions of this chapter and all of the terms and conditions of the grading permit, and shall complete all of the work contemplated under the grading permit within the time limit specified in the grading permit, or if no time limit is specified, within one hundred eighty (180) days after the date of the issuance of the permit. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-7. - Extension of time. 
    If the permittee is unable to complete the work within the time specified in the grading permit, the permittee may, at least ten (10) days prior to the expiration of the permit, present in writing to the building official a request for an extension of time, setting forth the reasons for the requested extension. In the event such an extension is warranted, the building official may, but shall not be required to, grant additional time for the completion of the work, but no such extension shall release the owner or the surety on the bond or the person furnishing the instrument of credit or cash bond. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-8. - Failure to complete work. 
    In the event of failure to complete the work or failure to comply with all of the requirements, conditions and terms of the applicable grading permit, the building official may order the immediate completion of such part of the work as is necessary to eliminate any danger to persons or property and to leave the site in a safe condition, or he may order the completion of all of the work authorized by the permit. The permittee and the surety executing the bond or person issuing the instrument of credit or making the cash deposit shall continue to be firmly bound under a continuing obligation for the payment of all necessary costs and expenses that may be incurred or expended by the city in causing any and all such work to be done by either the permittee or another party, including the city. In the case of a cash deposit, any unused portion thereof shall be refunded to the permittee. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-9. - Denial of permit. 
    Grading permits shall not be issued where: 
(1)  The proposed grading would cause hazards to the public safety and welfare; or 
(2)  The work as proposed by the application will damage any public or private property or interfere with any existing drainage course in such a manner as to cause damage to any adjacent property or result in the deposition of debris or sediment on any public way or into any waterway or create an unreasonable hazard to persons or property; or 
(3)  The land area for which grading is proposed is subject to geological hazard to the extent that no reasonable amount of corrective work can eliminate or sufficiently reduce settlement, slope instability or any other such hazard to persons or property; or 
(4)  The land area for which the grading is proposed may lie within the fifty-years flood plain of any stream or watercourse (not specifically designated and delineated by the city as an area subject to flood hazard), unless a hydrologic report, prepared by a professional engineer, is submitted to certify that the proposed grading will, in his or her opinion, have no detrimental influence on the public welfare or upon the total development of the watershed. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-10. - Modifications of approved plans. 
    All modifications of the approved grading plans must be submitted and approved by the building official prior to implementation of any proposed modification. All necessary sustaining reports shall be submitted with any proposal to modify the approved grading plan. No grading work in connection with any proposed modification shall be permitted without the approval of the building official. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-11. - Responsibility of permittee. 
    During grading operations the permittee shall be responsible for: 
(1)  The prevention of damage to public utilities and/or services within the limits of grading and along all routes of travel of the equipment. 
(2)  The prevention of damage to adjacent property. No person shall grade on land so close to the property line as to endanger any adjoining public street, sidewalk, alley or any public or private property without supporting and protecting such property from settling, cracking or other damage which might result. 
(3)  Carrying out the proposed work in accordance with the approved plans and in compliance with all the requirements of the grading permit and this chapter. 
(4)  The prompt removal of all soil, miscellaneous debris and other materials applied, dumped or otherwise deposited on public streets, highways, sidewalks, or other public thoroughfares during transit to and from the construction, where such spillage constitutes a public nuisance or hazard. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-12. - Maintenance requirements. 
    Persons carrying out soil erosion and sediment control measures under this chapter, and all subsequent owners of property concerning which such measures have been taken, shall maintain all permanent antierosion devices, retaining walls, structures, plantings, and other protective devices. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-13. - Minimum design standards for erosion and sediment control. 
    All grading plans and specifications including extensions of previously approved plans shall include provisions for erosion and sediment control in accordance with but not limited to the minimum control measures adopted by the board of directors of the Washtenaw County Soil Conservation District on June 13, 1974, and as subsequently amended and published by such board. Copies of such standards shall be available for inspection in the offices of the city clerk/treasurer and the building official. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-14. - Variances and exceptions. 
    The zoning board of appeals shall have the authority to interpret this chapter and may in specific cases grant variances and exceptions to these requirements, providing such variances or exceptions to these requirements are in general harmony with the general purpose and intent of these requirements. The procedural requirements and fees for appeals to the zoning board of appeals under the City of Milan Zoning Ordinance shall be applicable to appeals under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 171/2-15. - Inspection and enforcement. 
    The requirements of this chapter shall be enforced by the building official; provided, however, that any authorized local official, as defined in Chapter 131/4 of this Code, shall be authorized to issue municipal ordinance violation notices or citations for violations of the provisions of this article. The building official shall inspect the work and shall require adequate inspection of compaction by a soil engineer or by a soil testing agency, approved by the building official, unless he determines that such inspection requirements may be waived due to the nonhazardous nature of the grading. If the building official finds any existing conditions not as stated in any permit application, grading permit or approved plan, he may, in addition to the procedures and penalties referenced in section 171/2-16 of this article, refuse to approve further work until approval of a revised grading plan which will conform to the existing conditions. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 23, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 171/2-16. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  When, by the provisions of this chapter, the performance of any act is required, or the performance of any act is prohibited, a failure to comply with such provisions shall constitute a violation of this chapter. Violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for such municipal civil infraction, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this chapter is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(b)  The penalties specified in this section shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other remedy that the city may have at law and/or in equity. In the event of any violation of this chapter, the building official may issue a stop-work order on the remaining portion of the work and/or may refuse the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. Such actions by the building official shall not preclude the imposition of any other penalty provided for violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 23, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 171/2-17. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portion of this chapter; it being the intent of the city council that this chapter shall stand, notwithstanding the invalidity of any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 23, 5-9-94) 
Chapter 18 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city relative to streets, alleys and public ways, § 2.2(8), (9). 
Cross reference- Consumption of alcoholic liquor on the public streets prohibited, § 3-5; animals and fowl, Ch. 5; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; peddlers, solicitors, transient and itinerant merchants and itinerant vendors, Ch. 14; public improvements, Ch. 16; subdivisions, Ch. 19; traffic, Ch. 21; trees and shrubs, Ch. 22; vehicles for hire, Ch. 23; water and sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 24; zoning, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Obstructing streets, alleys, etc.; permit; penalties. 
(a)  It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to encumber, obstruct or make unsafe or inconvenient for travel in any manner whatsoever any public street, crosswalk, lane, alley, bridge, ground or right-of-way, or any portion thereof, within the city, or to wrongfully permit the same to remain, without first obtaining from the director of public works a permit to do so, and then only to such extent and for such time as is specified in such permit. Application for such a permit shall be made on forms designated by the director of public works and shall be accompanied by the fee specified for such a permit in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  In the event that any person shall violate the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, any authorized local official, as defined in section 131/4-1 of this Code, shall be authorized to notify, order or require the person responsible for such violation, if known, to forthwith cure such violation or cause the same to be cured in some effectual manner. If any such person shall neglect or refuse to comply with any such notice, order or requirement, he or she shall be deemed liable for a separate and distinct municipal civil infraction for each day after receiving any such notice, order or requirement, during which he or she shall continue to so neglect or refuse to cure the violation. Further, the curing of the violation of subsection (a) after receipt of the notice, order or requirement specified in this subsection (b), shall not operate to relieve any party of liability for the municipal civil infraction referenced in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  In the event that a violation of subsection (a) of this section is not cured in the manner provided in subsection (b) within a reasonable time after the notice, order or requirement mentioned in subsection (b) is given, and also in the event there is no proper person known to whom to give such notice, order or requirement, and any authorized local official, as defined in section 131/4-1 of this Code, shall be authorized to forthwith cure such violation or cause the same to be cured at the expense of the city. Such authorized local official shall keep a strict account in writing of all expenses incurred in the execution of the duties specified by this section, so as to preserve the city's ability to proceed against the violator under the provisions of section 1-10 of this Code. 
(d)  Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this section, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this chapter is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(Ord. of 4-21-1899, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 24, 5-9-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 24, 1-23-95) 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12; police, Ch. 15. 
Sec. 18-2. - Obstructing sidewalks generally; permit. 
(a)  It shall constitute a civil infraction for any person to permit the limbs or foliage of trees or shrubs which stand upon or in front of or adjacent to any premises in the city owned or occupied by him or her to grow or hang over any sidewalk and/or over any property between the property line and street line lower than seven (7) feet above the upper surface of the sidewalk and/or of the property between the property line and street line. It shall also constitute a civil infraction for any person to place or leave upon any sidewalk and/or upon any property between the property line and street line, or to negligently permit to remain upon any sidewalk adjacent to any premises owned or occupied by him or her and/or upon any property between the property line and the street line, any dirt, rubbish, wood, building materials, boxes, barrels, merchandise or other things whatever, which shall encumber or obstruct the sidewalk and/or the property between the property line and street line; provided, however, that the director of public works, with due consideration for the public health and safety and upon the applicant's payment of the fee specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council, may issue a permit for the temporary use and encumbering of any sidewalk and/or of the property between the property line and the street line for building purposes, or for any necessary and useful purpose. Such a permit shall specify the dates upon which such obstruction or encumbering is permitted, which dates shall be strictly adhered to by the permittee. 
(b)  If any person shall commit any violation of subsection (a) of this section, any authorized local official, as defined by section 131/4-1 of this Code, shall be authorized to immediately notify the person responsible for such violation to cure the violation. If any such person shall neglect or refuse to comply with such notice, he or she shall be deemed liable for a separate and distinct municipal civil infraction for each day after receiving such notice, during which he or she shall continue to so neglect or refuse to cure the violation. Further, the curing of the violation of subsection (a) after receipt of the notice, order or requirement specified in this subsection (b), shall not operate to relieve any party of liability for the municipal civil infraction referenced in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  In the event that a violation of subsection (a) of this section is not cured in the manner provided in subsection (b) within a reasonable time after the notice, order or requirement mentioned in subsection (b) is given, and also in the event there is no proper person known to whom to give such notice, order or requirement, any authorized local official, as defined in section 131/4 of this Code, shall be authorized to forthwith cure such violation or cause the same to be cured at the expense of the city. Such authorized local official shall keep a strict account in writing of all expenses incurred in the execution of the duties specified by this section, and of the names of the persons, if known, liable therefor, and shall promptly return the same, verified by his or her oath, to the best of his or her knowledge, to the city clerk/treasurer. 
(d)  In addition to any other penalty provided or permitted by this Code, the person(s) who violated this section shall be jointly and severally liable to the city for the full amount of all costs incurred by the city pursuant to subsection (c) of this section plus an amount equal to ten (10) per cent of such amount for administrative overhead. The city clerk/treasurer shall bill or cause the billing of all such sums to the person(s) who violated this section. 
(e)  All charges billed by the city clerk/treasurer pursuant to subsection (d) shall, upon billing, become a lien upon the premises to which they apply. On April 1 of each year, the city clerk/treasurer shall certify any and all unpaid charges for such services incurred during the preceding twelve (12) months to the city assessor. The city assessor shall add thereto ten (10) per cent of total charges against each of the several premises so certified to cover the city's additional costs should this procedure be necessary to effect collection, and shall enter the resulting total upon the next tax roll against each of the premises so certified. This lien shall be collected and/or enforced in the same manner as provided in respect to that for any other taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(f)  Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this section, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this chapter is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(Ord. of 3-1-1886, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 3-28-66, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 24, 5-9-94; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 24, 1-23-95) 
Cross reference- Garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 9; licenses, Ch. 12; trees and shrubs, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 18-3. - Obstructing sidewalks with vehicles prohibited. 
    No person shall ride, drive or park any vehicle upon or across, or otherwise obstruct, any public sidewalk within the city excepting for the purpose of ingress and egress to and from lands across or adjacent to such sidewalk. 
(Ord. of 3-1-1886, § 5; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 24, 1-23-95) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 5; traffic, Ch. 21; vehicles for hire, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 18-4. - Obstructing sidewalks by assemblages prohibited. 
    No person shall gather in a crowd upon any public sidewalk within the city so as to obstruct or hinder travel thereon, or fail or refuse to disperse so as to leave the sidewalk free and unobstructed for travel when directed to do so by any police officer. 
(Ord. of 3-1-1886, § 6; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 24, 1-23-95) 
Cross reference- Unlawful assembly, § 13-3. 
Sec. 18-5. - Sidewalks to be kept in good order and repair; failure to comply. 
    The owner and/or occupant of the land, building or premises adjacent to and abutting a public sidewalk within the city shall keep and maintain the portion of such sidewalk that is adjacent to and/or abutting his or her property in good order and repair and safe for use by the general public. If any owner or occupant shall neglect to keep and maintain the sidewalk along the front, rear or side of the land, building or premises owned or occupied by him or her in good repair and safe for the use of the public, then, in addition to any other penalty permitted or provided by this Code, the owner and/or occupant shall be jointly and severally liable to the city for all damages recovered against the city for injury or damage sustained by any person by reason of such sidewalk being unsafe or out of repair. If necessary, the city may collect such damages from such owner and/or occupant by civil suit in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. of 4-20-1899, § 6; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 24, 1-23-95) 
Charter reference- Power of city to require owner of real property to maintain sidewalks abutting upon such property, § 2.2(24). 
Sec. 18-6. - Removal of snow and ice from public sidewalks; charges; collection; lien on premises. 
(a)  The owner and/or occupant of the land, building or premises adjacent to and abutting a public sidewalk within the city shall remove, or cause to be removed, all snow and ice and any obstruction caused thereby for the sidewalk(s) adjacent to and/or abutting his or her property within forty-eight (48) hours after the end of any snow storm or ice accumulation resulting in the accumulation of any amount of snow or ice that would otherwise render the sidewalk unsafe for use by the general public; provided, however, that it shall be an affirmative defense to any violation notice or citation for violation of this subsection (a) that the land owner or occupant cited for violation was unaware of the accumulation of snow or ice upon his or her premises due to his or her physical absence from the premises in question or as the result of any legal incapacity. Further provided, however, that any owner and/or occupant of the land, building or premises adjacent to and abutting a public sidewalk within the city who has advance knowledge that he or she will be absent from the premises for any period in excess of seven (7) consecutive days during the winter season shall be responsible for arranging to have the sidewalk adjacent to and/or abutting his or her premises maintained in accordance with the first clause of this subsection. 
(b)  Violation of subsection (a) by any person responsible for compliance with that subsection shall also be cause for the director of public works to remove, or cause to be removed, all snow and ice and any obstruction caused thereby from the sidewalk(s) adjacent to and/or abutting the violator's property, with the costs of such removal being assessed in accordance with subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  In addition to any other penalty provided or permitted by this Code, the owner and/or occupant in violation of subsection (a) of this section shall be jointly and severally liable to the city for the full amount of all costs incurred by the city pursuant to subsection (b) of this section plus an amount equal to ten (10) per cent of such amount for administrative overhead. The clerk/treasurer shall bill or cause the billing of all such sums to the owner and/or occupant of the land adjacent to and/or abutting the sidewalk from which snow and/or ice were removed by city. 
(d)  All charges billed by the clerk/treasurer pursuant to section 18-6 shall, upon billing, become a lien upon the premises to which they apply. Thirty (30) days prior to the issuance of any/all tax bills each year, the clerk/treasurer shall certify any and all unpaid charges for such services which have been delinquent three (3) months or more and shall add thereto ten (10) percent of total charges against each of the several premises so certified to cover the city's additional costs should this procedure be necessary to effect collection, and shall enter the resulting total upon the next tax roll against each of the premises so certified. This lien shall be collected and/or enforced in the same manner as provided in respect to that for any other taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(Ord. of 12-14-14, §§ 1, 3, 4; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 24, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 2008-01, § 1, 2-25-08) 
Charter reference- Power of city to compel owners of real property to keep sidewalks abutting upon their property clear from snow, ice or other obstructions, § 2.2(26). 
Sec. 18-7. - Ventilator grates in sidewalks; openings under same to be kept clean. 
    All ventilator grates to be placed in public sidewalks within the city shall be placed so they can be removed and the opening under the same cleaned out. All openings under the grates shall be cleaned at least once in each month from the first day of April until the first day of November of each year. 
(Ord. of 6-21-06; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 24, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 18-8. - Violations; penalties. 
    The violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this section, in addition to any other penalty provided or permitted by this Code, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the city from requiring payment of double the normal permit fee if any permit required by this article is not obtained at the time that it is required. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 24, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 18-9-18-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 25 of Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, adopted May 9, 1994, repealed Ch. 18, Art. II, which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of 4-20-1899, §§ 1-13, and added a new Art. II to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 18-19. - Permits; fees. 
(a)  No person shall construct or install any cement walk within any street right-of-way within the city without first obtaining a permit to do so. Application for such permit shall be made by the owner of the property abutting such sidewalk or his agent in writing to the director of public works, and shall include a complete description of the premises adjacent to the proposed walk and detailed plans and specifications of the proposed walk, including the length thereof. Before any permit shall be issued under this article, such plans and specifications shall be approved by the director of public works, and a permit fee shall be paid by the applicant to the city for each permit required by this article. The amount of such fee shall be that specified for "right-of-way sidewalks" in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Under the terms of the permit, the owner on whose behalf the application is made shall agree to construct the sidewalk in conformity with the grade established by the director of public works, according to specifications established by the city engineer and under his inspection. Failure to complete the proposed walk within sixty (60) days after the permit therefor is granted shall result in the expiration of the permit and require making application for another permit which, when made, will be acted upon in the same manner and under the same conditions as the original. 
(b)  No person shall construct or install any cement walk on property that is not within a street right-of-way within the city without first obtaining a permit to do so. Application for such permit shall be made by the owner of the property abutting such sidewalk or his agent in writing to the building official, and shall include a complete description of the premises surrounding the proposed walk and detailed plans and specifications of the proposed walk, including the length thereof. Before any permit shall be issued under this article, such plans and specifications shall be approved by the building official, and a permit fee shall be paid by the applicant to the city for each permit required by this article. The amount of such fee shall be calculated in the same manner as those specified for "building permits" in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Under the terms of the permit, the owner on whose behalf the application is made shall agree to construct the sidewalk in conformity with the directions of the building official and under his inspection. Failure to complete the proposed walk within sixty (60) days after the permit therefor is granted shall result in the expiration of the permit and require making application for another permit which, when made, will be acted upon in the same manner and under the same conditions as the original. 
(c)  The owner of the property abutting the walk covered by a permit issued under this article shall be responsible for the condition of such walk, and all replacements of and repairs to such walk shall be at the expense of such property owner or his successor in title. 
(d)  No person shall construct or make any paved driveway approach or street curb cut or curb drop on any public easement within the city without first obtaining a permit to do so. Application for such permit shall be made by the owner of the property abutting the proposed work or his agent in writing to the director of public works, and shall include a complete description of the premises adjacent to the proposed work and detailed plans and specifications of the proposed work. Before any permit shall be issued under this article, such plans and specifications shall be approved by the director of public works, and a permit fee shall be paid by the applicant to the city for each permit required by this article. The amount of such fee shall be that specified for such permit in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 25, 5-9-94) 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 18-20. - Inspection. 
    Whenever the city shall approve the issuance of any permit required by section 18-19(a) or (d) of this article, all work performed under the permit shall be subject to inspection by the director of public works, who shall reject any material or work which he shall reasonably deem to not be in compliance with the specifications of this article. Whenever the city shall approve the issuance of any permit required by section 18-19(b) of this article, all work performed under the permit shall be subject to inspection by the building official, who shall reject any material or work which he shall reasonably deem to not be in compliance with the specifications of this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 25, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 18-21. - Specifications generally. 
(a)  All sidewalks graded, constructed, repaired or renewed within any street right-of-way within the city shall conform to such specifications as are set forth or provided for in the applicable Michigan Department of Transportation Standards then in effect. All sidewalks graded, constructed, repaired or renewed that are not within a street right-of-way within the city shall conform to such specifications as are set forth or provided for in the applicable building code adopted by ordinance of the city council. 
(b)  All sidewalks along any street within the city, unless otherwise ordered by the city council, shall be constructed of cement; be at least four (4) feet in width; and be so laid as to have one (1) foot of clear space between such walk and the boundary line of the street. 
(c)  Unless otherwise specified by the city council, persons in residential areas shall be permitted to construct sidewalks of a four-inch thickness, laid on a clean sand base. All concrete poured within the public right-of-way which is meant to support vehicular traffic shall be constructed with a minimum six-inch thickness on a clean sand base. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 25, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 18-22. - Petition by property owners; hearing; notice. 
    Whenever a majority of the resident owners of the land along any one side of any street in the city shall petition the city council to construct a sidewalk thereon, the city council shall notice such petition and shall appoint a time when it will meet to consider the same and also to hear objections, if any, and to decide as the public good may require. Notice of the time of such meeting shall be given by publication in a newspaper published in the city or by posting three (3) notices along the line of the proposed walk at least one (1) week before the time of such meeting. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 25, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 18-23. - Authority of city council to order construction. 
    The city council may order sidewalks constructed, repaired or renewed in the public streets of the city, which work shall be performed by the owners or occupants of lands adjacent to or abutting upon such walks, or by the city or its designee at the cost of the owners or occupants of lands adjacent to or abutting upon such walks. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 25, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 18-24. - Order to be by resolution; notice; contents; service. 
(a)  Whenever the city council shall order any walk constructed, renewed or repaired, it shall do so by resolution. Thereupon, it shall be the duty of the director of public works to at once serve a notice thereof upon each owner or occupant of each lot or premises abutting upon or adjacent to the line of the subject sidewalk. Such notice shall be directed to such owner if known, and if not known to the occupant, commanding him to construct, renew or repair such sidewalk as the case may be. Such notice shall contain a description of such lot or premises, the width, material and manner of constructing, renewing or repairing such walk and the time within which the same shall be constructed, renewed or repaired; provided that if in the opinion of the director of public works any walk is in need of immediate repair, the same may be forthwith repaired as provided for herein, after serving written notice as herein provided, commanding the same to be repaired within twenty-four (24) hours from such service. 
(b)  The director of public works shall serve the notice provided for in subsection (a) by delivering or mailing it to the owner of such lot or premises, if known and residing within the corporate limits of the city. If there is no owner known and residing within the corporate limits of the city, the notice shall be served upon the occupant of such lot or premises, if any. If there is no such owner or occupant, such notice shall be posted on the subject lot or premises and, if immediate repair is not necessary, a copy thereof shall be published one (1) week in a newspaper published in the city. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 25, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 18-25. - Failure to comply with notice; city to construct; payment. 
(a)  If the owner or occupant of the lot or premises shall neglect or refuse to construct, renew or repair the sidewalk in accordance with the notice served as provided for in section 18-24, the director of public works shall cause the same to be constructed, renewed or repaired in the manner specified in the notice, and to make and return to the clerk/treasurer an itemized bill showing the cost of material and labor used in and about the construction, renewal or repair of such walk. Such bill shall be certified to by the director of public works as correct and shall be levied and collected together with a penalty of ten (10) per cent added thereto as a special assessment upon such lot or premises. Such bill shall be reported to the city assessor and the [same] shall be collected in the same manner as other city taxes, or the city may collect such amount together with such penalty from the owner or occupant of such lot or premises by commencement of suit in a court of competent jurisdiction, together with the costs of such suit, including reasonable attorney fees. 
(b)  In case any sidewalk shall be constructed, renewed or repaired by the director of public works under and by virtue of any city council resolution passed pursuant to this article or otherwise, the same shall be paid for out of the general funds of the city or such fund as may otherwise be established therefor. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 25, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 18-26. - Violations; penalties. 
    The violation or any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this section, in addition to any other penalty provided or permitted by this Code, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the city from requiring payment of double the normal permit fee if any permit required by this article is not obtained at the time that it is required. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 25, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 18-27-18-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION OF CURBS AND GUTTERS 

Sec. 18-40. - Permit required. 
    No person, firm or corporation other than employees of the City of Milan shall construct, build or install, or cause to be constructed, built or installed, any curb and gutter within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a permit to do so. The application for such permit shall be made to the director of public works and shall be accompanied by any and all information, including a complete and detailed set of plans and specifications of the proposed work, necessary for the determination of whether the construction or installation of the curb and gutter will comply with the provisions of this article and with the applicable city ordinances and resolutions of the city council. Before any permit shall be issued under this article, such plans and specifications shall be approved by the director of public works, and a permit fee shall be paid by the applicant to the city for each permit required by this article. The amount of such fee shall be calculated in the same manner as those specified for "building permits" in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. If the work proposed shall include or require the making of any cut or excavation in any street or public right-of-way, the insurance and bond requirements specified in section 18-57 of this chapter shall also apply to the permit required by this section 18-40. 
(Ord. of 7-8-40, § 2; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 26, 5-9-94) 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 18-41. - Specifications. 
    All curbs and gutters within the city shall conform to the established grade of the street and at such distance from the center line of the street as shall in the discretion of the council be deemed advisable. 
(Ord. of 7-8-40, § 1) 
Sec. 18-42. - Petition by property owners; council to determine expense. 
    Whenever the owners, or their legally constituted representatives, of the majority of the line frontage on a street or a block, or blocks thereof, in the city shall petition for a curb and gutter, the city council shall determine the expense of such improvement, including necessary engineering, grading, graveling, labor and materials and other miscellaneous expense as shall by the city council be deemed necessary in its sole discretion to make the improvement according to the uniform height and width to be adopted by the city on such curbs and gutters. 
(Ord. of 7-8-40, § 1) 
Sec. 18-43. - Payment. 
(a)  The council shall determine the amount to be raised by tax upon all the property in the city, or the city may be divided into curb and gutter districts and a part of the whole expense of improvement in each district may be paid from a district fund to be raised by tax upon property in the district, or the expense may be defrayed by special assessment upon the lots and premises abutting upon such improvement in proportion to the number of feet upon the street, or a part of such expense may be paid and the remainder may be paid from the general fund or from the district fund as the council may decide. The lots and premises to be assessed upon their frontage upon a street improvement as aforesaid shall constitute a special assessment. 
(b)  When expenses for such improvement shall be assessed in a special assessment district and there shall be lands belonging to the city, school buildings or other public buildings or public grounds not taxable fronting upon such improvement, such part of the expense of such improvement as in the opinion of the council making the special assessment will be justly apportionable to such public grounds, buildings and city property, and to any interior squares or spaces formed by the intersection of streets, where they are taxable, shall be paid from such city fund as shall be determined by the council. The balance of such expense shall be assessed upon the taxable lots and premises included in the special assessment district in proportion to their feet frontage upon such improvement. When such assessment is to be made upon lots in proportion to their frontage upon the improvement if from the shape or size of any lot an assessment thereon in proportion to their frontage would be unjust and disproportionate to the assessment upon other lots, the council may assess such lot for such number of feet frontage as in its opinion will be just. 
(Ord. of 7-8-40, § 3) 
Cross reference- Special assessment procedure, Ch. 16, Art. II. 
Sec. 18-44. - Council to keep record; to let contract. 
    Whenever the council shall determine the necessary public improvement under this article, it shall do so by making a record thereof in its proceedings, and let the contract therefor to the lowest responsible bidder in the event the city council shall advertise for bids. 
(Ord. of 7-8-40, § 4) 
Sec. 18-45. - Hearing; collection of taxes and assessments. 
    A public hearing shall be held at any regular or special meeting of the city council after receipt of the petition under this article, at which time any person interested may be heard. The council shall determine the method of raising the funds by taxation for the improvement. All taxes and special assessments shall be collected in accordance with the present method of collecting taxes in the city and delinquent taxes and assessments shall be treated in the same manner as now provided by law for all delinquent and unpaid taxes. The city reserves unto itself all the rights and remedies now in full force and effect for the collection of unpaid taxes, including the sale of lands for delinquent taxes or suit at law. 
(Ord. of 7-8-40, § 5) 
Cross reference- Special assessment procedure, Ch. 16, Art. II. 
Sec. 18-46. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  The violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this section, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the city from requiring payment of double the normal permit fee if any permit required by this article is not obtained at the time that it is required. 
(b)  In the event that any person shall violate the provisions of any section of this article, any authorized local official, as defined in section 131/4-1 of this Code, shall be authorized to notify, order or require the person responsible for such violation, if known, to forthwith cure such violation or cause the same to be cured in some effectual manner. If any such person shall neglect or refuse to comply with any such notice, order or requirement, he or she shall be deemed liable for a separate and distinct municipal civil infraction for each day after receiving any such notice, order or requirement, during which he or she shall continue to so neglect or refuse to cure the violation. Further, the curing of the initial violation after receipt of the notice, order or requirement specified in this subsection (b), shall not operate to relieve any party of liability for the municipal civil infraction referenced in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  In the event that a violation of this article is not cured in the manner provided in subsection (b) within a reasonable time after the notice, order or requirement mentioned in subsection (b) is given, and also in the event there is no proper person known to whom to give such notice, order or requirement, any authorized local official, as defined in section 131/4-1 of this Code, shall be authorized to forthwith cure such violation or cause the same to be cured at the expense of the city. Such authorized local official shall keep a strict account in writing of all expenses incurred in the execution of the duties specified by this section, so as to preserve the city's ability to proceed against the violator under the provisions of section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 26, 1-23-95) 
Secs. 18-47-18-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATING IN PUBLIC STREETS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 27 of Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, adopted January 23, 1995, repealed Ch. 18, Art. IV, §§ 18-56-18-65, which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. C.O. 80-8, adopted August 25, 1980 and Ord. No. 94-5, § 27, adopted May 9, 1994. 

Sec. 18-56. - Permit required. 
    No person, firm or corporation other than employees of the City of Milan shall excavate, dig or cause to excavate or dig in any public street, alley or other public right-of-way within the City of Milan, nor shall any person, firm or corporation other than employees of the City of Milan destroy, remove or relocate any curb or gutter within the City of Milan for any purpose whatsoever without first having obtained a written permit for such work. The application for such permit shall be made to the director of public works and shall be accompanied by any and all information, including a complete and detailed set of plans and specifications of the proposed work, necessary for the determination of whether the work will comply with the provisions of this article and with the applicable city ordinances and resolutions of the city council. The applicant shall also file therewith documents evidencing the existence of all insurance and bonds required by this article. Before any permit shall be issued under this article, such plans and specifications shall be approved by the director of public works, and a permit fee shall be paid by the applicant to the city for each permit required by this article. The amounts of such fees shall be those specified for the applicable permit in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 27, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 18-56.1. - Prohibited openings. 
    No permit to make any opening or excavation in or under a paved street shall be granted to any person, firm or corporation within a three-year period after the completion of any reconstruction, paving or resurfacing thereof. If a street opening is necessary as a public safety measure, the director of public works or designee may suspend the operation of this section as to such street opening. 
    If any opening or excavation in or under a paved street is made within a three year period after the completion of any reconstruction, paving or resurfacing, the responsible person, firm or corporation will be assessed a set fee per the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2003-09, § 1, 12-22-2003) 
Sec. 18-57. - Insurance and bond requirements. 
(a)  Insurance and bond requirements for the issuance of any permit required by section 18-56 of this article are as follows: 
(1)  Prior to the issuance of any permit required by section 18-56 of this article, the permit applicant shall post with the city a surety bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); provided, however, that if the director of public works determines that the estimated maximum cost of fully restoring such a street or alley will exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), then the required bond shall be in the amount of the estimated maximum cost of restoration of the street or alley, as determined by the director of public works, plus ten (10) percent. Prior to the issuance of a permit for the making of any cut in or removal of any curb and/or gutter, the permit applicant shall post with the city a surety bond in the amount of the estimated maximum cost plus ten (10) percent, as determined by the director of public works, of restoring and replacing such curb and/or gutter. 
(2)  Every bond and instrument of credit submitted under this chapter shall include, and every cash or cashier's check deposit shall be made on, the penalty conditions that the permittee (i) shall comply with all of the provisions of this chapter including, but not limited to, all of the terms and conditions of each applicable permit and the timely payment of all repair and restoration costs, and (ii) shall complete all of the work contemplated by each applicable permit within the time limit(s) specified in the permits, or if no time limit is specified, within sixty (60) days after the date of the issuance of each permit. A cashier's check, payable to the city and for the required amount, may be submitted to the office of the clerk/treasurer in lieu of any surety bond otherwise required by this chapter. 
(3)  Public liability insurance, in the name of the applicant, naming the city as an additional insured, to include explosion, collapse and underground hazard coverage for bodily injury, including accidental death, and property damage. 
(4)  Owner's protective public liability in the name of the city, to include explosion, collapse and underground hazard coverage, for bodily injuries, including accidental death and property damage. 
(5)  Workers compensation insurance protecting all persons performing work in the excavation, digging and/or the restoration. 
(6)  All insurance required by this article shall provide policy limits per occurrence and in the aggregate in amounts deemed acceptable by the city attorney, and shall require thirty (30) days prior notice to the city before its cancellation or any reduction in coverage. 
(b)  Any public utility regulated by the Michigan Public Service Commission with a franchise in force with the city shall be responsible for any and all costs of restoration, signing and barricading and other related work performed as a result of and/or made necessary by the utility's operation in city streets. All provisions of this article shall apply to public utilities in a like manner and with equal respect as to any other person, firm or corporation. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 27, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 2010-02, § 1, 6-28-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-02, § 1, adopted June 28, 2010, amended § 18-57 to read as set out herein. Section 5 of Ord. No. 2010-02 provided for an effective date of July 18, 2010. 
Sec. 18-58. - Permit fee; contents of permit. 
(a)  The fees for permits to remove or replace curbs and/or gutters and/or for the relocation of a driveway and/or the creation of a driveway approach shall be those specified for such permits in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council and shall be paid at the time that application is made for the permit. 
(b)  The fees for permits to excavate or dig in a street or alley shall be those specified for such permits in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Such permit fees shall be paid by the applicant at the time that application for the permit is made. 
(c)  Each permit required herein shall state the following: 
(1)  Name and address of owner, agent or other party for whom the work is being done. 
(2)  Name and address of builder, contractor or agent having charge of such work. 
(3)  Location of work to be done. 
(4)  Date of commencement and estimated duration of the work. 
(5)  Nature of the work. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 27, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 18-59. - Barricades, lights, etc. 
    The recipient of any permit issued under this article shall provide, erect and maintain all necessary barricades, lights, warning signs, etc., to properly safeguard traffic while work is in progress, and at no time shall the street or highway be closed to traffic longer than is necessary to complete the work and maintain safety. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 27, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 18-60. - Replacement of asphalt pavement. 
    Upon completion of any work for which a permit is required by this article and which involves an excavation or trench in any public street, alley or right-of-way the permittee shall immediately cause such excavation to be back-filled in a method approved by the director of public works, and shall also cause each area from which concrete or asphalt pavement has been removed to be temporarily patched using the product commonly known as "cold patch." All surplus earth and all refuse resulting from the work shall also be removed from the street by the permittee. The director of public works or his designee shall immediately estimate the cost to make a permanent repair of all involved areas and notify the permittee of such estimated cost. The permittee shall immediately pay such estimated cost to the city, and upon failure to do so, the city may cause such amount to be deducted from or charged against the bond or cashier's check posted in accordance with this article, or may pursue any other remedy at law or in equity including, without limitation, its remedies under section 2-71 of the Milan City Code. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 27, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 18-61. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  The violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this section, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the city from requiring payment of double the normal permit fee if any permit required by this article is not obtained at the time that it is required. 
(b)  In the event that the permittee shall fail to fully carry out the provisions of this article and/or comply with the terms of the applicable permit, including without limitation, completing all work and/or restoring all excavation, trenches and curbs and gutters to a condition acceptable to the director of public works or his or her designee, then the city shall perform all work necessary to cure such noncompliance and/or violation(s), and, in addition to any other penalty provided or permitted by this Code, the permittee and the owner of the premises being served by the work at issue in the permit shall be jointly and severally liable to the city for the full amount of all costs incurred by the city in doing so plus an amount equal to ten (10) per cent of such amount for administrative overhead. The clerk/treasurer shall bill or cause the billing of all such sums to the permittee and the owner of the premises being served by the work at issue in the permit, and upon doing so, may deduct such amount from the surety company. The amount of the surety posted pursuant to section 18-57 shall not operate to limit the liability of the persons billed by the clerk/treasurer under this section, and they shall remain liable to the city for any amount so billed that exceeds the surety posted pursuant to section 18-57. 
(c)  All charges billed by the clerk/treasurer pursuant to subsection (b) shall, upon billing, become a lien upon the premises being served by the work at issue in the permit. On April 1 of each year, the clerk/treasurer shall certify any and all unpaid charges for such services incurred during the preceding twelve (12) months to the city assessor. The city assessor shall add thereto ten (10) per cent of total charges against each of the several premises so certified to cover the city's additional costs should this procedure be necessary to effect collection, and shall enter the resulting total upon the next tax roll against each of the premises so certified. This lien shall be collected and/or enforced in the same manner as provided in respect to that for any other taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 27, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 18-62. - Questions concerning matters covered by article. 
    Any question concerning any matter covered by this article shall first be directed to the director of public works for resolution. In the event that the director is unable to fully resolve any such question, the matter shall be resolved by the city council, whose decision shall be final. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 27, 1-23-95) 
Chapter 20 - SWIMMING POOLS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; subdivisions, Ch. 19; water and sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 24; zoning, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 20-1-20-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRIVATE SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 20-16. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, certain terms are herewith defined. 
    Private. The term "private" shall mean that it is not open to the public, that it is not publicly owned, or not otherwise regulated by the state either by statute or by rules or regulations of one of its administrative bodies. 
    Swimming pool. The term "swimming pool" shall mean any artificially constructed pool capable of being used for swimming or bathing, having a depth of two (2) feet or more at any point. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 1) 
Sec. 20-17. - Permit. 
    Any person desiring to construct or install, or cause to be constructed or installed, any private swimming pool upon property within the corporate limits of the City of Milan shall first apply to the building department for a permit to do so. The application for such permit shall be accompanied by any and all information, including a complete and detailed set of plans and specifications of the swimming pool, required and necessary for the determination of whether the construction or installation of the pool will comply with the provisions of this article and with the applicable city ordinances and resolutions of the city council. Before any permit shall be issued under this article, such plans and specifications shall be approved by the building department, and a permit fee shall be paid by the applicant to the city for each permit required by this article. The amount of such fee shall be calculated in the same manner as those specified for "building permits" in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Before any swimming pool shall be used, a final inspection and approval must be obtained from the building department. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 2; Ord. No. C.O. 78-5, § 1, 8-14-78; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 28, 5-9-94) 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 20-18. - Location. 
    Private swimming pools in the city shall not be any nearer than six (6) feet from the side or rear lot lines or from any house, building or residence unless the city inspector shall approve a shorter distance. If there are overhead power lines, a clearance of ten (10) feet is required from a vertical drop of the power line to the swimming pool. In addition, no swimming pool shall be located closer than one (1) foot from any recorded easement or within any easement or right-of-way which has been granted for public utility use. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3; Ord. No. 2003-01, § 4, 2-24-03) 
Sec. 20-19. - Walls and floors; materials, etc. 
    Private residential swimming pool walls and floors shall be constructed of any material which will provide a tight tank and easily cleaned surfaces. The walls shall be of a smooth finish. The floor or bottom surface of the pool shall have a finish as smooth as practicable. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-20. - Structural design of walls. 
    Nonportable private residential swimming pool walls shall be designed to withstand the water pressure from within and to resist the pressure of the earth or ground water when the pool is empty to a pressure of twenty-two hundred (2,200) pounds per square foot. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-21. - Slope. 
    The slope of the bottom of any private swimming pool in the city where the water is less than five (5) feet deep shall not be more than one (1) foot in each six (6), except at the deep end and at such point where the water is more than five (5) feet deep, there shall be securely installed into the walls of coping corrosion resistant fasteners on opposite sides of the pool to which shall be attached a life line with floats which shall not be more than five (5) feet apart. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-22. - Location of wires; underwater lighting. 
    No exposed electric wires shall be nearer than five (5) feet from the water's edge of any private swimming pool in the city. Any exposed and permanently installed electric wire within twenty-five (25) feet from the water's edge of the pool shall not be less than ten (10) feet above the ground. Wires of any kind shall not cross or be over the water surface unless otherwise approved by the city inspector. Any underwater lighting shall be accomplished by the use of methods and materials approved for such purposes. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-22.1. - Electrical requirements. 
    Private swimming pools in the city shall require #8 solid wire or larger bonding, attached at every upright at the bottom edge of the swimming pool. All electrical installations or wiring in connection with swimming pools shall conform to the provisions of the National Electrical Code and will require an electrical permit be obtained from the building department prior to commencement of work. 
(Ord. No. 2003-01, § 5, 2-24-03) 
Sec. 20-23. - Water supply. 
    No source of water other than that secured from the city waterworks distribution system shall be used in private residential swimming pools in the city. The line from the city water supply to the pool shall be protected against back flow of polluted water by means of an air gap and shall discharge at least six (6) inches above the maximum highwater level of the make-up tank or pool. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-24. - Recirculating system; rate of application of water on filters. 
    The entire recirculating system of any private swimming pool in the city shall be capable of filtering and recirculating the entire volume content of the pool during a twelve (12) hour period. The rate of application of pool water on the filters shall not be greater than three (3) gallons per minute per square foot of filter area. The health department may approve other rates of recirculation or rates of application of water on the filters. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-25. - Filter system. 
    The construction of any private swimming pool in the city shall be made in such a manner that all scum, splash and deck water shall not return to the pool except through the filter system. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-26. - To be kept clean.
