    Any private swimming pool in the city shall be kept free at all times of floating material, sediment and debris either by an automatic surface skimmer, scum gutter or by some other means approved by the health department. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-27. - Germicidal or bacterial control. 
    A provision shall be made for positive germicidal or bacterial control of any private swimming pool in the city by the use of chlorine, bromine or other such disinfecting agents as may be approved by the health department. Such disinfecting agents shall be applied to the pool water at a uniform rate. Provisions shall be made for adjusting the application thereof so as to keep the germicidal or bacterial protection of the water in the pool equal to a standard of 0.5 parts per million to 1.0 parts per million chlorine residual. Testing devices capable of accurately measuring such residual shall be provided. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-28. - Connection of drain line to city sewer system. 
    The drain line for any private swimming pool in the city may be connected to the city sewer system if the following provisions are complied with: 
(1)  The pool drain shall be connected to the storm sewer if one is available. 
(2)  Where a storm sewer is not available, the pool drain may be connected to a sanitary sewer or a combined sewer subject to the approval of the director of public works or his duly authorized representative. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-29. - To be enclosed by a fence; gates; exception. 
    All private swimming pools in the city to be constructed or installed or which are already constructed or installed shall be enclosed by a fence which shall be at least four (4) feet in height and which shall be of a type not readily climbed by children. The gates shall be of a self-closing and latching type with the latch on the inside of the gate, not readily available for children to open; provided, however, that if the entire premises of the residence is enclosed, then this provision may be waived by the city inspector upon inspection and approval of the residence enclosure. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 3) 
Sec. 20-30. - Disturbing the peace. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued at any private swimming pool in the city any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise or any noise which annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others. 
(b)  In the operation of any private swimming pool in the city, the use or permitting the use or operation of any radio, receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for the convenient hearing of any person who is in the swimming pool premises shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 5) 
Sec. 20-31. - Inspection. 
    The health department and the city inspector shall have the right at any reasonable hour to inspect any private swimming pool in the city for the purpose of determining that all provisions of this article are fulfilled and complied with. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 6) 
Sec. 20-32. - Violations; penalties; nuisances and abatement. 
(a)  The violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal infraction referenced in this section, the violator shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(b)  The violation of any provision of this article, including but not limited to any improper or incorrect installation, operation, maintenance or use, shall also constitute a nuisance, and the city may, in addition to the civil infraction penalties specified in subsection (a) of this section, obtain abatement of such nuisance through commencement of a civil action or any other procedure available to the city at law or in equity. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 8, Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 28, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 20-33. - Article not intended to amend or alter existing ordinances or state statutes. 
    This article in no wise is intended to amend or alter any existing city ordinance or state statute, provisions of which are not covered in this article. 
(Ord. of 2-25-60, § 7) 
Chapter 21 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; right-of-way of fire vehicles, § 8-31; storing and parking of junked motor vehicles, § 13-71 et seq.; motorboats, §§ 13-90, 13-91; police, Ch. 15; railroads, Ch. 17; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; obstructing sidewalks with vehicles, § 18-3; vehicles for hire, Ch. 23. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2004-02, § 1, repealed and reenacted article I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, article I pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2002-07, § 1, adopted December 23, 2002. 
State Law reference- Michigan Vehicle Code, M.S.A., § 9.1801 et seq. 

Sec. 21-1. - Code and amendments and revisions adopted. 
    The Uniform Traffic Code for the city as promulgated by the director of the Michigan Department of State Police pursuant to the administrative procedures act of 1969, 1969 PA 306, MCL 24.328 and made effective October 1, 2003 and all future amendments and revisions to the Uniform Traffic Code when they are promulgated and effective in this state are incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2004-02, § 1, 1-26-2004) 
Sec. 21-2. - References in the Code. 
    References in the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages to a "governmental unit" shall mean the city. 
(Ord. No. 2004-02, § 1, 1-26-2004) 
Sec. 21-3. - Notice to be published. 
    The city clerk shall publish this ordinance in the manner required by law and shall publish, at the same time, a notice stating the purpose of the of the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages and the fact that a complete copy of the code is available to the public at the office of the clerk for inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2004-02, § 1, 1-26-2004) 
Sec. 21-4. - Penalties. 
    The penalties provided by the Uniform Traffic Code for the city are adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2004-02, § 1, 1-26-2004) 
Secs. 21-5-21-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES GENERALLY 

Secs. 21-14, 21-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sections 21-14 and 21-15, derived from Ord. of June 13, 1955, §§ 1, 2, and Ord. No. C.O. 69-6, § 15, adopted Nov. 10, 1969, relative to operation of vehicles by persons who are habitual users of or under the influence of narcotic drugs or intoxicating liquor, were repealed by Ord. No. C.O. 81-4, adopted Aug. 10, 1981. 
Sec. 21-16. - Procedure when overtaking or meeting stopped school bus. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle shall not overtake or meet and pass any school bus which has stopped for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle overtaking or meeting any school bus which has stopped for the purpose of receiving or discharging any passenger shall bring such vehicle to a full stop at least ten (10) feet from the school bus and shall not proceed until the school bus resumes motion or the school bus driver signals to proceed or the visual signals are no longer actuated. The driver of the school bus, before resuming motion, shall signal stopped traffic to proceed and shall, when resuming motion, proceed in such a manner as to allow congested traffic to disperse by keeping the bus as near to the right side of the road as can be done with safety. Passengers crossing the road upon being discharged from a school bus shall cross in front of the stopped school bus. 
(Ord. of 5-25-59, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.S.A., § 9.2382(a), (b). 
Sec. 21-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 81-4, enacted Aug. 10, 1981, repealed § 21-17, prohibiting power-driven vehicles in certain areas. Said section was derived from Ord. No. C.O. 69-3, § 1, adopted June 23, 1969. 
Sec. 21-18. - Use, operation of bicycles. 
(a)  The operation of a bicycle within the limits of the City of Milan shall be in conformance with Chapter 6 of the Uniform Traffic Code of Cities, Townships and Villages, adopted by the City of Milan by Ordinance 81-4 [section 21-1 of this chapter.] 
(b)  No person shall ride a bicycle on the sidewalk on either side of Main Street between the intersection of County Street and the intersection of Church Street; on either side of Wabash Street between Wilson Park and Main Street; and on Tolan Street between Main Street and First Street. The rider of any bicycle entering this area shall dismount before entering onto the sidewalk, and shall walk his or her bicycle while on said sidewalk. 
(c)  The director of public works shall place signs at reasonable distances in the above stated areas informing of this prohibition. 
(d)  The chief of police, or his designated agent, shall remove bicycles from public places to a bicycle pound or other place of safety: 
(1)  When a bicycle is deemed to be abandoned; 
(2)  When a violation notice cannot be presented to the owner or operator of the bicycle in person; 
(3)  When a bicycle is blocking pedestrian traffic or a sidewalk within the area defined in subsection (b) hereof. 
(e)  When a bicycle is impounded under the provision of subsection (d) hereof, and the chief of police is able to ascertain the owner thereof, he shall, within a reasonable period of time, give or cause to be given a notice in writing to the owner of the fact of impoundment and the reason therefor. 
(f)  No impounded bicycle shall be released to the owner except upon payment to the city treasurer of the sum of three dollars ($3.00) as an impoundment fee. 
(g)  Any bicycle impounded hereunder may, after a month from date of impoundment, be sold by the chief of police pursuant to the provisions of section 15-1.1, Milan City Code. 
(h)  Violation of this section shall be a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 79-7, §§ 1-8, 8.13-79) 
Sec. 21-19. - Regulation of the operation, speed and parking of motor vehicles on property owned by any board of education, school district or community college. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. Act 175 of Public Acts of 1958 (MCL 257.961), as amended, authorizes the city to adopt an ordinance governing the operation, speed and parking without fees of motor vehicles on property owned by a board of education, school district or community college for the purposes of enforcement and the imposing of penalties for the violation thereof in the same manner as other codes and ordinances of the city are enforced on its city streets. Such authority is granted by state law upon receipt of a resolution from the board of education, school board or community college requesting the adoption of such ordinances. 
(b)  Requesting resolutions. The following educational entities have presented the city with a resolution requesting the enforcement of the operation, speed and parking without fees on their respective properties: 
Milan Area Schools Board of Education, by resolution dated September 13, 2006. 
(c)  Enforcement of Uniform Traffic Code, Michigan Vehicle Code and the Motor Carrier Safety Act. The provisions of the Uniform Vehicle Traffic Code, the Michigan Vehicle Code and the Motor Carrier Safety Act, respectively adopted by reference in sections 21-1 et seq., 21-110 et seq., and 21-114 et seq. are hereby made applicable to the property of the requesting educational entity set forth in subsection (b). 
(d)  Establishment of speeds. The city council may, by resolution, establish the speed limits for motor vehicles on the educational institution's property. Such speed limit shall become binding upon the installation of duly posted signs on the property. 
(e)  Revocation. The city shall revoke the speed limit upon receipt of a requesting resolution from the board of education, school district or community college to do so by amending this section to remove such educational institution from that subsection. 
(Ord. No. 2007-02, § 1, 2-26-07) 
Secs. 21-20-21-27. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRONICALLY AMPLIFIED SOUND SYSTEMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Noise control, § 13-84 et seq.; noise re sound amplifiers, radios, § 13-84(c), (h). 

Sec. 21-28. - Prohibited. 
    No persons operating or in control of a parked or moving motor vehicle (including motorcycles or mopeds) shall operate or permit to be operated an electronically amplified sound system in or on the vehicle so as to produce sound that is clearly audible more than fifty (50) feet from the vehicle except as hereafter provided. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 90-9, § 1(1), 10-22-90) 
Sec. 21-29. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of section 21-28 shall not apply to the following activities: 
(1)  Emergency work necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a fire, accident or natural disaster, to restore public utilities or to protect persons or property from imminent danger. 
(2)  Sound made to alert persons to the existence of an emergency, danger or attempted crisis. 
(3)  Activities or operation of governmental units or agencies. 
(4)  Parades, concerts, festivals, fairs or similar activities subject to any sound limits in the approval by the city. 
(5)  Athletic, musical or cultural activities or events (including practices and rehearsals) conducted by or under the auspices of public or private schools. 
(6)  Operation or use on or from a motor vehicle for any noncommercial purpose of any loud speaker, sound amplifier, public-address systems or similar device to amplify spoken words between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. with the prior approval of the city council. The city council shall grant such approval when it finds that: 
a.  The applicant has a noncommercial message that cannot be effectively communicated to the public by any other means of communication available. 
b.  The applicant will limit the use of the equipment to times, locations and sound levels which will not unreasonably disturb the public peace. 
c.  The applicant will not use the equipment in residential areas between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 90-9, § 10, 10-22-90) 
Sec. 21-30. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates this article or any provision thereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 90-9, § 10, 10-22-90; Ord. No. C.O. 91-2, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Secs. 21-31-21-48. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

No. 2000-02, § 2, adopted Feb. 14, 2000, repealed §§ 21-49-21-82, which contained provisions relating to stopping of school buses on highways, parking meters, and the city's parking violations bureau, and which derived from ordinances adopted Apr. 14, 1952; May 25, 1959; and Oct. 15, 1956; and from Ord. Nos. C.O.69-1, adopted May 12, 1969; and C.O. 70-11, adopted Aug. 24, 1970. 

Secs. 21-49-21-84. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SNOW EMERGENCY ROUTES 

Sec. 21-85. - Snow emergency routes defined. 
    Snow emergency routes are those streets designated by the mayor at the time of the snow emergency to be snow emergency routes pursuant to section 21-94. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-86. - Parking on designated snow emergency routes. 
    Whenever the mayor finds, on the basis of falling snow, sleet or freezing rain, or on the basis of a forecast by the United States Weather Bureau or other weather service of snow, sleet or freezing rain, that weather conditions will make it necessary that motor vehicle traffic be expedited and that parking on city streets be prohibited and restricted for snow plowing and other purposes, he shall put into effect a parking prohibition on snow emergency routes as necessary by declaring it in the manner hereafter prescribed. 
    Once in effect, a prohibition under this section shall remain in effect until terminated by announcement of the mayor, as hereafter provided. While the prohibition is in effect, no person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any portion of a snow emergency route to which it applies. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-87. - Condition of motor vehicles operated on designated snow emergency routes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on a snow emergency route on which there is a covering of snow, sleet or ice and allow the vehicle to become stalled wholly or partly because the drive wheels cannot maintain traction, the motor fuel is exhausted or the battery has become inoperative. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-88. - Stalled vehicle on designated snow emergency route. 
    Whenever a vehicle becomes stalled for any reason, whether or not in violation of this division, on any part of a snow emergency route on which there is a covering of snow, sleet or ice or on which there is a parking prohibition in effect, the person operating such vehicle shall take immediate action to have the vehicle towed or pushed off the roadway of such snow emergency route into the first cross-street which is not designated as a snow emergency route. No personal shall abandon or leave his or her vehicle in the roadway of a snow emergency route (regardless of whether it is indicated, by raising the hood or otherwise, that the vehicle is stalled), except for the propose of securing assistance during the actual time necessary to go to a nearby telephone or to a nearby garage, gasoline station or other place of assistance and return without delay. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-89. - Declarations by the mayor. 
    The mayor shall cause each declaration made pursuant to this division to be publicly announced by means calculated to inform city residents, including by way of example, broadcast or telecast, and/or newspaper(s) of general circulation when feasible. Each announcement shall describe the action taken by the mayor, including the time it became or will become effective, and shall specify the streets or areas affected. A parking prohibition declared by the mayor shall specify the streets designated as snow emergency routes and shall not go into effect until two (2) hours after personal notification, if such has been given, or until two (2) hours after it has been announced one (1) time between 6:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on any day. 
    The mayor shall make or cause to be made a record of the time and date when any declaration is announced to the public in accordance with this section, which record shall be filed with the city clerk/treasurer. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-90. - Termination of parking prohibition. 
    Whenever the mayor shall find that some or all of the conditions which give rise to a parking prohibition in effect pursuant to this division no longer exist, he may declare the prohibition terminated, in whole or in part, in a manner prescribed by this division, effective immediately upon announcement. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-91. - Provisions temporarily effective to take precedence. 
    Any provision of this division which becomes effective by declaration of the mayor or upon the occurrence of certain weather conditions shall, while temporarily in effect, take precedence over other conflicting provisions of law normally in effect, except that it shall not take precedence over provisions of law relating to traffic accidents, emergency travel of authorized emergency vehicles or emergency traffic directions by a police officer. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-92. - Impounding of vehicles. 
    Any vehicle parked on any snow emergency route in violation of any of the provisions of this division may be impounded, and no person shall recover any vehicle removed pursuant to this section without first paying the cost of removal and the cost of storage. Any payments required by this section shall not be construed as a penalty so as to preclude prosecution for violation of any of the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-93. - Evidence with respect to vehicles parked or left in violation of division. 
    In any prosecution with regard to a vehicle parked or left in a place or in a condition in violation of any provision of this division, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked or left in violation of a provision of this division, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the defendant was the person who parked or left the vehicle in violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-94. - Snow emergency routes declared. 
    At the time of a snow emergency, the mayor shall declare which streets within the City of Milan are designated as snow emergency routes for purposes of this division. Such designation of snow emergency routes shall be made by means of public announcement in accordance with section 21-89. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-95. - Penalty. 
    Violation of this division or any provision thereof shall be a civil infraction with a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) in addition to any other costs herein provided, including but not limited to, all costs associated with the removal and/or storage of the vehicle. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate infraction. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Sec. 21-96. - Mayor's delegation of authority. 
    The mayor may, by written instrument filed with the city clerk/treasurer, appoint another officer of the city to exercise the powers and authority conferred in this division in the mayor's absence. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 81-7, § 1, 12-28-81; Ord. No. 99-1, § 1, 1-11-99) 
Secs. 21-97-21-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MOTOR CARRIER SAFETY AND OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES[6] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- C.O. No. 98-10, adopted Oct. 19, 1998, amended the Code by adding a new Art. V to Ch. 21, §§ 21-50-21-53. Since this chapter already contained provisions with those section numbers, the editor has renumbered these new provisions as §§ 21-110-21-113. 

Sec. 21-110. - Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963 adopted. 
    The City of Milan hereby adopts and incorporates by reference in this Article the provisions of the Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963, as amended, being MCL section 480.11 et seq. 
(C.O. No. 98-10, § 1 (21-50), 10-19-98) 
Sec. 21-111. - Size, weight and load provisions of the Motor Vehicles Michigan Vehicle Code adopted. 
    The City of Milan hereby adopts and incorporates by reference in this article the following provisions of the Motor Vehicles Michigan Code, as amended: MCL section 257.722; MCL section 257.724; and MCL section 257.726b. 
(C.O. No. 98-10, § 1 (21-51), 10-19-98)

(C.O. No. 98-10, § 1 (21-52), 10-19-98) 
Sec. 21-113. - Penalties. 
(a)  Unless a lesser penalty is otherwise specified in an incorporated provision of section 21-110, any person who violates the provisions of section 21-110 shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days or both such fine and imprisonment for each violation. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation for purposes of this article. 
(b)  In accordance with MCL section 117.41(1)(a), any violation of, or failure to comply with the incorporated provisions of section 21-111 of this article, which violations constitute a civil infraction under the state statute, shall constitute a civil infraction for the purposes of this article carrying the fine specifically set forth in the incorporated and adopted provision of the state statute. 
(C.O. No. 98-10, § 1 (21-53), 10-19-98)
