ARTICLE VII. - MOTOR VEHICLE AND MOTORCYCLE INSURANCE REQUIRED 

Sec. 21-120. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article will have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automobile insurance means that term as defined in MCL 500.2102. 
    Highway means that term as defined in MCL 257.20. 
    Motorcycle means a vehicle having a saddle or seat for the use of the rider, designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, which is equipped with a motor that exceeds fifty (50) cubic centimeters piston displacement. The wheels on any attachment to the vehicle shall not be considered as wheels in contact with the ground. Motorcycle does not include a moped, as defined in MCL 257.32b. Motorcycle does not include an ORV. 
    Motor vehicle means a vehicle, including a trailer, operated or designed for operation upon a public highway by power other than muscular power which has more than two (2) wheels. Motor vehicle does not include a motorcycle or a moped, as defined in MCL 257.32b. Motor vehicle does not include a farm tractor or other implement of husbandry which is not subject to the registration requirements of the Michigan Vehicle Code pursuant to MCL 257.216. Motor vehicle does not include an ORV. 
    Owner means any of the following: 
(1)  A person renting a motor vehicle or having the use thereof, under a lease or otherwise, for a period that is greater than thirty (30) days. 
(2)  A person who holds the legal title to a vehicle, other than a person engaged in the business of leasing motor vehicles who is the lessor of a motor vehicle pursuant to a lease providing for the use of the motor vehicle by the lessee for a period that is greater than thirty (30) days. 
(3)  A person who has the immediate right of possession of a motor vehicle under an installment sale contract. 
    Registrant does not include a person engaged in the business of leasing motor vehicles who is the lessor of a motor vehicle pursuant to a lease providing for the use of the motor vehicle by the lessee for a period that is greater than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Sec. 21-121. - Operating or permitting a motor vehicle or motorcycle to be operated without insurance prohibited; presumption; penalty. 
(a)  An owner or registrant of a motor vehicle or motorcycle with respect to which security is required by MCL 500.3101, MCL 500.3102, or MCL 500.3103, may not operate the motor vehicle or motorcycle or permit it to be operated upon a public highway in the City of Milan, without having in full force and effect security complying with those sections. 
(b)  A person may not operate a motor vehicle or motorcycle upon a public highway in the City of Milan with the knowledge that the owner or registrant does not have security in full force and effect as required by MCL 500.3101, MCL 500.3102, or MCL 500.3103 for that motor vehicle or motorcycle. 
(c)  The failure of a person to produce evidence that a motor vehicle or motorcycle has in full force and effect security complying with MCL 500.3101, MCL 500.3102, or MCL 500.3103 on the date of the issuance of the citation, creates a rebuttable presumption in a prosecution that the motor vehicle or motorcycle did not have in full force and effect security complying with those sections on the date of the issuance of the citation. 
(d)  A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days or both. 
(Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Chapter 22 - TREES AND SHRUBS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city relative to trees, shrubs and plants, § 2.2(28). 
Cross reference- Yards, § 6-27; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; advertising matter on trees, § 10-2(g); streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; limbs or foliage of trees or shrubs obstructing sidewalks, § 18-2; water and sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 24. 

Sec. 22-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter may be known and cited as the "Tree and Shrub Ordinance." 
(Ord. of 9-24-56, § 1) 
Sec. 22-2. - Definition. 
    The word "highway," as used in this chapter, shall include all the land lying between the property lines on either side of all public streets, avenues and alleys. 
(Ord. of 9-24-56, § 2) 
Sec. 22-3. - Director of public works-General control and supervision. 
    Subject to the authority of the city council, the director of public works shall have control and supervision of all trees, plants and shrubs, planted or growing in or upon the public highways and public places of the city, and the planting, removal, care, maintenance and protection thereof. 
(Ord. of 9-24-56, § 3) 
Sec. 22-4. - Same-Authority to plant, etc., on public property. 
    The director of public works shall be authorized to plant, trim, spray, preserve and remove trees, shrubs and plants in or upon any public highway, park or other public place in the city as may be necessary to ensure safety, protect public improvements and promote and preserve the symmetry and beauty of such public places. 
(Ord. of 9-24-56, § 7) 
Sec. 22-5. - Power of director of public works and city employees to enter private property to inspect, etc. 
    The director of public works and city employees under his direction shall have power to enter upon any private grounds in the city to inspect, spray, or otherwise treat or cause to be sprayed or treated, any tree or shrub infected or infested by any plant disease, fungus, parasite, insect or animal pest when it shall be necessary to do so in order to prevent the spread of such disease, fungus or pest. Whenever the trimming or removal of any such tree or shrub located on private property shall be necessary in order to preserve surrounding trees or other property, then the director of public works shall have the power to take such action. 
(Ord. of 9-24-56, § 8) 
Sec. 22-6. - Interfering, etc., with director of public works or city employees prohibited. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with, or to cause or authorize or procure any delay or interference with the director of pubic works, or with any city employee working under his or her direction, while the director or employee is engaging in the planting, cultivating, pruning, spraying or removal of any trees or shrubs in or upon any public highway or public place or upon any private ground as authorized in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-24-56, § 11; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-7. - Injuring trees, etc. prohibited. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person, without the written permission of the director of public works, to remove, destroy, break, cut down, deface or in any way injure or interfere with any tree, shrub or plant in, on or upon any highway, park or public place within the city; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed so as to apply to the trimming of trees or shrubs as required in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 4; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-8. - Attaching ropes, etc. prohibited. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to attach or keep attached to any tree or shrub in or upon any public highway or public place within the city, or to the guard or stake intended for the protection of such tree or shrub, any rope, wire, chain, sign or other device whatsoever. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 4; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-9. - Excavations; driveways; permission required. 
    Excavations shall not be undertaken and driveways shall not be placed within six (6) feet of any tree located in any public highway or public place within the city without the prior written permission from the director of public works. Any person making or causing such excavation or construction shall guard every tree within six (6) feet thereof with a substantial frame box, and all building materials and debris shall be kept at least four (4) feet from any such tree. Violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 4; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-10. - Allowing injurious substances to come into contact with soil surrounding roots prohibited. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person owning, using or having control or charge of gas, gasoline, fuel oil or any other substance injurious to tree life, to allow any such substance to come into contact with the soil surrounding the roots of any tree, shrub or plant located in any public highway or public place within the city so as to destroy or injure such tree, shrub or plant, or the roots thereof, by dripping or seepage, or by any other manner whatsoever. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 4; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-11. - Interference with free passage of water, etc., to roots prohibited. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to place near or adjacent to any tree located in any public highway or public place within the city, any stone, cement, brick, sand or other material which would in any way interfere with the free passage of water, air or fertilizer to the roots of such tree. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 4; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-12. - Duty of owners to trim trees and shrubs overhanging streets. 
    Every owner of a tree or shrub overhanging a street or highway within the city shall trim and cut back such tree or shrub so that the foliage thereof shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp, obstruct the view of any street intersection, or interfere with the visibility of any traffic-control device or sign, and so that there shall be a clear space of twelve (12) feet above the surface of the street or highway. Violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 5; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-13. - Duty of owners to remove dead trees, etc. 
    Every owner shall, promptly upon their discovery, remove dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs, and the failure to do so shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 5; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-14. - Permit to plant required. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to plant or set out any tree or shrub or to cause or authorize or procure any person to plant or set out any tree or shrub in or upon any part of any public highway or public place without first obtaining from the director of public works a written permit to do so, and complying in all respects with the conditions set forth in such written permit and with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 5; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-15. - Planting trees and shrubs having extensive root systems prohibited; liability for damages; penalties. 
(a)  It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to plant a poplar, elm, box elder, basswood, soft maple, black walnut, willow or other tree or shrub having an extensive root system in any location where the roots are likely to penetrate through or under any public sidewalk or highway or under or through any city easement for water or sewer lines. 
(b)  Should the roots of any tree or shrub disturb any city water or sewer system, or cause any break or eruption in any sidewalk or highway within the city, then the owner of such tree or shrub shall, in addition to any other penalty provided or permitted by this Code, be liable to the city for the full cost of removing the offending tree or shrub and for the full amount of all costs incurred by the city as the result of such disturbance, breakage or eruption plus an amount equal to ten (10) per cent of such combined amount for administrative overhead. The clerk/treasurer shall bill or cause the billing of all such sums to the owner of the offending tree or shrub. 
(c)  All charges billed by the clerk/treasurer pursuant to subsection (b) shall, upon billing, become a lien upon the premises to which they apply. On April 1 of each year, the clerk/treasurer shall certify any and all unpaid charges for such services incurred during the preceding twelve (12) months to the city assessor. The city assessor shall add thereto ten (10) per cent of total charges against each of the several premises so certified to cover the city's additional costs should this procedure be necessary to effect collection, and shall enter the resulting total upon the next tax roll against each of the premises so certified. This lien shall be collected and/or enforced in the same manner as provided in respect to that for any other taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 5; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-16. - Planting certain trees in right-of-way prohibited. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to plant any tree that will exceed a maximum growth height of forty (40) feet, in any highway or right-of-way where street lighting, traffic signal or public utility overhead wires or equipment are located. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 5; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-17. - Notice to owner to trim, etc.; failure to comply; penalties. 
(a)  In the event that any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter requires that a tree or shrub be trimmed, cut or removed, then the director of public works or an authorized local official, as defined in section 131/4-1 of this Code, shall notify, in writing, the person responsible for such violation, if known, to cure such violation or cause the same to be cured by trimming, cutting or removing the offending tree or shrub, by the end of the thirtieth day after the date of such notice. Such notice shall be served in any means permitted by chapter 131/4 of this Code for the service of a municipal ordinance violation notice. Such notice may, but shall not be required to, be given by the issuance of a municipal ordinance violation notice or a citation for a municipal civil infraction, as those terms are defined in chapter 131/4 of this Code. The giving of such notice by any other means shall not preclude the additional issuance of a municipal ordinance violation notice or a citation for a municipal civil infraction for such violation. 
(b)  If the person served with the notice specified in subsection (a) of this section fails and/or refuses to cure the violation of this chapter by the end of the thirtieth day after the date of service of such notice, he or she shall be deemed liable for a separate and distinct municipal civil infraction and for an additional separate and distinct municipal civil infraction for each day thereafter that he or she continues to fail or refuse to cure the violation, in addition to the procedures and penalties specified in section 22-18 of this chapter. Further, the curing of the original violation of this chapter within the specified thirty-day period shall not operate to relieve any part of liability for the municipal civil infraction resulting from the original violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 5; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-18. - Charges for removal by city. 
(a)  If the person served with the notice specified in subsection (a) of section 22-17 fails and/or refuses to cure the violation of this chapter by the end of the thirtieth day after the date of service of such notice, then the director of public works shall be authorized to cure such violation or cause the same to be cured by trimming, cutting, or removing the offending tree(s) or shrub(s), and the owner of such tree or shrub shall, in addition to any other penalty provided or permitted by this Code, be liable to the city for the full cost of effecting such cure plus an amount equal to ten (10) per cent of such cost for administrative overhead. The director of public works shall keep an accurate account of the expenses incurred in carrying out the provisions of this section with respect to each parcel of land entered upon therefor, and shall make a sworn statement of such account and present the same to the clerk/treasurer. The clerk/treasurer shall bill or cause the billing of all such sums to the owner of the offending tree or shrub. 
(b)  All charges billed by the clerk/treasurer pursuant to subsection (a) shall, upon billing, become a lien upon the premises to which they apply. On April 1 of each year, the clerk/treasurer shall certify any and all unpaid charges for such services incurred during the preceding twelve (12) months to the city assessor. The city assessor shall add thereto ten (10) per cent of total charges against each of the several premises so certified to cover the city's additional costs should this procedure be necessary to effect collection, and shall enter the resulting total upon the next tax roll against each of the premises so certified. This lien shall be collected and/or enforced in the same manner as provided in respect to that for any other taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(Ord. of 9-4-56, § 9; Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 29, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 22-19. - Permit for public utilities to chemically control and trim; fee. 
(a)  Upon the written request of any public utility operating in the city and such utility's payment of the applicable permit fee specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council, the director of public works shall issue an annual permit, and shall annually thereafter renew such permit, granting permission to such public utility to chemically control and trim and keep trimmed all trees and shrubs intruding into the air spaces over, or growing within the confines of, the public highways, rights-of-way or public places of the city in such manner as shall keep the overhead lines and equipment of such public utility safe and accessible, and clear of all tree growth which endangers or may endanger such overhead lines or equipment and the public health and safety. Such chemical control and trimming shall be done in accordance with practices approved by and under the general direction of the director of public works. 
(b)  Such permit, as provided for in this section, shall require reasonable prior notice to the city before any work is commenced thereunder; provided, however, that in the event of an emergency requiring immediate maintenance work on overhead lines of any such public utility, prior notice of commencing work under such permit shall not be required. The word "emergency" as used in this section shall be defined to mean the occurrence or happening of an event which could not be expected or prevented by the exercise or reasonable care and foresight and which endanger or may endanger the overhead lines of the public utility and the public health and safety. 
(Ord. of 9-24-56, § 10; Ord. No. C. O. 94-5, § 29, 5-9-94) 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 22-20. - Violations; penalties. 
    The violation of any provisions of this chapter shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this chapter, the violator, in addition to any other penalty specified in this chapter, shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council, which fine and/or costs shall include the sum of all expenses incurred by the city in curing the violation, including, without limitation, replacement of any injured or damaged tree or shrub. Each day that a violation of any provision of this chapter is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction. 
(Ord. No. C. O. 95-1, § 30, 1-23-95) 
Chapter 23 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Police, Ch. 15; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; obstructing sidewalks with vehicles, § 18-3; traffic, Ch. 21. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 23-1-23-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, adopted Dec. 10, 1984, repealed former Art. II, relative to taxicabs, and enacted in lieu thereof a new Art. II, pertaining to the same subject matter. Former Art. II was derived from Ord. of April 4, 1946; Ord. of July 28, 1958; Ord. No. C.O. 67-2, adopted Dec. 11, 1967; Ord. No. C.O. 71-4, adopted April 26, 1971; and Ord. No. C.O. 75-1, adopted May 12, 1975. 

Sec. 23-16. - Definitions. 
(a)  Administrator: The city administrator or such city officer or employee as the city administrator may designate. 
(b)  Taxicab: Any vehicle operated on the streets of the city accepting passengers for hire between such points in the city as may be directed by the passenger. The term "taxicab" does not refer to mass transportation vehicles operating over fixed routes, vehicles owned and operated by governmental agencies, school buses, chartered buses or vehicles used solely for funerals, weddings, christenings and similar events. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-17. - Licenses required. 
    No person shall operate a taxicab within the city unless the vehicle and the driver are currently licensed pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-18. - Application for taxicab license. 
(1)  Application for a taxicab license shall be made on forms approved by the administrator. 
(2)  The application must be accompanied by the certificate of an automobile mechanic licensed in the State of Michigan. The certificate must be on a form approved by the administrator, must have been issued within sixty (60) days of the date of application, and must indicate that the vehicle sought to be licensed as a taxicab has been thoroughly inspected and has been found to comply with all the requirements of the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code. 
(3)  The application must be accompanied by proof of insurance in the minimum amount of two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) for injury or death to one person, and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injury or death to all persons arising out of one accident. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-19. - Issuing of taxicab license. 
    A taxicab license shall be issued by the city administrator if the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The applicant has paid the fee specified for such license in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council. 
(2)  It appears from the mechanic's certificate and a city inspection of the vehicle that it is clean, safe and in full compliance with the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code and this article of the Milan City Code. 
(3)  The vehicle is currently registered in the State of Michigan and insured for public liability in the amounts provided in section 23-18(3) hereof. 
(4)  The vehicle's meter has been inspected and tested by the police department to determine that it is accurate. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 30, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 23-20. - License plate. 
    If a taxicab license is issued to a vehicle, a license plate or decal, as approved by the administrator, shall be attached to the vehicle and visibly displayed on the rear thereof. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-21. - Maintenance of the vehicle. 
    No person shall operate any taxicab licensed pursuant to this article unless such vehicle is maintained at all times in the condition required for the issuance of a license. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-22. - Revocation of taxicab license. 
    A taxicab license shall be revoked by the administrator upon any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  The vehicle is found to be in a condition which would not comply with the maintenance requirements for the issuance of a license. 
(2)  A person is found driving the vehicle for taxicab purposes who does not have a current valid taxicab driver's and chauffeur's license. 
(3)  The owner of the vehicle is convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-23. - Application for and issuance of taxicab driver's license. 
    A taxicab driver's license shall be issued by the administrator, after application has been made therefor on forms approved by the administrator, if the following conditions are satisfied: 
(1)  The applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(2)  The applicant has a current Michigan chauffeur's license. 
(3)  The applicant is able to read, write and speak the English language. 
(4)  The applicant has no more than six (6) current points for moving violations in accordance with the Michigan Motor Vehicle Code. 
(5)  The applicant has not been convicted of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or controlled substances, while having a blood alcohol in excess of .10 percent by weight, or while visibly impaired by the use of intoxicating liquor or controlled substances within the two (2) years immediately preceding the application. 
(6)  The applicant has not within the previous five (5) years been convicted of a felony involving force or violence. 
(7)  The applicant does not have a physical or mental impairment which would make it unsafe to operate a taxicab. 
(8)  The applicant has not been convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article within the two (2) previous years. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-24. - Display of taxicab driver's license. 
    The taxicab driver's license issued pursuant hereto shall be at all times conspicuously displayed inside the taxicab while the driver is operating the taxicab. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-25. - Suspension or revocation of taxicab driver's license. 
    A taxicab driver's license may be suspended or revoked by the administrator if any of the following occur: 
(1)  The driver is no longer able to comply with the requirements for the issuance of a license. 
(2)  The driver is found to have falsified any information in his/her application for a license. 
(3)  The driver is convicted of violating any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-26. - Deception of passengers. 
    No driver shall deceive or attempt to deceive any passenger as to that passenger's destination or rate of fare. No driver shall convey any passenger to a place other than directed by the passenger or employ any longer route to a destination than necessary unless so requested by the passenger. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-27. - Driving and use of controlled substance on duty prohibited. 
    No taxicab driver shall drive or consume any alcoholic beverage or use any controlled substance either prior to the operation of the taxicab or while operating the same. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-28. - Use of taxicab for immoral or illegal purposes. 
    No owner or driver of a taxicab shall use, or permit the use of, any taxicab for immoral or illegal purposes. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-29. - Smoking prohibited. 
    No taxicab driver shall have in his/her possession a lighted cigar or pipe while transporting any passenger in a taxicab. No such driver shall have in his/her possession any lighted cigarette unless the driver first requests and obtains the permission of all passengers. No passenger shall smoke in a vehicle containing a notice stating "No Smoking". 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-30. - Driver appearance. 
    Drivers of taxicabs shall be clean in dress and in person at all times while operating a taxicab. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-31. - Seating capacity. 
    No driver shall permit a taxicab to be occupied by more persons over the age of two (2) than the number specified as the seating capacity of said vehicle as posted on the rate card. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-32. - Standard taxicab rates. 
    No person shall operate or permit the operation of a taxicab with a taximeter for the purpose of charging meter rates higher than the standard rates approved by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-33. - Baggage and parcels. 
    The rates for carrying the baggage and parcels of passengers shall be subject to the approval procedure provided in section 23-32. The rate charged for delivery of baggage and parcels not in connection with the transportation of passengers is not regulated by this article. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-34. - Rate card. 
    No person shall operate a taxicab that does not have a rate card posted in plain view of the passengers. The rate card must clearly indicate the rates charged and the occupancy limits for the taxicab. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-35. - Taxicab stands. 
    In accordance with the procedures of Section 2.53, Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages, as incorporated into section 21-1, Milan City Code, taxicab stands may be established by traffic-control orders. The traffic-control orders may specify restrictions on the number of taxicabs which may use the stands at one time, the use of the stands for parking other vehicles, and the hours of any restrictions. The restrictions shall be indicated by traffic control devices at the taxicab stands. No person shall violate the restrictions imposed on the use of taxicab stands. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-36. - Solicitation of passengers. 
    No taxicab driver shall solicit passengers at a location where he/she has not received a current request for taxicab services and where he/she has reason to know the services of another taxicab firm have been requested. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-37. - License term. 
    Taxicab licenses and taxicab drivers' licenses shall expire on January 1st of the year following the issuance thereof. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-38. - Meter seal. 
    When a taxicab meter is tested and inspected by the police department, the inspecting officer shall place a seal on the meter. No person shall operate a taxicab with a meter without such seal or if the seal is broken. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-39. - Defrauding a taxicab driver. 
    No person shall request taxicab services for the purpose of defrauding the owner or driver of the taxicab. The conduct prohibited by this section includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Refusal to pay the lawful rate for the taxicab services. 
(2)  Absconding without paying the lawful rate for the taxicab services. 
(3)  Requesting taxicab services for a person or a location where such services are not desired. 
(4)  Refusal to pay for taxicab services with other than a bill greater than twenty dollars ($20.00) over the fare. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-40. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the administrator regarding the issuance, suspension or revocation of a taxicab license and a taxicab driver's license may appeal the decision to the city council. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Sec. 23-41. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating a section of this article shall upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 84-10, § 1, 12-10-84) 
Secs. 23-42, 23-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC DRAYS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-44. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article "public drays" are defined to include all vehicles which shall be kept, maintained, used or employed for the transportation of any personal property from place to place, on the public streets of the city, for hire or reward. 
    It shall not, however, include vehicles used by any person for the purpose of hauling or conveying personal property which is owned and belongs to such person. 
    It shall not include vehicles engaged in the transportation of personal property from city to city in the state, and which only pass through the city, nor shall it include vehicles used in the transportation of the United States mail. 
(Ord. of 6-19-47, § 1) 
Sec. 23-45. - Identification. 
    When a license has been issued to any person as provided for in this article, there shall be painted or printed in letters at least three (3) inches in height in a conspicuous position on each side of the vehicle, the words "Milan Dray License No. __________". The number assigned to such dray by the city shall be the number inserted in such sign. 
(Ord. of 6-19-47, § 5) 
Sec. 23-46. - Equipment. 
    Every dray for which a license is issued by the city under the provisions of this article, shall be equipped with all the devices, equipment and other requirements set forth in the Michigan Vehicle Code as being necessary on vehicles used for hire. Any violation thereof shall be deemed a violation of this section. 
(Ord. of 6-19-47, § 7) 
Secs. 23-47-23-51. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 12. 

Sec. 23-52. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating a public dray in the city without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Ord. of 6-19-47, § 2) 
Sec. 23-53. - Application. 
    Application for a license under this division must be filed with the city clerk, giving the name and address of the owner of the vehicle, a description of the vehicle, and, if a motor vehicle, the serial number and any other information by which the same may be readily identified. 
(Ord. of 6-19-47, § 3) 
Sec. 23-54. - Insurance required of applicant. 
(a)  No license shall be issued under this division for the operation of a dray until the applicant has deposited with the city clerk/treasurer a prepaid one-year policy of liability insurance for each dray, which policy is issued by a company authorized to conduct insurance business within this state, and which contains coverage limits of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injury to one (1) person, and two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage in any one (1) accident, through the operation of such dray. 
(b)  Policies of insurance furnished under this division shall contain a clause requiring the issuing company to give not less than thirty (30) days' notice to the city before such policy can be canceled or its coverage limits reduced. In the event that any such policy shall be canceled or its policy limits reduced below the minimums specified in this section, the dray license of the applicant to which the policy applies shall be automatically revoked without further action by the city, and shall not be reissued without full compliance with all of the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. of 6-19-47, § 4; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 30, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 23-55. - Issuance; fee; term. 
    Any license required by this division shall be issued by the city council upon its determination that the applicant has satisfied all requirements of this division. When so issued, the applicant shall pay for such license the fee established the same in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the Milan City Council, which shall enable and authorize the licensee to operate the dray for a period of one (1) year from and after the issuance of such license. 
(Ord. of 6-19-47, § 3; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 30, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 23-56. - Transfer. 
    A dray license issued pursuant to this division may be transferred upon the sale or transfer of the vehicle covered thereby upon application to the city council. 
(Ord. of 6-19-47, § 6) 
Chapter 24 - WATER AND SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city relative to sewers and sewage disposal, § 2.2(5); power of city relative to sanitary and storm sewers in waterworks, § 2.2(31). 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; public improvement, Ch. 16; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 18; subdivisions, Ch. 19; swimming pools Ch. 20; zoning, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - General powers and duties of director of public works relative to waterworks system. 
(a)  The director of public works, subject to the supervision and control of the city council, shall have exclusive charge and control of the system of waterworks of the city and of all matters pertaining thereto including the engagement of all employees, but shall not have the power to make any expenditures, except for immediately required repairs or supplies, without first being authorized by the council so to do. 
(b)  The director of public works is hereby authorized at any time, when in his opinion the interest of the city will be best served thereby, to restrict, regulate or prohibit the use the water. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59; §§ 10, 11) 
Sec. 24-2. - Required water and sewer connections. 
(a)  Whenever the city council shall cause to be constructed in any of the streets of the city, water mains and/or trunk line sanitary sewer mains, for the purpose of protecting the health and welfare of the inhabitants of the city, all occupied property abutting on the streets in which such mains are constructed shall be connected to such mains and services thereby in accordance with the provisions set forth in this section. 
(b)  Within thirty (30) days after any water main or sanitary sewer line has been established and becomes operative in any street, the city council shall require that notice be sent to each owner or occupied property which abuts on such street, to cause the same to be connected to and serviced by such mains. Such notice shall require all such owners to complete such connection from their respective properties to such city mains within a period of eighteen (18) months from and after the date of the service of such notice. 
(c)  Such connection shall be made by the owner of the premises to be serviced after making application to the city clerk in writing. Such application shall specify whether water and sewer connections are desired and shall also specify the street number of the property to be serviced, together with the width of the property abutting on such street. At the time of making such application the owner shall pay to the city clerk the fees required by the city for such connections and will contract in writing to pay for the proportionate cost of the water and/or sanitary sewer mains, computed on the front footage of the property serviced, within eighteen (18) months from and after the date of such application, together with interest on such amount, at the rate of six (6) percent per annum from the date of such application to the date of such payment is made. 
(d)  The notice from the city to such owner to complete such connection shall be personally served, if such owner can be found within the city. In the event such owner is a nonresident of the city, or if absent from the city, then such notice may be served upon the occupant of the premises, or if he cannot be found, by posting the notice in a conspicuous place on such premises. 
(e)  In the event any owner shall fail to connect his property to the water or sewer line of the city within the eighteen (18) month period above-prescribed, after being notified to do so, it shall be the duty of the city authorities to report such failure or neglect to the city council. Thereupon, the council shall direct the city authorities to cause such connections. The proportionate cost of the construction of such main, chargeable to such property, shall be due and payable forthwith, and may be assessed as a special assessment against the premises for which such cost was incurred. 
(Ord. of 1-21-54, §§ 1-4) 
Sec. 24-3. - Tapping mains, etc. 
    No person, excepting those having special permission from the city council or persons in its service and approved by the council, will be permitted under any circumstances to tap the main or distributing pipes, or insert stopcocks therein. The kind and size of the connection with the mains shall be that specified in the permit or order from the city council. No openings of the street or tapping the mains will be permitted when the ground is frozen, except by special permission of the director of public works. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 7) 
Sec. 24-4. - Water service-Generally. 
(a)  The rules, regulations and water rates prescribed in this chapter shall be considered a part of the contract with every person within the city limits supplied with water through the water system of the city and with the owner of any building so supplied with water. Every such person or owner, by taking water or allowing the same to be taken by a tenant, shall be considered as expressing his consent to be bound thereby. Whenever any such rules and regulations or such other as the city shall adopt are violated, the water shall be shut off from the building or place of such violation (even though two (2) or more parties are receiving water through the same pipe) and shall not be turned on again except by order of the director of public works and on payment of all arrears of charges, the expenses of shutting off and turning it on (for which charges then in force as determined by the city council shall be charged, unless digging shall be done, in which case charges shall be proportioned to the cost) and such other terms as the city council shall determine, and a satisfactory understanding with the party that no further cause of complaint shall arise. 
(b)  In the case of any violation of the rules and regulations prescribed in this chapter, or of such other rules and regulations as the city shall adopt, the city council, may also declare any payment made by the party committing such violation for the water and/or sewer service to be forfeited. The right is expressly reserved by the city to change the rules, regulations and rates applicable to water and/or sewer service from time to time as the city may deem advisable. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 13; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 31, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 24-5. - Same-Application. 
    Every person within the city limits desiring a supply of water, must make application in writing therefor to the city clerk, in such form as may be prescribed for that purpose. Blanks for such application will be furnished at the office of the clerk. The application must state fully and truly all the uses to which the water is to be applied. No different or additional use will be allowed except upon further application and permission regularly obtained from the city. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 14) 
Sec. 24-6. - Applicant to pay costs of introduction, connection, re-connection, furnishing, turning-on and shutting-off of water. 
    All of the costs relating to the introduction, connection, re-connection, furnishing, turning-on and shutting-off of water to any private building or premises, whether for installation, maintenance, convenience, non-payment or any other reason, shall be paid and borne by the applicant for and/or recipient of the water service. The applicable fees to be paid for such services shall be those specified in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. In every instance in which the city incurs costs related to the introduction, connection, re-connection, furnishing, turning-on and/or shutting-off of water to any private building or premises and for which no fee is specified in the official fee schedule, the director of public works shall issue a bill to the recipient of the subject water service for the actual costs incurred by the city in connection therewith plus ten (10) percent of those costs. The amount so billed shall be immediately due and payable by the service recipient to the city and shall be a lien on the premises for which the permit was issued. The collection of such costs and the effects of their nonpayment shall be governed by section 24-48 of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 16; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 31, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 24-7. - Repair of underground utilities; permit; fees. 
    No person shall repair or cause to be repaired any underground utility system or portion thereof, or perform or cause to be performed any excavation pertaining to any repair of any underground utility system or portion thereof, without first obtaining from the director of public works a permit to do so. The application for such permit shall be accompanied by any and all information, including a complete and detailed set of plans and specifications of the proposed excavation and/or repair, required and necessary for the determination of whether the proposed excavation and/or repair will comply with the provisions of this article and with the applicable city ordinances and resolutions of the city council. Before any permit shall be issued under this article, such plans and specifications shall be approved by the director of public works, and a permit fee shall be paid by the applicant to the city for each permit required by this article. The amount of such fee shall be that specified for "underground utility repair permits" in the official fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. Before any such excavation and/or repair shall be commenced and upon its completion, the permittee must obtain all inspections and approvals required by the director of public works to determine compliance with the provisions of this chapter and applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 31, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 24-8. - Turning water into buildings or private service pipes. 
(a)  Water will not be turned into any building or private service pipe, except upon the order in writing of the director of public works or his duly authorized agent; nor until the applicant shall have paid for the connection from the street main to the street line, and also the water service charge due for the current period. 
(b)  All plumbers are strictly prohibited from turning water into any service pipe except upon the order or permission of the director of public works or his agent. This rule shall not be construed to prevent any plumber from admitting water into test pipes and for that purpose only. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 19) 
Sec. 24-9. - Water meters. 
(a)  Except as otherwise expressly provided in this chapter, all water furnished to any premises connected to the water supply shall be metered as provided in this chapter. Wanton waste of water supply water is strictly prohibited. 
(b)  All meters must be approved by the director of public works or his agent and must be installed and be at all times under the supervision and direction of the director of public works or his agent. Such meters shall be installed so that they can be easily examined and read, and be provided with suitable protection so that they are made safe from frost and other damages. All meters shall at all times be and remain the property of the city. 
(c)  All expenses of installing meters and of protecting them from frost and other damage shall be paid by the customer. Any meter found at any time frozen or damaged must be repaired or replaced upon the order of the director of public works or his agent and at the expense of the customer. No meter shall be repaired or removed except upon the permission granted by the director of public works or his designee. 
(d)  Each and every residence building and each and every other building or part of any building or premises having water connections with the city water supply shall be furnished with a water meter of such make, design and size as may from time to time be prescribed by the director of public works. 
(e)  The meters so required to be used as above provided shall be furnished by and shall be procured by the city, and be paid for in advance by the property owner at the actual cost to the city therefor, including freight and delivery and the cost of installation. The meters so supplied and used shall be under the sole charge and control of the city and its director of public works. 
(f)  It shall be the duty of the director of public works or his designee when such meter is put in place and ready for use, and on each occasion when the same is opened for examination, repairs or inspection, to seal the same. Such meter shall not be in any manner interfered with or opened or altered except by and under the direction of, and in the presence of the director of public works or his designee. It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with such water meter or to open or tamper with the same, or to cause any of such things to be done. 
(g)  The size of any water meter shall be determined by a builder or an engineer, retained and paid by the customer, during construction of the premises for which water is to be supplied through such meter, subject to approval by the director of public works. Once a meter is installed, the size of such meter shall not thereafter be changed unless the director of public works determines that such change is appropriate due to a change in the use of the premises to which the meter supplies water and that the change in meter size will not adversely affect the health, safety or welfare of the premises' occupants, the water supply, other customers of the water supply, or other residents of the city. Any request for change of meter size shall be made in writing and be accompanied by documentation of an engineer's review of the new use requirements an such engineer's recommendation as to new meter size. All costs of the review of such request by the director of public works or his designee, including the costs of any consultants to the director of public works, and all costs of any subsequently approved change in meter size, shall be borne exclusively by the customer who requested such change. 
(h)  For purposes of this chapter, "fire service lines" shall mean any pipe or line through which water is supplied to or for any fire suppression system. All fire service lines shall be monitored through the use of a fire service meter or a "detector check" system (a metered bypass). If the fire service lines provides water for daily water use as well as fire service, then a fire service meter must be used. If the service line is for fire service only, then the "detector check" system may be used. All water supply customers shall maintain their fire suppression systems and fire service lines in good condition at all times, and keep them free from leaks and unapproved use of water. Any and all testing of sprinkler and other fire suppression systems shall be conducted only after approval for the same is obtained from the director of public works or his designee. No penalty charges will be assessed for use of fire service line water during any approved testing, or as the result of fire suppression system activation due to an actual fire. 
(i)  All fire service lines installed after the effective date of this ordinance shall at all times comply with the requirements of subsection (h). All fire service lines installed and operational as of the effective date of this ordinance shall comply with the requirements of subsection (h) by not later than January 1, 2000, and at all times thereafter. 
(j)  On and after the effective date of this ordinance, no water meter shall be installed on any new service line unless there is installed, at the customer's expense, a separate outdoor shutoff device of size, type and location approved by the director of public works, by which the city may shutoff water from entering such meter or the particular premises, or portion of the premises, for which the meter is installed, without physically entering such premises, and without thereby shutting off water to any other separate meter on such premises. By not later than January 1, 2000, and at all times thereafter, each water meter within the city shall have in place a separate outdoor shut-off device meeting the requirements of this subsection. After January 1, 2000, any premises for which multiple water meters have been installed, but for each of which meters there is not installed a separate outdoor shutoff device meeting the requirements of this subsection, shall have all water and sewer furnished to such premises calculated and billed to the property owner. This provision does not apply to residential landscape meters. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, §§ 22-26; Ord. No. C.O. 97-1, § 1, 5-19-97) 
Sec. 24-10. - Hydrants, taps, etc., to be closed when not in use; improper use of water. 
    All persons using water shall keep the hydrants, taps, hoses, water closets, urinals, baths and other fixtures allotted to their use closed, except when obtaining water for use, and shall be responsible for any damage or injury that may result to others from the improper use of such water. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 15) 
Sec. 24-11. - Service pipes, etc., to be kept in good repair and protected from frost; unnecessary waste of water. 
    All persons taking water shall keep their own service pipes, stopcocks and apparatus in good repair and protected from frost at their own risk and expense and shall prevent any unnecessary waste of water. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 16) 
Sec. 24-12. - Inspection, etc. 
    The director of public works or any of his agents shall have power and authority at all reasonable hours to enter upon any premises where water is furnished from the city waterworks system for the purpose of reading, inspecting and/or testing the water meters, or the inspection of all pipes and fixtures connected with such waterworks system. They shall have power and authority to require any defective pipes or fixtures to be repaired, removed or replaced where the same are not in compliance with the provisions of the waterworks system. Any person refusing or neglecting to make such repairs, when so ordered, and failing to answer any questions in relation to the consumption of water, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section and liable to prosecution therefor. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 17) 
Sec. 24-13. - Right of city to cut off water supply. 
    The right is hereby reserved by the city to cut off the supply of water at any time for the purpose of repairs or any other necessary purpose, any permit granted or regulation to the contrary notwithstanding. Whenever it shall become necessary to shut off the water supply within any district of the city, the director of public works shall, if practicable, give notice to each and every consumer within such district of the time when such supply shall be cut off. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 18) 
Sec. 24-14. - Turning on water when same has been turned off by city. 
    When the water has been turned off by the order of the director of public works or his authorized agent, no consumer shall turn it on without the written consent of the director of public works or his agent. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59; § 20) 
Sec. 24-15. - Using water for lawns, etc. 
(a)  In order to conserve water for sanitary uses the following rules and regulations may be declared in force at such times as the city council shall deem necessary: 
(1)  Properties bearing an odd house number may use water for the sprinkling of lawns, gardens, shrubs or trees on the odd calendar dates, such as the first, third, fifth, etc., day of the month. 
(2)  Properties bearing an even house number may use water for the sprinkling of lawns, gardens, shrubs or trees on the even calendar dates, such as the second, fourth, sixth, etc., day of the month. 
(b)  The rules prescribed in subsection (a) shall apply to vacant property as such property lies on the odd or even numbered side of the street. 
(c)  Property fronting on two (2) streets shall, for the purpose of the rules prescribed in subsection (a), be guided by the house number of the main entrance of the property. 
(d)  In case none of the rules prescribed in subsection (a) seem to apply clearly to a piece of property, the owner of such property shall apply to the city council for definite assignment. 
(Ord. of 6-25-62, § 2) 
Sec. 24-16. - Private hydrants prohibited in streets; public drinking fountains not to be used for domestic supply. 
    No private hydrants, excepting public drinking fountains, shall be placed within the limits of any street in the city, and no drinking fountain shall be erected for the public use which has openings by which it can be used as a source of domestic supply. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 21) 
Sec. 24-17. - Polluting water in drinking fountains. 
    It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to place in, near or around any drinking fountain any substance or fluid which shall render the water in such fountain impure or unfit for human consumption. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 5; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 31, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 24-18. - Injuring, interfering with, etc., property of city waterworks, etc. 
    No person shall willfully or carelessly break, injure, mar or deface, interfere with or disturb any building, machinery, apparatus, fixture, attachment or appurtenance of the waterworks of the city or any public or private hydrant or stopcock, meter, water supply or service pipe or any part thereof; nor shall any person deposit anything in any stopcock box, or commit any act tending to obstruct or impair the intended use of any of the property mentioned in this section. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 5; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 31, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 24-19. - Excavations relative to water pipes. 
(a)  It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person not authorized to do so to make any excavation in any street or highway within ten (10) feet of any laid water pipe while the ground is frozen or to dig up or uncover so as to expose to the frost any water pipe of the city, except by permission of the director of public works. 
(b)  It shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for any person to make any excavation in any street or highway for the purpose of laying water pipes, or to tap any water pipe without a permit issued by the director of public works. All plumbing work required in any building or for any other purpose must be completed to the lines of the street before any excavation shall be made in any street for the purpose of connecting with the main. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, §§ 3, 4; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 31, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 24-20. - Public and private fire hydrants. 
(a)  All fire hydrants erected by the city within the city limits are hereby declared to be public hydrants. Excepting the director of public works, no person other than members of the city's fire department and then, only for the purposes and uses of such department, shall open or uncover or attempt to open or uncover any such hydrant, nor draw or attempt to draw water therefrom, nor remove or attempt to remove therefrom any matter or thing designed or intended for the protection thereof. The director of public works or his or her duly authorized agent may, consistent with public health and safety, grant to any suitable person permission to open any hydrant to a specified extent and for a specified length of time and to draw therefrom a specified quantity of water. The requesting and granting of such permission and the fees and charges for doing so shall be governed by the provisions of section 24-44 of this chapter. Any use permitted under the terms of this section shall be strictly limited by the terms imposed by the director of public works, and no person granted such permission shall delegate his authority to another person or permit or provide any other person with access to the wrenches used for opening any public hydrant. Any use beyond or contrary to the conditions imposed by the director of public works under this section or any other violation of the terms of this section shall be a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or both in the discretion of the court for each violation. 
(b)  Upon approval by the city council, the director of public works, may enter into written arrangements relating to the maintenance and/or cleaning of privately-owned fire hydrants; provided that, as a condition precedent to each such arrangement, the owners of the private hydrants in question shall agree to indemnify, defend and hold the city and its authorized representatives harmless from any and all costs and liability relating to and/or arising of out the city's participation in the arrangement. The owners of the private hydrants in question shall be solely responsible and liable for all of the costs of the city's entry into and performance of such arrangements, including their review by the city attorney. The fees for maintenance services provided pursuant to this section shall be those specified for such services in the official fee schedule adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. C.O. 94-5, § 31, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 24-21. - No claims against city. 
    It is expressly stipulated by the city that no claim shall be made against it by reason of the breaking or freezing of any service pipe or service cock; nor if from any cause the supply of water should fail; nor from damage arising from the shutting off of water to repair the mains, making the connections or extensions; nor for any other purpose that may be deemed necessary. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 18) 
Sec. 24-22. - Enforcement of chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforceable by any authorized local official as defined in section 131/4-1 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 10-26-59, § 8; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 31, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 24-23. - Cross-connections. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the following terms, words, phrases and their derivations, shall have the meaning given herein: 
(1)  Backflow means water of questionable quality, wastes or other contaminants entering a public water supply system due to a reversal of flow. 
(2)  Cross connection means a connection or arrangement of p1pmg or appurtenances through which a backflow could occur. 
(b)  That the city adopts by reference the Water Supply Cross Connection Rules of the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality being R325.11401 to R325.11407 of the Michigan Administrative Code. 
(c)  That it shall be the duty of the director of public works or his or her designee to cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water supply where cross connections with the public water supply is deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and re-inspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the director of public warks and as approved by the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality. 
(d)  That the representative of department of public works shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply system of the city for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems thereof for cross connections. On request, the owner, lessees, or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the inspection agency any pertinent information regarding the piping system or systems on such property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross connection. 
(e)  That the director of public works is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue water service after reasonable notice to any property wherein any connection in violation of this section exists and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply system. Water service to such property shall not be restored until the cross connection(s) has been eliminated in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(f)  That all testable backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested at the time of installation or relocation and after any repair. Subsequent testing of devices shall be conducted at a time interval specified by the director of public works and in accordance with Michigan Department of Environmental Quality requirements. Connections deemed high risk shall be tested annually. All others, including residential back flow prevention devices shall be tested once every three (3) years. Only individuals that hold a valid ASSE 5110 tester certification and have successfully passed an approved backflow testing class shall perform such testing. Each tester shall also be approved by the director of public works. Individual(s) performing assembly testing shall certify the results of his/her testing. The results need to be mailed to the city, director of public works. 
(g)  That the potable water supply made available on the properties served by the public water supply shall be protected from possible contamination as specified by this section and by the state and city plumbing code. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as: 
WATER UNSAFE FOR DRINKING 
(h)  That this section does not supersede the state plumbing code and city plumbing ordinance, but is supplementary to them. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 76-1, §§ 1-9, 2-9-76; Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 31, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 2018-01, § 1, 3-12-18) 
Sec. 24-24. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate the provisions of section 24-18 of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both, plus the costs of prosecution. 
(b)  The violation of any provision of any section of this article other than section 24-18, or of any written order of the City of Milan Water Supply and Sewage Disposal System issued pursuant to this article, shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. Upon an admission or determination of responsibility for a municipal civil infraction referenced in this article, the violator, in addition to any other penalty specified in this chapter, shall be subject to a civil fine and costs in the amounts specified in the Official Municipal Civil Infraction Fines and Costs Schedule adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Each day that a violation of any provision of this article is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation or infraction, as the case may be. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 95-1, § 32, 1-23-95) 
Sec. 24-25. - Capital benefit charge. 
    Property added to the city by annexation, an agreement pursuant to Public Act No. 425 of 1984, or by any other means, which benefits from water and/or sewer utilities located within the pre-existing city limits that were the subject of a special assessment project, a portion of the cost of which special assessment project was borne by the city, shall be subject to a capital benefit charge. Such capital benefit charge shall be payable by the property owner, in one cash payment, or, if the city council shall determine, in installments of a number specified by the city council in its approved motion, and shall be calculated as follows: 
(a)  Where the special assessment was calculated on the basis of acreage, the capital benefits charge shall be a fraction, the numerator of which is the total acreage of the subject property and the denominator of which is the total acreage of the portion of the special assessment project for which the cost was borne by the city; multiplied by the total cost borne by the city as part of the special assessment project plus interest thereon calculated from the date of the city's payment thereof to the date of the addition of the subject parcel to the city at a legal rate determined by the city and consistently applied. 
Acreage of subject property * [(Total cost borne by the city as part of the project) + (interest)] 
Acreage of portion of special 
assessment project for which 
cost was borne by the city 
(b)  Where the special assessment was calculated on the basis of frontage, the capital benefits charge shall be a fraction, the numerator of which is the total frontage of the subject property and the denominator of which is the total frontage of the portion of the special assessment project for which the cost was borne by the city; multiplied by the total cost borne by the city as part of the special assessment project plus interest thereon calculated from the date of the city's payment thereof to the date of the addition of the subject parcel to the city at a legal rate determined by the city and consistently applied. 
Frontage of subject property * [(Total cost borne by the city as part of the project) + (interest)] 
Frontage of portion of special 
assessment project for which 
cost was borne by the city 
(Ord. No. C.O. 98-3, § 1, 6-22-98) 
Secs. 24-26-24-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SUPPLY AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM[2] 

Footnotes:

No. 96-2, § 1, adopted April 8, 1996, repealed §§ 24-33-24-43, 24-46 and 24-50-24-59; § 2 of such ordinance renumbered §§ 24-44, 24-45, 24-48 and 24-49 as §§ 24-56-24-59; and § 3 of such ordinance enacted new §§ 24-33-24-55 to read as herein set out.
