Costs incurred by the city shall include, but shall not necessarily be limited to, the following: actual labor costs of city personnel, including worker's compensation, fringe benefits, administrative overhead, costs of equipment operation, costs of materials obtained directly by the city and cost of any contract labor and material. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, 6-24-02) 
Sec. 26-55. - Submittal of bill. 
    The city clerk/treasurer shall, within fifteen (15) days of receiving itemized costs incurred for an emergency response, submit a bill for such costs by first class mail or personal service to a person or entity liable for these expenses as enumerated under this article. The bill shall require full payment within thirty (30) days from the date of billing. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, 6-24-02) 
Sec. 26-56. - Liens; confiscation of vehicles and contents; court action. 
    If any person or entity fails to reimburse the city, as provided, and such person or entity is the owner of the affected property, the city shall have the right and power to add any and all costs of cleanup and restoration to the tax roll as to such property, and to levy and collect such costs in the same manner as provided for the levy and collection of real property taxes against such property. The city shall also have the right to confiscate any vehicle and its contents at the time of the incident where such costs cannot be added to the tax roll, i.e., nonresident or nontaxpayer of the city. The city shall also have the right to bring an action in the appropriate court to collect such costs if it deems such action to be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, 6-24-02) 
Sec. 26-57. - Liability of enforcing city officials. 
    Members of the fire department, police department or other duly authorized official of the city, in charge of the scene, shall not be liable for any costs or damages incurred as a result of enforcement of any provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, 6-24-02) 
Sec. 26-58. - Schedule of personnel, equipment, material, and noncity agent costs. 
    A schedule of personnel, equipment and material costs shall be formulated by each of the affected city departments, a copy of which shall be maintained on file in the appropriate department and in the city clerk/treasurer's office. The schedule of costs shall be revised and amended on an annual basis, to reflect any increases in personnel, equipment, or material costs. Noncity agent costs shall be that which is actually charged for the services rendered by an outside city agent or agencies. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, 6-24-02) 
Secs. 26-59-26-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RECOVERY OF COSTS FOR MILAN AREA FIRE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 26-71. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the words or phrases listed below shall have the following meanings: 
    City means the City of Milan, Counties of Monroe and Washtenaw, State of Michigan. 
    Department means the Milan Area Fire Department. 
    Emergency response means the request for or provision of any firefighting, emergency medical, or rescue services by the city, or by the department, or by a governmental or intergovernmental entity or agency, or by a private corporation, acting at the request of or direction of the city or the department. 
    Person means any individual, group, partnership or corporation, whether public or private. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 26-72. - Short title. 
    This article may be cited and referred to as the City's Emergency Response Cost Recovery Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 2, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 26-73. - Purpose. 
    The city hereby finds that incurring unreimbursed costs in providing emergency responses places great fiscal and operational strain on the health and welfare of the city, its residents and businesses. As a result of this determination, pursuant to Section 6a of Act 33 of the Public Acts of 1951, as amended, the city hereby enacts this article to allow the recovery of costs incurred in providing emergency responses. The enactment of this article is hereby found to be in the best interest of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 3, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 26-74. - Charges for emergency responses. 
    Any costs, fees or charges incurred by the department or the city as a result of an emergency response shall be billed by the city to and collected from the person for whose benefit the services were provided. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 4, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 26-75. - Multiple property/person protection. 
    When a particular service rendered by the department directly benefits multiple persons, each person shall be billed only for payment of the person's proportionate share of the services rendered as determined by the department or the city. Such determination of the proportionate responsibility shall be conclusive unless appealed to the city administrator within the time herein provided for payment. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 5, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 26-76. - Cost recovery process. 
(a)  The costs of an emergency response by the department or the city shall be a charge against the Person liable for such expense as set forth by this article. The charge shall constitute a debt of that Person and shall be collectible by the city for incurring those costs in the same manner as any other debt, or may be made the subject of an order of restitution in any criminal prosecution. 
(b)  The city shall be entitled to recover any and all costs of emergency responses by the department or the city. Such costs shall include, but are not limited to, any related third party costs which are necessary to insure the safety of the city and its populace and buildings. 
(c)  The city treasurer, or designee, may submit a statement of charges for the costs of an emergency response by first class mail to any such person whose identity and address may be ascertained by the city. Such a statement may also be transmitted via facsimile or other electronic means if such means are reasonably determined to provide actual notice to the intended recipient. Said statement shall require payment within forty-five (45) days of the statement date. 
(d)  Any person receiving such a statement shall have the opportunity to appeal all or any portion of the amount shown on such statement by filing a written request for appeal with the city administrator within thirty (30) days of receipt of an invoice. The request must be accompanied by a written explanation as to why the amount appealed should not be charged to the appellant. Appeals shall be heard by the city administrator, or a designee, as hearing officer. If the hearing officer determines that the appellant is not properly responsible for any or all of the amount charged, the hearing officer may waive all or a part of such charge against the appellant. The findings and decisions of the hearing officer shall be in writing. 
(e)  If no written request for appeal is received within the specified time, the city may proceed by suit in a court of appropriate jurisdiction to collect any monies remaining unpaid at the expiration of forty-five (45) days from billing. 
(f)  In addition to seeking to recover the costs of an emergency response, the city shall have any other remedy available to it by law. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 6, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 26-77. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  False alarms, unless they are determined to be of a malicious nature; 
(2)  Fires caused by railroad trains which are the specific responsibility of railroad companies; 
(3)  Fire service to property owned by the United States of America, or the State of Michigan, or any political subdivision of the State of Michigan; 
(4)  Fire service provided outside the jurisdiction of the city under a mutual aid contract with an adjoining municipality; and 
(5)  Charges waived by the city council. 
(6)  Effective January 1, 2016, any costs, fees, or charges, incurred by the department or by the city for the first two emergency medical responses made in any calendar year to provide care to a resident of the city, provided that such emergency medical response was not caused by an intentional or criminal act by the resident. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 7, 6-23-14; Ord. No. 2015-07, § 1,10-26-15) 
Sec. 26-78. - Non-exclusive charges. 
    All charges for services rendered pursuant to this article shall be in addition to any charges or taxes made by the department or the city pursuant to law for the maintenance or operation of the department. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 8, 6-23-14) 
Chapter 27 - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES 

Sec. 27-1. - Medical treatment of those confined. 
    Any person held in custody, confined or incarcerated by the city, including, but not limited to: individuals who are i) under arrest, ii) incarcerated, iii) imprisoned, iv) escaped from confinement, v) under supervised release, vi) on medical furlough, vii) residing in a mental health facility or halfway house, viii) living under home detention, ix) or confined completely or partially in any way under a state or local penal statute, ordinance or rule; shall be solely responsible for the payment of any medical services rendered to, and received by, that person during the course of his or her confinement with the city, or at the city's or court's direction, including without limitation, transportation to and from a medical treatment facility, and any treatment deemed necessary by his or her treating physician, whether or not requested by the prisoner; and shall be required to reimburse the city, in full for any fees or charges incurred for such services, if not paid directly to medical facility or practitioner by the prisoner or his or her insurance carrier. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Chapter 28 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICTS 

Sec. 28-1. - Statement of purpose. 
(a)  Historic preservation is hereby declared to be a public purpose and the City Council of the City of Milan may hereby regulate the construction, addition, alteration, repair, moving, excavation, and demolition of resources in historic preservation districts within the city limits. The purpose of this article is to: 
(1)  Safeguard the heritage of the City of Milan by preserving districts which reflect elements of its history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, or culture. 
(2)  Stabilize and improve property values in each district and surrounding areas. 
(3)  Foster civic beauty. 
(4)  Strengthen the local economy. 
(5)  Promote the use of historic preservation districts for the education, pleasure, and welfare of the citizens of the City of Milan and of the State of Michigan. 
(b)  The City of Milan may by ordinance establish one (1) or more historic preservation districts. The historic preservation district(s) shall be administered by the historic preservation district commission and pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-2. - Definitions. 
    Alteration means work that changes the detail of a resource but does not change its basic size or shape. 
    Certificate of appropriateness means the written approval of a permit application for work that is appropriate and that does not adversely affect a resource. 
    Commission means the Milan Historic Preservation District Commission. 
    Demolition means the razing or destruction, whether entirely or in part, of a resource and includes, but is not limited to, demolition by neglect. 
    Demolition by neglect means neglect in maintaining, repairing, or securing a resource that results in deterioration of an exterior feature of the resource or the loss of structural integrity of the resource. 
    Denial means the written rejection of a permit application for work that is inappropriate and that adversely affects a resource. 
    Fire alarm system means a system designed to detect and annunciate the presence of fire or by-products of fire. Fire alarm system includes smoke alarms. 
    Historic preservation district means an area, or group of areas, not necessarily having contiguous boundaries, that contains one resource or a group of resources that are related by history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, or culture. 
    Historic preservation means the identification, evaluation, establishment, and protection of resources significant in history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, or culture. 
    Historic resource means a publicly or privately owned building, structure, site, object, feature or open space that is significant in the history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, or culture of the City of Milan, State of Michigan, or the United States. 
    Notice to proceed means the written permission to issue a permit for work that is inappropriate and that adversely affects a resource, pursuant to a finding under section 399.205(6) of Public Act 169 of 1970, as amended, and section 28-11 herein. 
    Open space means undeveloped land, a naturally landscaped area, or a formal or man-made landscaped area that provides a connective link or buffer between other resources. 
    Ordinary maintenance means keeping a resource unimpaired and in good condition through ongoing minor intervention, undertaken from time to time, in its exterior condition. Ordinary maintenance does not change the external appearance of the resource except through the elimination of the usual and expected effects of weathering. Ordinary maintenance does not constitute work for the purposes of this chapter. 
    Permit means a permit issued by the city's building department following approval of a certificate of appropriateness or notice to proceed by the commission and before any work affecting the exterior appearance of a resource or the construction of a new structure or part thereof within a historic preservation district is performed. 
    Proposed historic preservation district means an area, or group of areas not necessarily having contiguous boundaries, that has delineated boundaries and that is under review by a study committee or a standing committee for the purpose of making a recommendation as to whether it should be established as a historic preservation district or added to an established historic preservation district. 
    Repair means to restore a decayed or damaged resource to good or sound condition by any process. A repair that changes the external appearance of a resource constitutes work for the purposes of this chapter. 
    Resource means one (1) or more publicly or privately owned historic or non-historic buildings, structures, sites, objects, features, or open spaces located within a historic preservation district. 
    Smoke alarm means a single-station or multiple-station alarm responsive to smoke and not connected to a system. As used in this subdivision, "single-station alarm" means an assembly incorporating a detector, the control equipment, and the alarm sounding device into a single unit, operated from a power supply either in the unit or obtained at the point of installation. "Multiple-station alarm" means two (2) or more single-station alarms that are capable of interconnection such that actuation of one (1) alarm causes all integrated separate audible alarms to operate. 
    Standing committee means a permanent body established by the city council pursuant to this chapter to conduct the activities of a historic preservation district study committee on a continuing basis. 
    Study committee means the historic preservation district study committee established by the city council pursuant to section 28-3 of this chapter. 
    Work means construction, addition, alteration, repair, moving, excavation, or demolition. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-3. - Historic preservation district study committee, the study committee report and establishing historic preservation districts. 
(a)  Study committee . Before establishing a historic preservation district, the city council shall appoint a historic preservation district study committee. A majority of the persons appointed to the study committee shall have a clearly demonstrated interest in or knowledge of historic preservation. The study committee shall contain representation of at least one (1)member appointed from one or more duly organized local historic preservation organizations. The study committee shall do all of the following: 
(1)  Conduct a photographic inventory of resources within each proposed historic preservation district following procedures established by the State Historic Preservation Office of the Michigan Historical Center. 
(2)  Conduct basic research of each proposed Historic Preservation District and historic resources located within that district. 
(3)  Determine the total number of historic and non-historic resources within a proposed historic preservation district and the percentage of historic resources of that total. In evaluating the significance of historic resources, the study committee shall be guided by the selection criteria for evaluation issued by the United States Secretary of the Interior for inclusion of resources in the National Register of Historic Places, as set forth in 36 CFR part 60, and criteria established or approved by the State Historic Preservation Office of the Michigan Historical Center. 
(4)  Prepare a preliminary historic preservation district study committee report that addresses at a minimum all of the following: 
a.  The charge of the study committee; 
b.  The composition of study committee membership; 
c.  The historic preservation district(s) studied; 
d.  The boundaries of each proposed historic preservation district in writing and on maps; 
e.  The history of each proposed historic preservation district; 
f.  The significance of each district as a whole, as well as a sufficient number of its individual resources to fully represent the variety of resources found within the district, relative to the evaluation criteria; 
g.  Transmit copies of the preliminary report for review and recommendations to the local planning body, the State Historic Preservation Office of the Michigan Historical Center, the Michigan Historical Commission, and the State Historic Preservation Review Board; and 
h.  Make copies of the preliminary report available to the public pursuant to Section 399.203 (4) of Public Act 169 of 1970, as amended ("Act 169"). 
(b)  Public hearing . Not less than sixty (60) calendar days after the transmittal of the preliminary report, the study committee shall hold a public hearing. Public notice of the time, date and place of the hearing shall be given in the manner required by the Open Meetings Act, Public Act 267 of 1976, as amended. Written notice shall be mailed by first class mail not less than fourteen (14) calendar days prior to the hearing to the owners of properties within the proposed historic preservation district. 
(c)  Report establishing a historic preservation district . After the date of the public hearing, the study committee and the city council have not more than one (1) year, unless otherwise authorized by the city council, to take the following actions: 
(1)  The study committee shall prepare and submit a final report with its recommendations and the recommendations, if any, of the local planning body to the city council as to the establishment of a historic preservation district(s). If the recommendation is to establish a historic preservation district(s), the final report shall include a draft of the proposed ordinance(s). 
(2)  After receiving a final report that recommends the establishment of a historic preservation district(s), the city council, at its discretion, may introduce and pass or reject an ordinance(s). If the city council passes an ordinance(s) establishing one (1) or more historic preservation districts, the city shall file a copy of the ordinance(s), including a legal description of the property or properties located within the historic preservation district(s) with the Register of Deeds. The city council shall not pass an ordinance establishing a contiguous historic preservation district less than 60 days after a majority of the property owners within the proposed historic preservation district, as listed on the tax rolls of the local unit, have approved the establishment of the historic preservation district pursuant to a written petition. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-4. - Establishing additional, modifying, or eliminating historic preservation districts. 
(a)  Additional historic preservation districts. The city council may at any time establish by ordinance additional historic preservation districts, including proposed districts previously considered and rejected, may modify boundaries of an existing historic preservation district, or may eliminate an existing historic preservation district. Before establishing, modifying, or eliminating a historic preservation district, a historic preservation district study committee appointed by the city council shall follow the procedures as stated in Section 399.203(1) through (3) of Act 169, and section 28-3 herein. To conduct these activities, the city council may retain the study committee, establish a standing committee, or establish a committee to consider only specific proposed districts and then be dissolved. The committee shall consider any previously written committee reports pertinent to the proposed action. 
(b)  Eliminating historic preservation districts . In considering elimination of a historic preservation district, a committee shall follow the procedures set forth in Section 399.214 (1) through (3) of Act 169, and Section 28-3 herein, for the issuance of a preliminary report, holding a public hearing, and issuing a final report but with the intent of showing one or more of the following: 
(1)  The historic preservation district has lost those physical characteristics that enabled the establishment of the district. 
(2)  The historic preservation district was not significant in the way previously defined. 
(3)  The historic preservation district was established pursuant to defective procedures. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-5. - Historic preservation district commission: creation, membership, vacancies, compensation, and termination. 
(a)  Creation . There is hereby created the Milan Historic Preservation District Commission, which shall consist of seven (7) members. Members shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council, for terms of office of three (3) years; provided, that two (2) of the initial members shall be appointed for one (1) year, two (2) members for two (2) years, and three (3) members for three (3) years. Terms shall expire on February first of the year of expiration. The first appointment shall be for terms of less than one (1), two (2) or three (3) years, in order to expire on February first. Members of the historic preservation district commission shall be eligible for reappointment. 
(b)  Membership . All members must reside in the city. A majority of the members shall have a clearly demonstrated interest in or knowledge of historic preservation. At least one (1) member of the historic preservation district commission shall be appointed from a list of residents submitted by a duly organized and existing local historic preservation organization, and at least one (1) member of the historic preservation district commission shall be a graduate of an accredited school of architecture who has at least two (2) years of architectural experience or who is an architect duly registered in this state if such person resides in the city and is available for appointment. 
(c)  Termination . Any member who is absent from three (3) meetings in a one-year period and who fails to show good cause therefore to the historic preservation district commission, shall be removed as a member from the commission. A recommendation for removal of any member of the historical commission may be made for just cause by a majority vote of the entire commission. Such recommendation shall then be forwarded to the Mayor for consideration and action. 
(d)  Vacancies . A vacancy occurring in the membership of the historic preservation district commission for any cause shall be filled by a person appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council for the duration of the unexpired term. 
(e)  Compensation . Members of the historic preservation district commission shall serve with such compensation as may be provided by the resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-6. - Historic preservation district commission: meetings, recordkeeping, rules of procedure. 
(a)  Meetings . The historic preservation district commission shall meet at least quarterly or more frequently at the call of the historic preservation district commission. the business that the historic preservation district commission may perform shall be conducted at a public meeting held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act, Public Act 267 of 1976, as amended. Public notice of the date, time, and place of the meeting shall be given in the manner required by Act 267. A meeting agenda shall be part of the notice and shall include a listing of each permit application to be reviewed or considered by the historic preservation district commission. 
(b)  Recordkeeping . The historic preservation district commission shall keep a record of its resolutions, proceedings and actions. A writing prepared, owned, used, in the possession of, or retained by the historic preservation district commission in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with the Freedom of Information, Public Act 442 of 1976, as amended. 
(c)  Rules of procedure . The historic preservation district commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall adopt design review standards and guidelines to carry out its duties under this Act. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-7. - Delegation of minor classes of work. 
    The historic preservation district commission may delegate the issuance of certificates of appropriateness for specified minor classes of work to its staff, or to another delegated authority. The historic preservation district commission shall provide to its delegated authority specific written standards for issuing certificates of appropriateness under this subsection. The historic preservation district commission shall review the certificates of appropriateness issued by the delegate on at least a quarterly basis to determine whether or not the delegated responsibilities should be continued. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-8. - Ordinary maintenance. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent ordinary maintenance or repair of a resource within a historic preservation district or to prevent work on any resource under a permit issued by the inspector of buildings or other duly delegated authority before the chapter was enacted. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-9. - Review by the commission. 
    The historic preservation district commission shall review and act upon only exterior features of a resource and shall not review and act upon interior arrangements unless specifically authorized to do so by the city council or unless interior work will cause visible change to the exterior of the resource. The commission shall not disapprove an application due to considerations not prescribed in subsection 399.205 (3) of Public Act 169 of 1970, as amended, or section 28-10 herein. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-10. - Work within historic preservation districts; permission required; review procedure. 
(a)  Requests for permission . Before commencing any work affecting the exterior appearance of a structure or the construction of a new structure or part thereof within a historic preservation district or interior work that will cause visible change to the exterior of the resource, the person, including any individual, partnership, firm, corporation, organization, institution, or agency of government, proposing to take such action shall apply for and obtain permission to do so from the historic preservation district commission. 
(b)  Application . The application shall be on a form and shall include such information and materials as prescribed in guidelines to be adopted by the building department official and provided to all applicants. A fee may be charged for the review and decision by the historic preservation district commission of any application, in accordance with the procedures established by the historic preservation district commission. As part of the information and materials to be supplied pursuant to the above referenced guidelines, the application shall generally consist of two (2) parts: 
(1)  A written proposal of the action for which commission approval is sought with an explanation of the reason for the requested action; and 
(2)  Plans and drawings sufficient to clearly illustrate the proposed actions and depicting the structure in question and its relation to adjacent structures. 
    The application shall be submitted to the building department before obtaining a building permit. A permit shall not be issued and proposed work shall not proceed until the historic preservation district commission has acted on the application by issuing a certificate of appropriateness or a notice to proceed. A certificate of appropriateness or notice to proceed shall not be issued unless the applicant certifies in the application that the property where work will be undertaken has, or will have before the proposed project completion date, a fire alarm system or a smoke alarm complying with the requirements of the Stile-DeRossett-Hale Single State Construction Code Act, 1972 PA 230, MCL 125.1501 - 125.1531. 
(c)  Transmittal of application to historic preservation district commission; building department certification . Copies of the complete application shall be transmitted to the historic preservation district commission immediately after filing with the building department. No work shall take place, nor a permit of any kind issued therefor, until the commission has issued a certificate of appropriateness or a notice to proceed and until the building department has certified that the plans and drawings meet the requirements of all applicable ordinances and regulations. 
(d)  Guidelines, standards, and criteria. 
(1)  In reviewing plans, the commission shall follow the U.S. Secretary of the Interior's "Standards for Rehabilitation and Guidelines for Rehabilitating Historic Buildings" as set forth in 36 C.F.R. part 67, as amended. The following standards are to be applied: 
a.  A property shall be used for its historic purpose or be placed in a new use that requires minimal change to the defining characteristics of the building and its site and environment. 
b.  The historic character of a property shall be retained and preserved. The removal of historic materials or alteration of features and spaces that characterize a property shall be avoided. 
c.  Each property shall be recognized as a physical record of its time, place, and use. Changes that create a false sense of historical development, such as adding conjectural features or architectural elements from other buildings, shall not be undertaken. 
d.  Most properties change over time; those changes that have acquired historic significance in their own right shall be retained and preserved. 
e.  Distinctive features, finishes, and construction techniques or examples of craftsmanship that characterize a historic property shall be preserved. 
f.  Deteriorated historic features shall be repaired rather than replaced. Where the severity of deterioration requires replacement of a distinctive feature, the new feature shall match the old in design, color, texture, and other visual qualities and, where possible, materials. Replacement of missing features shall be substantiated by documentary, physical, or pictorial evidence. 
g.  Chemical or physical treatments, such as sandblasting, that cause damage to historic materials shall not be used. The surface cleaning of structures, if appropriate, shall be undertaken using the gentlest means possible. 
h.  Significant archeological resources affected by a project shall be protected and preserved. If such resources must be disturbed, mitigation measures shall be undertaken. 
i.  New additions, exterior alterations, or related new construction shall not destroy historic materials that characterize the property. The new work shall be differentiated from the old and shall be compatible with the massing, size, scale, and architectural features to protect the historic integrity of the property and its environment. 
j.  New additions and adjacent or related new construction shall be undertaken in a manner that if removed in the future, the essential form and integrity of the historic property and its environment would be unimpaired. 
(2)  The commission shall also consider all of the following: 
a.  The historic or architectural value and significance of the resource and its relationship to the historical value of the surrounding area; 
b.  The relationship of any exterior architectural features of the resource to the rest of the resource and to the surrounding areas; 
c.  The general compatibility of the exterior design, arrangement, texture and materials proposed to be used; 
d.  Those features of the particular resource identified in the historic preservation district study committee report, which supported its recommendation of the site or structure for inclusion within a historic preservation district. 
e.  Other factors, such as aesthetic value, that the commission finds relevant; and 
f.  Whether the applicant has certified in the application that the property where work will be undertaken has, or will have before the proposed project completion date, a fire alarm system or a smoke alarm complying with the requirement of the Stile-DeRossett-Hale Single State Construction Code Act, 1972 PA 230, MCL 125.1501 - 125.1531. 
(3)  Additionally, the quality of materials and craftsmanship used in a rehabilitation project must be commensurate with the quality of materials and craftsmanship of the historic building in question. 
(4)  Owners are responsible for procuring copies of the Secretary of Interior's standards for rehabilitation to consult as part of the planning process. 
(5)  The historic preservation district commission may also adopt rules of procedure and additional review standards and guidelines for resource treatment in order to carry out its duties under this section and for resource treatment in order to carry out its duties under this section, as long as those rules and additional review standards and guidelines are equivalent in guidance to the Secretary of Interior's standards and guidelines and are established or approved by the State Historic Preservation Office. 
(e)  Plan for preservation of structures . In case of an application for repair or alteration affecting the exterior appearance of a structure or for moving or demolition of a structure which the historic preservation district commission deems so valuable to the city, state or Nation that the loss thereof will adversely affect the public purpose of the city, state or Nation, the historic preservation district commission shall endeavor to work out with the owner an economically feasible plan for preservation of the structure. 
(f)  Demolition or moving of structures. It shall be the public policy of this city to discourage the demolition, demolition by neglect or moving of historic resources. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-11. - Decision of the historic preservation district commission. 
(a)  Certificate of appropriateness . Upon its review, the historic preservation district commission shall first approve the proposal and secondly approve the plans if, in its judgment, the standards, guidelines, and criteria enumerated in section 28-10, above, are satisfied and there is no adverse effect caused by the request. In approving the proposal and plans, the commission shall issue a certificate of appropriateness. The approval of a certificate of appropriateness may be with or without conditions; provided that any conditions shall be consistent with and for purposes of fulfilling the values embodied in the standards, guidelines and criteria set forth in section 28-10. 
(b)  Approval of proposal with denial of plan . The historic preservation district commission may approve the proposal but reject the specific plans if it determines the plans are contrary or detrimental to the values embodied in the standards, guidelines, and criteria set forth in section 28-10. In that event the application shall be deemed denied, but the applicant shall have the right to submit revised, amended or new plans addressing the issues raised by the commission for further review and consideration, which submission shall constitute a new application for purposes of subsection (g), below. 
(c)  Denial . Denial of any application shall be based only on the considerations set forth in section 28-10, above. A denial shall be accompanied by a written explanation by the commission of the reasons for denial, and a notice of the applicant's right to resubmit its application addressing the issues raised by the commission for further review by the commission. Further, the denial shall notify the applicant of the right to appeal the denial pursuant to section 28-12 of this chapter. A denial shall be binding upon the building department and no permit shall be issued in such case. In the case of denial, either before or after a denial the commission shall endeavor to work out a feasible plan for preservation with the applicant and may give suggestions regarding changes in the application it deems desirable to the applicant. 
(d)  Notice to proceed . Work within a historic preservation district shall be permitted through the issuance of a notice to proceed by the commission if any of the following conditions prevail and if the proposed work can be demonstrated by a finding of the historic preservation district commission to be necessary to substantially improve or correct any of the following conditions: 
(1)  The resource constitutes a hazard to the safety of the public or to the structure's occupants. 
(2)  The resource is a deterrent to a major improvement program that will be of substantial benefit to the community and the applicant proposing the work has obtained all necessary planning and zoning approvals, financing, and environmental clearances. 
(3)  Retaining the resource will cause undue financial hardship to the owner when a governmental action, an act of God, or other events beyond the owner's control created the hardship, and all feasible alternatives to eliminate the financial hardship, which may include offering the resource for sale at its fair market value or moving the resource to a vacant site within the historic preservation district, have been attempted and exhausted by the owner. 
(4)  Retaining the resource is not in the interest of the majority of the community. 
(e)  Filing of decision . After due consideration, the historic preservation district commission shall file with the building department its certificate of appropriateness, notice to proceed, or denial of the application submitted to it for review. Such certificate shall be signed by the chairperson or secretary of the historic preservation district commission. The historic preservation district commission shall state the reasons and grounds for its action in its minutes and on the face of its certificate. 
(f)  Compliance with approved plan . After a certificate of appropriateness has been issued and the building or demolition permit granted to the applicant, the building department shall take such action as is necessary to require compliance with the building plan approved by the historic preservation district commission, including any conditions of such approval. Certificates of appropriateness shall remain effective for a period of one (1) year; provided, however, that any plan submitted with the application for a building permit shall meet all of the requirements of the building code in effect at the time the permit is applied for. If a building or demolition permit is not obtained within one (1) year, the approval shall expire and become null and void. 
(g)  Failure of historic preservation district commission to act. The failure of the commission to act within a maximum of sixty (60) days after the date of a complete and accurate application filed with it, unless an extension is agreed upon in writing by the applicant and the historic preservation district commission, shall be deemed to constitute approval. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-12. - Appeal of a historic preservation district commission decision. 
(a)  An applicant aggrieved by a decision of the historic preservation district commission concerning a permit application may file an appeal with the State Historic Preservation Review Board. The appeal shall be filed within sixty (60) calendar days after the decision is furnished to the applicant. The appellant may submit all or part of the appellant's evidence and arguments in written form. The State Historic Preservation Review Board shall consider an appeal at its first regularly scheduled meeting after receiving the appeal. A permit applicant aggrieved by the decision of the State Historic Preservation Review Board may appeal the decision to the circuit court having jurisdiction over the historic preservation district commission whose decision was appealed to the State Historic Preservation Review Board. 
(b)  Any citizen or duly organized historic preservation organization in the City of Milan as well as resource property owners, jointly or severally aggrieved by a decision of the historic preservation district commission may appeal the decision to the circuit court, except that a permit applicant aggrieved by a decision rendered under this chapter may not appeal to the court without first exhausting the right to appeal to the State Historic Preservation Review Board. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-13. - Work without a permit. 
    When work has been done upon a resource without a permit, and the historic preservation district commission finds that the work does not qualify for a certificate of appropriateness, the commission may require an owner to restore the resource to the condition that the resource was in before the inappropriate work or to modify the work so that it qualifies for a certificate of appropriateness. If the owner does not comply with the restoration or modification requirement within a reasonable time, the commission may seek an order from the circuit court to require the owner to restore the resource to its former condition or to modify the work so that it qualifies for a certificate of appropriateness. If the owner does not comply or cannot comply with the order of the court, the commission or its agents may enter the property and conduct work necessary to restore the resource to its former condition or modify the work so that it qualifies for a certificate of appropriateness in accordance with the court's order. The costs of the work done shall be charged to the owner, and may be levied by the City of Milan as a special assessment against the property. When acting pursuant to an order of the circuit court, the commission or its agents may enter a property for purposes of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-14. - Demolition by neglect. 
    Upon a finding by the commission that a historic resource within a historic preservation district or a proposed historic preservation district subject to its review and approval is threatened with demolition by neglect, the commission may do either of the following: 
(1)  Require the owner of the resource to repair all conditions contributing to demolition by neglect. 
(2)  If the owner does not make repairs within a reasonable time, the historic preservation district commission or its agents may enter the property and make such repairs as necessary to prevent demolition by neglect. The costs of the work shall be charged to the owner, and may be levied by the City of Milan as a special assessment against the property. The historic preservation district commission or its agents may enter the property for purposes of this section upon obtaining an order from the circuit court. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-15. - Review of work in proposed districts. 
    Upon receipt of substantial evidence showing the presence of historic, architectural, archaeological, engineering, or cultural significance of a proposed historic preservation district, the city council may, at its discretion, adopt a resolution requiring that all applications for permits within the proposed historic preservation district be referred to the historic preservation district commission as prescribed in section 28-10 of this chapter. The historic preservation district commission shall review permit applications with the same powers that would apply if the proposed historic preservation district was an established historic preservation district. The review may continue in the proposed historic preservation district for not more than one (1) year, or until such time as the city council approves or rejects the establishment of the historic preservation district by ordinance, whichever occurs first. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-16. - Emergency moratorium. 
    If the city council determines that pending work will cause irreparable harm to resources located within an established or proposed historic preservation district, the city council may by resolution declare an emergency moratorium on all such work for a period not to exceed six (6) months. The city council may extend the emergency moratorium for an additional period not to exceed six (6) months, upon finding that the threat of irreparable harm to resources is still present. Any pending permit application concerning a resource subject to an emergency moratorium may be summarily denied. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-17. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  A person, individual, partnership, firm, corporation, organization, institution, or agency of government that violates this Act is responsible for a civil violation and may be fined not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(b)  A person, individual, partnership, firm, corporation, organization, institution, or agency of government that violates this Act may be ordered by the court to pay the costs to restore or replicate a resource unlawfully constructed, added to, altered, repaired, moved, excavated or demolished. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-18. - Acceptance of gifts or grants. 
    The city council may accept state or federal grants for historic preservation purposes; may participate in state and federal programs that benefit historic preservation, and may accept public or private gifts for historic preservation purposes. The city council may appoint the historic preservation district commission to accept and administer grants, gifts, and program responsibilities. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17) 
Sec. 28-19. - Acquisition of historic resources. 
    If all efforts by the historic preservation district commission to preserve a resource fail, or if it is determined by the city council that public ownership is most suitable, the city council, if considered to be in the public interest, may acquire the resource using public funds, public or private gifts, grants or proceeds from the issuance of revenue bonds. The acquisition shall be based upon the recommendation of the historic preservation district commission. The historic preservation district commission is responsible for maintaining publicly owned resources using its own funds, if not specifically designated for other purposes, or public funds committed for that use by the city council. Upon recommendation of the historic preservation district commission, the city may sell resources acquired under this section with protective easements included in the property transfer documents, if appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-22-17)

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

1.01. - Short title. 
    This ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Milan Subdivision Ordinance." 
1.02. - Policy. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the policy of the City of Milan to consider the subdivision of land and the subsequent development of the subdivided plat as subject to control of the city pursuant to the adopted master plan for future land use of the City of Milan. 
(b)  Land to be subdivided shall be of such character that it can be used safely for building purposes without danger to health or peril from fire, flood, or other menace. Land shall not be subdivided unless proper provision has been made for drainage, water, sewerage, and capital improvements such as schools, parks, recreation facilities, and transportation facilities. 
(c)  Existing and proposed public improvements shall conform to and be properly related to the adopted master plan for future land use, and the adopted capital improvement and capital budget of the City of Milan. This ordinance shall supplement and facilitate enforcement of the building code, zoning ordinance, master plan, and capital program and capital budget of the City of Milan. 
1.03. - Purposes. 
(a)  To protect and provide for the public health, safety and general welfare of the City of Milan. 
(b)  To guide the future growth and orderly development of the City of Milan, in accordance with the adopted master plan for future land use. 
(c)  To provide adequate light, air, and privacy; to secure safety from fire, flood, and other danger, and to prevent overcrowding of the land and undue congestion of population. 
(d)  To protect the character and stability of all parts of the City of Milan. 
(e)  To protect and conserve the value of land and buildings throughout the City of Milan and to minimize the conflicts between the uses of land and buildings. 
(f)  To guide public and private policy and action in order to provide adequate and efficient transportation, water and sewer services, drainage, schools, parks, playgrounds, recreation and other public facilities. 
(g)  To provide for circulation of traffic throughout the city, to avoid congestion in the streets; for pedestrian traffic movements; and proper location and width of streets. 
(h)  To establish reasonable procedures for subdivisions and resubdivisions, in order to obtain orderly layout and use of land; and to ensure proper legal descriptions and monumenting of subdivided land. 
(i)  To ensure that public facilities are available and of sufficient capacity to serve a proposed subdivision. 
(j)  To prevent pollution of air, streams, and water bodies; to assure adequate drainage facilities; to safeguard the water table; and to encourage wise use and management of natural resources throughout the City of Milan. 
(k)  To preserve the functional integrity and beauty of the natural ecosystem within the City of Milan and to ensure that any development which must occur give appropriate regard to natural features and interrelationships. 
(l)  To provide open spaces through efficient design and layout of the land. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 1, 2-24-03) 
1.04. - Scope. 
(a)  This ordinance shall apply to all subdivisions of land within the City of Milan. 
(b)  No land shall be subdivided within the city without prior review and approval of the city land division board. In addition, no land shall be subdivided within the city until all requirements of this section and the Subdivision Control Act have been met. 
(c)  No building permit or certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any parcel of land which was created by subdivision after the effective date of this ordinance, unless the subdivision conforms to this ordinance. No excavation of land or construction of any public or private improvement shall commence except in conformity of this ordinance. 
(d)  The provisions of this ordinance, in their interpretation and application, shall be held to meet the minimum requirements for the promotion of public health, safety and welfare. 
(e)  This ordinance is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant or any other private agreement or restriction. Where provisions of this ordinance are more restrictive or impose higher standards or regulations, this ordinance shall govern. Where an easement, covenant, or private agreement or restriction imposes more restrictive obligations or higher standards than this ordinance, and where said provisions are not inconsistent with this ordinance, said provisions shall control. 
(f)  This ordinance shall not apply to any lot or lots which are a part of a subdivision created and recorded prior to the effective date of this ordinance, or to a lot or lots which are a part of a subdivision which is in process of review or construction prior to the effective date of this ordinance. This ordinance shall however, apply to the further dividing of such lots after the effective date of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 2, 2-24-03) 
1.05. - Legal basis. 
    This ordinance is enacted pursuant to Act 288, Public Acts of 1967, as amended, and Act 285, Public Acts of 1931, as amended. 
1.06. - Fees. 
    A schedule of fees for review of plans and plats, and tax inspection of improvements, shall be established by resolution of the Milan City Council. 
1.07. - Cemeteries. 
    Cemeteries shall not be included within the definition of subdivision, and shall not be subject to this ordinance. 
1.08. - Conformance of laws, rules and regulations. 
    All subdivision plats and all lots within plats shall comply with the following: 
(a)  The Subdivision Control Act and all other applicable statutes. 
(b)  The City of Milan Zoning Ordinance. 
(c)  The City of Milan Building Code. 
(d)  The adopted master plan of future land use and the adopted capital improvements program. 
(e)  The adopted, published and recorded regulations of the city planning commission, as approved by the city council. 
1.09. - Conflicts in ordinances. 
    If a provision of this ordinance is found to conflict with a provision of any zoning, building, fire, safety, or health ordinance of the City of Milan existing on the effective date of this ordinance, the provision which established the higher standard for the promotion and protection of health and safety of the people shall prevail. If a provision of this ordinance is found to conflict with a provision of any other ordinance of the City of Milan existing on the effective date of this ordinance, which establishes a lower standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people, the provision of this ordinance shall prevail. Such other ordinances or codes are hereby declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in conflict with this ordinance. 
1.10. - Severability. 
    If any action, subsection, paragraph, sentence or phrase of this ordinance is declared invalid for any reason whatsoever, such decision shall not affect the remaining portions of this ordinance, which shall remain in full force and effect. To this end the provisions of this ordinance are hereby declared to be severable. 
1.11. - Saving provision. 
    Nothing contained in this ordinance shall be deemed or construed to be a substitute for or to abolish or impair existing other or future legal remedies of the City of Milan or its officers, or agency, including criminal prosecution under this or any other ordinance of the City of Milan, or of the laws of the State of Michigan, even though such remedies may be specifically enumerated or mentioned herein. 
1.12. - Conditions. 
    Regulations of subdivision of land and attachment of conditions to plat approval is an exercise of valid police power delegated by the State of Michigan to the City of Milan. The proprietor has the duty of compliance with conditions established by the city planning commission and city council for design, dedication, improvement and restrictive use of the land, so as to conform to the orderly physical and economic development of the City of Milan; and so as to provide for the safety and general welfare of future land owners in the subdivision and of the community at large. 
1.13. - Metes and bounds descriptions. 
    A subdivision of any lot or parcel of land by the use of a metes and bounds description with the intent of evading the provisions of this ordinance shall be prohibited. 
1.14. - Dedications. 
    Dedications of lands and improvements within a subdivision shall be accepted only by resolution of the Milan City Council, as provided in Section 8.08, herein. 
1.15. - Public hearings. 
    Public hearings shall be held by the planning commission prior to tentative approval and final approval of a preliminary plat and prior to approval of a final plat. The city clerk shall send a notice of each public hearing by registered mail to the proprietor and to the owners of land immediately adjoining the land in the proposed plat at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the hearing. Notice of the public hearing shall be placed in a newspaper having general circulation in the City of Milan at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the hearing. 
ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS 

2.01. - Rules applying to the text. 
    For the purpose of this ordinance, the following rules of construction shall apply: 
(a)  Unless the contents clearly indicate the contrary, words used in the present tense include the future; words used in the plural number include the singular; the word "herein" means "in this ordinance". 
(b)  A "person" includes a corporation, partnership, and an incorporated association of persons, such as a club; "shall" is always mandatory; a "building" includes a "structure", a "building" or "structure" includes any part thereof; "used" or "occupied" as applied to any land or building shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged, designed to be used or occupied". 
2.02. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this ordinance, unless otherwise specifically stated: 
(1)  As-built plans: Construction plans revised to show an improvement as actually constructed. 
(2)  Block: A tract of land that is bounded by streets, or by a combination of streets, parks, cemeteries, railroad right-of-way, subdivided acreage, lines of watercourses, or water bodies, municipal boundary lines, or any other barrier to the continuity of development. 
(3)  Building inspector: The duly appointed building inspector of the City of Milan. 
(4)  Building line or setback line: The minimum distance established by the zoning ordinance, which any building or structure must be located from a street right-of-way line, property line, high water line or easement line of an approved private street. 
(5)  Caption: The name by which the plat is legally and commonly known. 
(6)  Certificate of completion: A certificate issued by the city engineer, which signifies that the improvement for which the certificate is issued was installed according to approved engineering plans and has passed city inspection. 
(7)  City: The City of Milan, Michigan. 
(8)  City attorney: The duly appointed city attorney of the City of Milan, Michigan. 
(9)  City clerk: The clerk of the City of Milan, Michigan. 
(10)  City engineer: A civil engineer registered in the State of Michigan as a professional engineer and appointed to the position of city engineer by the Milan City Council. The city engineer may be an individual or a duly appointed consulting civil engineering firm. 
(11)  City staff: The administrative assistant officer, fire chief, police chief, city engineer, zoning inspector, and planner. 
(12)  Common open space: An area within a subdivision which is held out of development by the proprietor and designed for the common use or enjoyment of residents of the subdivision. Common open space may contain such complementary structures as are necessary and appropriate for the use or enjoyment of the common open space. Common open space may include areas for recreational use, wildlife preserves, and nature study areas. 
(13)  Comprehensive development: A commercial or industrial park of a planned unit development. 
(14)  County drain commissioner: The Monroe County or Washtenaw County Drain Commissioner, whichever is applicable. 
(15)  County health department: The Monroe County or Washtenaw County Health Department, whichever is applicable. 
(16)  County plat board: The Monroe County or Washtenaw Plat Board, whichever is applicable. 
(17)  County road commission: The Monroe County or Washtenaw County Road Commission, whichever is applicable. 
(18)  Development: A subdivision of land or any material change in the use or appearance of any parcel of land subject to the provisions of this ordinance, or the act of building structures and installing site improvements. 
(19)  Filing date: The date on which a plat and a complete application for its review are accepted for official filing by the city clerk. 
(20)  Flood plain: The area adjoining a river, stream, water course, or lake which is inundated by a flood discharge which results from a one hundred-years storm frequency of a twenty-four-hour duration. The flood plain shall include the stream channel and overbank area (the floodway) and the fringe areas of the floodway. 
(21)  General development plan: A comprehensive plan or part or parts thereof for the City of Milan which, through any combination of text, charts, and maps, set forth proposals for general locations and extent of land uses, streets, and public facilities, and general standards and density of development. The plan shall be adopted and published in accordance with the Municipal Planning Commission Act (Act 285, P.A. of 1931), as amended. 
(22)  Improvements: Any structure or material change incident to servicing or furnishing facilities for a subdivision such as, but not limited to grading, street surfacing, curb and gutter, driveway approaches, sidewalks, pedestrian ways, water mains and lines, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, culverts, bridges, utilities, waterways, lakes, canals, and other appropriate items, with appurtenant construction; demolition of structures; planting or removal of trees and other vegetation cover. 
(23)  Lot: A measured portion of a tract of land, described and fixed in a recorded plat or in a plat proposed to be recorded. 
(24)  Model home: A dwelling unit used initially for display purposes which typifies the type of dwelling unit that will be constructed in the subdivision. 
(25)  Outlot: When included within the boundary of a recorded plat means a lot set aside for purposes other than a building site, park or other land dedicated to public use or reserved to private use. 
(26)  Pedestrian way: A separate right-of-way dedicated to or reserved for public use by pedestrians and bicyclists, which crosses blocks or other tracts of land for the purpose of facilitating pedestrian access to adjacent streets and properties. 
(27)  Planned unit development: A parcel of land which is to be developed in an integrated and coordinated manner with residential buildings and certain nonresidential uses, according to approved site plans and subdivision plats, as provided in the zoning ordinance. 
(28)  Planner: A person licensed by the State of Michigan as a professional community planner, or a firm composed of licensed professional community planners, and duly appointed by the planning commission. 
(29)  Planning commission: The planning commission of the City of Milan, as established under Act 295, P.A. of 1931, as amended. 
(30)  Persons: An individual, corporation, government, or governmental agency, business trust, estate trust, partnership or association, two (2) or more persons having a joint or common interest, or any legal entity. 
(31)  Plat: A map or chart of a subdivision of land. 
(32)  Proprietor: Any natural person, firm, association, partnership, corporation, or combination of these, including a governmental agency undertaking any development as defined in this ordinance, and which holds an ownership interest in land, whether recorded or not. The term "proprietor" includes such commonly used references as subdivider, developer, and owner. The word "proprietor" shall not include a person, firm, partnership, corporation, or combination of these which hold an option to purchase land. 
(33)  Public use areas: Public parks, playgrounds, or other recreational areas; scenic or historic sites, school sites or sites for other public buildings; and other areas dedicated to public use or enjoyment. 
(34)  Public utility: All persons, firms, corporations, copartnerships, or municipal or other public authority providing gas, electricity, water, steam, telephone, telegraph, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, transportation, or other services of a similar nature. 
(35)  Replat: The process of changing, or the map or plat which changes the boundaries of a recorded subdivision plat or part thereof. The legal dividing of an outlot within a recorded subdivision plat without changing the exterior boundaries of the outlot is not a replat. 
(36)  Right-of-way: A strip of land occupied or intended to be occupied by a street, pedestrian way, railroad, electric transmission line, oil or gas pipeline, water main, sanitary or storm sewer line, or for another special use. The term "right-of-way" for land platting purposes shall mean that every right-of-way hereafter established and shown on a final plat is to be separate and distinct from the lots or parcels adjoining such right-of-way. Such land area within the right-of-way shall not be included within the dimensions or areas of adjoining lots or parcels. Rights-of-way intended for streets, pedestrian ways, water mains, sanitary sewers, storm drains, or any other use involving maintenance by a public agency, shall be dedicated to public use by the proprietor, when dedication is requested by the governing body. 
(37)  Right-of-way street: The distance between property lines measured at right angles to the centerline of the street. 
(38)  Sidewalk: A facility, placed within the right-of-way of streets, or a facility connecting with buildings, parking lots, or other activities having access to the street right-of-way, for the purpose of providing safe movement of pedestrians and bicyclists. 
(39)  Street: A public or private traffic way which provides the principal means of vehicular and pedestrian access to abutting properties. 
(40)  Structure: Anything constructed, erected, or placed with a fixed location on the surface of the ground, or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground. 
(41)  Subdivide or subdivision: The partitioning of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors, or assigns for the purpose of sale, or lease of more than one year, or of building development, where the act of division creates five (5) or more parcels of land each of which is ten (10) acres or less in area, or five (5) or more parcels of land, each of which is ten (10) acres or less in area, which are created by successive divisions within a period of ten (10) years. The term "subdivision" also refers to any area which is subdivided in accordance with the foregoing definition. 
(42)  Subdivision Control Act: Act 288, P.A. of 1967, as amended. 
(43)  Surveyor: A land surveyor registered in the State of Michigan as a registered land surveyor or a civil engineer registered in Michigan as a professional engineer. 
(44)  Topographical map: A map showing existing physical characteristics, with contour lines of not greater than two (2) foot intervals, to permit determination of proposed grades and drainage. 
(45)  Water resources commission: The water resources commission of the Michigan Department of Natural Resources. 
(46)  Zoning inspector: The person appointed zoning inspector pursuant to the zoning ordinance. 
(47)  Zoning ordinance: The City of Milan Zoning Ordinance. 
ARTICLE III. - INITIAL PLAT REVIEW 
    The proprietor may discuss a proposed subdivision with the city planning commission prior to filing a preliminary plat for tentative approval. No fees shall be charged by the City of Milan for the initial procedures phase of the plat review process. 
ARTICLE IV. - PRELIMINARY PLAT PROCEDURES AND SPECIFICATIONS-TENTATIVE APPROVAL 

4.01. - Filing procedures. 
    The proprietor shall file fifteen (15) copies of the preliminary plat, a completed application form and plat review fees, with the building/zoning official. These documents shall be submitted at least thirty (30) days prior to the regularly scheduled planning commission meeting at which the plat is to be received. The proprietor shall also file twelve (12) copies of the plat reduced to eight and one-half (81/2) inch by eleven (11) inch page size. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 3, 2-24-03; Ord. No. 2004-04, § 1, 7-12-04) 
4.02. - Information required. 
    The following information is required for all preliminary plats which are submitted for tentative approval: 
(a)  Name of proposed subdivision. 
(b)  Legal description of the entire site to be subdivided. 
(c)  The location of the subdivision shall be clearly shown on the preliminary plat by a locator map. 
(d)  Scale, date, and north point shall be indicated on each map or plan. 
(e)  Name and address of proprietor; other owners; and engineer, planner, surveyor, or designer responsible for the subdivision layout. 
(f)  A map showing all contiguous land holdings of the proprietor and other owners if applicable, of the lands which include the land in the subject subdivision. 
(g)  An affidavit, signed by the proprietor, certifying the identity of all legal owners or record of the property in the subject subdivision. 
(h)  Names of adjacent subdivisions; layout and names of adjacent streets, right-of-way widths, connections with adjoining platted streets, location and width of alleys; easements and public walkways adjacent to or connecting with the proposed subdivision; names and addresses of owner or record of all adjacent property. 
(i)  Existing topography, at two (2) foot contour intervals. All topographic data shall relate to USGS data. 
(j)  Proposed deed restrictions or protective covenants; if none a statement of such in writing. 
(k)  Layout and width of rights-of-way and surfaces of all streets or public ways proposed for the subdivision. 
(l)  Lot layout, dimensions, setback requirements, area of each lot (in square feet or acres), and lot numbers. 
(m)  All parcels or lands to be dedicated or reserved for public use, or for use in common by property owners in the subdivision, shall be indicated on the preliminary plat, along with any conditions of such dedication or reservation. 
(n)  Location, size and invert elevation of all existing sanitary and storm sewers, location and size of all existing water mains, valves, and hydrants; location of existing electrical, telephone, and gas lines, and appurtenances. 
(o)  Identification, location, and nature of all uses other than single-family residences to be included within the subdivision. 
(p)  Staging of development of the entire subdivision shall be clearly shown; relation of each stage to the entire subdivision plan shall be clearly indicated. 
(q)  Location and purpose of all existing and proposed easements. 
(r)  Zoning status of property included in the preliminary plat and of all adjacent properties, civil jurisdiction of all properties. 
(s)  Existing natural features such as trees, wooded areas, streams, marshes, ponds and other wetlands; clear indication of all natural features to remain and to be removed. Groups of trees shall be shown by an approximate outline of the total canopy. Individual deciduous trees of six (6) inch diameter or larger and individual evergreen trees six (6) feet in height or higher when not a part of a group of trees, shall be accurately located on the preliminary plat. 
4.03. - Public hearing. 
    The planning commission shall hold a public hearing on each preliminary plat which is submitted for tentative approval. The public hearing shall be held within sixty (60) days of the filing date. Notice of the public hearing shall be provided as required in Section 1.15, herein. 
4.04. - Review procedures. 
(a)  The planning commission shall tentatively approve or disapprove the preliminary plat within sixty (60) days of the filing date. The reasons for disapproval shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting at which the action is taken. The planning commission secretary shall promptly inform the proprietor in writing of the action taken and shall include reasons, if the plat is disapproved. 
(b)  The planning commission shall immediately transmit the preliminary plat and its recommendations thereon to the city council its reasons in writing for disapproving the preliminary plat. 
(c)  The city council shall tentatively approve or shall disapprove the preliminary plat within thirty (30) days of receiving the preliminary plat from the planning commission. The city council shall notify the proprietor in writing of its reasons for disapproving the plat and shall cause these reasons to be recorded in the official records of the meeting. 
4.05. - Effect of tentative approval. 
    Tentative approval indicates planning commission and city council acceptance of lot size and orientation and street layout of the proposed subdivision. Approval shall be in effect for a period of one year from the date of city council approval. Tentative approval may be extended by the city council if applied for in writing by the proprietor. 
4.06. - Expiration of tentative approval. 
    A preliminary plat which has been tentatively approved by the city council shall be submitted to the planning commission for final approval within one year of the date of the city council's tentative approval. If this time period is exceeded, the city council may declare tentative approval to have expired, unless good cause can be shown for the delay. Before declaring approval expired, the council shall first obtain and consider a report and recommendation thereon from the planning commission. 
ARTICLE V. - PRELIMINARY PLAT PROCEDURES AND SPECIFICATIONS-FINAL APPROVAL 

5.01. - Filing procedures. 
    The proprietor shall file fifteen (15) copies of the preliminary plat, required information, a completed application form and fees, with the building/zoning official. These documents shall be submitted at least thirty (30) days prior to the regularly scheduled planning commission meeting at which the plat is to be received. The clerk shall not accept the plat if the tentative approval thereof has expired. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 4, 2-24-03; Ord. No. 2004-04, § 2, 7-12-04) 
5.02. - Information required. 
    The proprietor shall submit the following information: 
(a)  A list of all county and state authorities required by the Subdivision Control Act to approve the preliminary plat, certifying that the list is complete and that each authority has approved the preliminary plat. 
(b)  One approved copy of the preliminary plat from each county and state authority required by the Subdivision Control Act to approve the preliminary plat. 
(c)  One copy of a receipt from the city clerk, showing that all fees have been paid. 
(d)  A construction schedule, as required in Section 8.01 (h), herein. 
(e)  One copy of a permit for soil erosion and sedimentation control, as required by the city's soil erosion ordinance. 
5.03. - Public hearing. 
    The planning commission shall hold a public hearing on each preliminary plat which is submitted for final approval. The public hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days of the filing date. Notice of the public hearing shall be provided as required in Section 1.15, herein. 
5.04. - Review procedures. 
(a)  The planning commission shall give its final approval to the preliminary plat or shall disapprove the preliminary plat within twenty (20) days of the filing date. In the case of disapproval, the reasons shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting at which action is taken. The planning commission secretary shall promptly notify the proprietor in writing of the action taken and shall include the reasons, if the plat is disapproved. In the case of final approval, a certificate of final approval shall be signed by, and secured to the preliminary plat, by the planning commission secretary. 
(b)  After taking action on the preliminary plat, the planning commission shall immediately transmit the plat and the commission's action and recommendations thereon to the city council. In the case of disapproval, the planning commission shall transmit its reasons for disapproving the plat to the city council. 
(c)  The city council shall give its final approval to, or shall disapprove, the preliminary plat within twenty (20) days of the date on which it receives the plat from the planning commission. The city council shall notify the proprietor in writing of the action taken, including reasons, if the plat is disapproved. The reasons shall be recorded in the official records of the meeting at which action is taken. 
(d)  In case of disapproval of a preliminary plat, further consideration of a plat for subdividing the same land can be obtained only if the proprietor applies for tentative approval of a preliminary plat. 
(e)  The proprietor and the planning commission or city council, whichever is applicable, may agree in writing to extend either twenty-day review period. 
5.05. - Effect of final approval of preliminary plat. 
(a)  Final approval of the preliminary plat shall confer upon the proprietor for a period of two (2) years from the date of approval by the city council the conditional right that the general terms and conditions under which the final approval of the preliminary plat was granted will not be changed. The two-year period may be extended if an extension is applied for by the proprietor and granted by the planning commission and city council in writing. 
(b)  Construction of improvements may commence upon final approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission and city council, provided all engineering plans for such improvements have been approved by the city engineer, the city soil erosion control agent, and other applicable authority, and other requirements of this ordinance have been met. 
(c)  Final approval of a preliminary plat shall permit construction and display of not more that four (4) model homes, provided that the lots on which the model homes are to be located are individual lots as shown on the approved preliminary plat; that such lots are located within five hundred (500) feet of and have access to, an existing public street; that roadway from existing public street to said lots is a minimum base coat of asphalt; that the department of public works has approved the public water and sewer system and provided that such model homes shall not interfere with permanent improvements.
