The model homes shall not be occupied as residences until the final plat containing said lots is approved and recorded in accordance with this section and the Subdivision Control Act. Said lots shall be identified on the preliminary plat before the preliminary plat is submitted. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 5, 2-24-03) 
5.06. - Expiration of final approval. 
    Final approval of a preliminary plat shall be valid for a period of not more than two (2) years from the date of final approval by the city council and shall expire and be of no effect, unless a final plat is submitted to the planning commission for approval within that time period. If a final plat is submitted for only a part of the subdivision shown on the preliminary plat as finally approved, successive final plats shall be filed at intervals no longer than two (2) years from the date of approval by the city council of the immediately preceding final plat. If such period is exceeded, the city council may declare the preliminary plat as finally approved by the council to be invalid with respect to the remaining unplatted parts thereof, unless good cause can be shown for the delay. In such case the city council may require that a new preliminary plat be filed for tentative approval. Before declaring a plat invalid, the city council shall first obtain and consider a report and recommendation thereon from the planning commission. 
ARTICLE VI. - FINAL PLAT PROCEDURES AND SPECIFICATIONS 

6.01. - Filing procedures. 
(a)  The final plat shall be filed with the city clerk and shall consist of: 
(1)  The completed application form; 
(2)  Fees for filing, recording, plat review and inspection of improvements; 
(3)  The agreement and security required by Section 8.06, herein to guarantee performance; and 
(4)  One reproducible copy of the final plat, on dimensionally stable material, and fifteen (15) paper prints thereof. The proprietor shall also file twelve (12) copies of the plat reduced to eight and one-half (81/2) inch by eleven (11) inch page size. 
(b)  The plat shall be submitted at least thirty (30) days prior to the regularly scheduled planning commission meeting at which the plat is to be received. A final plat shall not be accepted for review after the date of expiration of the final approval of the preliminary plat. 
(c)  The final plat shall be signed by a registered land surveyor or a registered civil engineer and by the proprietor(s) prior to filing with the city clerk. 
(d)  The final plat shall be submitted to the following agencies in the indicated order, and the proprietor shall obtain signatures from each agency thereon, in the indicated order, prior to filing the final plat for planning commission approval: County treasurer; city treasurer; county drain commission, if applicable; board of county road commissioners, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, §§ 6, 7, 2-24-03; Ord. No. 2004-04, § 2, 7-12-04) 
6.02. - Information required. 
(a)  Abstract of title, certified to date, or a policy of title insurance, currently in force, covering all land within the boundaries of the proposed subdivision, and approved by the city attorney. 
(b)  A certificate from the proprietor's engineer indicating that improvements have been installed in conformance with approved engineering drawings. 
(c)  A copy of the certificate of completion, as required in Section 8.04, herein, for each improvement constructed prior to approval of the final plat. 
(d)  A list of all improvements to be constructed after the final plat is approved by the city council. 
(e)  An estimate of the total cost of each required improvement which is to be constructed after the final plat is approved, as provided in Section 8.06, herein. The estimate of costs shall be approved by the city engineer prior to review of the final plat by the planning commission. 
6.03. - Public hearing. 
    The planning commission shall hold a public hearing on each final plat which is submitted for approval. The public hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days of the filing date. Notice of the public hearing shall be provided as required in Section 1.15, herein. 
6.04. - Requirements for review. 
(a)  The final plat shall conform to the preliminary plat as finally approved. The final plat may cover only a portion of the area covered by the preliminary plat as finally approved. 
(b)  All improvements shall be installed, and shall be inspected and approved by the city engineer or adequate security may be provided in lieu of installation of improvements, as provided herein, before the planning commission may approve the final plat. 
(c)  All dedications shall be made and all easements shall be granted before the planning commission may approve the final plat. 
(d)  Any use, height, area or bulk requirements or restrictions governing buildings and premises within the subdivision shall be agreed to by the planning commission and applicant before the commission may approve the final plat. 
6.05. - Review procedures-Planning commission. 
(a)  The planning commission shall approve or disapprove the final plat within twenty (20) days of the filing date. In the case of disapproval, the reasons for disapproval shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting at which action is taken. The planning commission secretary shall promptly notify the proprietor in writing of the action taken and shall include the reasons, if the plat is disapproved. If the final plat is approved, the planning commission secretary shall sign the plat, signifying approval of the final plat by the planning commission. 
(b)  After taking action on the final plat the planning commission shall immediately transmit the reproducible copy of the plat, the four (4) signed prints thereof, and the commission's actions and recommendations thereon, to the city council. In the case of disapproval, the planning commission shall transmit its reasons for disapproving the plat in writing to the city council. The planning commission shall provide the city council with copies of any agreement made with the proprietor regarding requirements and restrictions governing building and premises. 
(c)  The proprietor and planning commission may agree, in writing, to extend the twenty-day review period. 
6.06. - Review procedures-City council. 
(a)  The city council shall approve or disapprove the final plat within twenty (20) days of the date on which it receives the final plat from the planning commission. 
(b)  If the final plat is approved, the city clerk shall sign the plat, signifying approval of the final plat by the city council. The city clerk shall promptly notify the proprietor, in writing, of approval. 
(c)  If the final plat is approved the city clerk shall transmit the reproducible copy of the plat, the four (4) signed copies of the plat, and the filing and recording fee to the county plat board. 
(d)  If the final plat is disapproved, the city clerk shall record the reasons in the minutes of the meeting, notify the proprietor in writing of the action and the reasons therefor, and return the plat to the proprietor. 
(e)  The proprietor and the city council may agree, in writing, to extend the twenty-day review period. 
Sec. 6.07. - Vested rights. 
    No vested rights shall accrue to any plat until a certificate of approval has been attached thereto by the city clerk. 
ARTICLE VII. - DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS 

Sec. 7.01. - General. 
    All subdivision plats and improvements shall conform to the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Milan and the Municipal Improvement Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 98-4, § 1, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 7.02. - Preparation and content. 
    The planning commission shall prepare and adopt regulations as provided in section 14, Act 285, Public Acts of 1931, as amended. The regulations shall be prepared with the assistance of, and shall be reviewed by, city staff. The regulations shall include, but not be limited to, street layout, design, and construction; grading; lot layout and access; sidewalks and pedestrian ways; water, sanitary, and storm sewer/drainage improvements; other utilities; soil erosion control; street trees and lights; and flood plains and other unbuildable areas. 
Sec. 7.03. - Public hearing. 
    The planning commission shall hold a public hearing on the proposed regulations prior to adoption. The planning commission shall give notice of the public hearing in a newspaper of general circulation within the City of Milan, not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the public hearing. 
Sec. 7.04. - Adoption by planning commission. 
    The planning commission shall consider comments made at the public hearing and by city staff. The commission may then adopt the regulations. The commission shall transmit the adopted regulations to the city council for approval. 
Sec. 7.05. - City council action. 
    The city council shall approve or disapprove the regulation within sixty (60) days of the date of the meeting at which the regulations are first received by the council. Council action shall be by resolution. 
Sec. 7.06. - Recording and publication. 
    Following approval by the city council, the planning commission shall certify the regulations to the register of deeds of Monroe and Washtenaw Counties for the recording thereof. The planning commission shall publish the regulations in the manner provided by law for ordinances. The regulations shall be effective immediately upon publication and recording. 
Sec. 7.07. - Amendments. 
    The regulations may be amended by following the procedures set forth herein for initial adoption. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SUBDIVISION IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 8.01. - General requirements. 
(a)  Standards. Improvements shall be provided by the proprietor in accordance with this article and standards and requirements which may be established by the city council, planning commission, city departments, and county and state agencies, in the form of ordinances or published regulations, including but not limited to, the Municipal Improvement Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. Whenever required improvements are covered by a performance bond, the proprietor and the surety company shall be severally and jointly liable for completing improvements according to approved specifications and plans. 
(b)  Preparation of plans. The proprietor shall have a complete set of constructions plans meeting the requirements of the Municipal Improvement Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan for streets, utilities, and other improvements referenced in section 8.02. Constructions plans shall conform to the preliminary plat as finally approved. 
(c)  Timing of improvements. No grading, removal of trees or other vegetation, land filling, construction of improvements or other material change except that which is required by a reviewing agency for purposes of aiding its review of the preliminary plat, shall commence on the subject property until the proprietor has: 
(1)  Received a written notice from the city clerk that the city council has given final approval of the preliminary plat. 
(2)  Entered into a subdivision agreement with the city council for completion and inspection of all improvements required in the preliminary plat as finally approved. 
(3)  Deposited with the city clerk a bond or other form of security as required by this ordinance for the provision of improvements. 
(4)  Received a certificate of approval from the city of the engineering plans of each improvement to be installed prior to approval of the final plat. Where approval of such plans must be obtained from a county or state agency, the proprietor shall provide evidence of such approvals to the city prior to the engineer's report and recommendation to the planning commission. Plans shall include soil erosion and sedimentation controls. 
(5)  Deposited inspection fees with the city clerk. 
(d)  Staging. If the subdivision is to be developed in stages, this article and the applicable provisions of the Municipal Improvement Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan shall apply to each stage. However, improvements and financial guarantees therefor may be required to extend beyond the boundaries of a subdivision stage if extension is necessary to insure relative self-sufficiency of a stage pending completion of the entire subdivision. Such improvements and financial guarantees shall be set forth in an agreement between the proprietor and the city council prior to the council's final approval of the preliminary plat. 
(e)  Costs of improvement. All required improvements under this article and the Municipal Improvement Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan shall be made by the proprietor, at the proprietor's expense, without reimbursement by the City of Milan. 
(f)  Completion of improvements. All required improvements under this article and the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan shall either be completed prior to filing the final plat for approval by the planning commission, or following final plat approval, if adequate financial guarantees of performance are provided. All improvements installed prior to city council's approval of the final plat, and which are to be dedicated to the City of Milan, shall be dedicated prior to filing plat for planning commission approval. Improvements and property to be dedicated shall be free and clear of all liens and encumbrances. 
(g)  Temporary improvements. The proprietor shall build and pay the costs of all temporary improvements required by the city. Prior to construction of any temporary facility or improvements, the proprietor shall file a bond with the city clerk to ensure that the temporary facilities will properly be constructed, maintained, and removed. 
(h)  Construction schedule. The proprietor shall submit a construction schedule for the construction of all required improvements in conformance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. The schedule shall be submitted with the filing of the preliminary plat for final approval. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 98-4, § 2, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 8.02. - Required improvements. 
(a)  Monuments and lot corners. Monuments and lot corners shall be set in accordance with the Subdivision Control Act, the rules of the state department of treasury, and the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(b)  Streets. All streets, curbs, and gutters shall be constructed in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(c)  Public utilities: 
(1)  Storm drainage. An adequate draining system, including necessary storm sewers, drain inlets, manholes, culverts, bridges, and other appurtenances, shall be required in all subdivisions. Storm drainage shall be constructed in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(2)  Water supply system. Water lines and appurtenances shall be provided. All easements and improvements for such systems shall be dedicated to the city for administration, operation and maintenance. Water supply systems shall be constructed in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(3)  Sanitary sewer system. Sanitary sewers and their appurtenances shall be provided. Sanitary sewer systems shall be constructed in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(4)  Gas, wire, and cable utilities. The proprietor shall arrange for all lines for telephone, electricity, television, and other services distributed by wire or cable to be installed underground, and may arrange for gas distribution facilities throughout a subdivided area. Overhead lines and facilities may be permitted where approved by the city. Construction of utilities shall be in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(5)  Oversize facilities. If oversize facilities are required the proprietor shall be responsible for his/her share of the costs of same as based on land area, population, or a similar proportionate measure. The amount of proprietor responsibility and the means for allocating costs shall be agreed to by the proprietor and the city council prior to final approval of the preliminary plat by the city council. 
(d)  Street name signs. Street name signs shall be in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan and the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Milan. 
(e)  Sidewalks and pedestrian ways. Sidewalks and pedestrian ways shall be provided. Sidewalks and pedestrian ways shall be in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(f)  Public use areas. Public use areas shall be provided. Public use areas shall be in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(g)  Street trees. Street trees shall be provided in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(h)  Street lighting. Street lighting shall be in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(i)  Driveway openings. Driveway openings, where provided, shall be installed from the edge of the street surface to the property line. 
(j)  Erosion and sedimentation control. Installation and maintenance of erosion and sedimentation control measures shall be provided in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan, chapter 171/2 of the Milan City Code and applicable state law. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 98-4, § 2, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 8.03. - Inspection of improvements. 
(a)  Required. All required improvements, except those made under the jurisdiction of the county or state agencies, shall be inspected during construction by the city. Where inspections are made by county and state agencies, the proprietor shall supply the city with written reports of each final inspection. 
(b)  Inspection schedule. The proprietor shall notify the city in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan when construction is ready for inspection. 
(c)  Inspection of improvements under construction. Before commencing construction of required improvements, the proprietor shall make an agreement with the city council to provide for inspection of the construction of each improvement. 
(d)  Fees. The proprietor shall pay all inspection costs incurred by the City of Milan according to fee schedules adopted by resolution by the city council. The proprietor shall make a deposit to cover such costs prior to commencement of construction. Any funds not used by the city in its inspection shall be refunded to the proprietor when the subdivision or stage thereof, is completed. The proprietor shall pay to the city an amount by which the inspection costs exceed the deposited fees. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 98-4, § 2, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 8.04. - Certificate of completion. 
    The city shall issue a certificate of completion to the city council when a required improvement under the jurisdiction of the City of Milan is satisfactorily completed. The certificate shall not be issued until the city has made a final inspection, has approved the installation and has approved the as-built drawings as required by the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. If the improvement is installed prior to the filing date for final plat approval, the city council shall not approve the final plat until a certificate of completion is provided. If the improvement is to be installed subsequent to final plat approval, no bond or other deposit shall be released or reduced until a certificate of completion is provided. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 98-4, § 2, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 8.05. - Site cleanup. 
    The proprietor shall be responsible for removal of all equipment, material, and general construction debris from the subdivision and from any lot, street, or public way or property therein or adjacent. 
Sec. 8.06. - Guarantee of improvements. 
(A)  General. In lieu of installation of improvements required in Section 8.02, herein, the city council may require, prior to council approval of the final plat, a financial guarantee of performance in one or a combination of the following arrangements. Guarantees shall be required for only those required improvements which do not have certificates of completion prior to the filing date for final plat approval. The guarantees shall be sufficient to secure to the City of Milan the satisfactory construction and dedication, where applicable, of the improvements. 
(1)  Performance bond. 
(a)  Form. The bond shall comply with all statutory requirements and shall be satisfactory to the city attorney as to form, sufficiency, and manner of execution. 
(b)  Accrual. The bond shall accrue to the city council. 
(c)  Amount. The amount shall be at least equal to the total estimated cost for completing construction of the improvement, including contingencies, as estimated by the proprietor's engineer and approved by the city council. 
(d)  Term length. The term shall be for a period specified by the city council, but shall not exceed two (2) years from the date on which the city council approves the final plat. City council may, upon proof of difficulty by the proprietor, extend the completion date set forth in the bond for a maximum period of one additional year. 
(e)  Surety company. The bond shall be with a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Michigan. 
(2)  Cash deposit, certified check, or irrevocable bank letter of credit. 
(a)  Treasurer, escrow agent or trust company. A deposit shall be made with the city in the form of cash, a certified check or irrevocable letter of credit, whichever the proprietor selects. The deposit shall accrue to the City of Milan for constructing the improvement. 
(b)  Amount. The amount of the deposit shall be equal to the total estimated cost of construction of the improvement, including contingencies as estimated by the proprietor's engineer and approved by the city council. 
(c)  Escrow period. The escrow period for the deposit shall be specified by the city council. 
(d)  Progressive payment. The city council and the proprietor may agree to provide progressive payment out of a cash deposit or reduction of a certified check, or irrevocable bank letter of credit to the extent of the estimated cost of the completed portion of the improvement. 
(B)  Maintenance bond. The city council shall require the proprietor to file a maintenance bond with the city, in addition to the foregoing security, to assure satisfactory condition of all required improvements under the jurisdiction of the City of Milan. The maintenance bond shall be in an amount determined by the city engineer to be adequate and in a form satisfactory to the city attorney. The term of the bond shall not exceed one year from the date of the certificate of completion. 
(C)  Protection and repair bond. The city council may also require, in addition to the foregoing security, a bond to cover damage that might occur during construction to existing improvements facilities, and features on or around the construction site or to adjacent properties. The bond shall include the costs of any cleaning of construction debris from the subdivision and from adjacent properties. The bond shall be in an amount determined by the city engineer to be adequate and in a form satisfactory to the city attorney. The term of the bond shall not exceed two (2) years from the date of approval of the final plat by the city council. 
(D)  Penalty. If the proprietor shall fail to complete an improvement within the period of time required by the conditions of the financial guarantee, the city council shall have the authority to have such work completed. The city council may appropriate the cash deposit, certified check, or irrevocable bank letter of credit, or may require performance by the surety company, to cover the costs of completing the improvement. 
Sec. 8.07. - Engineering drawings required. 
(a)  Required prior to construction. Engineering drawings of all required improvements shall be governed by the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. Where engineering drawings are approved by a county or state agency, the proprietor shall transmit written confirmation of such approvals to the city. 
(b)  Modification during construction. All construction shall conform to the approved engineering drawings as required by the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. Any changes made in design and specifications during construction shall be made at the proprietor's risk, without any assurance that the City of Milan will approve the changes. The proprietor shall be responsible, where required by the city, to correct installed improvements so as to conform to the approved engineering drawings. 
(c)  As-built drawings. As-built drawings shall be provided in accordance with the Municipal Improvements Standards and Specifications of the City of Milan. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 98-4, § 2, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 8.08. - Dedications. 
(a)  Acceptance. Acceptance of dedication of improvements and lands to the City of Milan shall be by resolution of the city council. Approval of a subdivision plat by the planning commission or city council shall not constitute or imply acceptance by the city council, or dedication of improvements and lands shown on the plat. 
(b)  Requirements. The following conditions shall be met before a dedication shall be accepted by the city council: 
(1)  A certificate of completion, where required, shall have been issued by the city engineer. 
(2)  A title insurance policy shall have been furnished to the city and approved by the city attorney as to content and amount. 
(3)  A maintenance bond, when required by the city council, shall have been supplied by the proprietor. 
Sec. 8.09. - Building permits and certificates of occupancy. 
(a)  Where a financial guarantee of performance has been required for a subdivision, the city council may direct the building inspector to refuse to issue a certificate of occupancy for any building within the subdivision prior to the completion of the improvements, if in the city council's opinion, such occupancy might endanger the health, safety, and general welfare of the occupants or residents in the vicinity. 
(b)  The extent of street improvements shall be adequate for vehicular access by prospective occupants and by fire and police equipment, as determined by the city council, prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(c)  No building permit shall be issued for the final ten (10) percent of lots in a subdivision until all required public improvements have been completed, and where applicable, dedicated. 
ARTICLE IX. - VARIANCES 

Sec. 9.01. - General. 
    A variance from the provisions of this ordinance may be obtained for relief from hardship and to permit a comprehensive development according to a plan for the entire project. Variances shall apply only to improvements, standards, and specifications set forth in this ordinance; variances shall not be granted on procedures required herein. 
Sec. 9.02. - Authority for granting variances. 
    The city council shall have authority for granting variances to this ordinance. 
Sec. 9.03. - Applications required. 
(a)  Hardship variance. An application shall be submitted in writing by the proprietor to the city clerk at the time the preliminary plat is filed for tentative approval. The application shall fully state the reasons and facts concerning the variance requests. 
(b)  Comprehensive development variance. Application shall be made in writing by the proprietor at the time the preliminary plat is filed for tentative approval. The application shall state all reasons and facts concerning the request. The planning commission shall submit a report on the variance request to the city council as required in section 9.05, herein. 
Sec. 9.04. - Hardship variance. 
(a)  General. A hardship variance may be granted so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest served. The proprietor shall show that strict compliance with the provisions of this ordinance, as they apply to the proprietor's property, will result in extraordinary hardship or practical difficulty, as distinguished from mere inconvenience. 
(b)  Findings required. A variance shall not be granted unless the following findings are made: 
(1)  That there are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property such that strict application of the provisions of the ordinance would clearly be impractical or unreasonable. These conditions or circumstances shall be determined to be unique to the property, and not generally applicable to other property. 
(2)  That the conditions requiring a variance were not created by the proprietor. 
(3)  That the granting of a variance will not be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare, or injurious to other property in the area in which the property is situated. 
(4)  That a variance will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of this ordinance, the adopted general development plan and the zoning ordinance, and will not in any manner vary the provisions of the zoning ordinance. 
(5)  That a variance will not violate the provisions of the Subdivision Control Act. 
(c)  Conditions. In granting a variance the city council may attach conditions which will substantially secure the objectives of this ordinance, and which will further the adopted policies as expressed in the general development plan. 
Sec. 9.05. - Comprehensive development variance. 
(a)  General. The city council may grant variances from this ordinance for a comprehensive development upon written request of the proprietor. The city council shall consider the recommendation of the planning commission before acting on the request for a variance. 
(b)  Findings required. The city council shall make the following findings on the basis of the planning commission's report on the same requirements: 
(1)  That the development plan together with the requested variances, provides for efficient circulation, adequate light and air, meets the intent of this ordinance, of the zoning ordinance, and of the adopted general development plan. 
(2)  That the criteria set forth in the preceding section 9.04 (b)(3) through (5) will be met. 
(3)  That the proposed project will constitute a desirable and stable community development. 
(4)  That the proposed project will be in harmony with the existing or proposed development of adjacent areas. 
(5)  That the planning commission has reviewed the project plan and recommends its approval as having met the standards and intent of the general development plan. 
(c)  The variance shall be valid only so long as the plan for the comprehensive development is carried out as approved. Any departure from the approved plan shall permit revocation by the city council of any variance granted. 
(d)  Schedule. The proprietor shall submit a time schedule for completing the various stages of a comprehensive development with the preliminary plat thereof. 
ARTICLE X. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 10.01. - Responsibility. 
    It shall be the duty of the city building inspector or the department of public works director, as applicable, to enforce this ordinance and to bring to the attention of the city attorney and city council any violations to this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 98-4, § 3, 8-10-98) 
Sec. 10.02. - Building and occupancy permits. 
(a)  Building permits. The building inspector shall not issue permits for the building of houses or other structures intended for human occupancy or any portion thereof until the preliminary plat has received final approval as provided in the Subdivision Control Act and until the building inspector has been officially notified of such approval by the city council. No building permits shall be issued for a tract of land between the time that the subdividing process has commenced and a preliminary plat thereof has received final approval. The city clerk shall immediately notify the building inspector that such process has been initiated. No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building or structure, which is to be located on a lot or plat subdivided or sold in violation of the provisions of this ordinance. 
(b)  Certificates of occupancy. The building inspector shall not issue certificates for the occupancy of structures or any parts thereof until all improvements required by this ordinance and agreed to in the preliminary plat as finally approved have been completed or otherwise provided for according to this ordinance, and until the building inspector has been notified by the city clerk of completion of improvements. A certificate of completion issued by the city engineer shall be evidence of completion of improvements. 
Sec. 10.03. - Penalties. 
    Penalties for failure to comply with the provisions of this ordinance shall be provided in the Subdivision Control Act. 
ARTICLE XI. - AMENDMENTS 

Sec. 11.01. - Procedure. 
    The city council may, from time to time, amend this ordinance in the manner prescribed by law. A proposed amendment may be originated by the city council, planning commission, or by petition. The planning commission shall hold a public hearing on each amendment to this ordinance. The planning commission shall transmit a report and recommendation on each amendment to the city council, following the public hearing. 
Sec. 11.02. - Recording. 
    Each amendment, after city council approval, shall be certified by the city clerk to the register of deeds of Washtenaw and Monroe Counties for the recording thereof, 
ARTICLE XII. - REPEAL OF CONFLICTING ORDINANCES 

Sec. 12.01. -   
    The provisions of Chapter 2, sections 2-33 and 2-34 of the Milan City Code are hereby repealed. 
APPENDIX C - FRANCHISES AND REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - CLEAR CABLEVISION, INC. 

Section 1. - Repeal of Community Antenna Television Ordinance; repeal not to affect acts done, offenses, rights, liabilities, penalties, punishments, etc., payment of franchise fee. 
    The Milan City Code is amended by repealing the Community Antenna Television Ordinance, originally adopted by the City of Milan on September 10, 1979, and codified as Article I of Appendix A to the Milan City Code, and all amendments thereto insofar as they conflict with this ordinance; provided, however, that such repeal does not affect or impair any act done, offense committed or right accruing, accrued or acquired or liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred prior to the time enforced, prosecuted or inflicted; and further provided that, on or before January 30, 1995, Clear Cablevision, Inc. shall pay to the City of Milan all franchise fee payments due under the franchise granted by Milan City Ordinance No. 79-8. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-7, § 1, 10-17-94) 
Section 2. - Adoption by reference. 
    Pursuant to chapter 14 of the Milan City Charter, the Milan City Code is further amended by setting forth provisions which are included as new Article I of Appendix C to read as set forth in the 1994 Cable Television Franchise Agreement with Clear Cablevision, Inc. ("Agreement"), which agreement is attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference as if fully set forth at length herein. Such agreement is hereby adopted as the nonexclusive cable television franchise, and the mayor and clerk/treasurer are hereby authorized and directed to execute the agreement on behalf of the City of Milan. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-7, § 2, 10-17-94) 
Section 3. - Publication of notice. 
    As soon as practicable, and in no case later than fifteen (15) days after the adoption of this ordinance, the following notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the City of Milan: 
    Ordinance No. 94-7 has been adopted by the City Council of the City of Milan. The ordinance renews the cable television franchise of Clear Cablevision, Inc. ("Clear"). Key provisions of the renewed franchise are: 
(1)  Clear is allowed to conduct a cable TV business service only. Any additional services will require a new agreement/amendment appropriate for them. 
(2)  Clear is required to serve areas with twenty (20) dwelling units per mile or fraction thereof. 
(3)  The agreement is for fifteen (15) years. 
(4)  There are extensive provisions dealing with customer service such as: 
a.  Clear must comply with all consumer protection standards established by the FCC pursuant to the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, including FCC Rule 76.309; 
b.  Standards for Clear's local or toll-free customer service number, including that it must be available twenty-four (24) hours per day; 
c.  Standards for service calls: The customer has the option of a four-hour appointment window, first call of day, last call of day, or call to meet basis; 
d.  Specific time limits are provided for billing, refunds, shutoffs for failure to pay and the like. 
(5)  Clear pays a rental fee for use of public highways, four per cent the first year and five per cent thereafter, as allowed by Federal law. 
(6)  Clear pays the city seventeen thousand dollars ($17,000.00) for the city's use in connection with the education and government channels. 
(7)  Extensive insurance and indemnity provisions to protect the community and its residents. 
(8)  Provisions to keep the franchise up to date if there are major changes in federal cable law, such as occurred last year. 
(9)  Provisions to allow the city to regulate Clear to the extent allowed by federal law. The ordinance also repeals all ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with Ordinance No. 94-7. Printed copies of the full text of Ordinance No. 94-7 are available for inspection and purchase by the public at the office of the city clerk during regular business hours, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. Ordinance No. 94-7 is effective four (4) weeks after publication of this summary notice. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-7, § 3, 10-17-94) 
Section 4. - Effective date. 
    Pursuant to section 14.2 of the Milan City Charter, the effective date of this ordinance shall be four (4) weeks after publication of the notice specified in section 2 of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-7, § 4, 10-17-94) 
Section 5. - Severability. 
    Sections of this ordinance shall be deemed to be severable and should any section, paragraph or provision hereof be declared by a court to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions or applications of this ordinance which can be given effect without the invalid portion or application, provided such remaining portions are not determined by the court to be inoperable. 
(Ord. No. C.O. 94-7, § 5, 10-17-94) 
ARTICLE II. - MICHIGAN CONSOLIDATED GAS COMPANY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Appendix C, Art. II, §§ 1-20, contains the franchise granted to Michigan Consolidated Gas Company being Ord. No. 93-4, adopted on July 26, 1993. Absence of a history note indicates the section derived unchanged from Ord. No. 93-4. Subsequent amendments will be indicated in a history note following the amended section. 

Section 1. - Grantee defined. 
    Wherever the word "grantee" appears in this article, it is intended to designate and shall be held to refer to the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, a corporation organized and doing business under the laws of the State of Michigan, its successors and assigns. 
Section 2. - Grant of gas franchise and consent of laying of pipes, etc. 
    Subject to all the terms and conditions contained in this article and in Chapter 14 of the Milan City Charter, consent is hereby given to grantee to lay, maintain, operate, and use gas pipes, mains, conductors, service pipes, and other necessary equipment in the highways, streets, alley, and other public places in the City of Milan, Washtenaw and Monroe Counties, Michigan; and a nonexclusive franchise is hereby granted to the grantee to transact local business in the city for the purposes of conveying gas into and through and supplying and selling gas in the city and all other matter incidental to such gas business. 
Section 3. - Grantee responsibility. 
    In consideration of the rights, power and authority hereby granted, grantee shall faithfully perform all things required by the terms of this article. 
Section 4. - Gas service and extension of system. 
    If the provisions and conditions herein contained are accepted by the grantee, as provided in Section 9 of this article, then the grantee shall construct and extend its gas distribution system within the city and furnish gas to applicants residing within the city all in accordance with applicable laws, rules and/or regulations and further, such initial installation and any extensions shall be subject to the main extension provisions, the area expansion program provisions (if and where applicable), and other applicable provisions, now or from time to time hereafter contained in the grantee's rules and regulations for gas service, provided that such provisions and rules and regulations have been approved by the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction and are not more onerous to citizens of the city than to the citizens of other communities serviced by the grantee within Washtenaw and Monroe Counties, Michigan. 
Section 5. - Use of streets and other public places; liability, defense and indemnity. 
    No highway, street, alley, bridge or other public place within the city used by the grantee shall be unnecessarily obstructed or obstructed for any longer period than necessary, and shall, promptly upon completion of grantee's use, including without limitation use for purposes of excavation, construction, installation or maintenance, be restored to the same order and condition as before such use was commenced. 
    No road, street, alley, or highway shall be opened for the laying of trunk lines or lateral mains except upon application to the highway commissioner of the city or other authority having jurisdiction in the premises stating the nature of the proposed work and the route. Upon receipt of such application with respect to any road, street, alley, or highway over which the city has jurisdiction to issue a permit to the grantee to do the work proposed, provided that grantee has complied with any and all other rules, regulations and requirements applicable to the work proposed. 
    The grantee, its successors and assigns shall use due care in exercising the privileges herein granted, and no part of the highways, street, alleys, bridges or other public places within the city shall be permitted to remain in a dangerous or unsafe condition by reason of anything done or omitted to be done by grantee. Grantee shall be liable for such injury and damage as may be suffered by any person or entity arising from the acts, omissions, default, carelessness or negligence of the grantee or its officers, agents, and servants, and grantee shall defend, indemnify and hold the city harmless from and against any and all liability, damages, costs and reasonable attorney fees arising from the acts, omissions, default, carelessness or negligence of the grantee or its officers, agents and servants. 
Section 6. - Standards and conditions of service; rules; regulations and rates. 
    The grantee is now under the jurisdiction of the Michigan Public Service Commission to the extent provided by statute. The rates to be charged for gas and the standards and conditions of service and operation hereunder shall be the same as set forth in the grantee's schedule of rules, regulations and rates as are now and may hereafter by validly prescribed for the city under the orders, rules, and regulations of the Michigan Public Service Commission or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction. All other conditions and elements of service not herein fixed but applicable to gas service within the city shall be and remain subject to the reasonable rules and regulations of the Michigan Public Service Commission or its successor agency having similar jurisdiction. 
Section 7. - Franchise not exclusive. 
    The rights and authority herein granted to grantee are not exclusive. 
Section 8. - Term of franchise; revocation. 
    The term of the franchise granted herein shall be for period of thirty (3) years from the effective date hereof, but such franchise shall be subject to earlier revocation at the will of the city council at any time during such thirty (30)-year period, upon the giving of written notice of such revocation to the grantee. 
Section 9. - Effective date; acceptance by grantee. 
    The effective date of this article shall be the day following the date of its publication, which publication shall be made within fifteen (15) days after the date of its adoption, but such effective date shall be not earlier than ten (10) days after the date of adoption of this article; provided however, that this ordinance and the franchise hereby granted shall cease and be of no effect as of the sixtieth (60) day after its effective date unless within such sixty (60)-day period the grantee shall have filed with the city clerk its written, unconditional acceptance off the conditions and provisions hereof. Within five (5) days after the effective date of this article, the city clerk shall deliver to the grantee a certified copy of this article accompanied by written evidence of publication and recording thereof in the Book of Ordinances. 
ARTICLE III. - ACCESS TO AND USE OF PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY BY TELECOMMUNICATIONS PROVIDERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2002-05, §§ 2-22, adopted October 21, 2002, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from C.O. No. 98-11, §§ 1-16, App. A, App. A-1, adopted November 9, 1998.   A copy of the Act can be obtained on the Internet at http://www.cis.state.mi.us/mpsc/comm/rightofway/rightofway.htm. 

Section 1. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of this ordinance are to regulate access to and ongoing use of public rights-of-way by telecommunications providers for their telecommunications facilities while protecting the public health, safety, and welfare and exercising reasonable control of the public rights-of-way in compliance with the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act (Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002) ("Act") and other applicable law, and to ensure that the City qualifies for distributions under the Act by modifying the fees charged to providers and complying with the Act. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 2, 10-21-02) 
Section 2. - Conflict. 
    Nothing in this ordinance shall be construed in such a manner as to conflict with the Act or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 3, 10-21-02) 
Section 3. - Terms defined. 
    The terms used in this ordinance shall have the following meanings: 
    Act means the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act (Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002), as amended from time to time. 
    Authority means the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Authority created pursuant to Section 3 of the Act. 
    City means the City of Milan. 
    City Administrator means the City Administrator or his or her designee. 
    City Council means the City Council of the City of Milan or its designee. This Section does not authorize delegation of any decision or function that is required by law to be made by the City Council. 
    MPSC means the Michigan Public Service Commission in the Department of Consumer and Industry Services, and shall have the same meaning as the term "Commission" in the Act. 
    Permit means a non-exclusive permit issued pursuant to the Act and this ordinance to a telecommunications provider to use the public rights-of-way in the City for its telecommunications facilities. 
All other terms used in this ordinance shall have the same meaning as defined or as provided in the Act, including without limitation the following: 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity, or any other legal entity. 
    Public Right-of-Way means the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, alley, easement or waterway. Public right-of-way does not include a federal, state, or private right-of-way. 
    Telecommunication Facilities or Facilities means the equipment or personal property, such as copper and fiber cables, lines, wires, switches, conduits, pipes, and sheaths, which are used to or can generate, receive, transmit, carry, amplify, or provide telecommunication services or signals. Telecommunication facilities or facilities do not include antennas, supporting structures for antennas, equipment shelters or houses, and any ancillary equipment and miscellaneous hardware used to provide federally licensed commercial mobile service as defined in section 332(d) of part I of title III of the communications act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, and service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. 
    Telecommunications Provider, Provider and Telecommunications Services mean those terms as defined in Section 102 of the Michigan telecommunications act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2102. Telecommunication provider does not include a person or an affiliate of that person when providing a federally licensed commercial mobile radio service as defined in Section 332(d) of part I of the communications act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, or service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. For the purpose of the Act and this ordinance only, a provider also includes all of the following: 
(a)  A cable television operator that provides a telecommunications service. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided by the Act, a person who owns telecommunication facilities located within a public right-of-way. 
(c)  A person providing broadband internet transport access service. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 4, 10-21-02) 
Section 4. - Permit required. 
(a)  Permit Required. Except as otherwise provided in the Act, a telecommunications provider using or seeking to use public rights-of-way in the City for its telecommunications facilities shall apply for and obtain a permit pursuant to this ordinance. 
(b)  Application. Telecommunications providers shall apply for a permit on an application form approved by the MPSC in accordance with Section 6(1) of the Act. A telecommunications provider shall file one (1) copy of the application with the City Clerk, one (1) copy with the City Administrator and one (1) copy with the City Attorney. Upon receipt, the City Clerk shall make the necessary copies of the application and distribute a copy to the DPW Director and City Engineer where appropriate. Applications shall be complete and include all information required by the Act, including without limitation a route map showing the location of the provider's existing and proposed facilities in accordance with Section 6(5) of the Act. 
(c)  Confidential Information. If a telecommunications provider claims that any portion of the route maps submitted by it as part of its application contain trade secret, proprietary, or confidential information, which is exempt from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246, pursuant to Section 6(5) of the Act, the telecommunications provider shall prominently so indicate on the face of each map. 
(d)  Application Fee. Except as otherwise provided by the Act, the application shall be accompanied by a one-time non-refundable application fee in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(e)  Additional Information. The City Administrator may request an applicant to submit such additional information, which the City Administrator deems reasonably necessary or relevant. The applicant shall comply with all such requests in compliance with reasonable deadlines for such additional information established by the City Administrator. If the City and the applicant cannot agree on the requirement of additional information requested by the City, the City or the applicant shall notify the MPSC as provided in Section 6(2) of the Act. 
(f)  Previously Issued Permits. Pursuant to Section 5(1) of the Act, authorizations or permits previously issued by the City under Section 251 of the Michigan telecommunications act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251 and authorizations or permits issued by the City to telecommunications providers prior to the 1995 enactment of Section 251 of the Michigan telecommunications act but after 1985 shall satisfy the permit requirements of this ordinance. 
(g)  Existing Providers. Pursuant to Section 5(3) of the Act, within 180 days from November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, a telecommunications provider with facilities located in a public right-of-way in the City as of such date, that has not previously obtained authorization or a permit under Section 251 of the Michigan telecommunications act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251, shall submit to the City an application for a permit in accordance with the requirements of this ordinance. Pursuant to Section 5(3) of the Act, a telecommunications provider submitting an application under this subsection is not required to pay the five hundred dollars ($500.00) application fee required under subsection (d) above. A provider under this subsection shall be given up to an additional one hundred eighty days (180) days to submit the permit application if allowed by the Authority, as provided in Section 5(4) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 5, 10-21-02) 
Section 5. - Issuance of Permit. 
(a)  Approval or Denial. The authority to approve or deny an application for a permit is hereby delegated to the City Administrator. Pursuant to Section 15(3) of the Act, the City Administrator shall approve or deny an application for a permit within forty-five (45) days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit under Section 4(b) of this ordinance for access to a public right-of-way within the City. Pursuant to Section 6(6) of the Act, the City Administrator shall notify the MPSC when the City Administrator has granted or denied a permit, including information regarding the date on which the application was filed and the date on which permit was granted or denied. The City Administrator shall not unreasonably deny an application for a permit. 
(b)  Form of Permit. If an application for permit is approved, the City Administrator shall issue the permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, in accordance with Sections 6(1), 6(2) and 15 of the Act. 
(c)  Conditions. Pursuant to Section 15(4) of the Act, the City Administrator may impose conditions on the issuance of a permit, which conditions shall be limited to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way. 
(d)  Bond Requirement. Pursuant to Section 15(3) of the Act, and without limitation on subsection (c) above, the City Administrator may require that a bond be posted by the telecommunications provider as a condition of the permit. If a bond is required, it shall not exceed the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunications provider's access and use. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 6, 10-21-02) 
Section 6. - Construction/Engineering Permit. 
    A telecommunications provider shall not commence construction upon, over, across, or under the public rights-of-way in the City without first obtaining a construction or engineering permit as required under Ordinance 98-1 as Appendix D of the Milan Code, as amended, for construction within the public rights-of-way. No fee shall be charged for such a construction or engineering permit. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 7, 10-21-02) 
Section 7. - Conduit or Utility Poles. 
    Pursuant to Section 4(3) of the Act, obtaining a permit or paying the fees required under the Act or under this ordinance does not give a telecommunications provider a right to use conduit or utility poles. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 8, 10-21-02) 
Section 8. - Route Maps. 
    Pursuant to Section 6(7) of the Act, a telecommunications provider shall, within ninety (90) days after the substantial completion of construction of new telecommunications facilities in the City, submit route maps showing the location of the telecommunications facilities to both the MPSC and to the City. The route maps should be in paper and electronic format unless and until the Commission determines otherwise, in accordance with Section 6(8) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 9, 10-21-02) 
Section 9. - Repair of Damage. 
    Pursuant to Section 15(5) of the Act, a telecommunications provider undertaking an excavation or construction or installing telecommunications facilities within a public right-of-way or temporarily obstructing a public right-of-way in the City, as authorized by a permit, shall promptly repair all damage done to the street surface and all installations under, over, below, or within the public right-of-way and shall promptly restore the public right-of-way to its preexisting condition. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 10, 10-21-02) 
Section 10. - Establishment and Payment of Maintenance Fee. 
    In addition to the non-refundable application fee paid to the City set forth in subsection 5(d) above, a telecommunications provider with telecommunications facilities in the City's public rights-of-way shall pay an annual maintenance fee to the Authority pursuant to Section 8 of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 11, 10-21-02) 
Section 11. - Modification of Existing Fees. 
    In compliance with the requirements of Section 13(1) of the Act, the City hereby modifies, to the extent necessary, any fees charged to telecommunications providers after November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, relating to access and usage of the public rights-of-way, to an amount not exceeding the amounts of fees and charges required under the Act, which shall be paid to the Authority. In compliance with the requirements of Section 13(4) of the Act, the City also hereby approves modification of the fees of providers with telecommunication facilities in public rights-of-way within the City's boundaries, so that those providers pay only those fees required under Section 8 of the Act. The City shall provide each telecommunications provider affected by the fee with a copy of this ordinance, in compliance with the requirement of Section 13(4) of the Act. To the extent any fees are charged telecommunications providers in excess of the amounts permitted under the Act, or which are otherwise inconsistent with the Act, such imposition is hereby declared to be contrary to the City's policy and intent, and upon application by a provider or discovery by the City, shall be promptly refunded as having been charged in error. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 12, 10-21-02) 
Section 12. - Savings Clause. 
    Pursuant to Section 13(5) of the Act, if Section 8 of the Act is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, the modification of fees under Section 11 above shall be void from the date the modification was made. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 13, 10-21-02) 
Section 13. - Use of Funds. 
    Pursuant Section 10(4) of the Act, all amounts received by the City from the Authority shall be used by the City solely for rights-of-way related purposes. In conformance with that requirement, all funds received by the City from the Authority shall be deposited into the Major Street Fund and/or the Local Street Fund maintained by the City under Act No. 51 of the Public Acts of 1951. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 14, 10-21-02) 
Section 14. - Annual Report. 
    Pursuant to Section 10(5) of the Act, the City Administrator or designee shall file an annual report with the Authority on the use and disposition of funds annually distributed by the Authority. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 15, 10-21-02) 
Section 15. - Cable Television Operators. 
    Pursuant to Section 13(6) of the Act, the City shall not hold a cable television operator in default or seek any remedy for its failure to satisfy an obligation, if any, to pay after November 1, 2002, the effective date of this Act, a franchise fee or similar fee on that portion of gross revenues from charges the cable operator received for cable modem services provided through broadband internet transport access services. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 16, 10-21-02) 
Section 16. - Existing Rights. 
    Pursuant to Section 4(2) of the Act, except as expressly provided herein with respect to fees, this ordinance shall not affect any existing rights that a telecommunications provider or the City may have under a permit issued by the City or under a contract between the City and a telecommunications provider related to the use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 17, 10-21-02) 
Section 17. - Compliance. 
    The City hereby declares that its policy and intent in adopting this ordinance is to fully comply with the requirements of the Act, and the provisions hereof should be construed in such a manner as to achieve that purpose. The City shall comply in all respects with the requirements of the Act, including but not limited to the following: 
(a)  Exempting certain route maps from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231, 215.246, as provided in Section 5(c) of this ordinance; 
(b)  Allowing certain previously issued permits to satisfy the permit requirements hereof, in accordance with Section 5(f) of this ordinance; 
(c)  Allowing existing providers additional time in which to submit an application for a permit, and excusing such providers from the five hundred dollar ($500) application fee, in accordance with Section 5(g) of this ordinance; 
(d)  Approving or denying an application for a permit within forty-five (45) days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit for access to and usage of a public right-of-way within the City, in accordance with Section 6(a) of this ordinance; 
(e)  Notifying the MPSC when the City has granted or denied a permit, in accordance with Section 6(a) of this ordinance; 
(f)  Not unreasonably denying an application for a permit, in accordance with Section 6(a) of this ordinance; 
(g)  Issuing a permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, as provided in Section 6(b) of this ordinance; 
(h)  Limiting the conditions imposed on the issuance of a permit to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way, in accordance with Section 6(c) of this ordinance; 
(i)  Not requiring a bond of a telecommunications provider which exceeds the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunication provider's access and use, in accordance with Section 6(d) of this ordinance; 
(j)  Not charging any telecommunications providers any additional fees for construction or engineering permits, in accordance with Section 7 of this ordinance; 
(k)  Providing each telecommunications provider affected by the City's right-of-way fees with a copy of this ordinance, in accordance with Section 12 of this ordinance; 
(l)  Submitting an annual report to the Authority, in accordance with Section 15 of this ordinance; and 
(m)  Not holding a cable television operator in default for a failure to pay certain franchise fees, in accordance with Section 16 of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 18, 10-21-02) 
Section 18. - Reservation of Police Powers. 
    Pursuant to Section 15(2) of the Act, this ordinance shall not limit the City's right to review and approve a telecommunication provider's access to and ongoing use of a public right-of-way or limit the City's authority to ensure and protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 19, 10-21-02) 
Section 19. - Severability. 
    The various parts, sentences, paragraphs, sections, and clauses of this ordinance are hereby declared to be severable. If any part, sentence, paragraph, section, or clause of this ordinance is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction, the unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect the constitutionality or validity of any remaining provisions of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 20, 10-21-02) 
Section 20. - Authorized City Officials. 
    The City Administrator or his or her designee is hereby designated as the authorized City official to issue municipal civil infraction citations or municipal civil infraction violation notices for violations under this ordinance as provided by the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 21, 10-21-02) 
Section 21. - Municipal Civil Infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of this ordinance or the terms or conditions of a permit is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, and shall be subject to Chapter 13 of the Milan City Code. Nothing in this Section 21 shall be construed to limit the remedies available to the City in the event of a violation by a person of this ordinance or a permit. 
(Ord. No. 2002-05, § 22, 10-21-02) 
ARTICLE IV. - NORDIC ELECTRIC, L.L.C. 

Section 1. - Grant of franchise. 
    The City of Milan with offices located at 147 Wabash Street, Milan, Michigan 48160 ("City"), grants to Nordic Electric, L.L.C., a Michigan limited liability company, with offices at 2010 Hogback Road, Suite 4, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48105 ("Grantee"), a limited, non-exclusive, revocable franchise to market electricity through and over existing and future electrical lines owned and operated by another authorized public utility and to conduct a local electric business as an electric power marketer and third-party supplier of electricity in the City for a period of ten (10) years after this Ordinance takes effect; provided that this grant of franchise excludes a franchise to construct, lay, maintain or operate electric utility facilities, including but not limited to electric lines, towers, masts, poles, crossarms, guys, braces, feeders, transmission and distribution wires, transformers and other electrical appliances in, along, over or under the highways, streets, alleys, and other public places in the City of Milan, Michigan; and further provided that Grantee shall transmit, supply, deliver and distribute electricity and electrical services solely through such electric utility facilities presently or hereafter owned and maintained by another authorized public utility, by agreement with such public utility or as otherwise provided by law. This grant of franchise includes a franchise for Grantee to own, operate and maintain metering and telemetry equipment for the purpose of serving its customers, provided that such equipment will not be used to bill services provided by another public utility. 
Section 2. - Conditions. 
(A)  As an electric power marketer and third-party supplier of electricity, Grantee will not directly transmit or generate electricity, nor impair, obstruct, or attempt to control or occupy any highway, street, alley, or any other public place, nor engage in any construction or installation in any highway, street, alley, or any other public place or right-of-way. 
(B)  The Grantee shall hold harmless, defend and indemnify the City and its officers, agents, and employees from and against all costs, claims, damages, liabilities, expenses, judgments and proceedings of whatever nature including, without limitation, attorneys' fees and the fees of expert witnesses and consultants, arising from the Grantee's exercise of its rights and obligations pursuant to this Ordinance (whether by the Grantee or the Grantee's contractors or subcontractors). 
(C)  The City may establish reasonable standards of service, prevent unjust discrimination in service, and impose any other regulations as may be determined by the City to be conductive to the safety, welfare and accommodation of the public. Grantee shall be and remain subject to all ordinances, rules and regulations of the City now in effect, or which are adopted hereafter including, without limitation, such ordinances, rules and regulations which regulate the use of public rights-of-way in the City. 
(D)  Grantee shall reimburse the City for the City's costs associated with issuance of this Franchise, including reasonable and documented attorney fees. 
(E)  The rights, power and authority granted by this Ordinance are not exclusive. 
Section 3. - Rates. 
    Grantee may charge its customers within the City for electricity and electrical services at a rate that is mutually agreeable to Grantee and its customers, subject to compliance with all applicable federal and state laws and Michigan Public Service Commission orders, rules and regulations. 
Section 4. - Insurance. 
    Grantee shall obtain and maintain in full force and effect the following insurance covering all insurable risks associated with its exercise of the rights granted by this ordinance: Comprehensive General Liability, including Completed Operations Liability, Independent Contractors Liability, Contractual Liability coverage and coverage for XCU hazards in an amount no less than One Million Dollars ($1,000,000.00) and workers' compensation insurance with Michigan statutory limits, including employers' liability coverage. In addition, Grantee shall maintain motor vehicle liability insurance covering all owned, hired, and non-owned vehicles in use by Grantee, its employees and agents, with personal protection insurance and property protection insurance to comply with the provisions of the Michigan no fault insurance law, including residual liability insurance with minimum limits of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) as the combined single limit for each occurrence of bodily injury and property damage. 
    The City shall be named as an additional insured in all applicable policies. All insurance policies shall provide that they shall not be canceled or modified unless thirty (30) days prior written notice is given to the City. If so requested by the City, Grantee shall provide the City with a certificate of insurance evidencing such coverage and maintain a current certificate on file with the City. 
    All insurance shall be issued by insurance carriers licensed to do business by the State of Michigan or by surplus line carriers on the Michigan Insurance Commission approved list of companies qualified to do business in Michigan. All insurance and surplus line carriers shall be rated A+ or better by A.M. Best Company. 
    Grantee shall require that each and every one of its contractors and their subcontractors carry such insurance in the same type and amounts as Grantee is required to obtain under this Section. 
Section 5. - Interpretation. 
    Nothing in this Franchise shall be construed to alienate the title of the public in and to any highway, street, alley or public place. Nothing in this Franchise shall be construed in any manner as a surrender by the City of is legislative power with respect to the subject matter of this Franchise or with respect to any other matter or in any manner limiting the right of the City to lawfully regulate the use of any highway, street, alley or public place in the City. 
Section 6. - Limitations. 
    Nothing in this Ordinance shall be construed as a waiver by Grantee of any rights under state or federal law. Grantee shall, as to all other conditions and elements of service not addressed or fixed by this Ordinance, remain subject to the rules and regulations applicable to electric service by the Michigan Public Service Commission, or its successor. If so requested by the City, Grantee shall provide the City with copies of all documents which Grantee sends to the Michigan Public Service Commission and copies of all orders, decisions, or correspondence Grantee receives from the Michigan Public Service Commission that relate to this Franchise. Grantee shall permit City inspection and examination of all records that relate to this Franchise that Grantee is required to maintain or file under Michigan Public Service commission rules and regulations. 
Section 7. - Assignment. 
    This Franchise may not be sold, leased, assigned, transferred or used by any party other than the Grantee without the consent of the City. 
Section 8. - Consideration. 
    In consideration of the rights, power and authority hereby granted, said Grantee shall faithfully perform all things required by the terms hereof. 
Section 9. - Revocation. 
    The franchise granted by this ordinance is subject to revocation at will and without cause upon sixty (60) days written notice by the party desiring such revocation. 
Section 10. - Michigan Public Service Commission jurisdiction. 
    Said Grantee shall, as to all other conditions and elements of electrical service, not herein fixed, be and remain subject to the orders, rules and regulations applicable to electric service in the City as prescribed by the Michigan Public Service Commission or its successors and by any federal agency with authority and jurisdiction to issue such orders, rules and regulations. 
Section 11. - Public emergency. 
    The City shall have the right to sever, disrupt, dig up or otherwise destroy electrical facilities owned or used by Grantee, without any prior notice, if such action is deemed necessary by the Fire Chief, Police Chief, or City Administrator because of a public emergency. Public emergency shall be any condition which, in the opinion of any of the officials named, possesses an immediate threat to the lives or property of the residents of the City, caused by any natural or man-made disaster, including but not limited to storms, floods, fire, accidents, explosions, major sewer or water main breaks, hazardous material spills, and similar events. Grantee or the owner of the electric facilities shall be responsible for repair, at its sole expense, of the electric facilities damaged pursuant to any such action taken by the City. 
Section 12. - Acceptance and effective date. 
    This Ordinance shall take effect 10 days after adoption and upon the publication thereof, provided, however, it shall cease and be of no effect after thirty (30) days from its adoption unless within said period the Grantee shall accept the same in writing filed with the City Clerk. Upon acceptance and publication hereof, this ordinance shall constitute a contract between the City and said Grantee. 
ARTICLE V. - DTE ENERGY MARKETING, INC. 

Section 1. - Grant of franchise. 
    The City of Milan with offices located at 147 Wabash Street, Milan, Michigan 48160 ("City"), grants to DTE Energy Marketing, Inc. which is incorporated in the State of Michigan, with offices at 101 N. Main Street, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48104 ("Grantee"), a limited, non-exclusive, revocable franchise to market electricity through and over existing and future electrical lines owned and operated by another authorized public utility and to conduct a local electric business as an electric power marketer and third-party supplier of electricity in the City for a period of ten (10) years after this Ordinance takes effect; provided that this grant of franchise excludes a franchise to construct, lay, maintain or operate electric utility facilities, including but not limited to electric lines, towers, masts, poles, crossarms, guys, braces, feeders, transmission and distribution wires, transformers and other electrical appliances in, along, over or under the highways, streets, alleys, and other public places in the City of Milan, Michigan; and further provided that Grantee shall transmit, supply, deliver and distribute electricity and electrical services solely through such electric utility facilities presently or hereafter owned and maintained by another authorized public utility, by agreement with such public utility or as otherwise provided by law. This grant of franchise includes a franchise for Grantee to own, operate and maintain metering and telemetry equipment for the purpose of serving its customers, provided that such equipment will not be used to bill services provided by another public utility. 
(Ord. No. 2000-6, § 1, 8-28-00) 
Section 2. - Conditions. 
(A)  As an electric power marketer and third-party supplier of electricity, Grantee will not directly transmit or generate electricity, nor impair, obstruct, or attempt to control or occupy any highway, street, alley, or any other public place, nor engage in any construction or installation in any highway, street, alley, or any other public place or right-of-way. 
(B)  The Grantee shall hold harmless, defend and indemnify the City and its officers, agents, and employees from and against all costs, claims, damages, liabilities, expenses, judgments and proceedings of whatever nature including, without limitation, attorneys' fees and the fees of expert witnesses and consultants, arising from the Grantee's exercise of its rights and obligations pursuant to this Ordinance (whether by the Grantee or the Grantee's contractors or subcontractors). 
(C)  The City may establish reasonable standards of service, prevent unjust discrimination in service, and impose any other regulations as may be determined by the City to be conductive to the safety, welfare and accommodation of the public. Grantee shall be and remain subject to all ordinances, rules and regulations of the City now in effect, or which are adopted hereafter including, without limitation, such ordinances, rules and regulations which regulate the use of public rights-of-way in the City. 
(D)  Grantee shall reimburse the City for the City's costs associated with issuance of this Franchise, including reasonable and documented attorney fees up to a maximum of $1,5000 [sic]. 
(E)  The rights, power and authority granted by this Ordinance are not exclusive. 
(Ord. No. 2000-6, § 2, 8-28-00) 
Section 3. - Rates. 
    Grantee may charge its customers within the City for electricity and electrical services at a rate that is mutually agreeable to Grantee and its customers, subject to compliance with all applicable federal and state laws and Michigan Public Service Commission orders, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2000-6, § 3, 8-28-00) 
Section 4. - Insurance. 
    Grantee shall obtain and maintain in full force and effect the following insurance covering all insurable risks associated with its exercise of the rights granted by this ordinance: Comprehensive General Liability, including Completed Operations Liability, Independent Contractors Liability, Contractual Liability coverage and coverage for XCU hazards in an amount no less than One Million Dollars ($1,000,000.00) and workers' compensation insurance with Michigan statutory limits, including employers' liability coverage.
